title: Quantum leap: observing antiferromagnetic transition in a 3D fermionic Hubbard model with ultracold atoms
authors: Laraib Niaz; Alex Krasnok
corresponding_authors: Alex Krasnok
abstract: The study by Shao et al.1 marks a critical advancement in quantum simulations by reporting the first experimental observation of the antiferromagnetic (AFM) phase transition in a 3D fermionic Hubbard model (FHM) using ultracold lithium-6 atoms. This experiment bridges a significant gap in our understanding of strongly correlated systems and provides a new platform to explore low-temperature quantum phases. This commentary will analyze the results, place them in the context of ongoing research, and discuss their broader implications for the field of quantum materials and technologies.

title: Twenty questions on the frontier of laser science and technology
authors: Liangliang Ji
corresponding_authors: Liangliang Ji
abstract: In celebration of the 60th anniversary of the founding of the Shanghai Institute of Optics and Fine Mechanics, the institute launched a public call for questions and challenges in laser science and technology. Twenty questions were ultimately selected, covering the mechanisms of coherent light sources, laser applications in imaging and manufacturing, new laser materials, and so on. These questions may serve as guidance in the future development of laser physics and applications.

title: Picosecond fiber laser mode-locked at 260th harmonic by GHz acoustic resonance in photonic crystal fiber core
authors: Meng Pang; Xin Jiang; G. K. L. Wong; G. Onishchukov; Nicolas Y. Joly; Goran Ahmed; P. St. J. Russell
corresponding_authors: Meng Pang; Xin Jiang; G. K. L. Wong; G. Onishchukov; Nicolas Y. Joly; Goran Ahmed; P. St. J. Russell
abstract: Stable generation of picosecond pulses with repetition rate of ~1.57 GHz is demonstrated in a soliton fiber laser passively mode-locked by an acoustic resonance in the solid core of a silica-glass photonic crystal fiber.

title: D-shape fiber with Mach Zehnder Long-Period Gratings for a High Resolution and Selective Sensor
authors: Lars Glavind; John Canning; Shengqiang Gao; K. Cook; Gang‐Ding Peng; Yanhua Luo; B.F. Skipper; Martin Kristensen
corresponding_authors: Lars Glavind; John Canning; Shengqiang Gao; K. Cook; Gang‐Ding Peng; Yanhua Luo; B.F. Skipper; Martin Kristensen
abstract: The advantages of D-shape fiber in combination with an optical analog of Ramsey fringes using LPGs are presented. The mode-profiles of the sensor were characterized experimentally to provide deeper knowledge about improved functionality.

title: Efficient writing of Bragg gratings through the coating of various optical fibers
authors: Martin Bernier; François Trépanier; Julien Carrier; Réal Vallée
corresponding_authors: Martin Bernier; François Trépanier; Julien Carrier; Réal Vallée
abstract: We report on the efficient direct inscription through the polymer coating of fundamental order fiber Bragg gratings (FBGs) with high refractive index modulation. This direct inscription was performed through fiber jackets made of various polymers including acrylate, polyimide and silicone, for optical fiber diameters ranging from 50 to 250 µm and for various glass compositions such as H2-loaded and unloaded germanosilicate, pure silica, fluorides and chalcogenides.

title: Electrochemical Route to Large-Area Mono-Crystalline Gold Platelets for High-Quality Plasmonic Applications
authors: Bettina Frank; Adrian Ruff; Wilfried Sigle; Li Fu; Philip Kahl; Sabine Ludwigs; Peter A. van Aken; W. Osten; F.‐J. Meyer zu Heringdorf; Paul V. Braun; Paul Mulvaney; Thomas Weiß; Harald Gießen
abstract: We present an electrochemical synthesis method that produces atomically flat single crystalline gold platelets. We use them as high-quality material for plasmonic applications, employing methods like electron energy loss spectroscopy or photoemission electron microscopy (PEEM).

title: Optical Fiber curvature sensors based on single mode - 7 core - single mode fiber structures
authors: G. Salceda-Delgado; A. Van-Newkirk; Jose Enrique Antonio Lopez; Axel Schülzgen; Rodrigo Amezcua Correa
corresponding_authors: G. Salceda-Delgado; A. Van-Newkirk; Jose Enrique Antonio Lopez; Axel Schülzgen; Rodrigo Amezcua Correa
abstract: A novel curvature sensor based on multicore fiber is presented. This device allows for optical interrogation by either fringe visibility or spectral shift. Experimental results show a repeatable, very stable and high sensitivity fiber sensor.

title: Bragg Gratings Made with IR Femtosecond Radiation in High Alumina Content Aluminosilicate Optical Fibers
authors: Dan Grobnic; Stephen J. Mihailov; John Ballato; Peter D. Dragic
abstract: Bragg gratings were manufactured in a high alumina content (30 mole %) optical fiber. More than 10−3 index modulation was generated for fundamental pitched gratings, and < 10−4 for higher order gratings.

title: High peak power nanosecond and picosecond pulse delivery through a hollow-core Negative Curvature Fiber in the green spectral region for micro-machining
authors: Piotr Jaworski; Fei Yu; Richard Carter; W. J. Wadsworth; T. A. Birks; J. C. Knight; Jonathan D. Shephard; Duncan P. Hand
abstract: We report efficient delivery of nanosecond and picosecond laser pulses in the green spectral region with peak powers of 6.9kW and 3MW respectively through a hollow-core Negative Curvature Fiber and demonstration of fiber-based precision micro-machining.

title: Tailored Waveform Generation in Mode-Locked Fiber Lasers by In-Cavity Pulse Shaper
authors: Sonia Boscolo; Christophe Finot; Periklis Petropoulos
abstract: We numerically show the possibility of pulse shaping in a mode-locked fiber laser by inclusion of an amplitude-phase spectral filter into the laser cavity. Various advanced temporal waveforms are generated, including parabolic, flat-top and triangular pulses.

title: Chalcogenide optical fibers for mid-infrared sensing: State of the art, future strategies
authors: Bruno Bureau; Catherine Boussard‐Plédel; Virginie Nazabal; Jean‐Luc Adam; Jacques Lucas
abstract: chalcogenide glasses optical fibers are matchless devices to carry out Fiber Evanescent Wave Spectroscopy which enables detecting the mid-infrared signature of most molecules and bio-molecules. Past promising results and future strategies will be presented.

title: Ultrasensitive Displacement Sensor Based on Photonic Crystal Fiber Modal Interferometer
authors: Jitendra Narayan Dash; Rajan Jha; Sumit Dass
abstract: An ultrasensitive displacement sensor based on photonic crystal fiber modal interferometer using an external mirror is proposed. The mirror is displaced by a nano-positioner and the sensitivity of the sensor is 43 pm/nm.

title: Spectroscopic detection of hazardous substances using broadband-tunable Quantum Cascade Lasers
authors: Stefan Hugger; F. Fuchs; J. Jarvis; Quankui Yang; R. Driad; W. Bronner; R. Aidam; R. Ostendorf; J. Wagner
abstract: Broadband tunable external cavity quantum cascade lasers (EC-QCL) [1] are very attractive light sources for mid-infrared (MIR) spectroscopy. Here we report on EC-QCL based spectroscopic detection of hazardous substances, focusing on two application examples: Stand-off detection of explosives and sensing of dangerous contaminations in water. Our standoff-system provides contactless identification of solid residues of different explosives over distances of several meters. In our setup for MIR absorption spectroscopy on liquids, the EC-QCL enables the use of a transmission cell with an extended optical path length of 100 μm despite the strong background absorption of water.

title: Porous nanogratings and related form birefringence in silicate and germanate glasses
authors: Matthieu Lancry; Rudy Desmarchelier; Nicolas Guth; F. Zimmerman; François Brisset; Stefan Nolte; B. Poumellec
abstract: We prove the formation of birefringent nanoporous structures in the volume of various doped silica (TiO2, F, GeO2), GeO2 and borosilicate glasses by femtosecond laser. Using quantitative birefringence measurements and scanning electron microscopy we determined that this birefringence is mainly induced by porous nanogratings. So far, the form birefringence induced by these modifications was known mainly in fused silica. We determined the repetition rate of the irradiating laser pulses as crucial processing parameter. The retardation in the laser modified doped silica or GeO2 is comparable to fused silica, while the birefringence in Borosilicate is two times weaker.

title: Gain from Helium-Xenon Discharges in Hollow Optical Fibres at 3.5 μm
authors: S. A. Bateman; Walter Belardi; Fei Yu; C. E. Webb; W. J. Wadsworth
corresponding_authors: S. A. Bateman; Walter Belardi; Fei Yu; C. E. Webb; W. J. Wadsworth
abstract: Metre length He-Xe discharges have been demonstrated in anti-resonant guiding hollow core photonic crystal fibres. Emission was observed at 3.11, 3.37 and 3.51 µm, with characteristics strongly suggestive of net gain in the fibre.

title: Dense Plasmonic Mach-Zehnder Modulator Array for High-Speed Optical Interconnects
authors: Claudia Hoessbacher; W. Heni; A. Melikyan; Yuriy Fedoryshyn; Christian Haffner; Benedikt Baeuerle; Arne Josten; D. Hillerkuss; Yannick Salamin; Manfred Kohl; Delwin L. Elder; Larry R. Dalton; Christian Hafner; Juerg Leuthold
abstract: A plasmonic Mach-Zehnder modulator array with 4×36 Gbit/s capacity is introduced. The densely packed devices are connected by a multicore fiber demonstrating a highly scalable interconnect solution in a most compact footprint.

title: Modulation format identification using sparse asynchronous amplitude histograms
authors: Shuting Zhang; Yingqin Peng; Qi Sui; Zhaohui Li
abstract: Sparse asynchronous amplitude histograms (AAHs) are used in genetic algorithm (GA) aided artificial neural network (ANN) based modulation format identification (MFI) in order to significantly simplify the computational complexity without sacrificing identification performance.

title: Phase-Change Materials for Electro-Optical Switching in the Near- and Mid-Infrared
authors: Richard Soref
corresponding_authors: Richard Soref
abstract: At wavelengths of 1.55 to 3.0 μm, theoretical simulations were made of electro-optical 2 x 2 switching utilizing a thin-film of Ge2Sb2Te5 or GeTe or GeSe that offers two voltage-triggered self-holding optical states. Low loss and low crosstalk were predicted but experiments are needed to confirm the theory.

authors: Xiang Meng; Asif Ahmed; Jerry I. Dadap; Keren Bergman; Richard M. Osgood
corresponding_authors: Xiang Meng; Asif Ahmed; Jerry I. Dadap; Keren Bergman; Richard M. Osgood
abstract: We introduce a dispersion analysis of hybrid optical interconnections for silicon-based plasmonic-photonic nanowires. This Si/Plasmonics hybrid interconnection is able to confine and manipulate photonic signals with zero dispersion at communications wavelength.

authors: Chongjin Xie
corresponding_authors: Chongjin Xie

authors: Ye Deng; Ming Li; Ningbo Huang; Ninghua Zhu
corresponding_authors: Ye Deng; Ming Li; Ningbo Huang; Ninghua Zhu
abstract: A tunable single-bandpass microwave photonic filter (MPF) with a narrow and flat-top shape operating in Ka-band is proposed and experimentally demonstrated. The MPF has a 3-dB and 20-dB bandwidths of 840-MHz and 2.43-GHz, respectively.

title: Multiplexed Single Wavelength Bio Sensor for Low Cost Applications
authors: Matthias Jäger; Danny Volkmann; J. Bruns; K. Petermann
abstract: A novel modulation technique for refractive index measurements using resonant nano-photonic structures is proposed. While results comparable to conventional setups are possible the need for a TLS is replaced by thermo-optical modulation.

title: Nondiffractive polarization feature of optical vortices
authors: Zhenwei Xie
corresponding_authors: Zhenwei Xie
abstract: Advanced Photonics, co-published by SPIE and Chinese Laser Press, is a highly selective, Gold Open Access, international journal publishing innovative research in all areas of optics and photonics, including fundamental and applied research.

authors: Yosuke Mizuno
corresponding_authors: Yosuke Mizuno
abstract: Advanced Photonics, co-published by SPIE and Chinese Laser Press, is a highly selective, Gold Open Access, international journal publishing innovative research in all areas of optics and photonics, including fundamental and applied research.

title: Compact multi-mode silicon-nitride micro-ring resonator with low loss
authors: Kaixuan Ye; David Marpaung
corresponding_authors: David Marpaung
abstract: Advanced Photonics, co-published by SPIE and Chinese Laser Press, is a highly selective, Gold Open Access, international journal publishing innovative research in all areas of optics and photonics, including fundamental and applied research.

title: Stripe-based Collimating Silica Planar Waveguide for a Free-space Wavelength Selective Cross Connect
authors: Nazirul Afham Idris; Keisuke Sorimoto; Daiki Tanaka; Hiroyuki Tsuda
abstract: We propose an integrated beam collimating silica waveguide with stripe-based structure for the use in wavelength selective cross connect (WSXC). The coupling loss of the device is below 0.15 dB within the ideal propagation distance.

title: Direct Embedding of Fiber-Optical Load Sensors into Wind Turbine Blades
authors: Lars Glavind; Stephen J. Buggy; Ib S. Olesen; B.F. Skipper; John Canning; Kevin Cook; Martin Kristensen
corresponding_authors: Lars Glavind; Stephen J. Buggy; Ib S. Olesen; B.F. Skipper; John Canning; Kevin Cook; Martin Kristensen
abstract: Long Period Gratings were embedded into the adhesive utilized in the matrix of a wind turbine blade. The LPGs were subsequently subjected to temperature-testing in order to assess their performance, which illustrates good embedding capabilities.

title: Research Directions for Low Energy Access Networks (Invited)
authors: Peter Vetter; Dusan Suvakovic
abstract: The paper addresses different options for reduction of energy consumption in fixed access networks, studied by the GreenTouch research consortium. A combination of different concepts at network architecture, protocol, system, and component level will lead to an energy efficiency improvement of more than 100×.

title: Point-to-point and Point-to-multipoint CDMA Access Network with Enhanced Security
authors: Alfredo A. Ortega; Víctor A. Bettachini; J. Ignacio Alvarez-Hamelin; D. F. Grosz
abstract: We propose a network implementation with enhanced security at the physical layer by means of time-hopping CDMA, supporting cryptographically secure point-to-point and point-to-multipoint communication for 128 users up to 20 km apart.

title: Stacking PS-QPSK and 64PPM for Long-Range Free-Space Transmission
authors: Alexandra Ludwig; Marc-Lorenzo Schulz; Philipp Schindler; R. Schmogrow; A. K. Mustafa; B. Moos; Sina Brunsch; Thomas Dippon; D. Malsam; D. Hillerkuss; Frederick Roos; W. Freude; C. Koos; Juerg Leuthold
abstract: In this paper a new sensitivity record for uncoded transmission with 2.6 photons per bit (4.15 dB) is presented. This is achieved using four dimensional (4-D) stacked orthogonal modulation formats i.e. PS-QPSK-64PPM.

title: Software-defined Transponders for Future Flexible Grid Networks
authors: Robert Elschner; Felix Frey; Carsten Schmidt‐Langhorst; Johannes Fischer; Markus Nölle; Colja Schubert
abstract: We discuss software-defined transponders in the context of flexible grid networks. Particular attention is paid to single-carrier digital signal processing approaches that enable resource-efficient reception of various modulation formats.

title: Waveguide-based Mid-Infrared Up-conversion Detectors
authors: Kai-Daniel F. Büchter; Harald Herrmann; Raimund Ricken; Viktor Quiring; W. Sohler
abstract: Nonlinear optical up-conversion detectors for 3.4 µm radiation are realized using Ti:PPLN waveguides. Both, sum-frequency generation (SFG) and difference-frequency generation (DFG) are investigated. Overall power conversion efficiencies of more than 8 % are achieved.

title: Dynamic Subcarrier Allocation for OFDMA-PONs with Monitoring Mechanism
authors: Wansu Lim; Pandelis Kourtessis; Miloš Milosavljević; John M. Senior
abstract: A new protocol design for 10G OFDMA-PONs is reported, demonstrating dynamic subcarrier allocation based on monitoring of each ONU's queuing status. 0.7 ms packet delay and 540 Mbps throughput were achieved for SLA0 ONUs.

title: Ultra-low-loss Waveguide Crossing Arrays Based on Imaginary Coupling of Multimode Bloch Waves
authors: Yangyang Liu; Jeffrey M. Shainline; Xiaoge Zeng; Miloš A. Popović
abstract: We experimentally demonstrate ultra-low-loss waveguide crossing arrays showing loss down to 0.04dB/crossing. They rely on a low loss, focusing Bloch wave that is stabilized by radiative scattering, via a radiative form of coupling.

title: A Near-Infrared LED-based Material Classification Sensor System
authors: Oliver Schwaneberg; Uwe Köckemann; H. Steiner; Norbert Jung
abstract: In safety applications it is often desired that certain materials do not enter a dangerous area. This paper presents a near-infrared LED-based sensor system for robust material classification and ranging up to a distance of 1,000mm.

title: A Low-loss Integrated Beam Combiner based on Polarization Multiplexing
authors: Bingnan Wang; Keisuke Kojima; Toshiaki Koike‐Akino; Kieran Parsons; Satoshi Nishikawa; Eiji Yagyu
abstract: We present a design of an integrated beam combiner which cascades power combiners and polarization converter/combiner. The proposed device has 2 dB lower loss than power combiners and is more fabrication-tolerant than wavelength combiners.

title: Infrared radiation detector interrogated by Optical Frequency Domain Reflectometer (OFDR)
authors: Kıvılcım Yüksel; Christophe Caucheteur; J-M. Renoirt; Marc Debliquy; Patrice Mégret; Marc Wuilpart
abstract: We experimentally demonstrated a fast infrared radiation sensor. The system is applicable in a quasi-distributed configuration to cover a large area using a single interrogation unit (OFDR) for early fire detection.

title: Nanoscale Photonic Transistor
authors: A. V. Krasavin; A. V. Zayats
corresponding_authors: A. V. Krasavin; A. V. Zayats
abstract: We combine a highly efficient nanoscale photonic guiding approach with a robust modulation principle, utilising novel electro-optical material and numerically demonstrate an active field-effect photonic modulator having an unprecedented short length of approximately 100 nm operating at telecom wavelength. The design promises a realisation of highly-integrated electro-optical circuitry for integrated photonics applications.

title: Structural slow light can enhance Beer-Lambert absorption
authors: Isabelle Dicaire; Sanghoon Chin; Luc Thévenaz
abstract: We experimentally demonstrate that structural slow light can enhance Beer-Lambert absorption. A 4-fold reduction of the group velocity induced by mere cavity effects has caused an increase of molecular absorption by 130%.

title: Optimization of CMOS-Compatible Hybrid Plasmonic Waveguides for Nonlinear Applications
authors: Ke-Yao Wang; Amy C. Foster
corresponding_authors: Ke-Yao Wang; Amy C. Foster
abstract: We demonstrate the design and optimization of three CMOS-compatible hybrid plasmonic waveguide structures for nonlinear interactions. Our proposed hybrid waveguide structure provides the largest nonlinear phase shift compared to other designs.

title: Confinement Loss of Tube Lattice and Kagome Fibers
authors: Luca Vincetti; V. Setti; M. Zoboli
corresponding_authors: Luca Vincetti; V. Setti; M. Zoboli
abstract: Confinement loss of two kinds of broad band hollow core fibers, the tube lattice fibers and the kagomé fibers, are numerically investigated and compared. The results show that the tube lattice fibers exhibit much lower confinement loss than the kagomé ones.

title: Self-optimized Metal Coatings for Fiber Plasmonics by Electroless Deposition
authors: A. Beliaev; Christophe Caucheteur; N. Ahamad; Anatoli Ianoul; Jacques Albert
corresponding_authors: A. Beliaev; Christophe Caucheteur; N. Ahamad; Anatoli Ianoul; Jacques Albert
abstract: Observation of the polarization dependent loss spectrum of a tilted fiber Bragg grating during electroless deposition of gold on the fiber allows the process to be stopped exactly when the surface Plasmon resonances are maximized.

title: Experimental observation of effective gravity and two-time physics in ferrofluid-based hyperbolic metamaterials
authors: Vera N. Smolyaninova; John Cartelli; Bryan Augstein; Stephanie Spickard; Mary Sajini Devadas; Igor I. Smolyaninov
abstract: Recently it was proposed that extraordinary light waves in hyperbolic metamaterials exhibit two times physics behavior (Phys. Rev. Lett. 105, 067402, 2010). We report experimental observation of this effect via investigation of gravity-like nonlinear optics of iron/cobalt-based ferrofluid hyperbolic metamaterials. In addition to conventional temporal coordinate, the spatial coordinate oriented along the optical axis of the metamaterial also exhibits timelike character, which leads to very unusual two times physics behavior in these systems.

title: Signal Processing for On-Chip Space Division Multiplexing
authors: Christophe Peucheret; Yunhong Ding; Jing Xu; Francesco Da Ros; Alberto Parini; Haiyan Ou
abstract: Our recent results on the demonstration of on-chip mode-division multiplexing functionalities are reviewed, with a special emphasis on the feasibility of nonlinear all-optical signal processing on the silicon-on-insulator SOI platform. Mode-selective parametric processes are demonstrated in a 4-mm long SOI waveguide.

title: Fibre Laser Imaging of Gas Turbine Exhaust Species – A Review of CO2 Aero Engine Imaging
authors: Michael Lengden; David Wilson; Ian Armstrong; Thomas Benoy; Walter Johnstone; Edward Fisher; Andrea Chighine; Alex Tsekenis; H. McCann; Paul Wright; David McCormick; Yutong Feng; Johan Nilsson; Mark Johnson; J. L. Black
abstract: Here we present the latest developments in tomographic imaging of gas turbine exhaust species, particularly CO2. The optical source, detection methodology and mechanical optical distribution design are discussed in detail.

title: Optical Fiber Sensors for Bio-Medical Applications
authors: Alexis Méndez
corresponding_authors: Alexis Méndez
abstract: Given their EM immunity, intrinsic safety, small size & weight, autoclave compatibility and capability to perform multi-point and multi-parameter sensing remotely, optical fibers and fiberoptic-based sensors are seeing increased acceptance and new uses for a variety of bio-medical applications—from laser delivery systems, to disposable body temperature sensors, to intra-aortic catheter probes. This talk will describe the needs for bio-medical sensing and illustrate—through several real-life application examples—the benefits brought by optical fibers and fiberoptic sensors and their ongoing development. Key technical and industry trends will be identified along with relevant commercial opportunities and challenges.

title: Integrated Plasmonic Sensors
authors: Min-Suk Kwon
corresponding_authors: Min-Suk Kwon
abstract: Two interferometer-type integrated plasmonic sensors based on a thick gold layer are explained. In addition, an integrated plasmonic sensor based on grating-assisted coupling between a dielectric waveguide mode and a surface plasmon polariton is discussed.

title: InP photonic integrated circuit for BOTDR fiber sensing
authors: Manuela Felicetti; Jos van der Tol; Robert Klein Breteler; Dominik Szymanski; M.K. Smit
abstract: We realized a potentially low-cost optical fiber sensor read-out unit. The device allows for a measurement distance resolution of about 2 m along a sensing fiber using 25 ns wide pulses generated on chip.

title: Poly-L-lysine monolayer-modified microfiber Bragg grating biosensor for specific DNA detection
authors: Dandan Sun; Tuan Guo; Yang Ran; Yunyun Huang; Bai‐Ou Guan
abstract: A label-free biosensor based on functionalized microfiber Bragg grating for DNA hybridization is demonstrated. The sensor is functionalized by poly-L-lysine monolayer with specific DNA sequences to bind with high specificity to a given target.

title: Two-Phase Flow Imaging by means of an 8x8 Optical Fiber Bragg Grating Grid
authors: Carlos R. Zamarreño; Cícero Martelli; Virgínia Baroncini; Eduardo Nunes dos Santos; Marco J. da Silva; Rigoberto Morales; Ignacio R. Matı́as; Francisco J. Arregui
abstract: Two-phase flows characterization by means of the utilization of an optical fiber Bragg grating (FBG) grid is presented. The force applied by the air/liquid flow on the FBGs is the underlying mechanism of this sensor.

title: Long-Range Surface Plasmon Polariton Excitation Using Tilted Fiber Bragg Gratings
authors: Christophe Caucheteur; Valérie Voisin; Jacques Albert; Pierre Berini
corresponding_authors: Christophe Caucheteur; Valérie Voisin; Jacques Albert; Pierre Berini
abstract: For the first time, we report the excitation of long-range surface plasmon polaritons in a cylindrical optical waveguide, using a tilted Bragg grating photo-imprinted in a single-mode optical fiber and coated by a bilayer of Cytop and gold.

title: High Density Ink Jet Printing of Bio-molecules for Photonic Crystal-based Microarray Applications
authors: Wei-Cheng Lai; Kathryn Moncivais; Swapnajit Chakravarty; Xiaolong Wang; Che-Yun Lin; Zhiwen J. Zhang; Ray T. Chen
abstract: High density inkjet printing of protein solutions was investigated for photonic crystal based microarray applications. Spacing of 60um has been demonstrated between unique inkjet-printed spots on a silicon substrate.

title: Polyelectrolyte Multilayers for Surface Functionalization: Advantages and Challenges
authors: F. Alexandre; Tze Cheung Foo; Tanya M. Monro
abstract: Polyelectrolytes (PE) are charged polymers in solution with a wide range of functionalities that have been used for various applications including surface functionalization for biosensing. In this presentation we will describe the standard approach and mechanisms involved in PE layer-by-layer deposition, present the advantages of such approach and the challenges it raises for biological sensing especially with respect to nonspecific binding as well as few examples of application for biosensing.

title: Method for poling high electro-optical coefficients Sr0.61Ba0.39Nb2O6 crystals: Application to SBN Pockels cells
authors: Jacques R. Chrétien; Cedric GUICHARD; Laurent Larger; M. Bouvrot
abstract: We demonstrate a method to polarize SBN for electro-optic devices. Efficiency and fabrication speed are significantly improved through a total depolarization. The method opens the way to novel SBN-based EO devices and systems.

title: Understanding Propagation Loss in Slow Light Waveguides
authors: Sebastian A. Schulz; Liam O’Faoláin; Isabella H. Rey; Thomas F. Krauss
abstract: Engineering dispersion and loss in photonic crystal waveguides allows us to control propagation up to moderate group indices. Novel results on 'overengineered' waveguides give insights into loss vs. both propagation constant and group index.

title: Low Cost 112G Direct Detection Metro Transmission System with Reduced Bandwidth (10G) Components and MLSE Compensation
authors: A. Gorshtein; Dan Sadot; Gilad Katz; Omri Levy
abstract: MLSE compensation for reduced bandwidth optoelectronic components, CD, and PMD at multi-wavelength 4x28G transmission with direct detection is proposed. Inclusive comparison analysis with conventional hard decision systems is presented.

title: Optical field molding within near-field coupled twinned nanobeam cavities
authors: Benoît Cluzel; Kevin Foubert; L. Lalouat; Emmanuelle Picard; Jean Dellinger; D. Peyrade; F. de Fornel; E. Hadji
abstract: Twinned high Q nanobeam cavities can be optically coupled while being placed in the optical near-field of each other. They form then a new optical system which supports discrete field maps addressable by wavelength selection.

title: Effects of scatterer size and concentration on the spectral features of dye-based random lasers
authors: Natanael Cuando-Espitia; Juan Hernández-Cordero; C. Garcı̀a-Segundo; Rosa M. Quispe-Siccha
abstract: Random lasers varying concentration and size of SiO2 scatterers were analyzed. We report on the dependence of the spectral features (wavelength and full width at half maximum) on the size and concentration of the scatterers.

title: Manakov Polarization Modulation Instability in Normal Dispersion Optical Fiber
authors: Bertrand Kibler; Benoit Frisquet; P. Morin; Julien Fatome; Fabio Baronio; Matteo Conforti; G. Millot; S. Wabnitz
abstract: We observed polarization modulation instability in the normal dispersion regime of randomly birefringent multi-km telecom optical fiber. The instability is pumped by two wavelength multiplexed and orthogonally polarized intense continuous lasers.

title: Ultra-Sensitive (Acoustic) Pressure Sensor with High Temporal Resolution
authors: Balthasar Fischer; E. Wintner
abstract: A novel all-optical pressure sensor is presented. Based on a rigid Fabry-Pérot, the transducer detects refractive index changes induced by pressure fluctuations (∆nmin = 10−14). This design is so sensitive that the miniaturized device is applicable as a microphone.

title: Application of Chalcogenide Fibers
authors: Daniel W. Hewak; K. Khan; Chung‐Che Huang
abstract: Chalcogenide glass optical fibers have been extensively studied since 1967, when sulphide based fibers and their potential applications were first proposed. While high quality fiber drawn from alloys containing a variety of chalcogen elements have been realized, their delicate nature, complicated fabrication methodology and expense has restricted widespread application and commercial acceptance. In this paper we describe our current work on the fabrication and application of chalcogenide fiber and our vision for their practical implementation in the future.

title: Near real-time, accurate, and sensitive fluorescence monitoring of microbiological safety
authors: Frédérique Vanholsbeeck; Simon Swift; Michael T. Cheng; E. Bogomolny
abstract: Enumeration of microorganisms is an essential microbiological task for many industrial sectors and research fields. To address the challenge of enumeration, we have tested an all-fibre fluorescence spectroscopic system to enumerate bacteria in industrial samples.

title: Quasi-Cyclic LDPC based on PEG Construction for Optical Communications
authors: Shahid Mumtaz; Ghaya Rekaya-Ben Othman; Yves Jaouën
abstract: A new construction of quasi-cyclic LDPC codes based on the progressive edge-growth algorithm is presented. These codes perform better than most LDPC codes proposed for optical transmissions and design parameters can be chosen without constraint.

title: Graphene based surface plasmonics in microfiber multimode interferometer for gas sensing
authors: Baicheng Yao; Yu Wu; Anqi Zhang; Yunjiang Rao; Zegao Wang; Yang Cheng; Yuan Gong; Weili Zhang; Yuanfu Chen; Kin Seng Chiang
corresponding_authors: Baicheng Yao; Yu Wu; Anqi Zhang; Yunjiang Rao; Zegao Wang; Yang Cheng; Yuan Gong; Weili Zhang; Yuanfu Chen; Kin Seng Chiang
abstract: Graphene based surface plasmonics in microfiber multimode interferometer is first proposed for realization of highly sensitive, temperature independent, and compact fiber-optic gas sensor. The achieved sensitivities are ~0.1ppm, ~0.2ppm for NH3 gas and H2O vapor, respectively.

title: Temperature Sensing of High Power Generator Stator using DTS
authors: João Paulo Bazzo; Felipe Mezzadri; Cícero Martelli; Erlon Wagner da Silva; Daniel Rodrigues Pipa; Jean Carlos Cardozo da Silva
abstract: Stator surface temperature monitoring of a 182 MW hydroelectric generator using DTS is presented. The main advantage of this approach over conventional sensors is the possibility to identify temperature variations over with high spatial resolution.

title: Converged In-home Networks using 1-mm Core Size Plastic Optical Fiber
authors: E. Tangdiongga; D. Visani; H. Yang; Y. Shi; Chigo Okonkwo; H.P.A. van den Boom; Giovanni Tartarini; A.M.J. Koonen
corresponding_authors: E. Tangdiongga; D. Visani; H. Yang; Y. Shi; Chigo Okonkwo; H.P.A. van den Boom; Giovanni Tartarini; A.M.J. Koonen
abstract: Broadband wireline and wireless transmission system over 1-mm core size 50-m long POF is discussed. Transmission capacity of 2.2 Gbit/s DMT and 528-MHz UWB wireless signals is achieved, having performance complying with requirements.

title: Hydrogen influence on regenerated FBGs produced by the phase mask technique with 266 nm femtosecond pulses
authors: Antonio Bueno; Karima Chah; Damien Kinet; Patrice Mégret; Christophe Caucheteur
abstract: We show the influence of hydrogen in the regeneration process of FBGs made by a femtosecond laser at 266 nm and the phase mask technique in optical fibers with different hydrogen content (pre-loaded, post-loaded and without hydrogen).

title: Pulse shortening and ICR enhancement for PW-class lasers
authors: Sergey Mironov; Е. А. Хазанов; G. Mourou
abstract: An original technique of implementation self-phase modulation effect for shortening duration and enhancement of intensity contrast ratio of PW pulses was proposed. The possibility of additional pulse compression from 27fs to 2fs was demonstrated.

title: Infrared optical tomography applied to two-phase flow monitoring
authors: Tiago P. Vendruscolo; Rodolfo L. Patyk; Guilherme Dutra; Cícero Martelli; Rigoberto Morales; Marco J. da Silva
corresponding_authors: Tiago P. Vendruscolo; Rodolfo L. Patyk; Guilherme Dutra; Cícero Martelli; Rigoberto Morales; Marco J. da Silva
abstract: In this paper we present an optical tomography system operating in NIR range which is applied to monitor air-water flow. Furthermore, preliminary study on transmission of infrared light over crude oil is also performed.

title: Determination of penetration depth of localized surface plasmon resonance fiber optic probe using polyelectrolyte multilayers
authors: Reshma Bharadwaj; Suparna Mukherji; Soumyo Mukherji
corresponding_authors: Reshma Bharadwaj; Suparna Mukherji; Soumyo Mukherji
abstract: The penetration depth of the localized surface plasmon evanescent field of a gold nanoparticle based fiber optic probe was estimated by measuring optical absorbance change at the resonance wavelength during the deposition of polyelectrolyte multilayers.

title: Test-bed functionality of the SARDANA Hybrid NG-PON
authors: Josep Prat; Víctor Polo; José A. Lázaro; Francesc Bonada; Eduardo Tommy Lopez; Bernhard Schrenk; M. Omella; Fabienne Saliou; Quang Trung Le; Philippe Chanclou; Dmitri Leino; Risto Soila; Spiros Spirou; L.C. Costa; A. Teixeira; G. Tosi-Beleffi; Dimitrios Klonidis; Ioannis Tomkos
abstract: The tests with broadband multimedia services of the SARDANA multi-layer prototype prove the feasibility of scalable hybrid DWDM/TDM-PON FTTH networks with resilient optically-integrated ring-trees architecture.

title: High-Finesse Cavities Fabricated by Buckling Self-Assembly of a-Si/SiO2 Multilayers
authors: T. W. Allen; Joshua W. Silverstone; N. Ponnampalam; R. G. DeCorby
abstract: Micro-cavities were fabricated by controlled formation of delamination buckles within a-Si/SiO2 multilayers. Linewidth (~0.1 nm in the 1550 nm-range) and finesse (>600) are close to reflectance-limited predictions, indicating low-defect cavities.

title: A Silicon Photonics Platform with Heterogeneous III-V Integration
authors: Wim Bogaerts; Shankar Kumar Selvaraja; Hui Yu; Thijs Spuessens; Pauline Mechet; S. Stanković; Shahram Keyvaninia; Joris Van Campenhout; P. Absil; Günther Roelkens; Dries Van Thourhout; Roel Baets
abstract: We present a silicon photonics technology platform combining silicon processing technologies and heterogeneously integrated III–V materials. This enables passive and active photonic functions on silicon, such as waveguide circuits, filters, modulators, photodetectors and integrated lasers.

title: Double peak rogue waves of the Sasa-Satsuma equation in a chaotic wave field
authors: J. M. Soto‐Crespo; N. Devine; Norbert Hoffmann; Nail Akhmediev
abstract: We study the properties of the chaotic wave fields generated in the frame of the Sasa-Satsuma equation, and analyze the presence of rogue waves in them.Our results also reveal the reason for the skewed profile of the exact rogue wave solutions.

title: Hybrid Plasmonic Waveguide Devices for Silicon on Insulator Platform
authors: Md. Zahangir Alam; J. Stewart Aitchison; Mo Mojahedi
abstract: Properties of the modes supported by the hybrid metal-low-high index waveguides are strongly polarization dependent. We present designs of a number of hybrid waveguide devices for silicon on insulator platform that utilize this property.

title: High-End FBG Design and Manufacturing for Industrial Lasers, Sensing and Telecommunications
authors: François Trépanier; G. Brochu; Michel Morin; Alain Mailloux
abstract: This paper reviews how efficient design and manufacturing techniques for fiber Bragg grating-based components enables superior performances in optical communications, industrial lasers and sensing applications.

title: Guided-Mode-Resonance Enabled Absorption in Amorphous Silicon for Thin-Film Solar Cell Applications
authors: Tanzina Khaleque; Jae Woong Yoon; Wenwen Wu; Mehrdad Shokooh‐Saremi; Robert Magnusson
abstract: Nanoscale patterns with 300-nm periods are fabricated on thin films of amorphous silicon on glass substrates. Around 50% integrated absorption enhancement compared to unpatterned silicon reference samples is observed for the 400–950-nm wavelength range.

title: Asymmetric, pole-zero microring-resonator filters for efficient on-chip dense WDM multiplexers
authors: Mark T. Wade; Jeffrey M. Shainline; Jason S. Orcutt; Miloš A. Popović
abstract: Channel add-drop filters with asymmetric responses based on transmission zero engineering are proposed and demonstrated in a zero-change 45nm SOI CMOS process. They enable multiplexers with 2.4× higher channel density using the same order filter.

title: A Low-Complexity and Single-Stage Carrier Phase Recovery Algorithm for 16-QAM Coherent Optical systems
authors: Rongshan Wang; Rui Ding; Ren Xiaobo; Huang Zhiyuan; Fan Zhang
abstract: A low-complexity and single-stage carrier phase recovery algorithm is presented for 16 quadrature-amplitude-modulation coherent optical transmission systems. It is shown that the algorithm achieves better performance and can significantly reduce the required compute power.

title: Vertical coupling mirror for on-wafer optical probing of photonic integrated circuits
authors: Rui Santos; Beatriz Barcones Campo; M.K. Smit; X.J.M. Leijtens
abstract: On-wafer probing of optical signals offers powerful means for assessing the fabrication process quality of photonic integrated circuits. We describe the fabrication and characterization of a vertical optical coupler that enables on-wafer probing.

title: Surface Roughness Effect on Q-Factor of Ge Whispering Gallery Mode Microdisk Resonator
authors: Seongjae Cho; Sukmo Koo; Kyungwan Yoo; Evan Pickett; Namkyoo Park; T. I. Kamins; Byung‐Gook Park; James S. Harris
abstract: In this paper, surface roughness effect on Q-factor of Ge whispering gallery mode (WGM) microdisk resonator is thoroughly investigated by 2D and 3D finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) simulation. Results reveal that the effective radius of nanohole along a microdisk perimeter, roughness index, significantly degrades the device Q-factor and should be sub-100 nm.

title: Optical pulse differentiation based on a resonant slow & fast light system
authors: Sang Hoon Chin; Tae-Jung Ahn; Luc Thévenaz
abstract: We experimentally demonstrate that temporal differentiation of optical pulses can be realized in a slow & fast light system based on a resonance. The waveform of a 13 ns Gaussian pulse was experimentally first-order differentiated.

title: Cocaine detection in liquid using a fibered platform and a mid-infrared quantum cascade laser
authors: G. Smolik; Lubos Hvozdara; J. Di Francesco; Pierre Jouy; Y. Bonetti; Kerstin M.‐C. Hans; Markus W. Sigrist; Jérôme Faist; Hans Peter Herzig
corresponding_authors: G. Smolik; Lubos Hvozdara; J. Di Francesco; Pierre Jouy; Y. Bonetti; Kerstin M.‐C. Hans; Markus W. Sigrist; Jérôme Faist; Hans Peter Herzig
abstract: A miniaturized, trace level sensor for cocaine is presented. A quantum cascade laser emitting at 1720 cm-1 is coupled to a fibred absorption flow-cell. A detection limit lower than 250 ng/mL (84 ppb) is reported.

title: Guided Acoustic-Wave Brillouin Scattering in Few-Mode Fibers
authors: Roland Ryf; R Essiambre; R.W. Tkach; A. R. Chraplyvy; D.W. Peckham; A.H. McCurdy; R. Lingle
corresponding_authors: Roland Ryf; R Essiambre; R.W. Tkach; A. R. Chraplyvy; D.W. Peckham; A.H. McCurdy; R. Lingle
abstract: We measured the guided acoustic-wave Brillouin scattering in a few-mode fiber that supports LP01 and LP11 modes. We observed a strong correlation between the acoustic modes and optical intramodal and intermodal Brillouin scattering.

title: Supermode Decomposition During Operation of a 7-Core Fiber Laser
authors: Clémence Jollivet; Daniel Flamm; Michael Duparré; Kay Schuster; Stephan Grimm; Axel Schülzgen
abstract: Lasing operation of a tunable fiber laser employing a flat cleaved 7-core gain fiber fusion spliced with a standard fiber Bragg grating is investigated. We present the first modal decomposition during multicore laser operation.

title: Incoherent beam combining of 5.1kW using a 7×1 signal combiner into a 50µm core output fiber
authors: Tina Eschrich; Denny Hoh; Florian Just; Jens Kobelke; Sonja Unger; Matthias Jäger; Hartmut Bartelt

title: Multi-directional Photonic Integrated Circuit (PIC) based Sliceable Transponder in Optical Networks
authors: Anuj Malik; Onur Turkcu; Nitin Goel; Steve Hand; Serge Melle
abstract: This paper introduces a multi-directional PIC based sliceable transponder enabling transmission from one point to multiple points and real world network model results show equivalent port use as 100G transponders and considerable operational savings.

title: Nanophotonic, Hot-Electron Avalanche Solar-Blind Ultraviolet Detectors with a Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor Structure
authors: Zhiyuan Wang; Xiaoxin Wang; Jifeng Liu
abstract: We present nanophotonic MOS solar-blind avalanche UV detectors with 0.95A/W responsivity at λ=290 nm (400% efficiency), using Sn nanogratings as the active UV absorber for hot-electron generation and transport across the metal/oxide barrier.

title: Soft-Glass Photonic Crystal Fibres
authors: Xin Jiang; F. Babic; Nicolas Y. Joly; T. G. Euser; Thomas Weiß; A. Abdolvand; M. A. Finger; G. K. L. Wong; Michael H. Frosz; Joris Lousteau; M. Saad; P. St. J. Russell
corresponding_authors: Xin Jiang; F. Babic; Nicolas Y. Joly; T. G. Euser; Thomas Weiß; A. Abdolvand; M. A. Finger; G. K. L. Wong; Michael H. Frosz; Joris Lousteau; M. Saad; P. St. J. Russell
abstract: We report on recent progress in the fabrication of solid- and hollow-core soft glass photonic crystal fibres. Unprecedented structural uniformity enables applications such as light guidance and supercontinuum generation in the mid-IR.

title: Multicore Erbium-doped Fiber Amplifier for Space Division Multiplexed Systems
authors: Kazi S. Abedin
corresponding_authors: Kazi S. Abedin
abstract: We present numerical simulation and experiments on 7-core fiber erbium-doped fiber amplifier, both core- and cladding-pumped, developed for amplifying space division multiplexed signals. Designing of a few-mode multicore cladding pump amplifier will also be shown. Article not available.

title: Coded Modulation for High Spectral Efficiency Long-Haul Optical Transmission System
authors: Hongbin Zhang; Hussam G. Batshon
corresponding_authors: Hongbin Zhang; Hussam G. Batshon
abstract: We review Trellis coded modulation and bit interleaved coded modulation (BICM) in optical communication systems. BICM with four dimensional mapping using single parity coding is discussed for high spectral efficiency transoceanic transmission systems.

title: Digital Camera with Spiral Odd-Symmetry Phase Grating Supports Full-Resolution Computational Refocussing
authors: P. Gill; David G. Stork
abstract: Novel odd-symmetry phase gratings produce spatially varying depth-dependent point-spread functions on an imager's sensor plane. The severely blurred sensed image can be inverted computationally to refocus and estimate target distances.

title: Rotated First Iteration Square Fractal Shaped Perfect Absorbers
authors: Ekin Aslan; Semih Korkmaz; Sabri Kaya; Mustafa Türkmen
abstract: The spectral responses and field distributions of square fractal-shaped nanohole arrays are analyzed by using finite-difference-time-domain (FDTD) method. The optical characteristics of the structure are obtained for different material thicknesses.

title: An Interior-Ridge Silicon Microring Switch with Integrated Thermal Tuner
authors: Zhan Su; Erman Timurdogan; Jie Sun; M. Moresco; Gerald Leake; Douglas Coolbaugh; Michael R. Watts
abstract: A 1-by-2 compact injection-based switch is reported utilizing interior-ridge ring resonators, demonstrating nanosecond-scale switching speed, single-mode, low-loss (0/1.3dB for thru/drop port) with efficient integrated thermal tuner (7.25µW/GHz).

title: Key technologies of dynamic control in multi-domain heterogeneous optical networks
authors: Xiaoping Zheng
corresponding_authors: Xiaoping Zheng
abstract: This paper compares three typical architectures for multi-domain heterogeneous optical networks and investigates some of their dynamic control technologies. An experimental platform based on a novel hybrid management and control architecture is also presented.

title: Multi-Channel DBP for Reach Enhancement of High Capacity M-QAM Super-Channels
authors: Robert Maher; Domaniç Lavery; Alex Alvarado; Milen Paskov; Polina Bayvel
corresponding_authors: Robert Maher; Domaniç Lavery; Alex Alvarado; Milen Paskov; Polina Bayvel
abstract: The combination of joint DSP and wideband digital coherent receivers are explored for the mitigation of nonlinear optical transmission impairments. Application in M-QAM super-channel transmission systems lead to increases in achievable reach and ISD.

title: Ideal POL-QAM Modulation for Coherent Detection Schemes
authors: H. Bülow
corresponding_authors: H. Bülow
