title: Implications of ODN on Energy Consumption in Access Networks
authors: A. Teixeira; Ali Shahpari
corresponding_authors: A. Teixeira; Ali Shahpari
abstract: The problem of installed fiber plants and the issue of energy consumption are two challenging points in the current techno-economical environment. This paper addresses the investment and interface technology level in Optical Distribution Network (ODN).

title: Hollow-core Photonic Crystal Fibers: Guidances and Applications
authors: Fetah Benabid
corresponding_authors: Fetah Benabid
abstract: We give a historical perspective on the major results that led to the advent of the photonic bandgap guiding hollow core photonic crystal fiber ( PBG HC-PCF) and to that of inhibited-coupling one (IC HC-PCF). We review the progress made on gas-filled HC-PCF and photonic microcells, along with their applications for coherent optics, Raman comb generation laser metrology, discharge based lasers and high field optics.

title: Thermal Imaging System for Hydroelectric Generator Stator Based on Distributed Optical Sensors
authors: João Paulo Bazzo; Felipe Mezzadri; Erlon Vagner da Silva; Daniel Rodrigues Pipa; Cícero Martelli; Jean Carlos Cardozo da Silva
corresponding_authors: João Paulo Bazzo; Felipe Mezzadri; Erlon Vagner da Silva; Daniel Rodrigues Pipa; Cícero Martelli; Jean Carlos Cardozo da Silva
abstract: This paper presents a thermal imaging system for stators of hydroelectric generators using distributed sensors. The main advantage of this approach over conventional sensors is the possibility to identify temperature variations over the stator structure.

title: Trellis-Coded High-Dimensional Modulation for Polarization Crosstalk Self Cancellation in Coherent Optical Communications
authors: Toshiaki Koike‐Akino; Keisuke Kojima; Kieran Parsons
abstract: We propose new trellis-coded high-dimensional modulation (TC-HDM) robust to polarization crosstalk in coherent optical communications. Since the modulation can automatically recover polarization crosstalk, it offers 2 dBQ improvement through the use of blind equalization.

title: Experimentally demonstrate the origin for asymmetric resonance splitting and contributions from couplers to backscattering in SOI microrings
authors: Ang Li; Thomas Van Vaerenbergh; Peter De Heyn; Ying Xing; Peter Bienstman; Wim Bogaerts
abstract: We build a new fitting method which could fit all kinds of resonances of microrings.With that, we experimentally demonstrate the cause for asymmetrically split resonances as well as couplers induced backscattering in SOI microrings.

title: Quadrature Hybrid RF Photonic Coupler Using an Integrated Frequency Comb Source
authors: Thach G. Nguyen; Mehrdad Shoeiby; Sai T. Chu; Roberto Morandotti; Arnan Mitchell; David Moss
corresponding_authors: Thach G. Nguyen; Mehrdad Shoeiby; Sai T. Chu; Roberto Morandotti; Arnan Mitchell; David Moss
abstract: An integrated CMOS-compatible multiple-wavelength optical source is exploited for photonic implementation of a quadrature hybrid RF coupler based on multi-tap transversal filtering scheme. Four octave bandwidth with almost ideal 90◦ phase shift has been achieved.

title: Emergence of Negative Index in a Lossy Chiral Metamaterial under First-Order Material Dispersion
authors: Monish R. Chatterjee; Tarig Algadey
corresponding_authors: Monish R. Chatterjee; Tarig Algadey
abstract: For a lossless dispersive chiral material, negative index (NIM) occurred only by use of parametric analysis (and not via practical models) to first-order. These findings are re-visited for the lossy problem and the results are compared.

title: Erbium nanoparticle doping for high power fiber lasers
authors: Colin Baker; E. J. Friebele; Charles G. Askins; Jacob P. Fontana; Michael Hunt; John R. Peele; Barbara A. Marcheschi; Woohong Kim; Jasbinder S. Sanghera; Jun Zhang; R. Pattnaik; Larry D. Merkle; Mark Dubinskii
abstract: A nanoparticle (NP) doping technique was used for making erbium-doped fibers (EDFs). The nanoparticles were doped into the silica soot of preforms which were drawn into fibers. Results have indicated optical-to-optical slope efficiencies of 80.4%.

title: Wavelength Routing and Multicasting Network in Ring-Based Integrated Photonics
authors: Zhan Su; Erman Timurdogan; M. Moresco; Gerald Leake; Douglas Coolbaugh; Michael R. Watts
corresponding_authors: Zhan Su; Erman Timurdogan; M. Moresco; Gerald Leake; Douglas Coolbaugh; Michael R. Watts
abstract: Wavelength routing and multicasting network is demonstrated in cross-grid waveguide structure. High channel efficiency and extensibility to a large-scale system are achieved with 0.5mW tuning power and 0.8dB power penalty among all casting functions.

title: Optical Flip-Flop Memory and Routing Operation Based on Polarization Bistability in Optical Fiber
authors: P.-Y. Bony; Massimiliano Guasoni; Elie Assémat; S. Pitois; D. Sugny; Antonio Picozzi; H. R. Jauslin; Julien Fatome
corresponding_authors: P.-Y. Bony; Massimiliano Guasoni; Elie Assémat; S. Pitois; D. Sugny; Antonio Picozzi; H. R. Jauslin; Julien Fatome
abstract: Thanks to a polarization bistability and associated hysteresis cycle generated in optical fibers through a counter-propagating four-wave mixing process, we report the proof-of-principle of an optical flip-flop memory and a 10-Gbit/s routing operation.

title: Single step epitaxial growth of Ge-on-Si for active photonic devices
authors: Rodolfo Camacho‐Aguilera; Jonathan T. Bessette; Yan Cai; Xili Duan; Jifeng Liu; Lionel C. Kimerling; Jürgen Michel
corresponding_authors: Rodolfo Camacho‐Aguilera; Jonathan T. Bessette; Yan Cai; Xili Duan; Jifeng Liu; Lionel C. Kimerling; Jürgen Michel
abstract: Germanium for integrated photonic devices has been grown selectively on Si, using a single step epitaxial process, eliminating the standard highly dislocated Ge or SiGe buffer layer to accommodate the Ge-Si lattice mismatch.

title: Wave-Particle duality of single surface plasmon polaritons
authors: Marie-Christine Dheur; Jean‐Jacques Greffet; Gaétan Messin; Éloïse Devaux; Philippe Lalanne; Thomas W. Ebbesen; François Marquier
abstract: We use a plasmonic beamsplitter in an interferometer to demonstrate the wave-particle duality of surface plasmon polaritons lying on a plane gold surface. The particle or wave behavior is chosen with the orientation of a half waveplate.

title: Low Crosstalk Design of an Optical Matrix Switch Using Phase-Change Material
authors: Takumi Moriyama; Daiki Tanaka; Paridhi Jain; Hiroyuki Tsuda
corresponding_authors: Takumi Moriyama; Daiki Tanaka; Paridhi Jain; Hiroyuki Tsuda
abstract: A crossbar type optical matrix switch using phase-change material was designed to have low crosstalk. The crosstalk of less than −49.1 dB was achieved for a 4×4 matrix switch by adjusting a unit switch structure.

title: Simulation of Waveguide Corner and Cross by Complex Mode Matching Method
authors: Rui Wang; Lin Han; Jianwei Mu; Wei‐Ping Huang
corresponding_authors: Rui Wang; Lin Han; Jianwei Mu; Wei‐Ping Huang
abstract: Radiation field emitting perpendicular to waveguide axis in waveguide corner and cross is simulated by complex mode matching method and validated by FDTD. Power conservation is demonstrated to establish self-consistency of the method.

title: Asymmetrically pumped Bragg scattering with the effects of nonlinear phase modulation
authors: L. Mejling; Søren Friis; Dileep V. Reddy; Karsten Rottwitt; Michael G. Raymer; C. J. McKinstrie
corresponding_authors: L. Mejling; Søren Friis; Dileep V. Reddy; Karsten Rottwitt; Michael G. Raymer; C. J. McKinstrie
abstract: We derive exact solutions to asymmetrically pumped Bragg scattering with nonlinear phase-modulation (NPM) and show that this setup allows for the frequency conversion of many temporal modes, while reducing the effects due to NPM.

title: An MMI-Based 4-Beam Combiner with Spline-Curved Index Step
authors: Toshiaki Koike‐Akino; Keisuke Kojima; Bingnan Wang; Kieran Parsons; Satoshi Nishikawa; Eiji Yagyu
abstract: We propose a compact MMI-based 4-beam combiner with a spline-curved index step. The 1.74 mm-long device designed in InP material systems offers 3 dB better transmittance than power combiners at a 4.5 nm wavelength spacing.

title: High mechanical fMQM product tuning fork cavity optomechanical transducers
authors: Rui Zhang; Chaoyang Ti; Marcelo Davanço; Yundong Ren; Vladimir Aksyuk; Yuxiang Liu; Kartik Srinivasan
corresponding_authors: Rui Zhang; Chaoyang Ti; Marcelo Davanço; Yundong Ren; Vladimir Aksyuk; Yuxiang Liu; Kartik Srinivasan
abstract: We present monolithic cavity optomechanical transducers combining microdisk optical cavities with tuning fork mechanical resonators to achieve high mechanical frequency (fM) and high quality factor (QM), with a measured fMQM product of 6.35×1012 Hz.

title: Thermal Emission Shaping and Radiative Cooling with Thermal Wells, Wires and Dots
authors: Svetlana V. Boriskina; Jonathan Tong; Lee A. Weinstein; Wei‐Chun Hsu; Yi Huang; Gang Chen
corresponding_authors: Svetlana V. Boriskina; Jonathan Tong; Lee A. Weinstein; Wei‐Chun Hsu; Yi Huang; Gang Chen
abstract: We discuss radiative heat extraction and spectral shaping via engineering of the density of confined photon states in low-dimensional potential traps, including wells, wires, and dots. Applications include thermophotovoltaics, radiative cooling, energy up- and down-conversion.

title: Sensing platforms exploiting surface plasmon resonance in polymeric optical fibers for chemical and biochemical applications
authors: Luigi Zeni; Sabato D’Auria; Maria Pesavento; Letizia De Maria; Nunzio Cennamo
abstract: An SPR sensor in POF, with possible implementation as bio/chemical sensor, is presented. This SPR-POF platform can be used in different application fields: industrial, medical diagnostics, environmental monitoring, food safety and security.

title: Observation of Background Fluorescence in a Poled Fiber
authors: E. Y. Zhu; Zhenzhou Tang; E. A. Lee Kim-Koon; Li Qian; L. G. Helt; Marco Liscidini; J. E. Sipe; C. Corbari; Albert Canagasabey; M. Ibsen; Peter G. Kazansky
corresponding_authors: E. Y. Zhu; Zhenzhou Tang; E. A. Lee Kim-Koon; Li Qian; L. G. Helt; Marco Liscidini; J. E. Sipe; C. Corbari; Albert Canagasabey; M. Ibsen; Peter G. Kazansky
abstract: We observe broadband fluorescence (1260-1610 nm) in a periodically-poled silica fiber pumped at 775 nm; it is a noise contribution to correlated photon pair generation. The fluorescence is significantly lower in an identical, but unpoled, fiber.

title: Performance Analyses of Digital Coherent Receivers with Symbol-rate Analog-to-digital Conversion
authors: K. Kikuchi
corresponding_authors: K. Kikuchi
abstract: We analyze the performance of digital coherent receivers with symbol-rate analog-to-digital conversion, aiming at short/medium-reach applications (<100 km). Efficient dispersion compensation can be done even under the aliasing effect, once the clock is recovered externally.

title: Infrared and Raman spectroscopic imaging for histopathology
authors: Rohit Bhargave
corresponding_authors: Rohit Bhargave
abstract: We present a new approach to recognizing cell types and disease states in tissue using vibrational spectroscopic imaging. Theory, instrumentation, pattern recognition algorithms and applications in specific areas will be discussed. Article not available.

title: Optical fibers with hermetic coating for high temperature applications
authors: В. А. Козлов; Joohyun Koh; Kevin Bennett; Paul G. Sanders; Trevor MacDougall
corresponding_authors: В. А. Козлов; Joohyun Koh; Kevin Bennett; Paul G. Sanders; Trevor MacDougall
abstract: Optical fibers with carbon coating and high temperature protective coating were tested at temperatures up to 200C and hydrogen pressures up to 400psi to study carbon coating hermetic properties at elevated temperatures.

title: Suspended Microring Resonator Sensor using Internal Sub-Wavelength Grating
authors: Soha Yousuf; Mahmoud Shahin; Hayk Gevorgyan; Bob Voort; Ayat M. Taha; Clara Dimas; Marcus S. Dahlem; Anatol Khilo
abstract: A fully suspended microring resonator sensor supported by a sub-wavelength grating is proposed. Sensitivity of 503nm/RIU and Q-factor of 75k are predicted for a resonator with 450nm-period grating. Q=29k is measured for an unsuspended resonator.

title: Hitless Multi-rate Coherent Transceiver
authors: Zhuhong Zhang; Chuandong Li
abstract: A novel multi-rate coherent transceiver that supports multi-order QAM and hitless rate change is achieved with additional digital signal processing modules in a coherent transceiver. Proof of concept simulation is presented and discussed.

title: Ultrahigh Bandwidth, Low Vπ Photonic Crystal BaTiO3 Modulators
authors: Peter Girouard; Pice Chen; Yongming Tu; Young Kyu Jeong; Zhifu Liu; Seng-Tiong Ho; Bruce W. Wessels
abstract: BaTiO3 modulators with as low as 3.9 V Vπ and as high as 28 GHz bandwidth are reported. We demonstrate photonic crystal waveguides with a group index of 4 and predict > 50GHz bandwidth and < 5V operation in optimized photonic crystal modulators.

title: Novel Gradient Smoothing Method-Based Time Domain Beam Propagation Analysis of Optical Integrated Circuits
authors: Khaled S. R. Atia; S. S. A. Obayya
abstract: Novel gradient smoothing method (GSM) is adopted for time domain beam propagation method. GSM uses unstructured mesh and no Galerkin procedure is required. It is utilized to simulate various integrated circuits.

title: Broadband 2×2 Multimode Interference Coupler for T- and O-band Communication by Wavefront Matching Method
authors: Koki Sugiyama; Hiroyuki Tsuda
abstract: A silica-based 2×2 multimode interference coupler for broad wavelength band from 1.05 μm to 1.30 μm was designed using wavefront matching method. The loss and imbalance characteristics are effectively improved compared to the conventional design.

title: Photonic Lantern
authors: Sergio G. Leon-Saval
corresponding_authors: Sergio G. Leon-Saval
abstract: The photonic lantern is a low-loss optical device that connects one multimode waveguide to several single-mode or/and few-mode waveguides. Hence, providing seamless transformation between multimode and single-mode/few-mode systems exploiting multimode photonics for the first time.

title: Optical Bio-Chemical Sensors on SNOW Ring Resonators
authors: Mohammadreza Khorasaninejad; M. P. Anantram; Simarjeet S. Saini
corresponding_authors: Mohammadreza Khorasaninejad; M. P. Anantram; Simarjeet S. Saini
abstract: In this paper we propose novel ring resonator based bio-chemical sensors on silicon-nanowire-optical-waveguide and show that the sensitivity can be increased by an order of magnitude as compared to Silicon-on-insulator based ring resonators.

title: Temperature Sensing of High Power Generator Stator using DTS
authors: João Paulo Bazzo; Felipe Mezzadri; Cícero Martelli; Erlon Vagner da Silva; Daniel Rodrigues Pipa; Jean Carlos Cardozo da Silva
corresponding_authors: João Paulo Bazzo; Felipe Mezzadri; Cícero Martelli; Erlon Vagner da Silva; Daniel Rodrigues Pipa; Jean Carlos Cardozo da Silva
abstract: Stator surface temperature monitoring of a 175 MW hydroelectric generator using DTS is presented. The main advantage of this approach over conventional sensors is the possibility to identify temperature variations over with high spatial resolution.

title: Directional and Selective Mid-Infrared Thermal Emitters for Sensing Applications
authors: Cédric Blanchard; Quentin Lévesque; D. Costantini; Cécile Jamois; Jean‐Louis Leclercq; A.-L. Coutrot; François Marquier; Laurent Milord; Christian Grillet; H. Benisty; Pierre Viktorovitch; X. Letartre; Jean‐Jacques Greffet
abstract: We propose energy efficient gas sensors that are based on the manipulation of the spectral and spatial emission of incandescent sources. To do so either photonic or plasmonic resonances in texturized nanostructures are employed.

title: Dispersion Compensation Filter Design Optimized for Robustness and Power Efficiency
authors: Alireza Sheikh; Christoffer Fougstedt; Alexandre Graell i Amat; Pontus Johannisson; Per Larsson-Edefors; Magnus Karlsson
abstract: We present an optimized CD compensation filter with improved performance and increased resilience to quantization errors. The filter is given in closed form based on a constrained least-squares problem.

title: Perspectives on the future of photonics: the best is yet to come
authors: Eugene G. Arthurs
corresponding_authors: Eugene G. Arthurs
abstract: Advanced Photonics, co-published by SPIE and Chinese Laser Press, is a highly selective, Gold Open Access, international journal publishing innovative research in all areas of optics and photonics, including fundamental and applied research.

title: Transforming optics: an interview with Sir John Pendry
authors: J. B. Pendry
corresponding_authors: J. B. Pendry

title: Microwaves trigger thermo-acoustic ultrasound generation
authors: Frederic Cegla
corresponding_authors: Frederic Cegla
abstract: In volume 2, issue 3 of Advanced Photonics, Lan et al. reveal that a split ring resonator can be used as a very efficient thermo-acoustic source compared to other configurations. This commentary provides a quick overview of the work and how it sits in context with other forms of ultrasonic signal acquisition.

title: Endless frontier of plasmonics: a conversation with Naomi Halas
authors: Jia Zhu
corresponding_authors: Jia Zhu
abstract: Naomi Halas, professor of electrical and computer engineering at Rice University and winner of the prestigious 2022 Eni Energy Transition Award, discusses her vision for the future of plasmonics and nanophotonics, in terms of fundamentals and applications, in conversation with Jia Zhu, professor in the College of Engineering and Applied Science at Nanjing University and associate editor for Advanced Photonics.

title: Electrical Crosstalk in Integrated Mach-Zehnder Modulators Caused by a Shared Ground Path
authors: Weiming Yao; Giovanni Gilardi; M.K. Smit; Michael J. Wale
abstract: We show that the majority of electrical crosstalk between integrated Mach-Zehnder modulators can be caused by a shared ground path and demonstrate that in its absence crosstalk and related transmission penalty is greatly reduced.

title: Challenging Applications for Regenerated FBGs Focus on Temperature Sensing
authors: Guillaume Laffont
corresponding_authors: Guillaume Laffont
abstract: This paper presents the development of regenerated FBG temperature sensors for the instrumentation of 4th Generation nuclear core, of the divertor for the ITER Tokamak (fusion study) and for petrochemical process experimentations (catalytic agents development).

title: Vortex Solitons and Azimuthons in Vertical-Cavity Surface-Emitting Lasers with Feedback
authors: J. Jimenez; P. V. Paulau; Gian‐Luca Oppo; W. J. Firth; T. Ackemann
abstract: We observe vortex solitons and dissipative azimuthons in a vertical-cavity surface-emitting laser with feedback, and demonstrate evolution between these states under parameter variation. Stable vortices and azimuthons also exist in a simple model system.

title: Grating Inscription with Two-Beam Interferometry and Non-Homogeneous Beam-Splitter
authors: Martin Becker; Tino Elsmann; Manfred Rothhardt; Hartmut Bartelt
corresponding_authors: Martin Becker; Tino Elsmann; Manfred Rothhardt; Hartmut Bartelt
abstract: We present a phase-mask interferometer for fiber Bragg grating inscription which uses a phase-mask as non-homogeneous beam-splitter. It allows writing continously chirped fiber Bragg gratings while maintaining the wavelength versatility of the interferometer.

title: Accelerating beam propagation in refractive index potentials
authors: Nikolaos K. Efremidis
corresponding_authors: Nikolaos K. Efremidis
abstract: We study the dynamics of accelerating beams impinging on different classes of index potentials. The analytic expressions for the reflected and transmitted waves show that the Airy-wave parabolic trajectory is modified with some particular exceptions.

title: Inversed-modified Soliton Generation in Mode-locked Fibre Laser at Normal Dispersion
authors: Maria Chernysheva; Aleksandr A Krylov; Chengbo Mou; Raz Arif; Aleksey Rozhin; Mark H. Rümelli; N. R. Arutyunyan; Е. Д. Образцова; Sergei K. Turitsyn; E. M. Dianov
corresponding_authors: Maria Chernysheva; Aleksandr A Krylov; Chengbo Mou; Raz Arif; Aleksey Rozhin; Mark H. Rümelli; N. R. Arutyunyan; Е. Д. Образцова; Sergei K. Turitsyn; E. M. Dianov
abstract: We demonstrate erbium- and thulium-doped fibre ring lasers mode-locked with a single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNT) operating at normal intracavity dispersion and high nonlinearity. The lasers generate transform-limited picosecond inversed-modified soliton pulses.

title: Photonic bandgap fiber lasers and multicore fiber lasers for next generation high power lasers
authors: A. Shirakawa; M. Chen; Yuta Suzuki; Kimitoshi Sato; Xiaojie Fan; Henrik Tünnermann; Malte Karow; Christina B. Olausson; Sidsel R. Petersen; Thomas Tanggaard Alkeskjold; Kazuya Saito
abstract: Photonic bandgap fiber lasers are realizing new laser spectra and nonlinearity mitigation that a conventional fiber laser cannot. Multicore fiber lasers are a promising tool for power scaling by coherent beam combination. © 2014 OSA.

title: Higher-order Femtosecond Solitons Generation in a Hybrid Mode-locked Tm-doped Fibre Laser
authors: Maria Chernysheva; A. A. Krylov; Chengbo Mou; Raz Arif; Aleksey Rozhin; Mark H. Rümelli; Sergei K. Turitsyn; E. M. Dianov
corresponding_authors: Maria Chernysheva; A. A. Krylov; Chengbo Mou; Raz Arif; Aleksey Rozhin; Mark H. Rümelli; Sergei K. Turitsyn; E. M. Dianov
abstract: A thulium-doped all-fibre laser hybrid mode-locked by the co-action of nonlinear polarization evolution and single-walled carbon nanotubes generating 500-fs high-order solitons with the pulse energy 10.87 nJ at 1.9 μm wavelength band is demonstrated.

title: Biomimetic optical filter based chemical sensing techniques
authors: Ishwar D. Aggarwal; Menelaos K. Poutous; Kevin J. Major; Kenneth J. Ewing; Jasbinder S. Sanghera
abstract: Biomimetic, filter-based chemical detectors have been designed to detect various chemicals of interest. We present some of the existing approaches, and a new comparative-discrimination spectral detection approach for the detection of overlapping chemical spectral signatures.

title: Bulk and edge transport in photonic Lieb lattices
authors: Diego Guzmán-Silva; Cristian Mejía-Cortés; Miguel A. Bandres; Mikael C. Rechtsman; Steffen Weimann; Stefan Nolte; Mordechai Segev; Rodrigo A. Vicencio; Alexander Szameit
abstract: We study the propagation of light in photonic Lieb lattices, observing dramatic differences on the observed diffraction patterns. Additionally, we find new edge states what are absent in the standard tight-binding model.

title: Angular Resolutions of the Porous Anodic Alumina/Aluminum Photonic-Plasmonic Sensors
authors: Hande Çavuş Arslan; Burcu Güleryüz; Mustafa M. Aslan
corresponding_authors: Hande Çavuş Arslan; Burcu Güleryüz; Mustafa M. Aslan
abstract: We study the angular resolution of photonic-plasmonic sensors that consist of porous anodic alumina and aluminum layers. The maximum resolution for the sensors is demonstrated as 6.8×10−8 in the refractive index range of 1.33-1.36 at p-0 polarization.

title: Collective coordinate approach for the dynamics of light pulses in fiber ring lasers
authors: Mohd Alsaleh; E. Tchomgo Felenou; C. B. L. Mback; P. Tchofo Dinda; Philippe Grelu
abstract: We present an efficient variational approach for fiber lasers in which light pulses may execute complex dynamics, and we establish its validity by comparison with the numerical approach based on the generalized nonlinear Schroedinger equation.

title: Phase and intensity retrieval of ultrashort laser pulses with single-shot VAMPIRE
authors: Karsten Sperlich; Birger Seifert; H. Stolz
abstract: We present our single-shot version of a self-referencing technique for measuring the phase and intensity of ultrashort laser pulses called VAMPIRE [Seifert et al., Meas. sci. technol. 20 015303 (2009)]. The cross-correlation setup utilizes filter elements to circumvent relative-phase or direction of time ambiguities.

title: Fibre-based mode multiplexers
authors: T. A. Birks; Stephanos Yerolatsitis; Itandehui Gris-Sánchez
abstract: We made fibre mode multiplexers by adiabatically merging three dissimilar fibre waveguides. The LP01 and both LP11 modes were excited with better than 0.7 dB loss, 10 dB mode purity and 100 nm bandwidth.

title: High-speed Non-contact Displacement Sensor Based on Microchip Nd:YVO4 Laser Feedback Interferometry
authors: Song Zhang; Y. X. Tan; Shulian Zhang
abstract: We analyze the measurement speed limit of the microchip laser feedback interferometer and demonstrate a much improved measurement speed from 100μm/s to 120mm/s owing to the optimized system parameters and a novel signal processing method.

title: Large mode area pixelated trench fiber
authors: Deepak Jain; Catherine Baskiotis; J. K. Sahu
abstract: We propose a novel fiber that offers excellent suppression of higher-order-modes with loss higher than 10dB/m and low loss for fundamental mode (<0.1dB/m) at 1.06μm, with effective area as large as 1100μm2 and excellent bend-robustness.

title: Dark-and-bright rogue waves in long wave-short wave resonance
authors: Shihua Chen; J. M. Soto‐Crespo; Philippe Grelu
abstract: Exact rogue wave solutions of intricate structures are presented for the long wave-short wave resonance equation. These vector parametric solutions feature coupled dark and bright field counterparts of the Peregrine soliton. Numerical simulations show the robustness of dark-and-bright rogue waves in spite of the onset of modulational instability.

title: Nonlinear Effects in High Peak Power 3C® Fiber Amplifiers
authors: Timothy S. McComb; Geoff Fanning; D. F. Logan; Roger L. Farrow; Tyson L. Lowder; Joona Koponen
abstract: Picosecond chirally coupled core (3C) fiber amplifiers show nonlinear effects at hundreds of kW peak power not typical in LMA fibers. Polarization rotation and modulation instability-like effects are observed and model backed origins are proposed.

title: Improving the sensitivity of an interferometric fiber optic sensor for acoustic detection in rockfalls
authors: Luca Schenato; Luca Palmieri; E. Autizi; Andrea Galtarossa; Alessandro Pasuto
corresponding_authors: Luca Schenato; Luca Palmieri; E. Autizi; Andrea Galtarossa; Alessandro Pasuto
abstract: Optimization of an interferometric fiber optic sensor for ultrasonic acoustic detection in rockfall monitoring is addressed. The optimized sensor employs a polyimide coated fiber and improved design with an almost doubled acoustic sensitivity.

title: High performance semiconductor nanowire and graphene Terahertz nanodetectors
authors: Miriam S. Vitiello
corresponding_authors: Miriam S. Vitiello
abstract: We report on the development of antenna-coupled plasma-wave field effect transistors based on InAs-nanowire or graphene, operating as room-temperature detectors in the 0.3-3THz range with responsivities ~110V/W and noise-equivalent power levels <10−10W/Hz1/2 suitable for large-area imaging applications.

title: Multi-axial strain sensing using polymer planar Bragg gratings
authors: M. Rosenberger; Steffen Hessler; S. Belle; Bernhard Schmauß; Ralf Hellmann
abstract: We demonstrate, for the first time ever, a polymer planar Bragg grating sensor for simultaneous multi-axial strain sensing. The sensor containing two perpendicular gratings is used for measuring compressive and tensile strain at different angles.

title: Double clad photonic crystal fiber for high resolution nonlinear endomicroscopy
authors: Flavie Braud; Guillaume Ducourthial; Tigran Mansuryan; Rémi Habert; Alexandre Kudlinski; Frédéric Louradour
abstract: We present a double-clad photonic crystal fiber optimized for high resolution nonlinear endomicroscopy. Label-free two-photon fluorescence and second-harmonic generation imaging of biological tissues are demonstrated through a 5 m-long fiber.

title: Mode-Resolved Gain Analysis of a 7-Core Fiber Laser Based on Multi-Supermode Interference
authors: Clémence Jollivet; Arash Mafi; Daniel Flamm; Michael Duparré; Kay Schuster; S. Grimm; Axel Schülzgen
abstract: A supermode interference monolithic fiber laser utilizing optical gain from several supermodes amplified in an Yb-doped 7-core fiber is investigated. In addition, we present mode-resolved gain measurements providing insight on the laser dynamics.

title: Splitting after collision of high-order bright spatial solitons in Kerr media
authors: M. D. Iturbe Castillo; S. Chávez-Cerda
abstract: We study numerically the asymmetric collision of high order bright spatial solitons with a fundamental one. It is demonstrated the splitting of the high-order soliton under some separation distances and angles between the solitons.

title: Hollow Core Photonic Bandgap Fibers for Mid-IR Applications
authors: N.V. Wheeler; M. N. Petrovich; Alexander M. Heidt; N. K. Baddela; Eric Numkam Fokoua; J. R. Hayes; S. R. Sandoghchi; Francesco Poletti; David J. Richardson
abstract: We review our fabrication of low loss (50dB/km at 3.3µm) and low bend sensitivity HC-PBGFs for mid-IR operation. Gas sensing applications are highlighted by a high resolution methane spectrum recorded in 1.26m of gas-filled fiber.

title: Spatiotemporal Nonlinear Dynamics in Gas-Filled Photonic-Crystal Fibers
authors: John C. Travers; Francesco Tani; A. Abdolvand; Federico Belli; P. St. J. Russell
abstract: We numerically and experimentally explore spatiotemporal effects during ultrashort pulse propagation in gas-filled kagomé-PCF. These include self-focusing, intermodal dispersive-wave emission, and multi-mode transient Raman frequency-comb generation.

title: Accurate Modelling of Hollow Core Photonic Bandgap Fibre
authors: Eric Numkam Fokoua; S. R. Sandoghchi; Yong Chen; Natalie V. Wheeler; N. K. Baddela; J. R. Hayes; M. N. Petrovich; David J. Richardson; Francesco Poletti
abstract: A modelling tool to accurately reproduce the performance of fabricated hollow-core photonic bandgap fibers from their SEM images is presented. This enables new understanding of the effect of cross-sectional distortions.

title: Phase-shifted fiber Bragg grating for strain measurement at extreme conditions
authors: Marta S. Ferreira; Graham C. B. Lee; J. L. Santos; Kate Sugden; Orlando Frazão
abstract: In this work, a phase-shifted fiber Bragg grating is proposed for strain sensing at extreme temperatures. The grating structure is written in bare standard single mode fiber, using the point-by-point femtosecond laser technique. Strain measurements are performed at temperatures ranging from room temperature up to 900°C. By subjecting the sensor to such extreme conditions, the wavelength of the grating increases.

title: New class of crystal inorganic scintillators
authors: A. S. Shmygalev; A. S. Korsakov; Liya Zhukova; Б. В. Шульгин
corresponding_authors: A. S. Shmygalev; A. S. Korsakov; Liya Zhukova; Б. В. Шульгин
abstract: We developed and made a new class of crystal single-layer and two-layer fiber inorganic scintillators (CIS). Received fiber CIS possess unique optic-physical properties. The CIS luminescent properties were studied by radiation bunches.

title: Nanoimprinted and Angular Evaporated Aluminum Plasmonic Nanoantennas Arrays
authors: Luc Duempelmann; Benjamin Gallinet; Lukáš Novotný
corresponding_authors: Luc Duempelmann; Benjamin Gallinet; Lukáš Novotný
abstract: We describe a toolbox to create high-throughput asymmetric subwavelength plasmonic nanostructures. The well-defined plasmon resonance leads to a specific angular unidirectional color change, tunable over the whole VIS spectra by varying the fabrication parameter.

title: Random distributed feedback fiber laser of ultimate efficiency
authors: Ilya D. Vatnik; Dmitry V. Churkin; E. V. Podivilov; Sergey A. Babin
corresponding_authors: Ilya D. Vatnik; Dmitry V. Churkin; E. V. Podivilov; Sergey A. Babin
abstract: We demonstrate a random fiber laser of ultimate efficiency. More than 2 Watts are generated from 0.5W of pump excess over the generation threshold. At higher power, an optical efficiency corresponds to the quantum limit.

title: Quantum Key Distribution using Phase Encoding in Double-Pass Silica-on-Silicon Circuits with Grating Reflectors
authors: M. Kristensen; Jonathan Maack; A.D. Thomasen; T. Balle; Jacob Selchau
abstract: The advantages of D-shape fiber in combination with an optical analog of Ramsey fringes using LPGs are presented. The mode-profiles of the sensor were characterized experimentally to provide deeper knowledge about improved functionality.

title: Mid IR-Fiber Optics for Process Spectroscopy and Laser Power Delivery
authors: Viacheslav Artyushenko
corresponding_authors: Viacheslav Artyushenko
abstract: Well known fused silica fibers possess by high transmission in a broad spectral range from 180nm up to 2.2μm and can be used for Near-InfraRed (NIR-) spectroscopy or for laser power delivery of Diode, Nd- or Ho-lasers. As silica fiber transmission is limited for a longer wavelengths by fundamental multi-phonon absorption wing – the other types of materials were used to fabricate fibers for Mid InfraRed range, i.e. for wavelengths above 2,2μm and up to 16μm. Hollow Waveguides (HW), including band-gap photonic crystals can be also used for flexible delivery of Mid IR-radiation, but with some limitations in their spectral attenuation and in beam divergence caused by HW-structure and bending radii.

title: Tunable coaxial resonators based on silicon optical fibers
authors: F. H. Suhailin; N. Healy; M. Sumetsky; Limin Xiao; John Ballato; Andrew Dibbs; Ursula J. Gibson; Anna C. Peacock
corresponding_authors: F. H. Suhailin; N. Healy; M. Sumetsky; Limin Xiao; John Ballato; Andrew Dibbs; Ursula J. Gibson; Anna C. Peacock
abstract: Thermal tuning of a coaxial fiber resonator with a silica cladding surrounding an inner silicon core is investigated. By pumping the silicon with below bandgap light, it is possible to redshift the WGM resonances.

title: Observation of Conical Diffraction in Photonic Lieb Lattices
authors: Falko Diebel; Daniel Leykam; S. Kroesen; Cornelia Denz; Anton S. Desyatnikov
abstract: We demonstrate conical diffraction in photonic Lieb lattices in fused silica glass. In contrast to Dirac fermions in photonic graphene here the conical intersections with flat band in lattice spectrum support eigenstates with integer pseudospin.

title: On Chip Broadband Terahertz Detection via Four-Wave Mixing in Electrically Biased Silica Micro-Slits
authors: Matteo Clerici; Anna Mazhorova; Shu‐peng Ho; Marco Peccianti; Alessia Pasquazi; Luca Razzari; Jalil Ali; Roberto Morandotti
corresponding_authors: Matteo Clerici; Anna Mazhorova; Shu‐peng Ho; Marco Peccianti; Alessia Pasquazi; Luca Razzari; Jalil Ali; Roberto Morandotti
abstract: Exploiting four-wave mixing between an optical probe and a Terahertz field in a few micrometers thick Silica sample we demonstrate broadband coherent Terahertz detection by applying a bias as low as 100 V.

authors: Guilherme Dutra; Cícero Martelli; Rodolfo L. Patyk; Marco J. da Silva; Tiago P. Vendruscolo; Rigoberto Morales

title: Metal-packaged Fiber Bragg Gratings for Structural Health Monitoring
authors: Grzegorz Fusiek; Paweł Niewczas; Michael B. Johnston
abstract: The application of metal-packaged fiber Bragg grating sensors for structural health monitoring is discussed based on an example of an instrumented steel tendon subjected to changing temperature and mechanical loading.

title: Experimental measurement of correlation in energy between multiple side lobes of modulation instability in dispersion oscillating fiber
authors: Xie Wang; Damien Bigourd; Alexandre Kudlinski; Kenneth K. Y. Wong; M. Douay; Laurent Bigot; Antoine Lerouge; Yves Quiquempois; Arnaud Mussot
corresponding_authors: Xie Wang; Damien Bigourd; Alexandre Kudlinski; Kenneth K. Y. Wong; M. Douay; Laurent Bigot; Antoine Lerouge; Yves Quiquempois; Arnaud Mussot
abstract: We experimentally investigate the spectral correlation between multiple modulation instability side lobes in dispersion oscillating fiber by leveraging the dispersive Fourier transformation. We found that parametric processes related to each side lobe pairs act quasi-independently.

title: Highly Sensitive Fiber-Optic Gas Sensors Based on Microfiber/Graphene Hybrid Waveguides
authors: Yunjiang Rao; Baicheng Yao; Yu Wu
abstract: Taking advantage of the surface field enhancement of graphene films, microfibers and graphene films are combined to form novel hybrid waveguides and highly sensitive gas sensors, for the first time. Sub-ppm sensitivity for gas molecular detection is achieved. Such a microstructure fiber-optic gas sensors with fast response could be used for trace detection.

title: IR-probes for Fourier spectrometry
authors: A. S. Korsakov; Liya Zhukova; A. S. Shmygalev; Dmitrii Salimgareev; В. С. Корсаков
corresponding_authors: A. S. Korsakov; Liya Zhukova; A. S. Shmygalev; Dmitrii Salimgareev; В. С. Корсаков

title: Highly sensitive SERS based nano-sculptured thin film biosensor for the detection of vitellogenin: an endocrine disruption biomarker
authors: Sachin Kumar Srivastava; Atef Shalabney; Isam Khalaila; Christoph Grüner; B. Rauschenbach; Ibrahim Abdulhalim
corresponding_authors: Sachin Kumar Srivastava; Atef Shalabney; Isam Khalaila; Christoph Grüner; B. Rauschenbach; Ibrahim Abdulhalim
abstract: A biosensor has been fabricated by using the SERS of 4-Aminothiophenol (4-ATP) on optimized nano-sculptured thin films (nSTFs) of silver over Si substrates. The limit of detection is as small as 5 pg/ml of vitellogenin.

title: Terahertz Detection with Field-effect Transistors: Intrinsic versus Device Sensitivity Limits
authors: Alvydas Lisauskas; Sebastian Boppel; Maris Bauer; Justinas Zdanevičius; Jonas Matukas; Viktor Krozer; Hartmut G. Roskos
corresponding_authors: Alvydas Lisauskas; Sebastian Boppel; Maris Bauer; Justinas Zdanevičius; Jonas Matukas; Viktor Krozer; Hartmut G. Roskos
abstract: We discuss on both fundamental and practical limitations for detection sensitivity of terahertz radiation using different kinds of field-effect transistors. Presentation overview different material systems including silicon CMOS, AlGaN/GaN HEMTs, carbon nanotubes and graphene.

title: Modulational instability and pulse generation in dispersion oscillating fiber ring cavities
authors: Matteo Conforti; Arnaud Mussot; Alexandre Kudlinski; S. Trillo
abstract: We show that the use of dispersion oscillating fiber in passive cavities significantly extend modulational instability to new branches of the steady response and to novel spectral bands, resulting into enhanced pulse train formation.

title: Dynamics and statistics of noise-like pulses and Rogue Waves
authors: Neil G. R. Broderick; Miro Erkintalo; Graham M. Donovan
abstract: Numerical simulations of three different laser cavities producing both solitons, noise-like pulses and optical rogue waves are compared. Both normal and anomalous dispersion cavities are examined as well as different models for mode-locking. We find that both noise-like pulses and solitons are robust effects but that optical rogue waves only appear under restricted circumstances.

title: Non-uniform shape sensor based on FBGs inscribed in multicore optical fibers
authors: David Barrera; Ivana Gasulla; Salvador Sales
abstract: A multi-point curvature sensor composed by an array of fifteen wavelength multiplexed FBGs has been inscribed in a multicore optical fiber and is demonstrated in order to measure nonuniform curvatures with a resolution of 0.5·10−3 m−1.

title: Self-Power, Energy Harvested, Fiber Optic Sensor (WiFOS™) Structural Health Monitor
authors: Edgar A. Mendoza; Connie Kempen; Yan Esterkin; Sunjian Sun
abstract: This paper describes recent progress towards the development of an innovative light weight, high-speed, and self-powered wireless fiber optic sensor (WiFOS™) structural health monitor system suitable for the onboard and in-flight unattended detection, localization, and classification of load, fatigue, and structural damage in advanced composite materials commonly used in avionics and aerospace systems. The WiFOS™ system is based on ROI's advancements on monolithic photonic integrated circuit microchip technology, integrated with smart power management, on-board data processing, wireless data transmission optoelectronics, and self-power using energy harvesting tools such as solar, vibration, thermoelectric, and magneto-electric.

title: Characterization of a Plasmonic Absorber Structure for Infrared Detection Applications
authors: Erdem Aslan; Semih Korkmaz; Ömer Galip Saraçoğlu; Mustafa Türkmen
abstract: The optical characterization of a plasmonic absorber structure is presented. The effect of the dielectric medium on the resonance frequency is determined. The results show that the structure can be utilized for infrared sensing applications.

title: Effects of Polishing Depth and Surface Roughness on D-Type F/O SPR Sensor Response
authors: Burcu Güleryüz; Mustafa M. Aslan
corresponding_authors: Burcu Güleryüz; Mustafa M. Aslan
abstract: D-type fiber optic SPR sensors are developed at different polishing depths and surface roughness to study their responses to surrounding refractive index change. The sensors' sensitivities are determined in the RI range zones between 1.33 and 1.47.

title: Chemical Composition Gratings
authors: Patrik Holmberg; Michael Fokine
abstract: Get PDF Email Share Share with Facebook Tweet This Post on reddit Share with LinkedIn Add to CiteULike Add to Mendeley Add to BibSonomy Get Citation Copy Citation Text P. Holmberg and M. title: Robust Fiber-Optic Sensor Systems
authors: Rosa Ana Pérez-Herrera; Manuel López-Amo
abstract: This work presents an overview of the most representative robust fiber-optic sensor systems, discussing their schemes, pros and cons and categories of protection to allow service to be reestablished after a failure.

title: The Potential for Networks with Capacities Exceeding the Nonlinear-Shannon Limit
authors: A.D. Ellis; Stylianos Sygletos
abstract: We examine the network benefits of various forms of nonlinearity compensation, showing that total network capacities that are more than double the capacity of a network with reaches determined by the Nonlinear-Shannon limit

title: Prolific Rogue Wave States in the Coupled Hirota Equations
authors: Shihua Chen
corresponding_authors: Shihua Chen
abstract: Two families of rogue wave solutions of the coupled Hirota equations are presented, exhibiting prolific dynamics beyond the reach of the scalar NLS equation. These isolated peaks may offer the possibility for modeling realistic extreme events.

title: Photonic Techniques for Sub-Terahertz Wireless Data Transmission
authors: Idelfonso Tafur Monroy
corresponding_authors: Idelfonso Tafur Monroy
abstract: Wireless data communication links with capacities beyond 100 Gbit/s will require operating at sub-Terahertz frequencies using a large bandpass bandwidth facing new engineering challenges. We review several implementation aspects by using photonic technologies. © 2015 OSA.

title: Optical Materials and Devices for A Mid-IR Sensing Platform
authors: Pao Tai Lin
corresponding_authors: Pao Tai Lin
abstract: Mid-Infrared optical sensing offers label-free biochemical identification because it overlaps with the characteristic absorption from a wide range of molecules. I will present chip-scale mid-IR sensors using i. hybrid polymer-silicon nitride waveguides and ii. opto-nanofluidic slot waveguides.

title: Broadband 3.4 nJ pulse generation using a fiber laser mode-locked by composite-type carbon nanotubes saturable absorber
authors: Jin Hwan Kim; Hyub Lee; Chanh D. Tr. Nguyen; Kyung‐Soo Kim; Soohyun Kim
corresponding_authors: Jin Hwan Kim; Hyub Lee; Chanh D. Tr. Nguyen; Kyung‐Soo Kim; Soohyun Kim
abstract: We demonstrated a long-cavity erbium-doped fiber laser mode-locked by a composite-type CNT-SA. Finally, the laser generated pulses, whose output spectrum and pulse energy were 20.2 nm and 3.4 nJ respectively.

title: Reliable lifetime prediction of gain flattening filters
authors: Matthieu Lancry; Sylvain V. Costes; T. Lopez; B. Poumellec
corresponding_authors: Matthieu Lancry; Sylvain V. Costes; T. Lopez; B. Poumellec
abstract: This paper is dedicated to the lifetime prediction of GFF monofiltres. First we used the master curves derived from elementary (no tilt, no chirp) FBG written in different conditions. Then we did the ageing of the refractive index profile (both in the core and in the photosensitive cladding). Finally we recalculated the spectral response of GFF after ageing and we compared it to experimental measurements. In addition we validated our prediction by building a new master curve using passivated components. A less general spectral prediction approach based on passivated GFF is also presented. This last method is more representative of the final products.

title: Design of Highly Birefringence Solid Core Photonic Crystal Fiber with Elliptical Holes
authors: Rahul Kumar Gangwar; Vinod Kumar Singh
abstract: A high birefringent photonic crystal fiber is designed using circular and elliptical air holes and numerically studied by finite element method. The birefringence value reaches the magnitude of 10-5 at 1.55 μm.

title: Complete control of temporal cavity solitons
authors: Jae K. Jang; Miro Erkintalo; Stuart G. Murdoch; Stéphane Coen
corresponding_authors: Jae K. Jang; Miro Erkintalo; Stuart G. Murdoch; Stéphane Coen
abstract: We experimentally demonstrate complete control and manipulation of picosecond optical pulses. By adjusting the phase profile of the driving beam, we can write, erase, trap and manipulate temporal cavity solitons.

title: Er-doped Tungstate-Tellurite Glasses and Fibers
authors: V. V. Dorofeev; А. Н. Моисеев; S. E. Motorin; В. Г. Плотниченко; В. В. Колташев; D. V. Philippovskiy; A. F. Kosolapov; M.V. Zhuldybina
corresponding_authors: V. V. Dorofeev; А. Н. Моисеев; S. E. Motorin; В. Г. Плотниченко; В. В. Колташев; D. V. Philippovskiy; A. F. Kosolapov; M.V. Zhuldybina
abstract: The TeO2–WO3–La2O3–Er2O3–Bi2O3 (TWLB+Er) glasses with 0–4 mol. % erbium oxide content and various hydroxyl group concentrations characterize by absorption of about 0,001–3 cm−1 at ~ 3 µm as well as optical fibers were produced and investigated. Stability against crystallization and Tg value don't depend on Er concentration. Dependences of intensity and decay time of luminescence bands at ~ 1.6 µm and ~ 2.75 µm upon 0.975 µm excitation vs Er and OH-groups content were studied.

title: Surface Nanoscale Axial Photonics Sensors
authors: M. Sumetsky
corresponding_authors: M. Sumetsky
abstract: The Surface Nanoscale Axial Photonics (SNAP) platform will be reviewed. This platform enables creation of miniature ultralow loss resonant photonic circuits with unprecedented subangstrom precision. The prospective slow light SNAP optofluidic sensors will be described.

title: Nanophotonics with Titanium Nitride and Transparent Conducting Oxides
authors: Nathaniel Kinsey; Marcello Ferrera; Clayton DeVault; J. Kim; Vladimir M. Shalaev; Alexandra Boltasseva
abstract: Recent advances in alternative nanophotonic materials, specifically CMOS-compatible materials, have propelled a unique class of integrated optical devices to achieve high performance.

title: Transition from Polarization Disorder to Antiphase Polarization Domains in a Fiber Laser
authors: Philippe Grelu; Caroline Lecaplain; Aliou Bâ; Foued Amrani; S. Wabnitz
corresponding_authors: Philippe Grelu; Caroline Lecaplain; Aliou Bâ; Foued Amrani; S. Wabnitz
abstract: Adjusting polarization coupling in a fiber ring laser may lead to anti-synchronization of spatio-temporal disorder into ordered laminar states of orthogonal polarization temporal domains, as well as stable lattices of soliton trains.

title: Propagation dynamics of temporal Airy pulses in optical fibers with periodic dispersion
authors: Dengfeng Fan; Shaofei Wang; Xuekun Bai; Xianglong Zeng
corresponding_authors: Dengfeng Fan; Shaofei Wang; Xuekun Bai; Xianglong Zeng
abstract: The evolution dynamics of temporal Airy pulses in optical fibers with periodic dispersion landscapes are numerically studied. The Airy wave packets are more robust to adapt to dispersion variation than conventional sech-shape pulses.

title: Functionalized Ultra-low Fouling Surface Platforms for Biosensing in Real-world Media
authors: Hana Vaisocherová; Jiřı́ Homola
corresponding_authors: Hana Vaisocherová; Jiřı́ Homola
abstract: The low-fouling and functionalizable surface platforms were investigated in terms of functionalization effect on fouling resistance from undiluted media (blood plasma, food extracts), surface capacities, and biorecognition capabilities. The platforms included hydroxy- and carboxy-functional polymer brushes and standard OEG-based alkanethiolate chemistry. In contrast to hydroxy-functional brushes, the fouling properties of carboxy-functional poly(carboxybetaine acrylamide) (pCBAA) were found to be rather insensitive to functionalization. An SPR sensor combining pCBAA with functionalized gold nanoparticles was capable of detecting Salmonella sp. and E.coli O157:H7 in hamburger samples at concentrations as low as tens of cells/ml.

title: Observation of linear properties in a Sawtooth photonic lattice
authors: Luis Morales-Inostrosa; Steffen Weimann; Stefan Nolte; Alexander Szameit; Rodrigo A. Vicencio
abstract: We study a Sawtooth photonic lattice, possessing two linear bands. The lower band becomes flat at a critical parameter, presenting linear localized modes. We found surfaces modes appearing at the gap between the two bands.

title: Transient Dynamics of Cavity Soliton Merging
authors: Jae K. Jang; Miro Erkintalo; Stuart G. Murdoch; Stéphane Coen
corresponding_authors: Jae K. Jang; Miro Erkintalo; Stuart G. Murdoch; Stéphane Coen
abstract: We experimentally probe the merging dynamics of temporal cavity solitons in a driven passive optical fiber ring cavity. This result unequivocally demonstrates that temporal cavity solitons are dissipative solitons.

title: Monolithic Integration of Active LMA PCF and Standard Fiber Bragg Gratings into All-Fiber Lasers
authors: Clémence Jollivet; Julie Guer; Peter Hofmann; Axel Schülzgen
corresponding_authors: Clémence Jollivet; Julie Guer; Peter Hofmann; Axel Schülzgen
abstract: A method to monolithically integrate active LMA PCF with conventional fiber components (fiber Bragg gratings) in all-fiber lasers is proposed. Using novel mode-field adapters, cavity losses are mitigated and laser performances significantly improved.

title: Record retardance in silica and compact waveplates and related optical components photo-induced by femtosecond laser
authors: Matthieu Lancry; Rudy Desmarchelier; Kevin Cook; John Canning; B. Poumellec
corresponding_authors: Matthieu Lancry; Rudy Desmarchelier; Kevin Cook; John Canning; B. Poumellec
abstract: A wide range of laser parameters to achieve the highest retardance value within a single layer of nano-porous grating layers is demonstrated; i.e. 350 nm at λ = 546 nm. The total retardance depends on the number of layers present and can be accumulated in the direction of laser propagation to values higher than 1600 nm. This opens the door to using these nanostructures as refined building blocks for novel optical elements based on strong retardance, including roating these properties with unprecedented resolution.

title: Blind Real-Time Multi-Format Carrier Recovery for Flexible Optical Networks
authors: Benedikt Baeuerle; Arne Josten; Felix C. Abrecht; E. Dornbierer; D. Hillerkuss; Juerg Leuthold
abstract: A low-complexity, multi-format, and real-time capable carrier recovery is demonstrated for QPSK, 8QAM and 16QAM. The algorithm performs a joint frequency and phase compensation, allowing for switching of modulation formats during operation.

title: Intra-Pulse Raman Scattering Controlled via Asymmetric Airy Pulses
authors: Yi Hu; Amirhossein Tehranchi; S. Wabnitz; Zhigang Chen; Raman Kashyap; Roberto Morandotti
corresponding_authors: Yi Hu; Amirhossein Tehranchi; S. Wabnitz; Zhigang Chen; Raman Kashyap; Roberto Morandotti
abstract: We study intra-pulse Raman scattering initiated by Airy pulses in optical fibers. Their asymmetric features are revealed from the spectrum of the primary/secondary Raman soliton. Their versatility towards effective frequency tuning is also presented.

title: Hybrid Plasmonic Waveguide Devices: A Complementary Technology for Silicon on Insulator Platform
authors: Mehboob Alam; J. Stewart Aitchison; Mo Mojahedi
abstract: Hybrid plasmonic waveguides offer the advantages of silicon compatibility, strong polarization dependency, and low propagation losses. We present a number of devices using this guiding scheme and compare their performance with existing alternatives.

title: Surface plasmon resonance (SPR) sensing for small molecules in biofluids
authors: Jean‐François Masson; Sandy Shuo Zhao; Natalia Bukar; Joelle N. Pelletier; Jérémie Labrecque-Carbonneau; Kristy S. McKeating; Hélène Yockell-Lelièvre
abstract: The rapid, label-free and ideally point-of-care detection of therapeutic drugs and other metabolites is of high importance for improving treatment of patients. SPR sensors were developed on a portable instrument for methotrexate, testosterone and antibiotics.

title: Hydrofluoric Acid Refractive Index Determination using In-situ Monitoring of Etched Fibre Bragg Gratings
authors: Medya Namiq; M. Ibsen
abstract: By monitoring the wavelength-shift of Bragg-resonances in a fibre grating during cladding-etching, we measure the refractive-index of buffered-HF acid (20:1) as 1.36±0.005 @ 1.55μm, and use that to demonstrate precise control the fibre etch-diameter.

authors: Е. Ф. Мартынович; V. P. Dresviansky; Andrey Kuznetsov; С. В. Алексеев; В. Ф. Лосев; A. N. Ratakhin; S.N. Bagayev

title: Temperature-control for optical vapor sensors based on photoluminescence quenching
authors: Nico Bolse; Ghazi Chouikh; Michael Sellner; Carsten Eschenbaum; Uli Lemmer
abstract: We investigate the influence of temperature on photoluminescence quenching sensors. A novel way for temperature-control based on a thin film heater is presented for applications aiming at the detection of oxygen and nitroaromatic trace vapors.

title: Advance of Wideband Ultra-Short Pulse Fiber Lasers and Sensing Applications
authors: Norihiko Nishizawa
corresponding_authors: Norihiko Nishizawa
abstract: We demonstrated wideband wavelength tunable narrow linewidth pulses and high quality super continuum using ultrashort pulse fiber lasers with carbon nanotube. Ultrahigh resolution optical coherence tomography and spectroscopic measurement were demonstrated using developed light sources.

title: Optical Sensors: a comprehensive approach
authors: José Miguel López Higuera; Luis Rodŕıguez-Cobo; Adolfo Cobo
abstract: After a mention of what it must be understood as Photonics field we will go into Optical Sensing area including the particular cases of the sensors using fiber technologies. Four significant cases will be presented and discussed.

title: Laser Damage Resistant Ta2O5/HfO2/SiO2 Multilayer Mirrors by Ion Beam Sputtering
authors: Drew Schiltz; D. Patel; Luke A. Emmert; Cory Baumgarten; Brendan A. Reagan; W. Rudolph; J. J. Rocca; C. S. Menoni
abstract: We show the threshold fluence for damage of Ta2O5/SiO2 multilayer interference coatings measured using 0.19 ns and 4 ns pulses with λ=1.03 µm can be increased by 2x when modifying the coating’s top layer design.

title: Biosensing applications of SERS: Bacterial Diagnostics, Blood Aging and Forensics
authors: L. D. Ziegler
corresponding_authors: L. D. Ziegler
abstract: Surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy provides unique spectral signatures for rapid, antibiotic specific bacterial diagnostics, monitoring blood aging, malaria detection and trace body fluid identification applicable in forensic science.

title: Plasmonic based focused light characterizing fiber
authors: Hyuntai Kim; Luis Alonso Vazquez-Zuniga; Jinseob Kim; Yoonchan Jeong
corresponding_authors: Hyuntai Kim; Luis Alonso Vazquez-Zuniga; Jinseob Kim; Yoonchan Jeong
abstract: We propose a device to characterize focused light. The device includes a single nano-slit etched on a metal coated fiber tip. The device is capable of resolving the focal point, beam size, polarization, and chromatic aberration of the focused light.

title: Fabrication of Regular and Bi-Level Grating Fiber Couplers using Thermal Scanning Probe Lithography
authors: Sasa Ristic; Matthieu Nannini; Philip Paul; Felix Holzner; Peter Grütter
abstract: Thermal scanning probe lithography is used for patterning of regular and bi-level grating fiber couplers. Tri-layer pattern transfer is presented as a means of amplifying the 2D and 3D grating patterns into the silicon-on-insulator substrate.

title: All-fiber based chaotic polarization scrambler
authors: Massimiliano Guasoni; P.-Y. Bony; D. Sugny; Antonio Picozzi; Hans-Rudolf Jauslin; Julien Fatome
corresponding_authors: Massimiliano Guasoni; P.-Y. Bony; D. Sugny; Antonio Picozzi; Hans-Rudolf Jauslin; Julien Fatome
abstract: We present a fiber-based polarization scrambler founded on the nonlinear interaction between a signal and its backward replica generated and amplified by a reflective loop. The output polarization dynamic turns out to be chaotic.

title: Phase Response Reconstruction in Ring Resonator Filters
authors: Kenaish Al Qubaisi; Hayk Gevorgyan; Anatol Khilo; Marcus S. Dahlem
abstract: Three methods for reconstructing the phase response, group delay and chromatic dispersion of minimum-phase filters, from their magnitude response, are applied to a second-order microring-resonator filter. Results are validated through an analytical model and measurements.

title: Passive Ring Resonator Integrated Optic Gyro Based on Optical Beat Detection
authors: Junjie Wang; Lishuang Feng; Yinzhou Zhi; Yichuang Tang; Hongchen Jiao; Qiwei Wang
corresponding_authors: Junjie Wang; Lishuang Feng; Yinzhou Zhi; Yichuang Tang; Hongchen Jiao; Qiwei Wang
abstract: A passive ring resonator integrated optic gyro based on optical beat detection is proposed and demonstrated for the first time. A long-term bias stability of 5×10−3rad/s is achieved using a silica waveguide ring resonator.

title: Hybrid Silicon Plasmonic TM-pass Polarizer Based on Titanium Nitride as a Plasmonic Material
authors: Shaimaa I. Azzam; S. S. A. Obayya
corresponding_authors: Shaimaa I. Azzam; S. S. A. Obayya
abstract: A TM-pass polarizer based on silicon-on-insulator platform and using titanium nitride as a CMOS-compatible plasmonic material is proposed. The polarizer is only 2.9 µm-long with 0.96 dB insertion loss (IL) and 20 dB extinction ratio (ER).

title: Nonlinear Temperature-Dependent Transfer Characteristics of Silicon Photonic Microring Resonators
authors: Meisam Bahadori; Alexander Gazman; Sébastien Rumley; Qi Li; Keren Bergman
abstract: We investigate the nonlinear power transfer characteristics of a silicon photonic microring resonator. We show that the microring device behaves as a power limiter if the roll-off tail of its resonance is steeper than a simple Lorentzian lineshape.

title: Suppression of Optical Rogue Waves in a CW Injected Semiconductor Laser With Current Modulation and Noise
authors: Jordi Zamora‐Munt; Sandro Perrone; R. Vilaseca; Cristina Masoller
corresponding_authors: Jordi Zamora‐Munt; Sandro Perrone; R. Vilaseca; Cristina Masoller
abstract: We study numerically the emission of sporadic rogue intensity pulses in an optically injected semiconductor laser operating in a chaotic dynamical regime. We show that the amplitude of these pulses can be reduced below a safety threshold by perturbing the system with a weak sinusoidal modulation of the bias current or with a moderate amount of incoherent light acting as a source of noise. The probability of observing rogue intensity pulses is also investigated when both a current modulation and noise act simultaneously. We show that their combined effects can significantly modify the likelihood of occurrence of a rogue wave. The results are compared with the unperturbed dynamics showing a resonant-like behavior near the characteristic time scales of the underlying dynamics.

title: Time-Wavelength Pulse Interleaver on a Silicon Platform
authors: Hayk Gevorgyan; Kenaish Al Qubaisi; Marcus S. Dahlem; Anatol Khilo
abstract: An integrated 4-channel time-wavelength pulse interleaver for 1GHz optical pulse trains is implemented on a silicon platform. The interleaver has 0.35% RMS pulse timing error, 1.6-5.8dB insertion loss, less than -24dB crosstalk, and 52nm FSR.

title: Standoff Detection of Explosives and Buried Landmines Using Bacterial Biosensors
authors: Yossef Kabessa; Ofer Bar‐On; Ori Eyal; Sharon Yagur‐Kroll; Shimshon Belkin; Aharon J. Agranat
corresponding_authors: Yossef Kabessa; Ofer Bar‐On; Ori Eyal; Sharon Yagur‐Kroll; Shimshon Belkin; Aharon J. Agranat
abstract: A Standoff detection scheme for buried landmines and concealed explosive charges based on genetically engineered bacterial biosensors is presented. Concentrations of 4 mg/L of 2,4-DNT on soil were detected from a distance of 50 meters.

title: Automated Laser-induced Breakdown Spectroscopy setup for chemical mapping of archaeological shells
authors: Adolfo Cobo; Asier García-Escárzaga; Luis Rodŕıguez-Cobo; Igor Gutiérrez-Zugasti; Manuel R. González Morales; José Miguel López Higuera
abstract: A Laser-induced Breakdown Spectroscopy (LIBS) setup for the measurement of the magnesium to calcium ratios along the growth lines of sea snails shells is presented. It allows an automatic measurement over the shell's surface without sample preparation.

title: Simultaneous Measurement of NO and NO2 using a Dual-Wavelength Quantum Cascade Laser
authors: Jana Jágerská; Pierre Jouy; Béla Tuzson; Herbert Looser; Markus Mangold; Patrik Soltic; Andreas Hugi; Martin Süess; Rolf Brönnimann; Morten Hundt; Jérôme Faist; Lukas Emmenegger
corresponding_authors: Lukas Emmenegger
abstract: We demonstrate a sequentially operating dual-wavelength QCL, emitting single-mode at 5.26 and 6.25 µm, and its spectroscopic application on an automotive test-bench, and for air pollution monitoring reaching over 10 Hz and sub-ppb detection.

title: Nanoimprinted Distributed Feedback Dye Laser Sensors for High Frame Rate Refractometric Imaging of Dissolution and Fluid Flow
authors: Christoph Vannahme; Kristian Tølbøl Sørensen; Carsten Gade; Pétur Gordon Hermannsson; Martin Dufva; Anders Kristensen
abstract: High frame rate refractometric dissolution and fluid flow monitoring in one and two dimensions of space with distributed feedback dye laser sensors is presented. The sensors provide both low detection limits and high spatial resolution. © 2015 OSA.

title: InP Based Very-Low Voltage Electro-optic Intensity Modulators in Conventional Waveguides
authors: Nak Ki Kim; Prashanth Bhasker; Selim Dogru; Nadir Dagli
corresponding_authors: Nak Ki Kim; Prashanth Bhasker; Selim Dogru; Nadir Dagli
abstract: Very-low drive voltage intensity modulators were fabricated in InP epitaxial layers containing MQW cores using conventional waveguides and processing. 1 cm long electrode devices have one arm driven Vπ of 1.6 V at 1550 nm.

title: Room temperature CW operation of 1.3um quantum dot lasers on a Si substrate by Pd-mediated wafer bonding
authors: Zihao Wang; Stefan F. Preble; Chi-Sen Lee; Wei Guo
abstract: Room temperature CW operation of a 1.3µm InAs quantum dot laser integrated on a Si substrate is demonstrated using palladium mediated wafer bonding. This integration offers excellent electrical and thermal contact for Photonic Integrated Circuits.

title: Kuramoto-Like Synchronization in Parametric Frequency Combs
authors: Yanan Wen; Michael R. E. Lamont; Isabel M. Kloumann; Steven H. Strogatz; Alexander L. Gaeta
corresponding_authors: Yanan Wen; Michael R. E. Lamont; Isabel M. Kloumann; Steven H. Strogatz; Alexander L. Gaeta
abstract: We show that soliton modelocking dynamics in parametric frequency combs is equivalent to synchronization phenomena that occur in many physical systems as described by the Kuramoto model for coupled oscillators.

title: Burst-mode operation of a 655GHz mode locked laser based on an 11-th order microring resonator
authors: Li Jin; Alessia Pasquazi; K.S. Tsang; Victor Ho; Marco Peccianti; Andrew Cooper; Lucia Caspani; Marcello Ferrera; Brent E. Little; David Moss; Roberto Morandotti; Sai T. Chu
abstract: We demonstrate a new regime for ultrafast mode-locked lasers termed "burst-mode". By exploiting an integrated 11th-order microring resonator, a stable mode-locked pulse train at 655GHz with an envelope of 42ps at 6.45MHz is achieved.

title: Plasmonic enhanced AlGaN solar-blind ultraviolet photodetectors with size-tunable Al nanoparticles
authors: Wei Zhang; Jin Xu; Wei Ye; Zhiqiang Qi; Jiangnan Dai; Zhihao Wu; Changqing Chen; Jintong Xu; Yanyan Fang
corresponding_authors: Wei Zhang; Jin Xu; Wei Ye; Zhiqiang Qi; Jiangnan Dai; Zhihao Wu; Changqing Chen; Jintong Xu; Yanyan Fang
abstract: High-performance AlGaN solar-blind UV photodetectors were realized by incorporating size-tunable Al nanoparticles. The highest peak responsivity can reach 2.02A/W at 269 nm. The effects and enhancement mechanism of Al nanoparticles are investigated.

authors: Cheng Zhang; Zhennan Zheng; Dan Wang; Xiaopeng Xie; Fan Zhang; Zhangyuan Chen
abstract: The monolithic optical frequency comb generators are used to generate constant channel spacing WDM subcarriers. 2.166Tb/s PDM-64-QAM Nyquist pulse shaping WDM signals have been successfully transmitted over 155km SSMF at a net SE of 7.88b/s/Hz.

title: Experimental Investigation of the Mode Coupling Behavior in a Few Mode Fiber
authors: Ryo Maruyama
corresponding_authors: Ryo Maruyama
abstract: Mode coupling is one of the important properties for few mode fiber in mode division multiplexing transmission. We review our recent experimental results on the mode coupling in a fiber and at a splice point.

title: Thermal probe nanolithography for novel photonic devices
authors: Felix Holzner; Philip Paul; Colin Rawlings; Heiko Wolf; U. Dürig; Armin W. Knoll
abstract: A novel alternative to E-beam lithography, in particular for plasmonic and nanophotonic devices, is presented. Patterning resolution and speed are similar; however, the novel technique enables direct 3D lithography and markerless overlay with sub-5 nm accuracy.

title: Single-Step Emulation of Nonlinear Fiber-Optic Link with Gaussian Mixture Model
authors: Robert Borkowski; Andy Doberstein; Hansjörg Haisch; Darko Zibar
corresponding_authors: Robert Borkowski; Andy Doberstein; Hansjörg Haisch; Darko Zibar
abstract: We use a fast and low-complexity statistical signal processing method to emulate nonlinear noise in fiber links. The proposed emulation technique stands in good agreement with the numerical NLSE simulation for 32 Gbaud DP-16QAM nonlinear transmission.

title: Rogue wave statistics from a noise-like-pulse laser
authors: Caroline Lecaplain; Philippe Grelu
corresponding_authors: Caroline Lecaplain; Philippe Grelu
abstract: We report on experimental conditions in a fiber ring laser where noise-like pulse emission fulfills the rogue wave criteria. We highlight the role of the chromatic dispersion sign, and use the dispersive Fourier-transform method to study the shot-to-shot spectral fluctuations of the laser output.

title: Development of a Glancing-Angle–Deposited Distributed Polarization Rotator
authors: J. B. Oliver; T. J. Kessler; C. Smith; B. Taylor; V. Gruschow; J. Hettrick; B. Charles; J. Spaulding; T. Noll; Amy L. Rigatti; S. Papernov; Karishma Sharma; G. H. Mitchell; Justin C. Foster
corresponding_authors: J. B. Oliver; T. J. Kessler; C. Smith; B. Taylor; V. Gruschow; J. Hettrick; B. Charles; J. Spaulding; T. Noll; Amy L. Rigatti; S. Papernov; Karishma Sharma; G. H. Mitchell; Justin C. Foster
abstract: Glancing-angle deposition (GLAD) by electron-beam evaporation is utilized to fabricate birefringent thin films. Substrate patterning of GLAD regions is being developed to create a distributed polarization rotator for high-peak-power applications at 351 nm.

title: SDM Transmission over 1 km of Conventional Multi-mode Fiber using Mode Group Multiplexing with OOK Modulation and Direct Detection
authors: Jean‐François Morizur
corresponding_authors: Jean‐François Morizur
abstract: We report on space division muliplexed transmission over 1 km of conventional graded-index multi-mode fiber using OOK modulation and direct detection. Reach and capacity boosts are enabled by selective mode-group multiplexing based on Multi-Plane Light Converters.

title: Tracking linear and nonlinear phase noise in 100G QPSK modulated systems using Kalman filter
authors: Ankita Jain; K. Pradeep Kumar
abstract: We investigate the use of Kalman filter to estimate both linear and nonlinear phase noise in 100G QPSK modulated systems. Simulations show a considerable improvement in BER with Kalman filter compared to digital backpropagation algorithm.

authors: Joel Villatoro; Vladimir P. Minkovich; Joseba Zubía
corresponding_authors: Joel Villatoro; Vladimir P. Minkovich; Joseba Zubía
abstract: A highly-sensitive fiber optic lateral force sensor is introduced. The device is based on a mode interferometer consisting of a short section of photonic crystal fiber fusion spliced to standard single-mode optical fiber.

title: Process-compatible analytical instrument based on optical absorption
authors: Axel Krämer; M. Porus; Th. A. Paul
corresponding_authors: Axel Krämer; M. Porus; Th. A. Paul
abstract: We developed a fiber-optic analyzer enabling concentration measurement of a specific gas in a gas mixture that allows the interrogation of various gas species with concurrent compensation of disturbing effects caused by dust and dirt.

title: Sensing of anesthetic drugs in blood with Raman spectroscopy
authors: Maciej S. Wróbel; Marcin Gnyba; Małgorzata Szczerska; Teemu Myllylä; Janusz Smulko; Ishan Barman
corresponding_authors: Maciej S. Wróbel; Marcin Gnyba; Małgorzata Szczerska; Teemu Myllylä; Janusz Smulko; Ishan Barman
abstract: A proof-of-concept study of a Raman spectroscopy-based approach for measuring the content of anesthesia drugs in blood is presented. Spectra of spiked blood from several patients exhibit prominent changes in regions associated with the drug.

title: Tunable multi-wavelength fiber laser using polarization and wavelength dependent loss
authors: Nishanth Chandra; Ankita Jain; Pradeep Kumar
corresponding_authors: Nishanth Chandra; Ankita Jain; Pradeep Kumar
abstract: We report a continuously tunable multi-wavelength fiber laser with a tuning range of 30 nm over 1530–1560 nm. The actively mode-locked laser generates pulses at 10 GHz repetition rate and 13 ps pulse width.

title: Background Reduction in a Young Interferometer Biosensor
authors: H. Mulder; Vinod Subramaniam; Johannes S. Kanger
corresponding_authors: H. Mulder; Vinod Subramaniam; Johannes S. Kanger
abstract: Integrated optical Young interferometer (IOYI) biosensors are among the most sensitive label-free biosensors. Detection limits are in the range of 20 fg/mm2. The applicability of these sensors is however strongly hampered by the large background that originates from both bulk refractive index changes and non-specific binding of molecules to the sensor surface. In this contribution we demonstrate a new method that allows us to separate the bulk background from the analyte signal. We show theoretical analysis and preliminary proof-of-principle experimental data, where binding of protein A is discriminated from a bulk refractive index change induced by D-Glucose, using multiple wavelengths. We anticipate that this method will increase the general applicability of IOYI sensors.

title: Improved sensitivity for pressure sensing in microbubble resonators
authors: Yong Yang; Sunny Saurabh; Síle Nic Chormaic
abstract: We have realized a liquid-filled microbubble and tuned the whispering gallery mode frequency by internally applying aerostatic pressure. In comparison to an air-filled microbubble the sensitivity is improved by nearly 20%.

title: Nanostructured Conductive SnOx (x<2) for High Efficiency Light Trapping in Thin film and 2D Material Photonic Devices
authors: Xiaoxin Wang; Andrew A. Wong; Stephanie C. Malek; Xiaobai Yu; Jing Kong; Jifeng Liu
corresponding_authors: Xiaoxin Wang; Andrew A. Wong; Stephanie C. Malek; Xiaobai Yu; Jing Kong; Jifeng Liu
abstract: Self-assembled, nano-needle structured conductive SnOx introduces high-efficiency, low-loss light trapping to double the photocurrent of Ge/Si photodetectors. It can also be applied to improve graphene absorption by 6x in a broad spectral range.

title: Mode-locked Microresonator Combs in the Normal Dispersion Region
authors: Xiaoxiao Xue; Yi Xuan; Yang Liu; Pei‐Hsun Wang; Dan E. Leaird; Minghao Qi; Andrew M. Weiner
corresponding_authors: Xiaoxiao Xue; Yi Xuan; Yang Liu; Pei‐Hsun Wang; Dan E. Leaird; Minghao Qi; Andrew M. Weiner
abstract: We investigate mode interaction aided modulational instability and dark solitons in normal-dispersion microresonators. A novel scheme of controllable mode interactions is demonstrated for repetition rate selectable and mode-locked comb generation.

title: Dynamic Routing, Wavelength and Core Allocation in Multi-Core Fiber Based Optical Networks Considering Inter-Core Crosstalk
authors: Xiaofei Xie; Nan Hua; Xiaoping Zheng
abstract: We investigate the inter-core crosstalk in MCF-based optical networks and propose a one-step adaptive algorithm to solve the routing, wavelength and core allocation problem. Results show that our proposed algorithm achieves low blocking probability.

title: Scattering of Gap Solitons by PT-symmetric Defects
authors: F. Kh. Abdullaev; V. A. Brazhnyi; Mario Salerno
corresponding_authors: F. Kh. Abdullaev; V. A. Brazhnyi; Mario Salerno
abstract: The resonant scattering of gap solitons of the periodic NLS equation with a PT-symmetric defect is investigated. For suitable parameters of the defect potential the resonant transmission of soliton through the defect becomes possible.

title: Universal Three-Dimensional Optical Logic
authors: Logan G. Wright; William H. Renninger; Frank W. Wise
corresponding_authors: Logan G. Wright; William H. Renninger; Frank W. Wise
abstract: We experimentally demonstrate a universal logic gate and extend to fully three-dimensional NAND and NOR. A weak pulse triggers the collapse and spatiotemporal instability of a stronger pulse. Extremely powerful new computational strategies appear possible.

title: Stimulated Raman-Kerr scattering in an integrated nonlinear optofluidic fiber arrangement
authors: G. Fanjoux; Jean‐Charles Beugnot; Aziza Sudirman; Luca Furfaro; Walter Margulis; Thibaut Sylvestre
corresponding_authors: G. Fanjoux; Jean‐Charles Beugnot; Aziza Sudirman; Luca Furfaro; Walter Margulis; Thibaut Sylvestre
abstract: We report in an original nonlinear optofluidic fiber arrangement the observation of an octave-spanning Raman cascade that subsequently broadens towards supercontinuum generation due to the stimulated Raman-Kerr scattering.

title: Writing nanometer-scale structures for centimeter-scale color printing
authors: Younghwan Yang; Trevon Badloe; Junsuk Rho
corresponding_authors: Junsuk Rho
abstract: The article comments on a recently proposed innovative process that uses direct laser writing to achieve vivid, fine-tunable color at centimeter scale by leveraging the fabrication speed and the spatial resolution of pixelated F-P cavity structures.

authors: Yuen‐Ron Shen
