title: Optical Subsystems for Next Generation Access Networks
authors: José A. Lázaro; Víctor Polo; Bernhard Schrenk; Francesc Bonada; Iván Caño; E. T. Lopez; C. Kazmierski; G. de Valicourt; R. Brenot; Johan Bauwelinck; Xing-Zhi Qiu; Peter Ossieur; Marco Forzati; P.-J. Rigole; I. T. Monroy; E. Tangdiongga; María Morant; L. Nicolau; A. Teixeira; Didier Erasme; Dimitrios Klonidis; Ioannis Tomkos; Josep Prat; Ch. Kouloumentas; H. Avramopoulos
abstract: Recent optical technologies are providing higher flexibility to next generation access networks: on the one hand, providing progressive FTTx and specifically FTTH deployment, progressively shortening the copper access network; on the other hand, also opening fixed-mobile convergence solutions in next generation PON architectures. It is provided an overview of the optical subsystems developed for the implementation of the proposed NG-Access Networks.

title: Suspended core polyethylene fiber for bio-sensing applications in the terahertz region
authors: Anna Mazhorova; Mohammed Zourob; Maksim Skorobogatiy
abstract: For the first time we demonstrate the possibility of using suspended core polyethylene fibers for the sensing of E. coli. Diameter of our fiber is 5.1 mm, it has 150 µm suspended core which is strongly isolated from the environment.

title: Spot-Size Converter: A Generic Building Block for Regrowth-Free Multi-Guide Vertical Integration in InP
authors: Fang Wu; Valery Tolstikhin; Yury Logvin; Chris Brooks
abstract: A wide-band spot-size converter for low-loss and high alignment tolerance coupling to a single-mode fiber that also allows for on-chip wavelength splitting and routing is reported. The design, fabrication and characterization of the device are presented by referring to a regrowth-free multi-guide vertical integration in InP, to which it serves as a generic building block for an efficient wavelength-selective optical connection between functional waveguides and fiber.

title: Numerical Simulation of Dicke Superradiance in a Semiconductor Laser Device
authors: Xuhan Guo; K.A. Williams; V. F. Olle; A. Wonfor; R. V. Penty; I.H. White
abstract: This paper reports a theoretical model for Dicke Superradiance in semiconductor laser devices. Simulations agree well with previously-observed superradiance properties and are used to optimize driving conditions and device geometry.

title: Luneburg lens in Silicon-on-Insulator platform
authors: Andrea Di Falco; Susanne C. Kehr; Ulf Leonhardt
abstract: We discuss the design and experimental demonstration of an integrated Luneburg lens realized in Silicon-on-Insulator platform, via grey-scale lithography. The lens implements on-chip Fourier transform, independently on the angle of incidence. The presented technique allows for the fabrication of perfect imaging devices.

title: 100Gb/s Receiver Photonic Integrated Circuits in InP for Applications in Fiber-Optics Interconnects
authors: Valery Tolstikhin; Fang Wu; Yury Logvin; Sasa Ristic; Yongbo Tang; Kirill Pimenov; Arash Khajooeizadeh
abstract: We present 4×25Gb/s space and wavelength division multiplexing receiver chips, based on a multi-guide vertical integration in InP. State-of-the-art performance and small footprint size make them well suited for use in 100Gb/s optical interconnects.

title: Reaction tubes as a platform for silicon nanophotonic ring resonator biosensors
authors: Cristina Lerma Arce; Arne Goes; Elewout Hallynck; Peter Dubruel; Kasia Komorowska; Steven Van Put; Peter Bienstman
corresponding_authors: Cristina Lerma Arce; Arne Goes; Elewout Hallynck; Peter Dubruel; Kasia Komorowska; Steven Van Put; Peter Bienstman
abstract: We propose the combination of a simple reaction tube platform with label free SOI photonic biosensors. The device allows for the excellent performance of ring resonator sensors in a user-friendly platform to be used in labs and hospitals.

title: A multimode fiber tip based temperature sensor
authors: Pengfei Wang; Lin Bo; Yuliya Semenova; Qiang Wu; Gerald Farrell; Gilberto Brambilla
corresponding_authors: Pengfei Wang; Lin Bo; Yuliya Semenova; Qiang Wu; Gerald Farrell; Gilberto Brambilla
abstract: A multimode fiber tip based temperature sensor is demonstrated. The temperature sensor presented can measure a broad temperature interval ranging from room temperature to 445 °C. An average sensitivity of 14.59 pm/°C is achieved.

title: Design Optimization of High Performance Single-mode Fabry-Perot Lasers Based on Quantum Dot Materials
authors: Lanxin Deng; Lin Han; Yanping Xi; Xun Li; Wei-Ping Huang
abstract: The interplay of inhomogeneous and homogeneous broadening of InGaAs/GaAs quantum dot (QD) Fabry Perot laser is discussed by a comprehensive rate equation model. It is found that for a given inhomogeneous broadening, there is always an optimum homogeneous broadening which leads to a narrowest output power spectrum. With the optimum values, the single longitudinal mode laser is designed. For a cavity length of 200-m, a SMSR (side mode suppression ratio) of 41.65dB and 3dB bandwidth of 17GHz are obtained under 5mA driving current. Moreover, to get a SMSR over 38dB, the inhomogeneous broadening should be lower than 17meV. This work can provide a quantitative reference basis for the single mode quantum dot laser design.

title: Silicon Mid-Infrared Photonic Integrated Circuits
authors: Richard Soref
corresponding_authors: Richard Soref
abstract: A review of recent progress in Si-based MIR on-chip components and PICs is given. We survey new OEIC technologies, hybrid and monolithic laser/detector integration, waveguiding, plasmo-photonics, spectrometer-on-a-chip applications, and free-space interaction with PIC arrays.

title: Suspended core subwavelength fibers for practical low-loss terahertz guidance
authors: Bora Ung; Mathieu Rozé; Anna Mazhorova; M. Walther; Maksim Skorobogatiy
abstract: We describe fabrication of polymer suspended core fibers (porous & non-porous cores) for terahertz guiding, and their characterization via near-field THz microscopy. These novel fibers enable convenient handling and mode isolation from perturbations.

title: Novel Silicon Cross-slot Optical Waveguide for Polarization Diversity Applications
authors: B. M. A. Rahman
corresponding_authors: B. M. A. Rahman
abstract: Novel concept of a cross-slot optical waveguide is presented which confines power in the slot region for both the quasi-TE and TM polarizations. Optimization of power confinements is shown by using a rigorous full-vectorial formulation.

title: Radial processing scheme of speckle patterns for sensing applications
authors: Luis Rodŕıguez-Cobo; Mauro Matías Lomer Barboza; Adolfo Cobo; José Miguel López Higuera
abstract: A processing scheme to enhance the speckle sensitivity to dynamic perturbation has been proposed and experimentally tested. Considering different areas within speckle patterns where highest order modes interfere, a better dynamic sensitivity has been achieved.

title: Scalable Integrated DFT Demultiplexer for Terabit Optical OFDM Transmission
authors: Štefan Schwarz; Abdul Rahim; Juergen Bruns; K. Petermann; Christian Schaeffer
abstract: We present a scalable optical filter structure for realization of a real-time capable DFT operation. The performance of a serial-parallel filter structure for demultiplexing eight channels in an optical OFDM system is analyzed.

title: Implementation and Evaluation by Hardware Emulator of Soft-Decision Forward Error Correction for 100G Systems
authors: Kiyoshi Onohara; Yoshikuni Miyata; Kenya Sugihara; Takashi Sugihara; Kazuo Kubo; Hideo Yoshida; Kazuumi Koguchi; Takashi Mizuochi
abstract: We discuss implementation and performance evaluation of LDPC(4608,4080) for 100Gb/s throughput by hardware emulator. We expect that an NCG of the LDPC code concatenated with enhanced FEC is 10.8 dB at a BER of 10−15.

title: Nyquist Pulse Shaping in Optical Communications
authors: Juerg Leuthold; R. Schmogrow; D. Hillerkuss; C. Koos; W. Freude
corresponding_authors: Juerg Leuthold; R. Schmogrow; D. Hillerkuss; C. Koos; W. Freude
abstract: Nyquist pulse shaping is a means to achieve optical multiplexing at highest spectral efficiency. We review the various aspects of its implementation in optical communications. As an example we show transmission with 15 bit/s/Hz spectral efficiency or encoding of a single laser with 32 Tbit/s.

title: Chromatic Dispersion-Tolerant Higher-Order Multilevel Transmission with Optical Delay Detection
authors: Nobuhiko Kikuchi
corresponding_authors: Nobuhiko Kikuchi
abstract: We present a practical receiver-side chromatic dispersion (CD) compensation scheme for higher-order multilevel signaling using optical delay-detection, and up to 40-Gbit/s 16QAM signaling experiments have been demonstrated with large tolerance to CD (±40-km SSMF) and laser phase noise (1-MHz linewidth).

title: High Power Balanced InGaAs/InP Photodetector Flip-chip Bonded on Diamond
authors: Qiugui Zhou; Allen C. Cross; Andréas Beling; Joe C. Campbell
abstract: We present monolithic integrated uni-traveling-carrier balanced photodiode flip-chip bonded on diamond. The devices with bandwidth of 15 GHz and 20 GHz demonstrated maximum output power of 27.4 dBm and 24.1 dBm, respectively.

title: Novel 16QAM Detection Scheme for Optical Access
authors: Nikolaos Sotiropoulos; H. de Waardt; A.M.J. Koonen
abstract: In this paper, incoherent detection of a square 16QAM signal is demonstrated for the first time using simulations and the scheme's suitability for future optical access networks, along with conventional coherent detection, is explored.

title: Digital Signal Procession for Optical yquist WDM Signal in Coherent Detection Systems
authors: Jianjun Yu
corresponding_authors: Jianjun Yu
abstract: Two different digital signal procession schemes are proposed for optical Nyquist WDM signal. Based on constant-modulus processing, a post-filter by receiver-side duobinary shaping and MLSE are used to release inter-symbol interference (ISI) impact in the first scheme. DSP scheme based on multi-modulus blind equalizations (MMBE) is proposed and experimentally demonstrated in the second. It is found that the recovering 9-QAM-like signal in the second scheme has better performance than post-filter scheme under further strong filtering.

title: Non-Iterative Interpolation-Based Phase Noise ICI Mitigation for CO-OFDM Transport Systems
authors: Mohammad E. Mousa-Pasandi; David V. Plant
abstract: We study the performance of a non-iterative phase noise induced ICI compensation scheme based on linear interpolation for CO-OFDM transport systems. This practical approach does not suffer from error propagation while enjoying low computational complexity.

title: Generating a Frequency-Bin Entangled Comb of Photon Pairs via Four-Wave Mixing in a Silicon-on-Insulator Microring Resonator*
authors: Jun Chen; Zachary H. Levine; Jingyun Fan; Alan L. Migdall
corresponding_authors: Jun Chen; Zachary H. Levine; Jingyun Fan; Alan L. Migdall
abstract: We present a quantum theory for generation of frequency-bin entangled comb of photon pairs via four-wave mixing in a Silicon-on-Insulator microring resonator. We also provide design principles of such a microring through extensive numerical simulations.

authors: Shahab Bakhtiari Gorajoobi; M. Mustafa Kaykisiz; Erdal Bulgan
abstract: Overlap of evanescent fields in coupled waveguides can strongly confine the optical field in between the waveguides. At very small separations, sharp deviations in output powers are employed to realize sensing devices at nano-scale.

title: Method for comprehensive dynamic spectral characterization of wavelength dependent modulators
authors: Sebastian Kupijai; Stefan Meister; Christoph Theiss; Bülent A. Franke; Aws Al-Saadi; Lars Zimmermann; Bernd Tillack; Hans Joachim Eichler; U. Woggon; Hanjo Rhee
abstract: We present a method to simultaneously determine the temporal and spectral dynamics of modulator devices that utilize spectral changes during modulation operation. For this purpose, a series of signal traces at different wavelengths is recorded.

title: Noise Figure of Slow Light Cascaded SOA based Microwave Photonic Phase Shifters
authors: Juan Bautista Martí Lloret; J. Sancho; Ivana Gasulla; F. Ramos; Salvador Sales; J. Capmany
abstract: The noise figure of Slow and Fast Light Microwave Photonic phase shifters made up by SOA followed by optical filtering stages is experimentally evaluated. Noise figure results show compression when adding the third cascaded stage.

title: Ink-Jet-Printed Optofluidic SERS for Molecular Analysis
authors: Ian M. White
corresponding_authors: Ian M. White
abstract: In this review, we present ink-jet fabrication of optofluidic surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) devices with no micro/nano-fabrication required. This novel, ultra-low-cost technique enables on-demand fabrication of SERS devices for lab and field use.

title: THz Bragg gratings by CO2 laser inscription and their application in paper quality monitoring
authors: Guofeng Yan; Yasser Chinifooroshan; Predrag Mikulic; Wojtek J. Bock; Maksim Skorobogatiy
abstract: THz Bragg gratings were fabricated by using CO2 laser inscription. The simulated and experimental results demonstrate potential of such gratings in paper thickness monitoring, with experimental spectral sensitivities of ~ −0.67 GHz / 10 μm.

title: Nonlinearity Compensation Using Digital Backward Propagation
authors: Eduardo Mateo; Fatih Yaman; Ting Wang; Guifang Li
abstract: Compensation of fiber impairments using advanced DPS techniques will play a fundamental role in future communications systems. In particular, technologies for nonlinearity compensation using digital backward propagation are discussed in this paper.

authors: V. Lal; S. Corzine; Peter Evans; M. Fisher; A. James; P. Studenkov; T. Vallaitis; Masashi Kato; Parmijit Samra; E. Strzelecka; R.A. Salvatore; Forrest Sedgwick; M. abstract: We report on the development of monolithically integrated multi-wavelength coherent transmitter and receiver PICs employing polarization multiplexing and advanced phase-shift keying modulation to provide an aggregate bandwidth greater than 1Tbps on a single chip.

title: Exploiting photosensitivity in chalcogenide-assisted integrated optics
authors: Andrea Melloni; A. Canciamilla; C. Ferrari; Stefano Grillanda; Francesco Morichetti; Philippe Velha; Marc Sorel; Juejun Hu; J. David Musgraves; Bogdan Zdyrko; Igor Luzinov; Kathleen Richardson; Vivek Singh; Anu Agarwal; Lionel C. Kimerling
abstract: We show the potential of post-fabrication trimming of integrated devices by exploiting photosensitivity in chalcogenide glass. Compensation of fabrication tolerances is demonstrated in As2S3 and As2S3-assisted silicon ring filters.

title: Post-fabrication tuning of Silicon microring resonators by femtosecond laser modification
authors: Daniel Bachman; Zhijiang Chen; Ashok M. Prabhu; R. Fedosejevs; Ying Y. Tsui; Vien Van
abstract: We investigated the feasibility of post-fabrication tuning of Silicon microring resonators by fs laser modification at 400nm wavelength. Red and blue shifts were obtained for different laser fluences, with a maximum resonance shift of 10nm/shot.

title: Optically Tunable Bandpass Filter Using Series-connected Photonic Liquid Crystal Fibers
authors: Jia-Hong Liou; Ta Hui Lin; Yan-Jhen Huang; Chia‐Rong Lee; Chin-Ping Yu
abstract: We demonstrate an optically tunable bandpass filter based on two series-connected photonic liquid crystal fibers filled with different LCs. By using photoresponsive LCs, 115-nm bandwidth tunability can be achieved by 5-second blue-laser irradiation.

title: Microwave Photonics Applications using Slow and Fast Light Effects
authors: J. Sancho; Juan Bautista Martí Lloret; Ivana Gasulla; Salvador Sales; J. Capmany
abstract: We review the potential applicability of SFL techniques to the field of Microwave photonics. The main results obtained for several applications such as filtering, phased array antennas and radar system, arbitrary waveform generation and optoelectronic oscillators will be analyzed.

title: Adiabatic Couplers for Linear Power Division
authors: Moustafa Mohamed; Zheng Li; Eric Dudley; Xi Chen; Li Shang; Won Park; Alan R. Mickelson
abstract: Adiabatic 3 dB couplers exhibit wide bandwidth and resistance to process and thermal variations. In this work, we investigate tradeoffs between sensitivity and overall length. The discussion includes plans for commercial fabrication.

authors: Bora Ung; Maksim Skorobogatiy
abstract: Tuning of the microporosity in the core of chalcogenide fibers provides extensive dispersion engineering that allows red-shifting of zero-dispersion points and flattened dispersion profiles. The porosity also significantly lowers propagation losses.

authors: Mohammad H. Asghari; Yongwoo Park; José Azaña
abstract: By cascading an ultrafast time-limited intensity integrator with a discrete-time integrator, a new method for integration of microwave/optical intensity signals is experimentally demonstrated with unprecedented processing time-bandwidth product >140.

title: Thermal tuning of fiber quarter-wave retarders for temperature compensation of fiber-optic current sensors
authors: Miklós Lenner; R. Wüest; Andreas Frank; K. Bohnert
abstract: The fiber retarder of an interferometric fiber-optic current sensor is fine-tuned by controlled local heat treatment for temperature compensation of the Faraday effect. The retardation is determined from sensor scale factor measurement.

title: CMOS Compatible High Power Erbium Doped Distributed Feedback Lasers
authors: Purnawirman; Ehsan Shah Hosseini; Jonathan D. B. Bradley; Jie Sun; Gerald Leake; Thomas Adam; Douglas Coolbaugh; Michael R. Watts
abstract: On chip, high power (75mW), erbium-doped distributed feedback lasers are demonstrated in a CMOS compatible fabrication flow. The laser cavities consist of silicon nitride waveguide and grating features defined by wafer-scale immersion lithography and a top erbium-doped aluminum oxide layer deposited as the final step in the fabrication process.

title: Liquid filled hollow core photonic bandgap fiber sensor
authors: Hang Qu; Bora Ung; Maksim Skorobogatiy
abstract: we propose a low-refractive-index-contrast hollow-core Bragg fiber sensor operating with a resonant sensing principle. Clear transmission spectrum shifts are obtained when filling the fiber with liquid analytes of different refractive indices.

title: Design of Nanophotonic MOS Solar-Blind Avalanche UV Detectors
authors: Xiaoxin Wang; Zhiyuan Wang; Jifeng Liu
abstract: We design a novel nanophotonic metal-oxide-semiconductor structure coupled with avalanche gain in Si for solar-blind UV detectors. The efficiency can reach >500%, and the solar-blind behavior is achieved without using wide-bandgap semiconductors.

title: Deep-level Mediated Silicon Micro-ring Power Monitors
authors: D. F. Logan; Philippe Velha; Marc Sorel; R.M. De La Rue; Andrew P. Knights; P. E. Jessop
abstract: Deep-level mediated photodiode power monitors were integrated onto the ports of a silicon waveguide micro-rings operating at 1550 nm. Demonstrated feasibility of rapid, on-chip diagnostic measurements is presently optimized to 20 mA/W/dB.

title: Design and Fabrication of Thermo-Optic Tunable Guided-Mode Resonance Filters
authors: Mohammad Jalal Uddin; Robert Magnusson
abstract: A novel thermo-optic tunable guided-mode resonance filter is designed and fabricated. The fabricated filter has a spectral width of 12 nm, tuning range of 15 nm, and tuning efficiency of 0.15 nm per degree Celsius.

title: A Novel Centralized Scheduling for Time-Slotted Optical Burst Switching in Elastic Optical Network
authors: Xin Chen; Bingli Guo; Songwei Ma; Ping Zhang; Juhao Li; Zhangyuan Chen; Yongqi He
abstract: We proposed a novel centralized scheduling for bandwidth variable time-slotted optical burst switching (CBVTS-OBS) in elastic optical network. Compared with previous schemes, CBVTS-OBS reduces bandwidth blocking ratio significantly.

title: Novel Designs for On-chip Mid-Infrared Detectors Integrated with Chalcogenide Waveguides
authors: Vivek Singh; Juejun Hu; Timothy Zens; Jianfei Wang; Pao Tai Lin; Jacklyn Wilkinson; Spencer Novak; J. David Musgraves; Lionel C. Kimerling; Kathleen Richardson; Anu Agarwal
corresponding_authors: Vivek Singh; Juejun Hu; Timothy Zens; Jianfei Wang; Pao Tai Lin; Jacklyn Wilkinson; Spencer Novak; J. David Musgraves; Lionel C. Kimerling; Kathleen Richardson; Anu Agarwal
abstract: We present novel designs with corresponding simulation and measurement results showing a reduction in reflection for a waveguide-integrated on-chip detector for the mid-infrared regime using chalcogenide glass waveguides integrated with a PbTe detector.

title: Tomographic sensing of displacement fields
authors: Pablo D. Ruiz
corresponding_authors: Pablo D. Ruiz
abstract: A wavelength scanning interferometry system is used to measure all the orthogonal components of the displacement field inside semitransparent scattering materials. A near infrared tunable laser illuminates a sample from multiple directions. The image of the sample is recombined with a reference beam on a photodetector array. As the laser frequency is linearly tuned during a scan, a sequence of speckle interferograms is recorded. In order to reconstruct the sample structure, Fourier transformation is performed on a pixel by pixel basis along the temporal axis of the 3-D data cube obtained. Multiple displacement sensitivities are achieved by introducing different optical delays between the reference and the illumination beams, which separate the reconstruction signals in the frequency domain. Phase changes due to mechanical loading of the sample can finally be measured and combined to obtain all orthogonal components of the displacement field in a convenient coordinate system. Controlled rigid body rotations of an epoxy phantom have been used to validate the methodology.

title: Metamaterial-based Terahertz Detectors
authors: Harold Y. Hwang; Kebin Fan; Aaron Sternbach; Xin Zhang; Richard D. Averitt; Keith A. Nelson
corresponding_authors: Harold Y. Hwang; Kebin Fan; Aaron Sternbach; Xin Zhang; Richard D. Averitt; Keith A. Nelson
abstract: We present recent work utilizing terahertz field enhancement in metamaterial structures to drive carrier generation in semiconductors. We implement this as a novel platform to detect terahertz radiation which is a purely electronic effect.

title: 3D Fluorescent Imaging with Highly Nonlinear Photosensitive Materials
authors: Е. Ф. Мартынович; Д. С. Глазунов; Andrey Kuznetsov; E. V. Pestriakov; A. V. Kirpichnikov; S.N. Bagayev
abstract: Permanent 3D fluorescent structures were induced with single laser shots with energy < 1 μJ. Mechanism of nonlinear photosensitivity is explained. Proposed materials can be used in different areas of photonics, including sensors and optical memory.

title: Optical MIMO Demultiplexing and Space-Division Multiplexing using a Photonic Integrated Circuit
authors: Nicolas K. Fontaine
corresponding_authors: Nicolas K. Fontaine
abstract: All-optical multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) techniques and optical integration can provide a low cost and low energy solution for space-division multiplexing (SDM). We demonstrate optical MIMO using a silicon photonic integrated circuit.

title: In-service Measurement of Fiber Fault in WDM-PON
authors: Jingjing Liu; Nianyu Zou; Zhe Kang; Dong Wang; Li Ping
abstract: A scheme for in-service measurement of fiber fault in WDM-PON is proposed, which can monitor all the fiber branches simultaneously without disturbing the service, and locate the failure point accurately by a selective OTDR.

title: A Novel Dispersion and PMD Tolerant Clock Phase Detector
authors: Kuang-Tsan Wu; Han Sun
abstract: A novel clock phase detector is presented and shown to be tolerant to chromatic dispersion and PMD. The phase detector can be used in a clock recovery circuit for demodulation of 100Gb coherent transmission system.

title: Coupled-Resonator Optical Waveguides (CROWs) Based on Grating Resonators with Modulated Bandgap
authors: Hsi-Chun Liu; Christos T. Santis; Amnon Yariv
abstract: We theoretically study CROWs based on modulated grating resonators. The defect sections between resonators control the coupling coefficients and frequency detuning. The transmission spectra of CROWs rely on a proper choice of the defect length.

title: First Demonstration of Cavity-Resonator-Integrated Guided-Mode Resonance Filter
authors: Kenji Kintaka; Tatsuya Majima; Junichi Inoue; Koji Hatanaka; Shogo Ura; Junji Nishii
abstract: A guided-mode resonance filter integrated in a SiO2-based waveguide cavity resonator was designed and fabricated for miniaturization of aperture size. A high-reflection narrowband filter at around 850-nm wavelength was experimentally demonstrated for the first time.

title: Digital Subcarrier Optical Cross-connects
authors: Rongqing Hui; Andrea Fumagalli; Maurice O’Sullivan
abstract: Digital cross-connection in optical networks based on DSCM is discussed. This frequency domain cross-connect has may provide high spectral efficiency, flexible switching granularity, and electronic compensation of transmission impairments.

title: Heterogeneously integrated InGaAsSb detectors on SOI waveguide circuits for short-wave infrared applications
authors: Nannicha Hattasan; Alban Gassenq; Bart Kuyken; L. Cerutti; Jean‐Baptiste Rodriguez; E. Tournié; Dries Van Thourhout; Günther Roelkens
abstract: We present evanescently coupled, heterogeneously integrated InGaAsSb photodetectors on silicon-on-insulator waveguide circuits for short-wave infrared applications. A fiber-to-detector responsivity of 0.13 A/W is obtained at a wavelength of 2.17μm. The photodetector dark current is 3.5 μA at −1V.

title: Linear Photonic Crystal Microcavities in Zero-Change SOI CMOS
authors: Christopher V. Poulton; Xiaoge Zeng; Jason S. Orcutt; Jeffrey M. Shainline; Mark T. Wade; Miloš A. Popović
abstract: Linear photonic crystal microcavities are demonstrated in 45 nm SOI CMOS with no process changes in foundry. Side-coupled waveguide excitation decouples cavity and coupling design. A loss Q on the order of 100,000 is demonstrated.

title: UV written planar Bragg grating sensors - an overview of fabrication, geometries and applications
authors: James C. Gates; Stephen G. Lynch; Paolo L. Mennea; Peter A. Cooper; Sumiaty Ambran; Helen Rogers; Lewis G. Carpenter; Chaotan Sima; Dominic J. Wales; Christopher Holmes; Peter G. R. Smith
abstract: The presentation will give an overview of the fabrication process of direct UV written planar Bragg grating sensors and the various geometries and applications investigated over the last several years.

title: Wide-Angle Imaging Lidar for High-Resolution Near-Ground Aerosol Studies
authors: Nimmi Sharma; John Barnes
abstract: The development of an imaging lidar system allows high resolution (sub-meter) near-ground atmospheric aerosol measurements and enables aerosol light scattering measurements all the way to the ground without requiring an overlap correction function.

title: FDTD Simulation of Passively Mode-Locked Lasers Using a Dynamic Saturable Absorption Model for Graphene
authors: Adam Mock
corresponding_authors: Adam Mock
abstract: A nonlinear rate equation is coupled with the FDTD method to incorporate the experimentally measured carrier lifetime and saturation intensity of graphene for modeling 100fs pulse generation. A one-dimensional Bragg cavity is analyzed.

title: Semiconductor Optical Amplifiers in Extended Reach PONs
authors: Juerg Leuthold; W. Freude; C. Koos; R. Bonk; S. Koenig; D. Hillerkuss; R. Schmogrow
abstract: Design guidelines for semiconductor optical amplifiers (SOAs) in extended reach PON networks are discussed. Important parameters such as the input saturation power or the alpha factor and their impact in PON networks are discussed. ©2011 Optical Society of America

title: Direct observation of Temporal Solitons and Pulse acceleration in III-V semiconductor Photonic crystal waveguides
authors: T. J. Karle; P. Monnier; Sylvain Combrié; Alfredo De Rossi; Fabrice Raineri; R. Raj
abstract: Temporal mapping of 20pJ pulse propagation in a 2DPhC waveguide show of soliton formation. For high signal powers the photonic band is modified influencing the group velocity leading to an acceleration of the pulse propagation.

title: High-Q Contacted Ring Microcavities with Scatterer-Avoiding “Wiggler” Supermode Fields
authors: Yangyang Liu; Xiaoge Zeng; Jeffrey M. Shainline; Miloš A. Popović
abstract: We demonstrate novel, azimuthally periodic microcavities with core attachments. Radiative coupling between degenerate modes leads to imaginary frequency (Q) splitting and a scatterer avoiding high-Q supermode field with measured Q's up to 258,000.

title: Phase Locking of SBS Slow Light in a 2.2-km Single-Mode Fiber
authors: Joseph E. Vornehm; Aaron Schweinsberg; Zhimin Shi; Robert W. Boyd
corresponding_authors: Joseph E. Vornehm; Aaron Schweinsberg; Zhimin Shi; Robert W. Boyd
abstract: A stimulated Brillouin scattering (SBS) slow light system in a 2.2-km single-mode fiber is phase locked to a reference signal. Optical pulses of 6.5 ns duration are delayed 0.9 pulse width while maintaining lock.

title: Silicon-Organic Hybrid (SOH) Electro-Optical Devices
authors: C. Koos; L. Alloatti; D. Korn; R. Palmer; D. Hillerkuss; Jiawen Li; Anna Barklund; R. Dinu; J. Wieland; Maxime Fournier; Jean Marc Fédéli; Haoran Yu; Wim Bogaerts; Pieter Dumon; Roel Baets; W. Freude; Juerg Leuthold
abstract: Silicon-organic hybrid (SOH) integration enables electro-optical devices that combine high modulation speed with low power consumption. We give an overview on SOH modulator concepts, underlying material systems, and recent experimental demonstrations.

title: Optoelectronic Sensor on Moving Platforms for Monitoring Environmental Parameters
authors: Rao Tatavarti; P. Arulmozhivarman; Anil Jakkam; Shanmuka Rao S; Tatavarti Aparna
corresponding_authors: Rao Tatavarti; P. Arulmozhivarman; Anil Jakkam; Shanmuka Rao S; Tatavarti Aparna
abstract: The development of an optoelectronic sensor for real time monitoring of environmental parameters in atmosphere and ocean is presented here with envisaged applications onboard automobiles, aircrafts and underwater platforms.

abstract: We present a novel on-chip plasmonic nanofocusing technique based on tapering the metal layer of a hybrid Si-Au waveguide. Input optical energy becomes strongly concentrated and highly localized at the metallic tip.

title: A Modified CMA for PS-QPSK
authors: Pontus Johannisson; Martin Sjödin; Magnus Karlsson
abstract: A modified constant modulus algorithm (CMA) is presented that allows polarization demultiplexing of polarization-switched QPSK. The suggested algorithm has been found to work well on both numerical and experimental data.

title: Light Propagation in 3-D Photonic Crystals
authors: Kenji Ishizaki; Susumu Noda
abstract: We introduce recent progress on the control of light propagation in three-dimensional (3-D) photonic crystals. We demonstrate 3-D guiding within photonic crystal-embedded waveguides. A novel controlling approach using the surface of crystals is also discussed.

title: Analysis of a metallic periodic structure at oblique incidence using the FDTD method for the Drude-critical points model
authors: Yuu Wakabayashi; Junji Yamauchi; Hisamatsu Nakano
corresponding_authors: Yuu Wakabayashi; Junji Yamauchi; Hisamatsu Nakano
abstract: We develop the FDTD method based on the trapezoidal recursive convolution technique to analyze metallic periodic structures at oblique incidence. The results from the FDTD method agree well with the analytical results.

title: Grating-based Fiber-to-chip Coupling Efficiency for Small Mode Field Diameter Fibers
authors: Aramais R. Zakharian; S. Kuchinsky; Xue Liu; A. Kobyakov
corresponding_authors: Aramais R. Zakharian; S. Kuchinsky; Xue Liu; A. Kobyakov
abstract: We compute the fiber-to-chip coupling efficiency of grating couplers for fiber mode diameters ≤ 10µm. Modeling shows that high coupling efficiency (−1.5dB loss) can be achieved with smaller footprint for fibers with half the mode field diameter of the standard single mode fiber.

title: Progress and Technical Challenges for Integrated Optics
authors: Katsunari Okamoto
corresponding_authors: Katsunari Okamoto
abstract: The paper reviews progress of integrated optics and discuss technical challenges of silicon photonics devices. It also describes a novel planar waveguide spectrometer based on Fourier transform spectroscopy.

title: Tapered Optical Fibers for Reproducible Detection of Liquids
authors: Matěj Komanec; Tomáš Martan; Stanislav Zvánovec
corresponding_authors: Matěj Komanec; Tomáš Martan; Stanislav Zvánovec
abstract: Fiber taper refractometric sensors for detection of liquids are presented. Almost one hundred tapers of a wide waist diameter range were reproducibly prepared from multi-mode and polymer-clad silica fibers. Sensitivity above 400%/RIU was achieved.

title: Tactical-grade interferometric fiber optic gyroscope driven with a narrow-linewidth laser
authors: Seth W. Lloyd; Michel J. F. Digonnet; Shanhui Fan
corresponding_authors: Seth W. Lloyd; Michel J. F. Digonnet; Shanhui Fan
abstract: We report on the use of narrowband lasers in fiber optic gyroscopes using solid-core and microstructured air-core fiber coils. We present theoretical and experimental results and discuss the benefits over traditional fiber gyroscopes.

title: Photoluminescence of Strain-Engineered CdSe/Cd0.5Zn0.5S Core/Shell Colloidal Quantum Dots
authors: Jaime Brar; Vincent Veilleux; P.A. Krug; Karin Hinzer; Claudine Nì. Allen; Henry Schriemer
abstract: Photoluminescence (PL) measurements were performed to gain insight into bleaching processes, to determine relative quantum efficiency, temperature dependence of the PL and the contribution of carrier-phonon scattering processes to thermal broadening.

title: New approach to fabricate low-loss Titanium dioxide waveguides with electron beam lithography and atomic layer deposition
authors: Markus Häyrinen; M. Roussey; Vishal Gandhi; Markku Kuittinen; Seppo Honkanen
corresponding_authors: Markus Häyrinen; M. Roussey; Vishal Gandhi; Markku Kuittinen; Seppo Honkanen
abstract: We introduce a new approach to reduce losses of amorphous titanium dioxide (TiO2) strip waveguides with sub-wavelength dimensions using atomic layer deposition (ALD) technology. The fabrication process and the characterization are presented.

title: Computationally Efficient Dual Perforated Finite Element Time Domain Method
authors: B. M. A. Rahman
corresponding_authors: B. M. A. Rahman
abstract: Finite element based meshing can discretise structures more accurately than finite difference technique. The FDTD method is currently the dominant method. This paper presents the dual perforated FETD to perform faster simulation by reducing resolution.

title: Analysis of Periodic Structures at Oblique Incidence Using an LOD-FDTD Method
authors: Yuu Wakabayashi; Jun Shibayama; Junji Yamauchi; Hisamatsu Nakano
corresponding_authors: Yuu Wakabayashi; Jun Shibayama; Junji Yamauchi; Hisamatsu Nakano
abstract: A broadband mirror consisting of a subwavelength grating is analyzed using a locally one-dimensional FDTD method with the periodic boundary condition. A high reflectivity is obtained around wavelengths of 1.4 µm and 1.9 µm.

title: Integration of a Tunable, Optical Delay Generator in a Silicon Photonics Platform
authors: Kambiz Jamshidi; Stefan Meister; Aws Al-Saadi; Hans Joachim Eichler; Thomas Schneider
corresponding_authors: Kambiz Jamshidi; Stefan Meister; Aws Al-Saadi; Hans Joachim Eichler; Thomas Schneider
abstract: We propose an integrated optical delay generator based on Frequency-to-Time conversion. The required dispersions are produced by micro ring resonators based on SOI nano wires. Our design can provide delays up to 500 nanoseconds.

title: On the Joint Optimization of Modulation and Channel Coding for High Data-Rate Optical Communication Systems
authors: Paolo Leoni; Stefano Calabrò; Berthold Lankl; Bernhard Spinnler
corresponding_authors: Paolo Leoni; Stefano Calabrò; Berthold Lankl; Bernhard Spinnler
abstract: We present a method to jointly optimize modulation and channel coding for high data-rate, non-differentially encoded optical systems, taking phase noise into account. Applied to 100G systems, it shows that "constellation expansion" might be beneficial.

authors: S. Corzine; Pete Evans; M. Fisher; A.G. Dentai; R. Muthiah; R.A. Salvatore; A. James; P. Studenkov; E. Strzelecka; T. Vallaitis; Forrest Sedgwick; M. Küntz; V. Lal; Masashi Kato; M. Missey; Radhakrishnan Nagarajan; Rodrigo Schneider; J. Stewart; M. Reffle; T. Butrie; C.H. Joyner; M. Ziari; F. A. Kish; David Welch
abstract: In this talk, we describe the monolithic integration of 10 InP-based phase-modulated transmitter channels employing polarization multiplexing and quadrature phase-shift keying coherent modulation format to provide an aggregate 500Gb/s bandwidth on a single chip.

title: 25 Gbps Re-Growth-Free Externally Modulated Laser for Multi-Guide Vertical Integration in InP
authors: Sasa Ristic; Kirill Pimenov; Valery Tolstikhin; Christopher D. Watson; Yuri Logvin
corresponding_authors: Sasa Ristic; Kirill Pimenov; Valery Tolstikhin; Christopher D. Watson; Yuri Logvin
abstract: A 25Gbps electro-absorption modulator is monolithically integrated with DFB laser, passive waveguide, and spot-size converter using a re-growth-free platform in InP. The device is well suited for applications in fiber-optics interconnects.

title: Mid Wave Infrared and Long Wave Infrared QCLs and Their Applications to Sensors
authors: Chandan Kumar; Neil Patel
abstract: During the past six years, substantial progress has been made in the performance of MWIR and LWIR quantum cascade lasers. Continuous wave (CW), room temperature (RT) power of more than 4 W is now available from QCLs at 4.6 µm with a wall plug efficiency exceeding 16%. Similar high power, high wall plug efficiency improvement in performance has been demonstrated at all wavelengths from ~3.5 µm to ~12 µm. These semiconductor devices, when inserted into an wavelength dispersive optical cavity, produce single frequency tunable radiation that can cover most of the MWIR and LWIR spectral regions, which are rich in spectral absorption features of most of the industrial toxic gases, chemical warfare agents and explosives vapors. These tunable QCLs have now become the engines for a variety of sensors of the harmful gases. Substantial progress has been made both in the area of in-situ sensors and standoff detectors for the gases.I will describe the advances in QCL technology and applications of QCLs to a broad range of defense, homeland security and commercial applications.

title: Enhancing FWM Conversion Efficiency in a Silicon Waveguide by exploiting Phase-Matching via a Pump-induced Nonlinear Grating
authors: Jeffrey B. Driscoll; Xiaoping Liu; Richard R. Grote; Jerry I. Dadap; Nicolae C. Panoiu; Richard M. Osgood
corresponding_authors: Jeffrey B. Driscoll; Xiaoping Liu; Richard R. Grote; Jerry I. Dadap; Nicolae C. Panoiu; Richard M. Osgood
abstract: We show that the anisotropy of Si may be used to induce a nonlinear grating on-chip, which could be exploited by FWM to phase-match signals well outside of the conversion bandwidth, allowing a >10dB conversion-efficiency-enhancement.

title: Single mode collection efficiency enhancement for free space systems using photonic lantern
authors: İbrahim Özdür; P. Toliver; Anjali Agarwal; T. K. Woodward
corresponding_authors: İbrahim Özdür; P. Toliver; Anjali Agarwal; T. K. Woodward
abstract: We analyze and demonstrate free-space to 19-port photonic lantern light collection efficiency for scattering from diffuse objects. A single-mode collection efficiency improvement of ~8 dB is demonstrated in the near field region.

title: On Fast Light and Signal Detection Latency
authors: Levent Kayili; Mo Mojahedi
corresponding_authors: Levent Kayili; Mo Mojahedi
abstract: Through the calculation of time-varying error probability, we show that a reduction in signal latency can be obtained in a practical active medium with negative group velocity (negative group delay) in the presence of noise.

title: Subband Switching on Optical Supperchannel for Elastic Optical Networks
authors: Zhangyuan Chen; Yuanxiang Chen; Juhao Li; Paikun Zhu; Bingli Guo; Yongqi He
corresponding_authors: Zhangyuan Chen; Yuanxiang Chen; Juhao Li; Paikun Zhu; Bingli Guo; Yongqi He
abstract: We propose subband-based optical networking on optical OFDM/SCFDM super-channel in elastic optical networks. Feasibilities of add-drop, switching, conversion and multicasting functionalities on optical superchannel are experimentally demonstrated.

title: All-fiber Raman Probe using Higher Order Modes
authors: S. H. M. Larsen; Lars Søgaard Rishøj; Karsten Rottwitt
corresponding_authors: S. H. M. Larsen; Lars Søgaard Rishøj; Karsten Rottwitt
abstract: We demonstrate the first all-fiber Raman probe utilizing higher order modes for the excitation. The spectrum of cyclohexane is measured using both the fundamental mode as well as in-fiber-generated Bessel-like modes.

title: Poled-Fiber Source of Polarization-Entangled Photon Pairs
authors: E. Y. Zhu; Zhenzhou Tang; Li Qian; L. G. Helt; Marco Liscidini; J. E. Sipe; C. Corbari; Albert Canagasabey; M. Ibsen; Peter G. Kazansky
corresponding_authors: E. Y. Zhu; Zhenzhou Tang; Li Qian; L. G. Helt; Marco Liscidini; J. E. Sipe; C. Corbari; Albert Canagasabey; M. Ibsen; Peter G. Kazansky
abstract: We demonstrate broadband telecom-wavelength polarization-entangled photon pair generation in a periodically-poled silica fiber (PPSF). Two-photon interference visibility exceeds 90%, and Bell's inequality is violated by 8 standard deviations.

title: Comparison of PMF and LEAF as Optical Fibre Stress and Temperature Sensing Elements
authors: Stanley Kuja; D. Kiboi Boiyo; David Waswa; George Amolo; E.K. Rotich Kipnoo; T. B. Gibbon; Andrew R. Leitch
corresponding_authors: Stanley Kuja; D. Kiboi Boiyo; David Waswa; George Amolo; E.K. Rotich Kipnoo; T. B. Gibbon; Andrew R. Leitch
abstract: We experimentally investigate the sensitivity of PMF and LEAF fibre. The design of a stress sensor gave the best sensitivity of 0.051 kg−1 while that of a temperature sensor, gave the best sensitivity of 0.181 °C−1.

title: Photonic wire bonding: An enabling technology for heterogeneous multi-chip integration
authors: C. Koos; W. Freude; Juerg Leuthold; N. Lindenmann; S. Koeber; Joerg Hoffmann; T. Hoose; P. Huebner; Muhammad Rodlin Billah
corresponding_authors: C. Koos; W. Freude; Juerg Leuthold; N. Lindenmann; S. Koeber; Joerg Hoffmann; T. Hoose; P. Huebner; Muhammad Rodlin Billah
abstract: Photonic wire bonding enables advanced multi-chip assemblies that combine the specific strengths of different photonic integration platforms. The technique is based on in-situ fabrication of 3D freeform waveguides by two-photon polymerization. We introduce the concept and show first experimental demonstrations.

title: Silicon photonic wire Bragg grating for on-chip wavelength (de)multiplexing employing ring resonators
authors: Paul Müellner; R. Bruck; Matthias Karl; M. Baus; T. Wahlbrink; Rainer Hainberger
corresponding_authors: Paul Müellner; R. Bruck; Matthias Karl; M. Baus; T. Wahlbrink; Rainer Hainberger
abstract: We optimized silicon photonic wire Bragg gratings covered with SU-8 for quasi-TM polarized light at a center wavelength of 1550 nm with respect to high reflectivity and large wavelength range by means of 3D FDTD simulations. The simulations resulted in a grating design providing a reflectivity of >70% over a wavelength range of 50 nm. Corresponding samples were fabricated employing e-beam lithography and reactive ion etching. The measured reflection spectrum demonstrates the good performance of the optimized Bragg grating reflector. First experimental results of a silicon photonic device combining the Bragg reflector with ring resonators for on-chip wavelength (de)multiplexing in refractometric sensor arrays are presented.

title: Coupled-Mode Theory for Optical Waveguides: Beyond the Limitation of Guided Fields
authors: Wei‐Ping Huang; Jianwei Mu
corresponding_authors: Wei‐Ping Huang; Jianwei Mu
abstract: Resonant coupling to radiation field in optical waveguides has been simulated by complex coupled mode theory. Salient features of complex mode theory are demonstrated by investigation of transmission spectra in short/long period gratings.

title: Progress in Slow/Fast/Stopped Light
authors: Jacob B. Khurgin
corresponding_authors: Jacob B. Khurgin
abstract: The past 5 years have seen rapid developments of methods for manipulating the group velocity of light. In this talk we assess the current state of slow light versus fundamental limitations and attempt to identify promising application niches for slow and fast light. Article not available.

title: Low-Pass Filter Assisted Digital Back Propagation Algorithm for 112 Gb/s DP 16-QAM

abstract: We present a method for synthesizing strongly coupled microring networks of general 2D coupling topologies. The method is based on the power coupling formalism of coupled microrings and can be used to design broadband filters.

abstract: Metasurfaces, with their compactness, multifunctionality, and subwavelength coding, revolutionize imaging systems by offering unmatched modulation devices.Their high-dimensional modulation capacity, when intricately modeled, enables the simultaneous optimization of metasurface structure and reconstruction algorithms.This tailoring to specific imaging or perception goals opens doors to previously impossible achievements like extreme depth of field, compact full-Stokes, and snapshot full-space 3D perception.These innovations, emerging from the convergence of nanophotonics, electronics, AI, and information theory, herald new imaging techniques and breakthroughs.Featured on the cover of Advanced Photonics Volume 6 Issue 1 is a schematic of a system utilizing metasurface-based optical modulation and computation.It modulates high-dimensional optical signals, encoding target information for tailored imaging tasks.Combined with co-optimized computational reconstruction, this approach ensures the high-quality recovery of diverse data typeshyperspectral, full-Stokes polarization, wavefront phase, or depthdepending on the specific imaging challenge.The image is based on the review paper by

title: Zwitterionic additive for high-performance pure-blue perovskite light-emitting diodes
authors: Hongling Yu; Feng Gao
corresponding_authors: Feng Gao
abstract: Despite the significant advancements in perovskite light-emitting diodes (PeLEDs), achieving high-performance blue LEDs remains a key concern for future display and optical communication applications, particularly pure-blue PeLEDs with high external quantum efficiency (EQE) and luminance. Recently, Hou and colleagues reported the utilization of an efficient additive that enables stable emission color with an enhanced EQE of 9.25% and a maximum luminance of 1806 cd cm-2, representing one of the best-performing pure-blue PeLEDs.

title: About the cover: Advanced Photonics Volume 6, Issue 2
authors: No authors
abstract: Perovskite light-emitting diodes (PeLEDs) are considered promising candidates for future display and lighting technologies due to their excellent optoelectronic properties and simple fabrication methods.However, the performance of blue PeLEDs is not satisfactory.The introduction of the zwitterionic molecule 3-(benzyldimethylammonio)propanesulfonate (3-BAS) serves multiple purposes: it passivates defects on the perovskite surface, suppresses the migration of halide ions, and effectively regulates the crystallization process of perovskite thin films.This leads to the development of high-performance pure blue perovskite LEDs, which can further be applied in the field of visible light communications.The image on the cover of Advanced Photonics Volume 6 Issue 2 illustrates blue LEDs based on perovskites and suggests potential application prospects in future visible light communication.The image is based on the original research presented in the article by

title: About the cover: Advanced Photonics Volume 6, Issue 4
authors: No authors
abstract: Aberrations and fluctuations in light fields induced by complex media have presented significant challenges to optical detection and communication systems.Consequently, there has been substantial scholarly interest in the study of embedded invariants, including spatial modes and polarizations.Coherence, a fundamental characteristic of light fields, is closely related to the statistical properties of a randomly fluctuating incoherent light field.Recently, researchers revealed that a general global coherence characteristic of incoherent light fields, namely coherence entropy, remains robust after transmission through unitary complex media.The cover of Advanced Photonics Volume 6 Issue 4 features a schematic illustrating the robustness of the coherence entropy despite the deformation of individual modes.This research paves the way for the selection of modes suitable for generating incoherent light sources with potential applications in antiturbulence communication.The image is based on the research presented in the article by

authors: Ezra Guralnik; Behnam Tayebi; Yi Yuan; Justin M. Little; Michal Balberg; Shy Shoham
corresponding_authors: Ezra Guralnik; Behnam Tayebi; Justin M. Little; Michal Balberg; Shy Shoham
abstract: Two-photon microscopy provides sectioned excitation, but in practical settings, it often suffers from contrast limitations. Here, we report the observation of a strong acousto-optic modulation of two-photon excited fluorescence. Harnessing this effect yields enhanced image detail and contrast and improves optical sectioning in deep brain tissue in vivo. Ultrasound-modulation assisted multiphoton imaging (UMAMI) is compatible with standard multiphoton microscopes, without requiring changes to the optical path or image acquisition parameters.

title: About the cover: Advanced Photonics Volume 6, Issue 3
authors: No authors
abstract: Efforts to boost information processing capacity have led scientists to optical multiplexing techniques, such as polarization and wavelength, enhancing communication capacity.Spatial mode-division multiplexing utilizes orthogonal spatial modes, notably orbital angular momentum (OAM) modes/vortex beams, which offer vast information capacity due to OAM's arbitrary quantization.OAM multiplexing, combined with other multiplexing techniques, appears as a solution to capacity challenges.However, challenges persist, especially with the beam size and divergence of vortex beams increasing with OAM, such as the Laguerre-Gaussian beam.This necessitates larger receivers for more modes and greater capacity, posing a constraint for spatial multiplexing especially with realistically limited-size receivers.

authors: Mengjie Yu

title: MIR Photoacoustic Trace Gas Sensing Using a Miniaturized 3D Printed Gas Cell
authors: Ralf Bauer; David Wilson; Walter Johnstone; Michael Lengden
abstract: A miniaturized 3D printed photoacoustic trace gas sensor is presented, using a mid-infrared QCL at 5.26µm as excitation source. Its performance for sensing CH4 resulted in a normalized noise equivalent absorbance of 7.7·10−9cm−1WHz−½.

title: Mask Testing of 28 Gbaud 16-QAM Transmitters using Time-Resolved Error Vector Magnitude
authors: Carl Lundström; Henrik Eliasson; Irshaad Fatadin; Pontus Johannisson; Peter A. Andrekson
abstract: We propose time-resolved EVM for characterization of 16-QAM transmitters. By designing a mask test, different impairments can be separated and quantified. The impact from quadrature error and timing skew are investigated experimentally.

title: Multi-Stability and Super Cavity Solitons in Microresonator Frequency Combs
authors: Tobias Hansson; S. Wabnitz
abstract: Frequency comb generation in microresonators is considered beyond the mean-field approximation. We show the appearance of multi-valued stationary states and predict the existence of a novel type of super cavity solitons.

title: Direct bandgap GeSn alloys for laser application
authors: Dan Buca; Stephan Wirths; Daniela Stange; C. Schulte‐Braucks; Nils von den Driesch; Richard Geiger; Bahareh Marzban; Jean‐Michel Hartmann; Z. Ikonić; S. Mantl; Jeremy Witzens; H. Sigg; Detlev Grützmacher
abstract: Efforts towards development of monolithically integrated silicon-compatible lasers have been revitalized since the demonstration of optically pumped GeSn waveguide lasers. Here we investigate the laser emission of GeSn alloys by means of waveguide and microdisk photoluminescence.

title: Stabilization of frequency combs using third order dispersion
authors: Pedro Parra‐Rivas; Damià Gomila; François Léo; Stéphane Coen; Lendert Gelens
corresponding_authors: Pedro Parra‐Rivas; Damià Gomila; François Léo; Stéphane Coen; Lendert Gelens
abstract: We analyze the stability and nonlinear dynamics of Kerr frequency combs generated in microresonators and fiber resonators taking into account third-order dispersion effects. We show that cavity solitons underlying Kerr frequency combs, sensitive to oscillatory and chaotic instabilities, are stabilized in a wide range of parameter space by third-order dispersion.

title: Theoretical Investigation of a Quasi-Distributed Current Sensor Based on Hybrid PCF
authors: F. C. Salgado; Arismar Cerqueira S.; Danilo H. Spadoti
abstract: Using hybrid photonic crystal fiber to maintain the state-of-polarization (SOP), a quasi-distributed current sensor based on Rayleigh backscattering process and polarization optical-time domain (POTDR) technique is proposed.

title: Advancement of an Interferometric Velocity Measurement Technique by Adaptive Optics
authors: Lars Büttner; Jürgen Czarske; Christoph Leithold
abstract: A technique for interferometric velocity measurements through a fluctuating gas-liquid interface based on wavefront correction is presented. Experimental methods, adaptive optic components, simulations and applications are described.

title: Soliton fission in nanophotonic waveguides unveiled by near-field measurements
authors: Chad Husko; Matthias Wulf; Sylvain Combrié; A. de Rossi; Kobus Kuipers; Benjamin J. Eggleton
abstract: We demonstrate time-resolved measurements of soliton fission in nanophotonic waveguides for the first time. Using near-field measurements, we directly observe the nonlinear pulse evolution along the 1.5 millimetre device in-situ.

title: Energy Scalability Limits of Dissipative Solitons: Impact of Quantum and Raman Noise
authors: В. Л. Калашников; Evgeni Sorokin; A. Apolonski
abstract: Quantum and Raman noise impose fundamental constrains on the energy scalability of dissipative solitons. Raman scattering complicates soliton dynamics and forms a dissipative Raman soliton, which behaves chaotically and cannot accumulate energy without stability loss.

title: Fiber sensors for the high-speed railway environment
authors: Miguel González‐Herráez; Massimo L. Filograno; Pedro Corredera; Álvaro Andres-Alguacil; Miguel Rodrıguez-Plaza
abstract: We review some recent work on fiber-optic sensors for the high-speed railway environment. In particular, we show convenient fiber-optic solutions for rail and wheel monitoring, perimeter security and catenary protection in changeover sections.

title: Experimental demonstration of coherent supercontinuum generation in a silicon wire pumped at telecommunication wavelengths
authors: François Léo; Simon-Pierre Gorza; Stéphane Coen; Bart Kuyken; Günther Roelkens
corresponding_authors: François Léo; Simon-Pierre Gorza; Stéphane Coen; Bart Kuyken; Günther Roelkens
abstract: We study the coherence properties of supercontinuum spectra generated in a silicon wire pumped at telecommunication wavelengths. We numerically and experimentally demonstrate coherence across a span of 500 nm.

title: All-fiber passively mode-locked picosecond erbium doped fiber laser using a 45°-tilted fiber grating
authors: Zhongyuan Sun; Chengbo Mou; Youjian Song; Zhijun Yan; Kaiming Zhou; Lin Zhang
abstract: We demonstrate an all-fiber erbium doped fiber laser passively mode-locked using a 45° tilted fiber grating and a fiber Bragg grating in the laser cavity. The laser generates 18ps pulses with output pulse energies ~0.2nJ.

title: Nonlinear Diamond Photonics
authors: Marko Lončar
corresponding_authors: Marko Lončar
abstract: We developed a single-crystal diamond nanophotonics platform and demonstrated ring resonators with quality factors >106. Furthermore, we leveraged diamond's third order nonlinearity to demonstrate frequency comb generation at telecom wavelengths in our resonators.

title: SHG Response Reciprocity for a Specially-Designed Step-chirped Grating
authors: Ameneh Bostani; Meenu Ahlawat; Amirhossein Tehranchi; Roberto Morandotti; Raman Kashyap
corresponding_authors: Ameneh Bostani; Meenu Ahlawat; Amirhossein Tehranchi; Roberto Morandotti; Raman Kashyap
abstract: A specially-designed apodized step-chirped PPLN device has been fabricated to demonstrate both theoretically and experimentally, the reciprocal response in the SHG for up-chirp and down-chirp directions over a 30nm bandwidth.

title: Real-time heterodyned measurements of spatio-frequency dynamics in fibre lasers
authors: Srikanth Sugavanam; Son Thai Le; Simon J. Fabbri; Ivan A. Lobach; S. I. Kablukov; S. Khorev; Dmitry V. Churkin
corresponding_authors: Srikanth Sugavanam; Son Thai Le; Simon J. Fabbri; Ivan A. Lobach; S. I. Kablukov; S. Khorev; Dmitry V. Churkin
abstract: We report high-resolution real-time measurements of spectrum evolution in a fibre. The proposed method combines optical heterodyning with a technique of spatio-temporal intensity measurements revealing fast spectral dynamics of cavity-based systems.

title: Efficient wavelength conversion in CF4-filled photonic bandgap fibers
authors: Lior Ben Yehud; Amiel A. Ishaaya
corresponding_authors: Lior Ben Yehud; Amiel A. Ishaaya
abstract: We investigate Raman wavelength conversion in CF4-filled hollow-core photonic bandgap fibers. We obtain a record of more than 35% conversion efficiency in a 35cm-long, weakly pressurized, fiber at a peak power of only 2.6kW.

title: Dispersive waves dynamics in optical fibre systems
authors: S. Couliblay; M. Taki; E. Louvergneaux
abstract: The study of spatio-temporal growth of a localized initial condition in an optical fibre system allows us to evidence two distinct regimes versus the third order dispersion strength. A value for the transition is found.

title: Designing Tunable Miniaturized Spectroscopic Gas Sensor Using Optofluidic Hollow-Core Photonic Crystal Fiber
authors: Majid Ebnali-Heidari; Farshid Koohi-Kamali; Aliakbar Ebnali-Heidari; Mohammad Kazem Moravvej‐Farshi; Boris T. Kuhlmey
abstract: A tunable optofluidic slow-light hollow-core photonic crystal fiber (HPCF), applicable to miniaturized spectroscopic gas sensors is proposed. We present numerical results showing how this optofluidic structure can be used for gas detection.

title: Plasmon-enhanced emission of polarization entangled photons
authors: Shahabedin Chatraee Azizabadi; V. Hizhnyakov
abstract: The emission of polarization entangled photons by a metal-dielectric interface in case of superluminally propagating laser-induced nonlinear polarization is considered. The emission is strongly enhanced for definite intensity and excitation angle.

title: Nanowire Photonic Sensors
authors: Limin Tong
corresponding_authors: Limin Tong
abstract: Photonic nanowires functionalized with active dopants, show excellent properties for guiding light with tight optical confinement and strong evanescent fields, as well as versatile building blocks for optical sensors with miniaturized sizes and fast response.

title: Laser-Based Oxygen Monitoring in Waste Incineration Facilities: Benefits and Challenges
authors: Hannes Merbold; U. Wahl; Steven Stosky
abstract: Oxygen measurements using tunable diode laser absorption spectroscopy were performed at a full scale waste incineration facility. A comparative analysis to a reference method allowed identifying benefits and challenges inherent to the laser method.

title: Photonic Integrator Based on a Distributed Feedback Semiconductor Optical Amplifier
authors: Luis Romero Cortés; Reza Maram; José Azaña
abstract: A temporal photonic integrator based on a distributed-feedback semiconductor optical amplifier is proposed and theoretically investigated. The designed structure features a time-bandwidth product of 150000 and a tunable integration window of 300 ns.

title: Tunable wavelength shifters using tight focusing in a wideband engineered PPLN crystal
authors: Meenu Ahlawat; Ameneh Bostani; Amirhossein Tehranchi; Raman Kashyap
corresponding_authors: Meenu Ahlawat; Ameneh Bostani; Amirhossein Tehranchi; Raman Kashyap
abstract: Enhanced tuning of pump bandwidth of an efficient broadband engineered PPLN is realized with a non-confocal focusing to variably shift signal wavelengths in the C-band based on cascaded second-harmonic and difference-frequency generation.

title: Dispersion Flattened Silicon Nitride Waveguide for Supercontinuum Generation
authors: J.M. Chávez Boggio; D. Bodenmüller; T. Fremberg; René Eisermann; Roger Haynes; Lars Zimmermann; Martin M. Roth
abstract: Dispersion-flattening in silicon-nitride waveguides (dispersion variation of ±3ps/nm/km over 400nm) is demonstrated by optimizing the refractive indices and thicknesses of three cladding layers. SC generation spanning three octaves is shown in those waveguides.

title: Conservative nonlinear interaction of light and a Bose-Einstein condensate in a lossy optical cavity
authors: M. Diver; G. R. M. Robb; Gian‐Luca Oppo
abstract: We consider a Bose-Einstein condensate in an optical cavity being driven by an external laser beam. The modulated optical lattice induces conservative chaotic oscillations that are ubiquitous for pump rates that exceed a critical value.
