title: Multi-Element Fiber Technology for High-Capacity Optical Communication Systems
authors: Victor J. F. Rancaño; S. Jain; T.C. May-Smith; J. K. Sahu; Periklis Petropoulos; David J. Richardson
abstract: Multi-element fiber technology is presented as an alternative approach to high capacity communication systems based on spatial division multiplexing. This talk discusses the advantages and potential drawbacks of this technology with respect to multicore and multimode approaches.

title: Efficient Tunable Frequency Up-Conversion via Molecular Modulation in Gas-Filled Hollow-Core PCF
authors: S. T. Bauerschmidt; David Novoa; Barbara M. Trabold; A. Abdolvand; P. St. J. Russell
corresponding_authors: S. T. Bauerschmidt; David Novoa; Barbara M. Trabold; A. Abdolvand; P. St. J. Russell
abstract: Supercontinuum radiation is frequency up-shifted with ~50% quantum efficiency by Raman-driven molecular modulation in a hydrogen-filled hollow-core PCF. Perfect phase-matching is achieved by pressure tuning and the use of higher order modes.

title: Visible Supercontinuum for Flow Cytometry in Multimode Rectangular Optical Fibers pumped at 532nm
authors: Badr Mohamed Ibrahim Shalaby; Alexis Labruyère; Katarzyna Krupa; Denisa Subtirelu; Nelly Rongeat; Alessandro Tonello; Vincent Couderc
corresponding_authors: Badr Mohamed Ibrahim Shalaby; Alexis Labruyère; Katarzyna Krupa; Denisa Subtirelu; Nelly Rongeat; Alessandro Tonello; Vincent Couderc
abstract: We present an experimental study of supercontinuum generation for applications in flow cytometry in a rectangular-core multimode microstructured optical fiber pumped at 532nm. We generated a bright visible supercontinuum spectrum spanning from 350 nm to 1080 nm.

title: Direct Generation of Orthogonally Polarized Photon Pairs on a Chip via Spontaneous Non-Degenerate FWM
authors: Christian Reimer; Lucia Caspani; Y. Jestin; Matteo Clerici; Marcello Ferrera; Luca Razzari; Marco Peccianti; Alessia Pasquazi; Brent E. Litte; Sai T. Chu; David Moss; Roberto Morandotti
corresponding_authors: Christian Reimer; Lucia Caspani; Y. Jestin; Matteo Clerici; Marcello Ferrera; Luca Razzari; Marco Peccianti; Alessia Pasquazi; Brent E. Litte; Sai T. Chu; David Moss; Roberto Morandotti
abstract: By suppressing stimulated processes, we demonstrate the direct generation of orthogonally polarized photon pairs via spontaneous non-degenerate four-wave-mixing (FWM) between orthogonally polarized pumps in a CMOS-compatible micro-ring. Photon coincidences and optical parametric oscillation are measured.

title: Manipulation of large soliton ensembles in Er-doped double-clad fiber laser
authors: Alioune Niang; Foued Amrani; Mohamed Salhi; H. Leblond; Andrey Komarov; Konstantin Komarov; François Sanchez
abstract: We have studied the influence of an external continuous wave on a passively modelocked fiber laser operating in the soliton regime.Starting from an irregular soliton distribution it is shown that harmonic mode-locking is obtained.

title: Photodarkening: Investigation, Measurement and Standard
authors: Stefano Taccheo; Hrvoje Gebavi; Riccardo Piccoli; Thierry Robin; L. Lablonde; Benoît Cadier; Achille Monteville; David Méchin; Daniel Milanese; Thomas Brand; Lasse Leick; François Salin; Andy Malinovski; U. Hefter; Tim Durrant; Udo Klotzback
abstract: This paper reports on the work done on photodarkening by our consortium. Particular emphasis is given to mitigate and measure photondarkening in high-quality Al-silicate fibers with high doping concentration.

title: Collapse Arrest in Instantaneous Kerr Media via Parametric Interactions
authors: Alessia Pasquazi; Marco Peccianti; Matteo Clerici; Claudio Conti; Roberto Morandotti
corresponding_authors: Alessia Pasquazi; Marco Peccianti; Matteo Clerici; Claudio Conti; Roberto Morandotti
abstract: We demonstrate a four wave mixing interaction based on four wave mixing that can arrest the collapse and stabilize solitary propagation in a pure Kerr material by controlling the wavelength of the interacting beams.

title: Polymer-Clad Silica Tapers for Liquid Sensing: Long-term Measurement Repeatability and Production Imperfections
authors: Matěj Komanec; Tomáš Martan; Stanislav Zvánovec
abstract: Polymer-clad silica fiber tapers for refractometric detection of liquids are presented. Experimental study of sensor stability and measurement reproducibility is carried out, providing stable sensitivities with respect to production imperfections.

title: Miniature optical fiber sensors based on inner air-cavity
authors: D. N. Wang; Minghong Yang
corresponding_authors: D. N. Wang; Minghong Yang
abstract: Optical fiber sensors based on inner air-cavity have compact size, high sensitivity and good robustness. A few types of such sensors are proposed and demonstrated for a wide range of sensing applications.

title: A distributed and key-position fiber sensing system based on LPFG and WFBG assisted OTDR
authors: Xiangchuan Wang; Zhijun Yan; Feng Wang; Chengbo Mou; Zhongyuan Sun; Xuping Zhang; Lin Zhang
corresponding_authors: Xiangchuan Wang; Zhijun Yan; Feng Wang; Chengbo Mou; Zhongyuan Sun; Xuping Zhang; Lin Zhang
abstract: An enhanced fiber sensing system used for distributed bending and key-position sensing is reported by integrating WFBGs, LPFG and OTDR, which also achieves strain and temperature sensitivities up to 0.047mv/µε and 0.675mv/°C respectively.

title: Influence of high-order dispersion on Kerr frequency combs and intracavity soliton dynamics
authors: Shaofei Wang; Hairun Guo; Xuekun Bai; Xianglong Zeng
abstract: The influence of high-order dispersion on both temporal and spectral characteristics of microresonator-based optical frequency combs are investigated. The moment method and intracavity dispersive wave generations are utilized to analyze comb dynamics. © 2014 Optical Society of America.

title: Challenges of Long Distance Detection by Brillouin Scattering
authors: Sonia Martín‐López
corresponding_authors: Sonia Martín‐López
abstract: Brillouin distributed sensors have attracted the attention of both academic and industrial sectors, in particular for long distance applications. Here I review some techniques for range increase in BOTDA and explain the challenges behind them.

title: Optical Sensor Based on the Protein Molecule, Comprising a Luminescent Probe
authors: Andrei G. Melnikov; G.V. Melnikov
abstract: According to the results of fundamental research of quenching of luminescence of the probes bound to proteins, we developed an optical sensors based on protein macromolecules. Suggested sensors are human serum albumin proteins with noncovalently bound fluorescent probe. As fluorescent probes we selected quantum dots ZnCdS, and dyes from acridine and xanthene series. It was established that the fluorescence of quantum dots is selectively responsive to heavy metal ions such as zinc, cadmium and copper. Sensitivity of luminescent-kinetic parameters of the probes from xanthene and acridine series to the presence of heavy metal ions as well as to structural changes in proteins was revealed. Sensors based on electronic excitation energy transfer between proteins and probes as well as between the probes associated by noncovalent bonds with proteins for determination of the structural changes in proteins were developed.

title: Time dependent defect in periodic dielectric waveguide for path delay multiplexing in distributed fiber sensor
authors: Pandian Chelliah; Annie Sujatha; Pandiyarasan Veluswamy; Trilochan Sahoo
abstract: A time dependent defect in one dimensional periodic dielectric waveguide using Finite difference time domain method is analyzed. The effect of this defect on the propagation time can be used for path delay multiplexing in a distributed fiber sensor.

title: Supermode Interference in Multicore Fiber Optimized for use in Sensing Applications
authors: Amy Van Newkirk; Enrique Antonio‐Lopez; G. Salceda-Delgado; Rodrigo Amezcua‐Correa; Axel Schülzgen
abstract: A multicore fiber has been optimized for use in sensing applications. Supermode interference was investigated through simulation and experiment, enabling sharp spectral features and high transmission necessary for sensor multiplexing.

title: Interaction between positive and negative frequencies in nonlinear optics
authors: Matteo Conforti; Andrea Marini; Daniele Faccio; Fabio Biancalana
corresponding_authors: Matteo Conforti; Andrea Marini; Daniele Faccio; Fabio Biancalana
abstract: We show that new surprising nonlinear phenomena can be predicted by using a propagation equation that correctly includes the nonlinear interactions between the positive and negative frequencies of an ultrashort pulse.

title: Nonlinear optical phenomena in bulk dielectric media with few optical cycle mid-IR pulses
authors: A. Dubietis; N. Garejev; Vytautas Jukna; G. Tamošauskas; I. Gražulevičiūtė; D. Majus; G. Valiulis; A. Couairon
corresponding_authors: A. Dubietis; N. Garejev; Vytautas Jukna; G. Tamošauskas; I. Gražulevičiūtė; D. Majus; G. Valiulis; A. Couairon
abstract: We present an investigation of supercontinuum, third and fifth harmonics generation in transparent dielectrics with few optical-cycle pulses at 2 µm, revealing a negligible role of higher order nonlinearities for intensities up to 15 TW/cm2.

title: Optical parametric oscillator based on the interaction of dispersive waves and solitons
authors: Dmitry V. Skryabin; A. V. Yulin; M. Taki
abstract: We report a new class of instabilities of cavity solitons, which can exist due to periodic boundary conditions in microring and fiber cavities. These instabilities are associated with exponential growth of dispersive waves and thereby have applications for frequency conversion and design of novel soliton based optical parametric oscillators.

title: Formation of Auto-Oscillation under Continuous Laser Illumination in Optical Nonlinear Dissipative System
authors: S. Bugaychuk
corresponding_authors: S. Bugaychuk
abstract: The interaction of continuous waves in nonlocal dissipative dynamical medium is considered. This whole nonlinear system can be described by one CGLE. The regime of auto-oscillations is found for the two-wave mixing in the dynamical medium.

title: Phase-locked Cascaded Stimulated Brillouin Scattering and Pulse Train Generation on a Photonic Chip
authors: Thomas Büttner; Irina V. Kabakova; Moritz Merklein; Darren D. Hudson; Duk‐Yong Choi; Barry Luther‐Davies; Steve Madden; Benjamin J. Eggleton
abstract: We experimentally demonstrate the generation of phase-locked Brillouin-frequency combs and gigahertz repetition rate pulse trains via the interplay of stimulated Brillouin scattering and Kerr-nonlinear four-wave mixing on a chalcogenide chip.

title: Spatiotemporal Light Bullets in Bulk Media
authors: Daniele Faccio; Thomas Roger; M. Petev; Matteo Clerici; Roberto Morandotti; François Légaré; D. Majus; G. Tamošauskas; A. Dubietis; A. Couairon; Goëry Genty; Πάρις Παναγιωτόπουλος; M. Kolesík
corresponding_authors: Daniele Faccio; Thomas Roger; M. Petev; Matteo Clerici; Roberto Morandotti; François Légaré; D. Majus; G. Tamošauskas; A. Dubietis; A. Couairon; Goëry Genty; Πάρις Παναγιωτόπουλος; M. Kolesík
abstract: Three-dimensional light bullets in bulk media are identified, through their specific energy density flux, as polychromatic Bessel-like pulses. We also study resonant radiation emission with applications in rogue event studies and THz detection.

title: Single and two-phase flow measurements using optical fiber Bragg gratings
authors: Virgínia Baroncini; Cícero Martelli; Marco J. da Silva; Rigoberto Morales
corresponding_authors: Virgínia Baroncini; Cícero Martelli; Marco J. da Silva; Rigoberto Morales
abstract: The use of quasi-distributed optical fiber Bragg grating strain sensors is demonstrated as single and dual phase flow meters. Results show the potential of this technique to characterize and investigate flow evolution along a pipeline.

title: Modal Decomposition in Asymmetric Wavelength-Selective Fused Fiber Couplers
authors: Gabriel Pelegrina-Bonilla; Katharina Hausmann; Henrik Tünnermann; P. Weßels; Hakan Sayınc; Uwe Morgner; Jörg Neumann; Dietmar Kracht
corresponding_authors: Gabriel Pelegrina-Bonilla; Katharina Hausmann; Henrik Tünnermann; P. Weßels; Hakan Sayınc; Uwe Morgner; Jörg Neumann; Dietmar Kracht
abstract: The coupling mechanism in asymmetric fused fiber couplers is investigated by tuning the pretaper length. A numerical modal decomposition is performed to analyze the impact of pretapering on the modal weight of the excited super-modes.

title: Long-Range interaction of temporal incoherent solitons
authors: Gang Xu; C. Michel; Josselin Garnier; Bertrand Kibler; Antonio Picozzi
abstract: Contrary to conventional solitons, temporal incoherent solitons are sustained by a defocusing nonlinearity with anomalous dispersion and exhibit a non-mutual attractive-repulsive interaction. We explain these results by a long-range Vlasov formalism.

title: Topological dissipative solitons in semiconductor lasers
authors: François Gustave; Lorenzo Columbo; M. Giudici; Othmane Mouane; Massimo Brambilla; Franco Prati; G. Tissoni; Bryan Kelleher; Bogusław Tykalewicz; S. Barland
corresponding_authors: François Gustave; Lorenzo Columbo; M. Giudici; Othmane Mouane; Massimo Brambilla; Franco Prati; G. Tissoni; Bryan Kelleher; Bogusław Tykalewicz; S. Barland
abstract: We analyze the formation of non dispersive solitary waves along the propagation dimension of a ring semiconductor laser with coherent forcing. We measure their phase dynamics and show that they can host a topological charge.

title: Strain fiber ring cavity laser sensor based on the multiple-mode interference in photonic crystal fiber
authors: Xuekun Bai; Dengfeng Fan; Shaofei Wang; Xianglong Zeng
abstract: A strain fiber laser sensor is demonstrated, which consists of a photonic crystal fiber in-line Mach-Zehnder interferometer as an optical filter and strain sensing head. Strain sensing sensitivity of 2.1 pm/µε, and high sensing quality are achieved.

title: Diffraction-resisting vortex Bessel beams with arbitrary trajectories
authors: Ioannis Chremmos; Juanying Zhao; Demetrios N. Christodoulides; Zhigang Chen; Nikolaos K. Efremidis
corresponding_authors: Ioannis Chremmos; Juanying Zhao; Demetrios N. Christodoulides; Zhigang Chen; Nikolaos K. Efremidis
abstract: We theoretically predict and experimentally demonstrate that it is possible to generate diffraction-resisting higher order Bessel beams with vortex profiles that follow arbitrary trajectories. These beams are utilized for particle manipulation.

title: Tunable, Continuous-wave, Single-frequency Ultraviolet Sources Based on BiB3O6
authors: Kavita Devi; S. Chaitanya Kumar; M. Ebrahim-Zadeh
corresponding_authors: Kavita Devi; S. Chaitanya Kumar; M. Ebrahim-Zadeh
abstract: We report stable, single-frequency, continuous-wave (cw) UV sources based on single-pass and intracavity sum-frequency-generation in BiB3O6. We have generated >68mW of cw power at 354.7nm, and demonstrate tunable wavelength coverage across 333-345nm in the UV.

title: Arbitrary Optical Retardance Patterns Generated in Bulk Silica Glass by Laser-Written Stressors
authors: Ben McMillen; Yves Bellouard
abstract: We present micro-scale stressors written in bulk silica using an ultrafast laser. Stress from nanograting formation produces optical retardance, which is then tailored through control of the orientation, magnitude, and anisotropy of the stress field.

title: Nanoarray-Enhanced Micromechanical Pressure Sensor with Remote Optical Readout
authors: Jeong O. Lee; Trong-Tuong Nguyen; David W. Sretavan; Hyuck Choo
abstract: We demonstrate a compact implantable intraocular pressure (IOP) sensor with remote optical readout for glaucoma research and patient management. Using non-invasive white light, we excite the sensor's pressure-sensitive optomechanical cavity and detect the reflected light, whose optical signature changes as a function of IOP. The sensor has provided robust measurements of hydrostatic pressure between 10-60 mmHg with an accuracy of 0.15 mmHg.

title: Optical Waveguide-based Single-molecule Studies in Diagnostics and Drug Screening
authors: Fredrik Höök
corresponding_authors: Fredrik Höök
abstract: Single binding events between membrane-protein receptors and their ligands in near-natural environments are presented, and the advantage offered by single-molecule sensitivity is discussed in the context of mechanistic biophysical studies, medical diagnostics and drug discovery.

title: Flaticon pulses in optical fibers
authors: Bastien Varlot; S. Wabnitz; Julien Fatome; G. Millot; Christophe Finot
abstract: We experimentally investigate the nonlinear reshaping of a continuous wave which leads to chirp-free and flat-top intense pulses or flaticons exhibiting strong temporal oscillations at their edges and a stable self-similar expansion upon propagation of their central region.

title: All-solid chalcogenide microstructured optical fibers with photonic band gap propagation
authors: Johann Trolès; Céline Caillaud; Gilles Renversez; Laurent Brilland; David Méchin; Jean‐Luc Adam
abstract: all-solid microstructured optical fibers based on chalcogenide glasses have been elaborated and characterized. Photonic band gap propagation and single mode regime were demonstrated theoretically and experimentally by near-field measurements in the infrared.

title: Influencing the Conversion Efficiency of Second Harmonic Generation Using Counterpropagating Light
authors: R. C. Myer; Allison Penfield; Etienne Gagnon; Amy L. Lytle
abstract: We have observed modulation of the conversion efficiency of second harmonic generation by 1-2% of the spectral intensity using a single counterpropagating pulse to locally disrupt the phase of the nonlinear polarization wave.

title: Simultaneous Temperature and Strain Measurement by Using a Power-Interrogated Long-Period Fiber Grating
authors: Peng Wang; Keisuke Hishiki; Hongpu Li
abstract: A novel power-interrogated LPG sensor that allows for simultaneous measurement of temperature and strain is proposed and experimentally demonstrated. The proposed LPG here is simultaneously used as both the sensing and the interrogating element.

title: Photonic Sensors as Imaging Tools for Industrial Monitoring
authors: Cícero Martelli; Marco J. da Silva; Jean Carlos Cardozo da Silva; Rigoberto Morales; Erlon V. da Silva; Carlos R. Zamarreño; Virgínia Baroncini; Felipe Mezzadri; Rodolfo L. Patyk; Guilherme Dutra; João Paulo Bazzo; Tiago P. Vendruscolo
abstract: Single point, quasi-distributed and distributed optical (fiber) sensors are demonstrated to be robust and reliable tools for one, two and three dimensional imaging of physical phenomena in industrial monitoring. Real world results are presented.

title: Acoustically Induced Increase of Bragg Grating Bandwidth in Four Holes Suspended Core Fiber
authors: Ricardo E. da Silva; Martin Becker; Manfred Rothhardt; Alexandre de Almeida Prado Pohl; Hartmut Bartelt
corresponding_authors: Ricardo E. da Silva; Martin Becker; Manfred Rothhardt; Alexandre de Almeida Prado Pohl; Hartmut Bartelt
abstract: The acousto-optic induced modulation of fiber Bragg gratings in a suspended core fiber is experimentally demonstrated. The grating bandwidth is increased by up to 57%, which is tunable by 10 V of an electric signal.

title: Who needs contacts? Optical fiber poling by induction
authors: Ding Huang; Francesco De Lucia; N. Healy; C. Corbari; Pier J. A. Sazio
abstract: Conventional thermal poling methods require direct physical contact to internal fibers electrodes. Here, we report a novel indirect method in which external fields are used to charge floating internal electrodes to generate depletion regions for SHG.

title: Guiding and Steering Light With Nanocolloids
authors: Roland A. Terborg; Juan P. Torres; Karen Volke-Sepúlveda
corresponding_authors: Roland A. Terborg; Juan P. Torres; Karen Volke-Sepúlveda
abstract: We experimentally demonstrate steering and guiding of a low power beam (633nm) by a light-induced waveguide created by self-focusing of a pump beam (532nm) in a nonlinear medium consisting of a suspension of dielectric nanoparticles.

title: Modeling the Dynamics of Frequency Comb Generation and Design of Planar Microring Resonators
authors: Tobias Hansson
corresponding_authors: Tobias Hansson
abstract: We model wideband Kerr frequency comb generation in planar microring resonators. We show that the dispersion can be engineered by suitably designing the microrings, and the dynamics of the frequency comb generation process is considered.

title: Controlling Second-Harmonic Generation by Electro-optic Photonic Crystals
authors: Yuping Chen; Guangzhen Li; Haowei Jiang; Xianfeng Chen
corresponding_authors: Yuping Chen; Guangzhen Li; Haowei Jiang; Xianfeng Chen
abstract: We propose and experimentally demonstrate controlling second-harmonic generation in electro-optic photonic crystals constructed by cascading Pockels effects. The second harmonic spectrum shifts toward the transmission bandgap when they are overlapped due to effective nonlinear phase shifts for the cascading polarization coupling.

title: Coherent THz imaging using the self-mixing effect in quantum cascade lasers
authors: Paul Dean; Thomas Taimre; Hoi-Shun Lui; Karl Bertling; Yah Leng Lim; A. Valavanis; James Keeley; R. Alhathlool; Sourav Das Chowdhury; Lianhe Li; Suraj P. Khanna; M. Lachab; D. Indjin; Aleksandar D. Rakić; E. H. Linfield; A. G. Davies
abstract: We demonstrate that the self-mixing effect in terahertz frequency quantum cascade lasers can be used for three-dimensional coherent imaging; swept-frequency interferometry for imaging and materials analysis; and, high-resolution inverse synthetic aperture radar imaging.

title: OAM mode converter in twisted fibers
authors: Mario A. Usuga; Felipe Beltrán-Mejía; Cristiano M. B. Cordeiro; Idelfonso Tafur Monroy
abstract: We analyze the case of an OAM mode converter based on a twisted fiber, through finite element simulations where we exploit an equivalence between geometric and material transformations. The obtained converter has potential applications in MDM. © 2014 OSA.

title: Functionalization Strategies for Biointerfaces between Optical Structures and Biochemical Targets – the Good, the Bad, and the Not-So-Ugly
authors: Chris R. Taitt
corresponding_authors: Chris R. Taitt
abstract: Immobilization of biomolecules can be accomplished through a number of different approaches. While each approach has its advantages and drawbacks, some results are not easily predicted. This talk highlights some unusual and unexpected results we and others have observed.

title: Point-of-care diagnostics using integrated optical-based interferometric nanobiosensors
authors: Daphné Duval; Ana Belén González‐Guerrero; S. Dante; César S. Huertas; Jesús Maldonado; Laura M. Lechuga
abstract: We present our last advances towards the achievement of a portable and label-free point-of-care platform based on bimodal waveguide interferometers for proteomics, genomics, and environmental applications.

title: Gratings in Polymer Fibres
authors: D. J. Webb
corresponding_authors: D. J. Webb
abstract: We report on recent progress in polymer optical fibre grating sensors, covering developments in our understanding of the fundamental behaviour of the devices, improvements to the usability of the technology and the opening up of new applications.

title: Sensitivity enhanced SRI sensor based on an Ex-TFG in thin cladding fiber
authors: Zhijun Yan; Songsong Xiong; Zhongyuan Sun; Binbin Luo; Changle Wang; Cheng Li; Chengbo Mou; Kaiming Zhou; Lin Zhang
abstract: A high sensitivity SRI sensor was fabricated by inscribing an ex-TFG in a thin cladding fiber, achieving enhanced SRI sensitivities of the TM and TE resonance peaks around 1180nm/RIU and 1150nm/RIU at the index of 1.345.

title: Fibre Optic Hydrogen Sulphide Gas Sensor Utilizing Cu/ZnO Nanoparticles
authors: Satyendra K. Mishra; Charul Varshney; Banshi D. Gupta
abstract: In this paper we report the fabrication and characterization of a fiber optic H2S gas sensor utilizing zinc oxide (ZnO) nanoparticles. The sensor works on wavelength modulation scheme. The resonance wavelength increases with gas concentration.

title: Specialty Fibres and Components for Advanced Microscopy
authors: Lucas Lago; C. Corbari; A. V. Gladyshev; Peter G. Kazansky; Oleksandr Tarasenko; Walter Margulis; Y. Hernandez
abstract: We investigate fibre basic functions like SHG and pulse gating. We achieved 5.2% conversion efficiency into green light with 50 W peak pump power and demonstrated in-fibre pulse gating at 1 MHz repetition rate.

title: Ultrafast (THz-bandwidth) Photonic Hilbert Transformer Based On a Fiber Bragg Grating in Transmission
authors: María R. Fernández‐Ruiz; Alejandro Carballar; José Azaña
abstract: A fiber-based photonic Hilbert transformer with an unprecedented 2.5 THz bandwidth is presented, using a feasible linearly chirped fiber Bragg grating (FBG) in transmission. Critical parameters are compared considering different FBG-implementations.

title: Using Tunable Nanoscale Confinement to Image and Manipulate DNA
authors: Daniel Berard; Jason S. Leith; François Michaud; Sabrina Leslie
abstract: We present a modular microscopy device that transforms a basic inverted fluorescence microscope into a versatile single-molecule imaging and diagnostic system, with applications in the biomedical, biophysical and materials sciences. The device employs a recently developed and accessible imaging approach, Convex Lens- Induced Confinement (CLIC), delivering key advantages based on its tunable nanoscale imaging geometry: sensitive detection and enhanced background suppression; minimal required analyte volume (~μL); direct visualization of molecular interactions and dynamics over extended time periods (seconds to minutes); and direct manipulation of molecular conformations [1]. The presented CLIC device loads the sample into a flow-cell using a microfluidics system and mechanically deforms the flow-cell, creating a tunable, nanoscale imaging chamber. A powerful feature of CLIC imaging is the ability to manipulate and visualize single molecules under a continuum of applied confinement, from the micrometer to nanometer scale. It overcomes a key challenge faced by existing nanofluidic technologies of delivering molecules from a microscale loading environment into a nanoscale imaging environment. We demonstrate the device's ability to manipulate the conformations of DNA molecules in free-solution, providing a new approach to partitioning and probing their physical properties. Further, combining CLIC imaging with surface-lithography presents a powerful approach to controllably manipulating and trapping molecules over a wide range of imaging conditions.

title: Multiple appearances and disappearances of Fermi Pasta Ulam Recurrence due to reversible and irreversible losses in Nonlinear Fiber Optics
authors: Arnaud Mussot; Alexandre Kudlinski; Maxime Droques; Pascal Szriftgiser; Nail Akhmediev
abstract: We have found experimentally and numerically, that the Fermi Pasta Ulam (FPU) recurrence is strongly influenced by the third-order dispersion (TOD) term. Namely, its presence leads to several disappearances and recoveries of the FPU recurrence when the central frequency of the pump wave is varied. The effect is highly non-trivial and can be explained in terms of reversible and irreversible losses caused by Cherenkov radiations interacting with signal harmonics of the modulation instability process.

title: Broadband parametric processes in quadratic nonlinear photonic crystals
authors: Matteo Conforti; Fabio Baronio; Martin Levenius; Katia Gallo
abstract: We develop a general model, based on a (2+1)D unidirectional pulse propagation equation, for describing broadband noncollinear parametric interactions in two-dimensional quadratic lattices. We apply it to the analysis of twin-beam optical parametric generation in hexagonally poled LiTaO3, gaining further insights into experimental observations.

title: Experimental Observation of Auto-Oscillations in Nonlinear Optical Correlator
authors: S. Bugaychuk; I.I. Pryadko; V. Gnatovskiy; L. Pryadko; N. V. Medvid
abstract: Auto-oscillations are found experimentally in the optical correlator based on nonlinear interaction of periodic fields. Their appearance may be explained by generating a dynamical moving grating in nonlinear medium, which is included into the correlator.

title: Femtosecond single-beam direct laser poling of silver-doped oxide glasses : correlation between fluorescence, metallic nanoparticles precipitation and effective second-order nonlinear optical properties
authors: Marie Vangheluwe; Yannick Petit; Nicolas Marquestaut; Patricia Hée; Alexia Corcoran; Benjamin Gaufrès; Alexandre Fargues; Feng Liang; Évelyne Fargin; Thierry Cardinal; Réal Vallée; Lionel Canioni
abstract: We study spatial distribution, stability and correlation of linear and nonlinear optical properties made by femtosecond laser writing in silver-containing oxide glasses. The results provide relevant approaches to design nonlinear photonic structures.

title: Hyperspectral Backscattering Imaging Using Gold-Silver Alloy Plasmonics Nanoparticles as Chromatic Biomarkers
authors: David Rioux; Sergiy Patskovsky; Éric Bergeron; Michel Meunier
abstract: Gold-silver alloy nanoparticles (ANPs) are used as chromatic biomarkers to label cells. An epi-illumination configuration is used for hyperspectral backscattering imaging of the ANPs in cellular environment. Spectral identification of the ANPs is performed on the hyperspectral image.

title: Distortionless analog photonic link employing optical phase sensitive amplification
authors: Tarek Labidi; Ihsan Fsaifes; Fabienne Goldfarb; Fabien Bretenaker
abstract: The linearity of an analog photonic link employing phase sensitive optical parametric amplification is demonstrated by performing third order intermodulation distortion products measurements using two RF tones. Amplification without any distortion increase is obtained.

title: High-energy nanosecond-pulses from a flat-top mode 50 μm-core ytterbium-doped leakage channel fiber
authors: Pierre Calvet; A. Perrin; Pierre Gouriou; Bryce Samson; Thomas W. Hawkins; F. Kong; D. Liang; P. Dupriez; Emmanuel Hugonnot
abstract: A flat-top mode 50μm-core ytterbium-doped leakage channel fiber has been used as a high-energy stage in a fiber MOPA. More than 1.4 mJ pulses have been obtained in the few nanoseconds and narrow bandwidth regime at 10 kHz with a flattened output beam

title: Water on Au films
authors: John Canning; N. Tzoumis; James K. Beattie
corresponding_authors: John Canning; N. Tzoumis; James K. Beattie
abstract: The interaction between deionized water and gold is shown to occur with just water immersion. A reduction in measured contact angles of ~ 10 deg is observed. This recovers over time, accelerated by heating.

title: Generation and Control of Isolated Attosecond Pulses by Fiber-Compressed Sub-Cycle Pulses
authors: Wei-Chun Chu; Ka Fai Mak; John C. Travers; P. St. J. Russell
abstract: High-harmonic generation driven by 2-fs self-compressed pulses from an argon-filled kagome photonic-crystal fiber is investigated with the 1D atom model. The input carrier-envelope phase strongly modulates the simulated attosecond-pulse emission.

title: Gapless Dual THz Comb Spectroscopy
authors: Takeshi Yasui
corresponding_authors: Takeshi Yasui
abstract: We applied the gapless THz comb for high-precision gas spectroscopy by combination of dual THz comb spectroscopy and spectrally interleaving technique. This method enhanced the spectral resolution to the comb-mode linewidth rather than its interval.

title: Solitons that are too Short in Duration
authors: Shalva Amiranashvili; Uwe Bandelow; Nail Akhmediev
abstract: Optical solitons cannot go beyond the critical single-cycle duration even for the most favorable medium dispersion. A universal feature that prohibits existence of too short solitons is an unavoidable formation of the singular cusp.

title: Efficient Continuous Wave Conversion of Light Beyond the Half-Bandgap Spectral Region of Silicon
authors: François Léo; Bart Kuyken; Roel Baets; Günther Roelkens
abstract: The efficient conversion of light with photon energies lower than the halfband-gap-energy is reported. Record efficiencies are demonstrated in a 7cm dispersion engineered silicon photonic wire at a pump power of 150 mW.

title: Multi-stability and polariton solitons in microcavity polaritonic wires
authors: G. Slavcheva; A. V. Gorbach; Alexander Pimenov; Dmitry V. Skryabin
corresponding_authors: G. Slavcheva; A. V. Gorbach; Alexander Pimenov; Dmitry V. Skryabin
abstract: We present theoretical and numerical study of nonlinear effects in microcavity polaritonic wires. We report that the typical microcavity bistability is replaced with multi-stability and study parametric generation and dynamics of polariton solitons in these wire waveguides.

title: Extreme events in Q-switched lasers
authors: F. M. de Aguiar; J. R. Rios Leite; Cyrille Métayer; Thomas Quiniou; A. Serres; J. R. Tredicce; Alejandro Hnilo; Marcelo G. Kovalsky
abstract: Since optical rogue waves (RWs) were first reported by Solli et al. in 2007 [1], the study of extreme pulses in optical systems has been a very active research field [2]. In semiconductor lasers, ultra-high intensity pulses occur when the laser is subjected to optical injection [3], [4]. RWs induced by the interplay of multistability and noise in a erbium-doped fiber laser (EDFL) have also been reported [5].

title: P T-symmetric coupler with randomly varying parameters
authors: V. V. Konotop; Dmitry A. Zezyulin
abstract: We consider a stochastic P T-symmetric coupler with fluctuating parameters, which in average preserve conditions of exactly balanced gain and losses. We address different parametric regimes corresponding to the broken and unbroken P T symmetries.

title: Mode-Selective Sensing using Asymmetric Waveguide Junctions
authors: Gergely Zs. Racz; N. Bamiedakis; Richard V. Penty
abstract: An evanescent-wave absorption sensor based on mode-selective asymmetric waveguide junctions is proposed for the first time. The device mitigates the common optical effect of spurious response in absorption sensors due to the analyte transport fluid.

title: Power threshold of noise-seeded CW-pumped single-pass stimulated Raman-like scattering in dual-nanoweb fibre
authors: Roman E. Noskov; A. Butsch; J. R. Koehler; P. St. J. Russell
abstract: Flexural resonances in the dual-nanoweb fibre begin to oscillate upon pumping with mW of laser light, generating a frequency comb. Theory shows that structural inhomogeneities play an important role in determining the threshold power.

title: Metallic nanoslit array with nanoislands for multiplexed plasmonic sensor design
authors: Taerin Chung; Kyookeun Lee; Byoungho Lee
abstract: Metallic nanoslit array has been designed for the design of multiplexed plasmonic sensor. A metallic nanoslit with embedded metallic nanoislands gives rise to multiple peaks, resulting from plasmonic waveguide mode. In response to the spacing between embedded metallic nanoislands, the wavelength peaks can be tuned. Metallic nanoslit array with embedded nanoislands with various spacing can be used for designing a multiplexed plasmonic sensor for multi-analyte detection.

title: CdSiP2 optical parametric oscillator tunable across 6-8 μm synchronously pumped by a Ti:sapphire laser
authors: Venkata Ramaiah Badarla; A. Esteban-Martín; S. Chaitanya Kumar; Kavita Devi; Kevin T. Zawilski; Peter G. Schunemann; M. Ebrahim-Zadeh
corresponding_authors: Venkata Ramaiah Badarla; A. Esteban-Martín; S. Chaitanya Kumar; Kavita Devi; Kevin T. Zawilski; Peter G. Schunemann; M. Ebrahim-Zadeh
abstract: We report the first ultrafast OPO based on CdSiP2 synchronously-pumped by a KLM Ti:sapphire laser, continuously tunable across ~6-8 μm in deep-IR under rapid static cavity length tuning, with high output stability, at room temperature.

title: Selective Compression of Temporally Splitted Femtosecond Pulses and Nonlinear Effects under Dynamical Bragg Diffraction in 1D Photonic Crystals
authors: S. E. Svyakhovskiy; A. A. Skorynin; V. A. Bushuev; С. В. Чекалин; Lidiya V. Frolova; V. O. Kompanets; A. I. Maidykovskiy; T. V. Murzina; B. I. Mantsyzov
abstract: Temporal splitting of chirped femtosecond pulses and the Laue soliton propagation under the dynamical Bragg diffraction in the Laue scheme in 1D porous quartz-based photonic crystals are studied theoretically and experimentally. We have observed the selective compression of frequency-modulated splitted pulses, i., the compression of either the fast Borrmann or slow anti-Borrmann pulses, depending on the sign of the input signal frequency modulation.

title: Self-focusing of Optical Beams Below the Diffraction Limit
authors: Christopher Travis; Gail McConnell; Johanna Trägårdh; Alison M. Yao; Gian‐Luca Oppo
abstract: We present simulations of the self-focusing effect in nonlinear media for cw and pulsed input. Although some energy is lost during the process, the resulting self-trapped beams have widths below Abbe's diffraction limit.

title: THz Parametric Amplifier Using LiNbO3 Crystal
authors: Kodo Kawase; Kosuke Murate; Shin’ichiro Hayashi; Hiroaki Minamide
corresponding_authors: Kodo Kawase; Kosuke Murate; Shin’ichiro Hayashi; Hiroaki Minamide
abstract: The importance of terahertz (THz) wave techniques has been demonstrated in various fields and the range of applications is now expanding rapidly. However, the practical implementation of THz science in the civil theatre is restricted due to the lack not only of convenient high power THz wave emitters and sensitive detectors but also of efficient quasi-optical active devices such as amplifiers. In this work, we demonstrated the direct amplification of THz waves using Magnesium doped Lithium Niobate (MgO: LiNbO3) crystals as the non-linear gain medium. The input THz wave was injected as a seed beam along with the pump beam into the non-linear crystal and it was amplified by the optical parametric process. We report gain in excess of 50dB with an input THz pulse energy of less than 20 aJ. We believe that this demonstration will contribute to the convenience and further applicability of THz sensing techniques.

title: Rogue Wave Structures in Spontaneous Modulation Instability
authors: Shanti Toenger; Goëry Genty; Frédéric Dias; Miro Erkintalo; John M. Dudley
abstract: Simulations of the stochastic nonlinear Schrodinger equation show analytic localized structures solutions emerging spontaneously from chaotic modulation instability. Statistical analysis identifies the extreme events with higher-order breather.

title: Quantitative Mode Quality Characterization in a Leakage Channel Fiber with 100 μm Core Diameter
authors: Fanting Kong; Guancheng Gu; Thomas W. Hawkins; Joshua Parsons; Maxwell Jones; Christopher Dunn; Monica T. Kalichevsky-Dong; Stephen P. Palese; Eric Cheung; Dong Liang
abstract: We demonstrate a novel white-light interferometry with ~20fs temporal resolution for quantitative mode characterization in a 100μm-core leakage channel fiber, obtaining ~55fs/m intermodal group delay and >~29dB/m higher order modes suppression.

title: Localized Surface Plasmon Resonances for Sensing Applicaions
authors: E. Popov; A.-L. Fehrembach; Nadège Rassem
abstract: Using a rigorous electromagnetic method based on a curvilinear transformation of the coordinate system, we demonstrate the role of localized surface plasmon resonances on deep two-dimensional metallic gratings in enhancing the sensibility of optical sensing of several nanometer thin layers deposited on the grating surface. Comparison with the non-localized surface plasmons on shallow gratings shows that a significant enhancement and strong localization of electric field intensity can be obtained when using deep corrugation.

title: Demonstration of 4.4 dB on-off Brillouin gain in a silicon photonic wire
authors: Raphaël Van Laer; Bart Kuyken; Dries Van Thourhout; Roel Baets
abstract: We experimentally show record 4.4 dB continuous-wave on-off Brillouin gain in a partially underetched silicon wire. Additional improvements in optical losses and mechanical confinement may enable clear net gain in this structure.

title: Nonlinear Optical Holography
authors: Ady Arie
corresponding_authors: Ady Arie
abstract: Coding schemes for designing computer generated holograms can be implemented in nonlinear optics. Spatial modulation of the quadratic nonlinearity enables to arbitrarily shape the amplitude, phase and spectrum of the frequency converted beam.

title: Wavelength tunable Yb3+-doped fiber laser based on an all-fiber geometry with fiber Bragg grating arrays
authors: Tobias Tieß; Matthias Jäger; Manfred Rothhardt; Christoph Chojetzki; Hartmut Bartelt
corresponding_authors: Tobias Tieß; Matthias Jäger; Manfred Rothhardt; Christoph Chojetzki; Hartmut Bartelt
abstract: We present a method to tune the emission wavelength of pulsed fiber lasers using stepchirped fiber Bragg grating arrays as filters. First experimental results demonstrate excellent spectral characteristics and a tuning range of 18 nm.

title: Plasmonic gas and glucose sensing using resonant nanoantennas
authors: Harald Gießen
corresponding_authors: Harald Gießen
abstract: We use resonant plasmonic nanoantennas for detection of glucose at physiological levels in the tear liquid, as well as for hydrogen gas at the lower explosive level concentration and CO in the mid-IR using vibration.

title: Spontaneous degenerate four-wave mixing in hybrid photonic crystal fibers
authors: Sidsel R. Petersen; Jesper Lægsgaard; Thomas Tanggaard Alkeskjold
abstract: Frequency conversion through spontaneous degenerate four-wave mixing in large mode area hybrid photonic crystal fibers is considered. Intra- and intermodal four-wave mixing across photonic bandgaps is observed, with generation efficiencies up to 17 %.

title: Optical Switching by Nonlinear Lightwave Circuits Inscribed in Chalcogenide Glass by Ultrafast Laser
authors: Mingshan Li; Sheng Huang; Qingqing Wang; Kevin P. Chen
abstract: We report nonlinear lightwave circuits inscribed in chalcogenide glass by ultrafast laser. Exploiting the large nonlinearity of the material, optical switching is demonstrated with reduced power in 1D waveguide array and waveguide Bragg grating.

title: Nonlinear Mid-Infrared Photothermal Spectroscopy with Fiber Laser Probe
authors: Michelle Y. Sander; Atcha Totachawattana; Hui Liu; Alket Mërtiri; Mi K. Hong; Shyamsunder Erramilli
corresponding_authors: Michelle Y. Sander; Atcha Totachawattana; Hui Liu; Alket Mërtiri; Mi K. Hong; Shyamsunder Erramilli
abstract: Nonlinear mid-infrared photothermal spectroscopy with an erbium-doped fiber laser probe is reported for a liquid crystal, using a tunable quantum cascade laser pump. Extreme nonlinear spectral enhancements are observed compared to the linear regime.

title: Fabrication and performance of Er-doped phase-separated alumino-silicate based optical fiber for fiber amplifier
authors: Mukul Chandra Paul; Anirban Dhar; Shyamal Das; Mrinmay Pal
abstract: Fabrication of Er-doped phase-separated SiO2-Al2O3 glass based preform using conventional MCVD-SD technique is presented. The fiber developed exhibits better optical and spectral performance in C-band region compare to known silica-based counterpart.

title: Electron-Transfer Kinetics in Protein Assemblies by Single-Mode Electro-Active Integrated Optical Waveguides
authors: Xue Han; Sergio B. Mendes
abstract: An optical impedance spectroscopy (OIS) technique based on a single-mode electro-active integrated optical waveguide (EA-IOW) was developed to investigate electron-transfer processes of redox adsorbates. A highly sensitive single-mode EA-IOW device was created to optically follow the time-dependent faradaic current originated from a sub-monolayer of cytochrome c protein species undergoing redox exchanges driven by a harmonic modulation of the electric potential at several DC bias potentials and at several frequencies. To properly retrieve the faradaic current density from the AC-modulated optical signal we introduce a mathematical formalism that i) accounts for intrinsic changes that invariably occur in the optical baseline of the EA-IOW device during potential modulation and ii) provides accurate results for the electrochemical parameters. We experimentally demonstrate the optical reconstruction of the faradaic current density, identify the formal potential and energy-width of the electron-transfer process, and determine the reaction rate constant of the charge-transfer process. Our experimental approach brings additional sensitivity, accuracy, and simplicity to electrochemical analysis, and is expected to become a useful tool in investigations of currently challenging redox processes.

title: Mid-IR Few-Cycle Pulse Generation by Two-Pulse Collision
authors: Ayhan Demircan; Shalva Amiranashvili; Carsten Brée; Uwe Morgner; Günter Steinmeyer
abstract: We propose a novel adjustable compression scheme by two-color pumping, enabling a coherent pulse source with pedestal-free few-cycle pulses in the mid-infrared regime directly in one stage, without necessity of an external compensation scheme.

title: Self-induced photonic structures in lithium niobate Fabry-Perot interferometer
authors: A. S. Perin; V. Ryabchenok; V. Shandarov
abstract: The results of experimental study of self-induced one-dimensional structures in lithium niobate Fabry-Perot interferometer are discussed. It has been shown that their spatial periods depend on the light propagation direction within the crystal plate.

title: Coming to Grips with Amyloid Oligomers: Single Molecule Photobleaching Approaches
authors: Vinod Subramaniam
corresponding_authors: Vinod Subramaniam
abstract: We report on using single molecule photobleaching spectroscopy to determine the molecular aggregation number of specific nanometer-scale supramolecular oligomeric aggregates formed by the misfolding and self-assembly of proteins involved in neurodegenerative diseases.

title: Theoretical Description of Pulse Evolution and Phase Sensitive Amplification in Silicon Waveguides
authors: Y. Zhang; Chad Husko; Jochen Schröder; Benjamin J. Eggleton
abstract: We provide an analytic solution for pulse propagation and phase sensitive amplification in the regime of high nonlinearity in silicon waveguides including two-photon absorption (TPA) and free carriers. Excellent agreement with experimental results validates our analytic approach and indicates free carriers saturate the gain.

title: Soliton-Soliton Collision Enhanced Dispersive Wave Emission in Microstructured Fiber
authors: A. Tonello; D. Modotto; Katarzyna Krupa; Alexis Labruyère; Badr Mohamed Ibrahim Shalaby; Vincent Couderc; A. Barthélémy; Umberto Minoni; S. Wabnitz; A. B. Aceves
corresponding_authors: A. Tonello; D. Modotto; Katarzyna Krupa; Alexis Labruyère; Badr Mohamed Ibrahim Shalaby; Vincent Couderc; A. Barthélémy; Umberto Minoni; S. Wabnitz; A. B. Aceves
abstract: We developed an analytical approach to estimate the influence of soliton-soliton collision on the growth rate of dispersive waves in optical fibers. Our theoretical model shows an excellent agreement with numerical results.

title: Tuning the FBG period with a spatial light modulator
authors: Christian Voigtländer; Ria G. Krämer; Jens Thomas; Daniel Richter; Stefan Nolte
corresponding_authors: Christian Voigtländer; Ria G. Krämer; Jens Thomas; Daniel Richter; Stefan Nolte
abstract: We present uniform and chirped fiber Bragg gratings inscribed using femtosecond pulses with a deformed wavefront generated by a spatial light modulator. The dependence of the grating properties on different aberrations is investigated.

title: Analysis of Rogue Wave Phenomenon in Optical Fiber Based on Soliton’s Eigenvalue
authors: Gihan Weerasekara; Akihiro Tokunaga; Hiroki Terauchi; M. Eberhard; Akihiro Maruta
abstract: The impact of third-order dispersion (TOD) on optical rogue wave phenomenon is investigated numerically. We validate the TOD coefficient by utilizing the eigenvalue of the associated equation of the nonlinear Schrödinger equation (NLSE).

title: Multiple Equilibrium States of Soliton Molecules
authors: A. Hause; F. Mitschke
abstract: Bound fiber-optic dispersion-managed solitons are investigated. A sequence of alternatingly stable and unstable equilibria arises when the pulse separation is increased. It terminates at a point defined by the radiation background.

title: Tungstate-Tellurite Glass Microstructured Optical Fibers
authors: V. V. Dorofeev; А. Н. Моисеев; A. F. Kosolapov; В. Г. Плотниченко; Sergey V. Muraviov; M. Yu. Koptev; A. V. Kim
corresponding_authors: V. V. Dorofeev; А. Н. Моисеев; A. F. Kosolapov; В. Г. Плотниченко; Sergey V. Muraviov; M. Yu. Koptev; A. V. Kim
abstract: Suspended core microstructured optical fibers were fabricated of TeO2-WO3-La2O3 glass with reduced content of 3d-transition metals and hydroxyl groups impurities by drilled preforms stretching. Total loss in the best sample was less than 3 dB/m within 1-2 μm with minimum of 0.7 dB/m at 1.4 μm. The broadband emission with 1300 nm bandwidth was successfully generated in 0.8 m of TWL fiber using 2 nJ femtosecond laser as a source.

title: Designs of Large Mode Area Solid-Core Photonic Bandgap Fibers for High Power Applications
authors: Y. Quiquempois; A.I. Baz; Pierre Calvet; Géraud Bouwmans; Hicham El Hamzaoui; Emmanuel Hugonnot; Mohamed Bouazaoui; Olivier Vanvincq; M. Douay; Laurent Bigot
abstract: Solid-Core Photonic BandGap Fibers (SC-PBGF) are interesting candidates for high power delivery and laser/amplifier fiber applications due to their specific guiding properties. For example, mode diameters as large as 36 μm can be obtained in a flexible Yb3+ -doped SC-PBGF with bending radius as small as 10 cm. In addition to specific fiber designs, large diameter pure-silica Yb3+ -doped monoliths are used as raw material for the active core, enabling a reduced refractive index increase as compared to silica. Recent advances will be discussed during this talk.

title: Tunable Anisotropic Strain in Laser Crystallized Silicon Core Optical Fibers
authors: N. Healy; S. Mailis; Nadezhda M. Bulgakova; T. D. Day; Pier J. A. Sazio; J. V. Badding; Anna C. Peacock
corresponding_authors: N. Healy; S. Mailis; Nadezhda M. Bulgakova; T. D. Day; Pier J. A. Sazio; J. V. Badding; Anna C. Peacock
abstract: A laser processing method for tuning the size of the anisotropic strain in a silicon core optical fiber is demonstrated. We propose that this technique can be used to modify the core's opto-electronic properties for applications with specific requirements.

title: Up-Scalable Method to Amplify the 1st Order Transmittance of Simple Gratings
authors: Fabian Lütolf; M. Stalder; Olivier J. F. Martin
corresponding_authors: Fabian Lütolf; M. Stalder; Olivier J. F. Martin
abstract: Shadow evaporation is used to asymmetrically coat binary gratings and enhance the diffraction efficiency into a single order. First order transmittances of close to 70% are achieved experimentally for perpendicularly incident, non-polarized light.

title: Femtosecond laser induced material modifications to control stress states in silica
authors: Yves Bellouard
corresponding_authors: Yves Bellouard
abstract: Femtosecond laser exposure of silica in the non-ablative regime induces localized volume changes resulting in a stress-field surrounding laser affected zones. Here, we review these effects and illustrate potential applications of laser-induced controlled stress-state in silica.

title: Foundations of photonic crystal fibres: a review
authors: Gilles Renversez
corresponding_authors: Gilles Renversez
abstract: In this tutorial, we review the main types and main linear properties of microstructured optical fibers (MOFs) also called photonic crystal fibers (PCFs). We explain both solid core and hollow core MOF guidance mechanisms. We also describe finite size effects that can not be neglected for many applications.

title: Broadly Tunable Room Temperature Monolithic Terahertz Quantum Cascade Laser Sources
authors: Seungyong Jung; Aiting Jiang; Yifan Jiang; Karun Vijayraghavan; Xiaojun Wang; Mariano Troccoli; Frederic Demmerle; Gerhard Boehm; Markus-Christian Amann; Mikhail A. Belkin
abstract: We demonstrate monolithic tunable terahertz quantum cascades laser sources with a tuning range over 580 GHz at room temperature by integrating electrically separated distributed feedback section and distributed Bragg reflector section into a single device.

title: Post-processing Fibers for Sensing Applications
authors: Orlando Frazão; Marta S. Ferreira; Ricardo M. André; Susana Silva; Manuel B. Marques; J. L. Santos
abstract: A review in fiber post-processing for sensing applications is presented. The review is divided in three parts. Tapers devices, chemical etching for Fabry-Perot cavities and focused ion beam (FIB) as post-processing applied in optical fibers are considered. The most recent results as sensing elements are shown.

title: Phosphate glass fibers for optical amplifier applications
authors: Joris Lousteau; Gerardo Cristian Scarpignato; Nadia G. Boetti; Diego Pugliese; Daniel Milanese
abstract: We report on the development and characterization of phosphate glass optical fibers for laser and optical amplifier applications. We discuss preliminary results on the implementation of compact fiber lasers and optical amplifiers.

title: Simultaneous Force and Temperature Measurement using Optical Microfiber Asymmetrical Interferometer
authors: Caibin Yu; Yuan Gong; Yu Wu; Yunjiang Rao; Gang‐Ding Peng
abstract: A novel optical microfiber asymmetric Fabry-Perot interferometric (MAFPI) sensor is developed for simultaneous measurement of force and temperature. Sensitivities of 9.8 pm/°C and 0.025 dB/μN are obtained experimentally for temperature and force measurements, respectively.

title: Control of Ultrafast Laser Nanostructuring of Glasses using Temporal and Spatial Pulse Design
authors: Razvan Stoian; Konstantin Mishchik; Cyril Mauclair; Praveen Kumar Velpula; M. K. Bhuyan; Jean‐Philippe Colombier; Ciro D’Amico; M. Zamfirescu; Guanghua Cheng
abstract: Laser transformation of optical glasses depends on the rate of energy feedthrough, affecting the resulting function. We discuss the role of spatio-temporal design of laser pulses in 3D nanostructuring either via self-arrangements or direct writing.

title: Raman-induced soliton oscillations and tunneling in gas-filled photonic crystal fibers
authors: Mohammed F. Saleh; Federico Belli; A. Abdolvand; Andrea Marini; Andrea Armaroli; John C. Travers; P. St. J. Russell; Fabio Biancalana
corresponding_authors: Mohammed F. Saleh; Federico Belli; A. Abdolvand; Andrea Marini; Andrea Armaroli; John C. Travers; P. St. J. Russell; Fabio Biancalana
abstract: We have developed an analytical model to study pulse propagation in photonic crystal fibers filled by Raman-active gases. Solitons can show oscillations and tunneling inside the Raman-induced sinusoidal temporal potential in these fibers.

title: Time-domain optical signal processing based on discrete space-to-time mapping in cascaded co-directional couplers
authors: Hamed Pishvai Bazargani; Reza Ashrafi; José Azaña
abstract: A novel optical signal processing scheme based on cascaded co-directional couplers is proposed and numerically demonstrated. The proposed approach can overcome important limitations of grating-assisted coupler structures.

title: Scattering assisted launch of SPR modes in Au films
authors: John Canning; Akib Karim; N. Tzoumis; Yanzhen Tan; Rodolfo L. Patyk; Patrick Trimby
corresponding_authors: John Canning; Akib Karim; N. Tzoumis; Yanzhen Tan; Rodolfo L. Patyk; Patrick Trimby
abstract: We report the excitation of a surface plasmon resonance (SPR) close to the orthogonal axis of a gold (Au) film on borosilicate glass. The need for prisms is removed simplifying the practical requirements for photonic devices and sensors. Spectroscopic measurement of SPR spectral shifts ~5° incidence within a reflection spectrophotometer for two liquids are taken.

title: Polarization Independent, Tunable Waveguide Bragg Gratings in Lithium Niobate by Femtosecond Laser Micromachining
authors: S. Kroesen; Jörg Imbrock; Cornelia Denz
abstract: We report integration of two-dimensional waveguide Bragg gratings that support low loss, polarization independent guiding and tunable reflection spectra around λ=1.55 μm. Effective nonlinear coefficients of r13=7.73 pm/V and r33=25.62 pm/V are shown.

title: Fluorescent Ordered Structured Polymer Membranes: Facile Preparation and Application in Fluorescence Fiber-Optic Sensing
authors: Yunyun Huang; Zhuang Tian; Yang Ran; Li‐Peng Sun; Jie Li; Bai‐Ou Guan
abstract: Sensitive fluorescent membranes with different morphologies have been transferred to long period grating fiber (LPG) sensors by simple solvent-induced way. It combines polymer self-assembly with LPG fiber, promising a wide application in fluorescence optical sensors.

title: Origin, Control, and Predictability of Optical Rogue Waves in Semiconductor Lasers
authors: Jordi Zamora‐Munt; José A. Reinoso; Bruno Garbin; Stéphane Barland; M. Giudici; Jose Roberto Rios Leite; Cristina Masoller; Jorge R. Tredicce
corresponding_authors: Jordi Zamora‐Munt; José A. Reinoso; Bruno Garbin; Stéphane Barland; M. Giudici; Jose Roberto Rios Leite; Cristina Masoller; Jorge R. Tredicce
abstract: We show that optical rogue waves in the form of sharp abnormally large intensity pulses can be predicted with long anticipation times, that they are generated by a crisis-like process, and that noise can be employed to either enhance or suppress their probability of occurrence. We support our findings with numerical simulations and experimental results. By providing a good understanding of the mechanisms triggering and controlling the rogue waves, we can compare the extreme intensity pulses generated in a semiconductor laser with cw optical injection and with an external optical feedback in the short cavity regime. Despite the different mechanisms behind the generation of extreme intensity pulses we show that both systems have similar behaviors.

authors: Eric Y. Zhu; Li Qian; C. Corbari; A. V. Gladyshev; Peter G. Kazansky
abstract: We discuss the various aspects of polarization-entangled photon pair generation in a poled fiber, including the role that fiber birefringence and dispersion play. The broadband nature of the fiber source is demonstrated, and the downconversion spectrum is measured.

title: The Next Generation CCD or CMOS Lens-free Microscopy for Bio-medical and Material Processing Analysis
authors: Valerio Pruneri
corresponding_authors: Valerio Pruneri
abstract: We will present SixSenso's low cost and portable devices for measuring scattering, reading microarrays, detecting and counting microorganisms, cells and particles, by exploiting full field of view CMOS or CCD at the highest resolution.

title: Size effects on bifurcations in nonlinear slots
authors: Wiktor Walasik; Yaroslav V. Kartashov; Gilles Renversez
corresponding_authors: Wiktor Walasik; Yaroslav V. Kartashov; Gilles Renversez
abstract: We study the nonlinear waves in symmetric metal slot waveguides with a Kerr-type core. Using semi-analytical models, we have found new higher order nonlinear modes and studied the influence of slot width on the observed bifurcations.

title: 3D Femtosecond Laser Processing: Towards Multi-functional Lab-in-Fibre
authors: Peter R. Herman; Jason R. Grenier; Moez Haque; Kenneth K. C. Lee
abstract: Oil immersion focusing of femtosecond laser light enables non-distorted patterning of refractive index and etching structures in fibre cladding, enabling 3D optical circuit, microfluidic, and optical resonator components to connect efficiently with the core waveguide.

title: Fano- and EIT-type Resonances in Surface Plasmon-Waveguide Hybrid Sensors
authors: Shinji Hayashi; Dmitry V. Nesterenko; Zouheir Sekkat
corresponding_authors: Shinji Hayashi; Dmitry V. Nesterenko; Zouheir Sekkat
abstract: Sharp Fano resonance and electromagnetically induced transparency (EIT) are demonstrated for a planar sensor structure. The sharp resonances are due to coupling between a surface plasmon mode and a waveguide mode.

title: Temporal dynamics of incoherent nonlinear waves
authors: Gang Xu; Josselin Garnier; S. Trillo; Bertrand Kibler; G. Millot; Pierre Suret; Stéphane Randoux; Antonio Picozzi
abstract: We review different formalisms describing temporal incoherent waves: the wave turbulence kinetic equation, the Vlasov equation in analogy with Gravitation, the weak Langmuir turbulence equation describing spectral incoherent solitons and incoherent dispersive shocks waves.

title: Integrated all-optical memories/switches in a photonic crystal chip
authors: Kengo Nozaki; Eiichi Kuramochi; Akihiko Shinya; Shinji Matsuo; Tomonari Sato; Masaya Notomi
corresponding_authors: Kengo Nozaki; Eiichi Kuramochi; Akihiko Shinya; Shinji Matsuo; Tomonari Sato; Masaya Notomi
abstract: Photonic crystal nanocavities were monolithically integrated to construct multi-channel all-optical switches and memories on Si and InP platform. Successful wavelength-addressing operations for more than 25 resonant channels were demonstrated with ultralow power consumption.

title: Ultrafast laser written integrated photonics: a quest for killer 3D applications
authors: Simon Gross; Izabela Spaleniak; Thomas Meany; Zachary Chaboyer; Alexander Arriola; Nemanja Jovanović; A. Fuerbach; L. G. Helt; M. J. Steel; Michael Ireland; Michael J. Withford
abstract: The challenges encountered by 3D laser written integrated photonics are both cultural and technical in nature. In this talk we will comment on the former, review the latter and highlight new 3D enabled applications.

title: High-energy ultrafast fiber lasers
authors: H. Wang; Mincheng Tang; Martin Baumgartl; C. Lecaplain; Thomas Schreiber; Jens Limpert; Andreas Tünnermann; Ammar Hideur
corresponding_authors: H. Wang; Mincheng Tang; Martin Baumgartl; C. Lecaplain; Thomas Schreiber; Jens Limpert; Andreas Tünnermann; Ammar Hideur
abstract: Recent progress in the development of mode-locked fiber oscillators has reached performance levels which make them directly suitable for applications without the need for complex amplifier systems. We discuss the key elements that enabled these advances.

title: Generation of reconfigurable photon-pair states in aperiodically poled quadratic waveguide arrays
authors: James Titchener; Alexander S. Solntsev; Andrey A. Sukhorukov
abstract: We propose special poling of quadratic nonlinear waveguide arrays enabling generation of photon pairs in any path entangled quantum state. Real-time switching between output quantum states can be achieved by varying classical input laser amplitudes.

title: Hollow-core photonic bandgap fiber cladding designs for third harmonic generation
authors: Z. Montz; Amiel A. Ishaaya
corresponding_authors: Z. Montz; Amiel A. Ishaaya
abstract: We present two novel silica cladding structures that have two well separated spectral bandgaps appropriate for frequency tripling. The low loss bandgaps are tens to hundreds of nm wide and support Gaussian like fundamental modes.

authors: Richard Al Hadi; Janusz Grzyb; Wolfgang Förster; Stefan Malz; H. Keller; Neelanjan Sarmah; Ullrich R. Pfeiffer

title: Liquid crystals as a matrix to induce an oriented polyfluorene β-phase
authors: Serena Bolis; Jeroen Beeckman; Pascal Kockaert; Tersilla Virgili
corresponding_authors: Serena Bolis; Jeroen Beeckman; Pascal Kockaert; Tersilla Virgili
abstract: Liquid crystals can induce β-phase of PFO with anisotropic absorption and emission spectra. Pump-probe spectra also show the presence of a stimulated emission band polarized parallel to the PFO chains.

title: Incoherent Dispersive Shocks and Spectral Collapse
authors: Gang Xu; Josselin Garnier; S. Trillo; Antonio Picozzi
abstract: We predict the existence of incoherent dispersive shock waves and collapse-like singularities that occur in the spectral evolution of incoherent optical waves propagating in a noninstantaneous nonlinear medium.

title: Interaction of Breathers in the Two-Component Discrete Nonlinear Schrödinger Equation
authors: Russell Campbell; Gian‐Luca Oppo; Mateusz Borkowski
abstract: Coupled discrete nonlinear Schrödinger equations describe two-species BEC in optical lattices or light polarization coupling in waveguide arrays. Elastic or inelastic collisions of travelling discrete breathers depend on the interaction parameter.

title: Dissipative Vector Solitons with Fast Evolving States of Polarization
authors: Sergey Sergeyev; Gunnar Jacobsen; Sergei Popov; Sergei K. Turitsyn
abstract: We report on a new vector model of an erbium doped fiber laser mode locked with carbon nanotubes. This model goes beyond the limitations of the previously used models based on either coupled nonlinear Schrödinger or Ginzburg-Landau equations. It results in a new family of vector solitons with fast evolving states of polarization experimentally observed in our previous papers.

title: Supercontinuum generation in silicon waveguides based on optical wave-breaking
authors: David Castelló‐Lurbe; Víctor Torres–Company; Enrique Silvestre
corresponding_authors: David Castelló‐Lurbe; Víctor Torres–Company; Enrique Silvestre
abstract: We theoretically find the third order dispersion that optimizes the spectral broadening induced by optical wave-breaking. It produces supercontinuum spectra spanning beyond 2/3 of an octave in a silicon waveguide pumping at 1550 nm.

title: RIN Transfer in Second-Order Raman Amplification with Centrally-Pumped Random Distributed Feedback Lasers
authors: Javier Nuño; Juan Diego Ania‐Castañón
corresponding_authors: Javier Nuño; Juan Diego Ania‐Castañón
abstract: The predicted RIN transfer function for 2nd-order amplification based on centrally-pumped RDFLs is studied over a broad range of lengths and signal powers. Transfer is shown to be generally higher than in a cavity URFLs.

title: All-Optical Add-Drop Multiplexing of OFDM Signals
authors: Stylianos Sygletos; Simon J. Fabbri; Andreas Perentos; Mariia Sorokina; A.D. Ellis
