title: In-line Few mode Optical Amplifiers for SDM Transmission
authors: Yongmin Jung
corresponding_authors: Yongmin Jung
abstract: A review of recent progress on the implementation of in-line few mode EDFAs for SDM transmission is provided. Additionally, the design and construction of fully fiberised few-mode EDFAs will be discussed and the key technical challenges described.

title: Polymer Fibre Bragg Gratings and Sensing
authors: Gang‐Ding Peng; Kishore Bhowmik; Ginu Rajan; Eliathamby Ambikairajah; D. J. Webb
abstract: Polymer FBGs have advantages for sensing because of low Young's modulus, high temperature sensitivity, large strain range and so on. They are attractive for many niche applications such as structural health monitoring of composite materials, biochemical and biomedical sensing. While polymer FBGs have been developed for some time, polymer microfibre Bragg gratings are developed only recently and have shown to introduce some interesting features, e.g. increased pressure sensitivity to pressure / force and improved response time to humidity. We will report and discuss the recent work on polymer FBG and polymer microfibre Bragg gratings as well as their applications such as accelerometer, humidity sensor and force and pressure sensor.

title: Plasmonic Metasurfaces to Steer Near-Field and Far-Field Optical Waves
authors: Yongmin Liu
corresponding_authors: Yongmin Liu
abstract: We present anomalous dispersion engineering of surface plasmons based on metallic grating metasurfaces, a new type of surface waves supported by bi-hyperbolic materials, and tunable graphene metasurfaces for far-field, infrared light steering.

title: Numerical study of extreme events and chaos in a laser diode with phase-conjugate feedback
authors: Émeric Mercier; Delphine Wolfersberger; Marc Sciamanna
abstract: A model adapted from the Lang-Kobayashi equations is used to qualitatively reproduce experimental dynamics observed in a laser diode with phase-conjugate feedback, such as extreme events (rogue waves) and chaotic low-frequency fluctuations.

title: Light propagation In Cavity Formed By Nonlinear Defect And Interface Between Two Different Linear Waveguide Arrays
authors: Slavica Kuzmanović; Marija Stojanović Krasić; Daniela Milović; A. Radosavljević; Goran Gligorić; Aleksandra Maluckov; Milutin Stepić
corresponding_authors: Slavica Kuzmanović; Marija Stojanović Krasić; Daniela Milović; A. Radosavljević; Goran Gligorić; Aleksandra Maluckov; Milutin Stepić
abstract: We study light propagation in the vicinity of nonlinear defect that is placed near the interface between disparate linear lattices. Various dynamical regimes including simultaneous excitation of different strongly localized cavity modes are observed.

title: Ultra-flat and broadband optical parametric amplification in highly nonlinear tellurite hybrid microstructured optical fibers
authors: Tong Hoang Tuan; Edmund Samuel; Tonglei Cheng; Zhongchao Duan; Koji Asano; Takenobu Suzuki; Yasutake Ohishi
corresponding_authors: Tong Hoang Tuan; Edmund Samuel; Tonglei Cheng; Zhongchao Duan; Koji Asano; Takenobu Suzuki; Yasutake Ohishi
abstract: It is shown that an ultra-flat gain bandwidth of 658 nm at 30 dB (± 0.01-dB gain fluctuation) can be obtained by dual-pump optical parametric amplification using highly nonlinear tellurite hybrid microstructured optical fibers (HMOFs).

title: Enhanced optical phase conjugation in nonlinear metamaterials
authors: Kihong Kim
corresponding_authors: Kihong Kim
abstract: Optical phase conjugation by degenerate four-wave mixing is studied theoretically using the invariant imbedding method. It is found that the efficiency of phase conjugation can be significantly enhanced in various metamaterial structures.

title: Indistinguishable Photons from Deterministically Fabricated Quantum Dot Microlenses
authors: Alexander Thoma; Peter Schnauber; Manuel Gschrey; Rainer Schmidt; Benjamin Wohlfeil; M. Seifried; J.-H. Schulze; Sven Burger; Franziska Schmidt; A. Strittmatter; Sven Rodt; Tobias Heindel; S. Reitzenstein
abstract: We present the modelling and realization of deterministic quantum-light sources with enhanced photon outcoupling efficiency. The devices are based on single quantum dots being integrated into microlenses by means of 3D in-situ electron-beam lithography.

title: Wireless Bluetooth Heart Rate Monitor for Android Phone
authors: Lo Sze Chun; K. Ennser
corresponding_authors: Lo Sze Chun; K. Ennser
abstract: This paper presents the design and realization of portable, easy-to-use Arduino-based heart rate monitor. The data is received by detecting cardio-vascular pulse wave from a fingertip and transmitted to the android phone by Bluetooth connectivity.

title: Mobility of 1D solitons in the discrete CQ Schrödinger equation
authors: Cristian Mejía-Cortés; Rodrigo A. Vicencio; Boris A. Malomed
corresponding_authors: Cristian Mejía-Cortés; Rodrigo A. Vicencio; Boris A. Malomed
abstract: We investigate mobility for localized modes in the discrete nonlinear Schrödinger equation with cubic and quintic (focusing and defocusing) terms. The largest soliton's power admitting motion of kicked solitons is predicted analytically and numerically corroborated.

title: Frequency Comb-Linked Mid-Infrared Continuous-Wave Optical Parametric Oscillator
authors: Jari Peltola; Markku Vainio; Thomas Fordell; Tuomas Hieta; M. Merimaa; Lauri Halonen
abstract: We report on a frequency comb-referenced mid-infrared continuous-wave optical parametric oscillator. The frequency of the mid-infrared idler beam is locked to a near-infrared frequency comb after frequency doubling the idler beam.

title: Experimental realisation of transverse mode conversion using optically induced transient long-period gratings
authors: Tim Hellwig; Martin Schnack; Sven Dobner; Carsten Fallnich
corresponding_authors: Tim Hellwig; Martin Schnack; Sven Dobner; Carsten Fallnich
abstract: We present the experimental realization of transverse mode conversion in an optical fiber via an optically induced long-period grating by employing a setup with co-propagating femtosecond write and probe laser pulses.

title: Development of beam distribution fibers for high energy pulsed laser within HiLASE project
authors: Jan Vanda; Roman Svabek; Alessandro Candiani
corresponding_authors: Jan Vanda; Roman Svabek; Alessandro Candiani
abstract: Together with high power laser progress, a proper beam delivery system needs to be developed. Such a fiber system requires a new approach regarding fiber development and its integration with the laser beam distribution system.

title: Nonlinear All-optical Vortex Switch in Optically Induced Two-dimensional Waveguide Arrays
authors: Falko Diebel; Daniel Leykam; Martin Boguslawski; Patrick Rose; Cornelia Denz; Anton S. Desyatnikov
corresponding_authors: Falko Diebel; Daniel Leykam; Martin Boguslawski; Patrick Rose; Cornelia Denz; Anton S. Desyatnikov
abstract: We present all-optical switching of the topological charge of a discrete vortex in a nonlinear four-waveguide structure optically induced in photorefractive media. The flip of the vorticity is fully controllable by the vortex beam power.

title: Image transmission in Kagome photonic lattices
authors: Cristian Mejía-Cortés; Rodrigo A. Vicencio
corresponding_authors: Cristian Mejía-Cortés; Rodrigo A. Vicencio
abstract: We study the propagation of well localized (and nondiffracting) linear modes in kagome photonic lattices. By combining these modes, different shapes can be composed and, therefore, a given image will propagate without distortion.

title: Nonlinearities in Periodic Media, From Fiber to Silicon Chips: Plenty to Bragg About
authors: Benjamin J. Eggleton
corresponding_authors: Benjamin J. Eggleton
abstract: We review recent advances related to nonlinear propagation in periodic structures, where the refractive index varies along one or two directions, i.e. gratings and planar photonic crystals. I will present recent experiments showing how periodic media have been used for pulse compression and the generation of slow Bragg solitons. I then present recent nonlinear experiments performed in photonic crystal waveguides that demonstrate the strong reinforcement of nonlinear third-order optical phenomena with slow light with applications to optical switching, quantum light sources and broadband frequency conversion.

title: Refractive index sensor based on a pair of hybrid 45° and 81° tilted fiber gratings
authors: Zhijun Yan; Zhongyuan Sun; Songsong Xiong; Changle Wang; Chengbo Mou; Cheng Li; Jianfeng Li; Kaiming Zhou; Lin Zhang
corresponding_authors: Zhijun Yan; Zhongyuan Sun; Songsong Xiong; Changle Wang; Chengbo Mou; Cheng Li; Jianfeng Li; Kaiming Zhou; Lin Zhang
abstract: A hybrid structure comprising of a 45° and an 81° TFG based RI sensor has been demonstrated. The experiment results show a higher RI sensitivity, being around 180nm/RIU at RI=1.345 and 926nm/RIU at RI=1.412 region.

title: Filterless Approaches to Flexible Submarine Networking
authors: Christine Tremblay
corresponding_authors: Christine Tremblay
abstract: Filterless architectures are proposed for enabling agility in coherent submarine networks. The advantages of the filterless approach are shown through a comparative cost and performance analysis of WDM trunk and branch undersea networks.

title: Chalcogenide waveguides on a sapphire substrate for 3-5 µm wavelengths applications
authors: Amir Herzog; B. Hadad; V. Lyubin; Matvey Klebanov; Avraham Reiner; Avishay Shamir; Amiel A. Ishaaya
corresponding_authors: Amir Herzog; B. Hadad; V. Lyubin; Matvey Klebanov; Avraham Reiner; Avishay Shamir; Amiel A. Ishaaya
abstract: Arsenic tri-Sulfide Chalcogenide strip waveguides on a sapphire substrate were fabricated and characterized. The substrate material enables efficient transmission of 3–5µm wavelengths through the waveguide, and numerical simulations reveal benefits over silica and silicon substrates.

title: A Waveguide Directional Coupler Based on Quantum Nanostructures with Decay Interference
authors: Antonios Fountoulakis; J. Boviatsis; Emmanuel Paspalakis
abstract: We propose a two-waveguide directional coupler where the constituent waveguides are made of quantum structures that exhibit decay interference. Analytical and numerical results are presented and loss-free propagation and slow light switching occur.

title: Exciton physics in transition-metal dichalcogenides at the atomic scale
authors: Frank Tseng; Ergun Smisek; Daniel Gunlycke
abstract: We present an atomistic model for excitons in monolayer transition-metal dichalcogenides consistent with recent experiments. Using this model we show how to extend exciton lifetimes, which could be important for future optoelectronic applications.

title: Demonstration of multiple-channel wavelength conversion in a photonic crystal nanocavity
authors: Bong-Shik Song; Shota Yamada; Seungwoo Jeon; Takashi Asano; Susumu Noda
abstract: We demonstrate multiple-channel wavelength conversions in a photonic-crystal nanocavity by employing nonlinearity optical effects of SiC and multiple resonances of the cavity. Also, we investigate the polarization of the wavelength-converted light.

title: Evidence of stress-state inversion induced by non-ablative femtosecond laser pulses in fused silica
authors: Audrey Champion; Ben McMillen; Yves Bellouard
corresponding_authors: Audrey Champion; Ben McMillen; Yves Bellouard
abstract: Femtosecond laser induces stress around laser-exposed areas. We report evidences of stress-state inversion between tensile and compressive stress while switching between continuous modifications and self-organized nanogratings, respectively.

title: Efficiency of VUV Optical Materials According to Variations in Deposition Conditions
authors: Matteo Nardello; Alain Jody Corso; Paola Zuppella; Francesca Gerlin; Enrico Tessarolo; Davide Bacco; Maria Guglielmina Pelizzo
abstract: Optical elements working at 121.6nm make use of Al and MgF2. We analyzed mono- and bi-layers of these materials, deposited by e-beam evaporation, and discussed how substrate temperatures and annealing affect their performances.

title: Development of pure silica core F-down-doped clad optical fiber for communication in radiation environment
authors: Anirban Dhar; Atasi Pal; Ranjan Sen
corresponding_authors: Anirban Dhar; Atasi Pal; Ranjan Sen
abstract: Low loss silica core fluorine down doped clad radiation resistant optical fiber has been fabricated using modified chemical vapor deposition process to transmit signals from optical sensors in radiation environment with reduced signal-to-noise-ratio.

title: Peptide and Ionic Liquid Monolayers to Reduce Nonspecific Adsorption of Biofluids and Improve Sensitivity of SPR Biosensors
authors: Jean‐François Masson
corresponding_authors: Jean‐François Masson
abstract: Surface chemistries based on peptides and ionic liquids are competent to create biosensors working in crude biofluids. Surface plasmon resonance sensors using these monolayers were effective to detect proteins and small molecules.

title: Coupling light into a whispering-gallery mode resonator with self-focused beam
authors: Kien Phan Huy; Jassem Safioui; Thibaut Sylvestre; Mathieu Chauvet; Patrice Féron
corresponding_authors: Kien Phan Huy; Jassem Safioui; Thibaut Sylvestre; Mathieu Chauvet; Patrice Féron
abstract: Light coupling into a whispering-gallery mode resonator with a spatial soliton is demonstrated. Our setup, based on a LiNbO3 prism, features robustness, mode selectivity and single-mode propagation thanks to the nonlinear confinement.

title: Multi-photon microscopy using a compact, environmentally stable, polarization maintaining fiber laser
authors: Bastian Braeuer; Sean Liew; Ivy Win Long Au; Antoine F. J. Runge; Neil G. R. Broderick; Claude Aguergaray; Frédérique Vanholsbeeck
corresponding_authors: Bastian Braeuer; Sean Liew; Ivy Win Long Au; Antoine F. J. Runge; Neil G. R. Broderick; Claude Aguergaray; Frédérique Vanholsbeeck
abstract: We report on two-photon microscopy imaging of collagen tissues using a portable all-fiber, all polarization maintaining, Ytterbium-doped fiber laser. Our results demonstrate the suitability of such sources for nonlinear microscopy applications.

title: Supercontinuum Generation in a Three-core Chalcogenide-tellurite Fiber
authors: Tonglei Cheng; Xiaojie Xue; Dinghuan Deng; Morio Matsumoto; Takashi Misumi; Takenobu Suzuki; Yasutake Ohishi
corresponding_authors: Tonglei Cheng; Xiaojie Xue; Dinghuan Deng; Morio Matsumoto; Takashi Misumi; Takenobu Suzuki; Yasutake Ohishi
abstract: A three-core chalcogenide-tellurite hybrid optical fiber is designed and fabricated. Supercontinuum generation in each core of the fiber is investigated when it is pumped by an optical parametric oscillator with the wavelengths of ~ 2.4 μm.

title: Relative Humidity Measurement with a Thin Gelatin Film
authors: Sergio Calixto
corresponding_authors: Sergio Calixto
abstract: A relative humidity (RH) detector consisting of a thin gelatin film inserted in a Mach – Zehnder interferometer is proposed. Due to swelling of the gelatin, by the water vapor absorption, interference pattern is modified and RH is measured.

title: Spatial-coherence effect on damage occurrence in multimode optical fibers using nanosecond pulses
authors: Amir Herzog; Amiel A. Ishaaya
abstract: We investigate high peak power delivery in highly multimode optical fibers. By altering the spatial-coherence of the input beam, we demonstrate the transmission of 120mJ ns pulses at 355nm through a multimode fiber.

title: Energy Efficient RF Signal Processing with On-chip Stimulated Brillouin Scattering
authors: David Marpaung; Blair Morrison; Mattia Pagani; Ravi Pant; Duk‐Yong Choi; Barry Luther‐Davies; Steve Madden; Benjamin J. Eggleton
abstract: Here we show the first chip-based RF photonic band-stop filter with ultra-high suppression, high resolution, and 1-30 GHz frequency tuning. This record performance was achieved using an ultra-low Brillouin gain from a compact photonic chip.

title: Simplified Han–Kobayashi Coding Strategy for Tb/s Optical Superchannel Transmissions
authors: Toshiaki Koike‐Akino; Keisuke Kojima; David S. Millar; Kieran Parsons
abstract: We propose a simplified strategy as a special case of Han–Kobayashi coding to handle inter-channel interference in optical superchannels. The proposed scheme achieves higher than Tb/s data rates while the complexity for superposition coding is avoided.

title: Flexible Cavity and Waveguide Light Confinement in Hyperuniform Photonic Slabs
authors: Timothy Amoah; Marian Florescu
abstract: We introduce novel planar hyperuniform-disordered (HUD) architectures as potential general-purpose platform for optical microcircuits. Efficient confinement of TE-polarized radiation and high-Q optical-cavities and low-loss waveguides is demonstrated using finite difference-time-domain and band-structure simulations.

title: Techno-economic Drivers for SDM in Communication Systems
authors: Peter J. Winzer
corresponding_authors: Peter J. Winzer
abstract: Space-division multiplexing (SDM) is widely recognized as a key ingredient to scale interface rates and system capacities, from short-reach to ultra-long-haul. We discuss the highly application specific economics of the introduction of various SDM technologies.

title: Gain sideband splitting in dispersion oscillating fibers
authors: Christophe Finot; S. Wabnitz
corresponding_authors: Christophe Finot; S. Wabnitz
abstract: We analyze the modulation instability spectrum in a varying dispersion optical fiber as a function of the dispersion oscillation amplitude, and predict a novel sideband splitting into different sub-sidebands for relatively large dispersion oscillations.

title: Analytical expression for the z-scan normalized transmittance of a thin nonlocal nonlinear media
authors: A. Balbuena Ortega; M. L. Arroyo Carrasco; M. M. Méndez Otero; M. D. Iturbe Castillo
abstract: Starting from a phenomenological model which takes into account the nonlocal character of a nonlinear interaction we obtain an analytical expression for the z-scan normalized transmittance of a thin nonlocal nonlinear media by means of the Gaussian decomposition method.

title: Terahertz Beam Shaping Using Inkjet Printed Plasmonic Structures with Spatially Varying Conductivities
authors: Barun Gupta; Shashank Pandey; Ajay Nahata
corresponding_authors: Barun Gupta; Shashank Pandey; Ajay Nahata
abstract: We demonstrate a new technique for controlling the terahertz beam profile. We demonstrate this by fabricating plasmonic structures via inkjet printing that incorporate a spatial variation into the conductivity of the metallic layer.

title: Polymer Surface Layers for Functionalizing Plasmonic Nanoparticles
authors: Andrea R. Tao
corresponding_authors: Andrea R. Tao
abstract: Polymer grafts play a key role in organizing and functionalizing metal nanoparticles for plasmonic sensors which provide surface-sensitive optical readouts and require analytes to be placed in the vicinity of an intense optical field.

title: Optical fiber sensors: the last step towards mainstream
authors: Cícero Martelli; Jean Carlos Cardozo da Silva; Marco J. da Silva; Daniel Rodrigues Pipa; Felipe Mezzadri; Kleiton de M. Souza; João Paulo Bazzo; Guilherme Dutra; Uilian José Dreyer; José Rodolfo Galvão; Rodolfo L. Patyk; Fabiano Cordeiro Moreira; Pedro Esber Schaphauser; Marcelo Lourenço da Silva; Rigoberto Morales
corresponding_authors: Cícero Martelli; Jean Carlos Cardozo da Silva; Marco J. da Silva; Daniel Rodrigues Pipa; Felipe Mezzadri; Kleiton de M. Souza; João Paulo Bazzo; Guilherme Dutra; Uilian José Dreyer; José Rodolfo Galvão; Rodolfo L. Patyk; Fabiano Cordeiro Moreira; Pedro Esber Schaphauser; Marcelo Lourenço da Silva; Rigoberto Morales
abstract: Optical fiber sensors have now been studied and developed for over 25 years and as they are successfully transferred from research labs to the real world, standardization issues become very important and threaten to limit the growth of the entire industry. A discussion about the need for application related standardization of the entire supply chain for optical fiber sensors is presented as well as our group's latest results and an approach to overcome this problem.

title: Enhancement of Plasmonic Properties of an All-Glass AgPO3/Silica Photonic Bandgap Fibre Using Thermal Poling
authors: Ioannis Konidakis; Stavros Pissadakis
corresponding_authors: Ioannis Konidakis; Stavros Pissadakis
abstract: We report on exposure of composite AgPO3/silica photonic bandgap fibers on external electric field, which leads to poling of the phosphate glass medium and causes significant changes on the guiding properties of the composite fibres.

title: Integration of Microfibers and Ag nanowires for Hybrid Plasmonic Sensors
authors: Xin Guo; Limin Tong

title: Octave spanning supercontinuum generation in InGaP waveguides on a silicon substrate at 1550 nm
authors: Utsav D. Dave; Bart Kuyken; Sylvain Combrié; Alfredo De Rossi; Fabrice Raineri; Günther Roelkens
corresponding_authors: Utsav D. Dave; Bart Kuyken; Sylvain Combrié; Alfredo De Rossi; Fabrice Raineri; Günther Roelkens
abstract: We present an octave spanning supercontinuum (at the -35 dB level) ranging from 1100 nm to 2500 nm in InGaP photonic wire waveguides that are bonded to a silicon substrate and pumped by an ultrashort pulsed laser centered at 1550 nm.

title: Optical Polymer Waveguides for Biomedical Applications
authors: Seok-Hyun Andy Yun
corresponding_authors: Seok-Hyun Andy Yun
abstract: Optical glass/plastic fibers are widely used in medicine for bringing light into target tissues. Here, we demonstrate waveguides based on biocompatible polymers and hydrogels, enabling new approaches and functionalities for in-body applications.

title: Low insertion loss single-walled carbon nanotube saturable absorber enabled by vacuum filtration method for all-fiber mode-locked laser
authors: Hyub Lee; Won Sik Kwon; Jin Hwan Kim; Kyung‐Soo Kim; Soohyun Kim
corresponding_authors: Hyub Lee; Won Sik Kwon; Jin Hwan Kim; Kyung‐Soo Kim; Soohyun Kim
abstract: We present a 1550nm all-fiber mode-locked laser employing a film-type saturable absorber incorporating carbon nanotubes which is embedded in PDMS substrates by vacuum filtration to reduce nonsaturable insertion loss of the device.

title: IR Gradient Index (GRIN) Materials For Broad-Band IR Optics
authors: Daniel Gibson; Shyam Bayya; Jas Sanghera; N. Q. Vinh; Mikhail Kotov; Gryphon A. Drake
corresponding_authors: Daniel Gibson; Shyam Bayya; Jas Sanghera; N. Q. Vinh; Mikhail Kotov; Gryphon A. Drake
abstract: We report new IR GRIN materials for multi-spectral IR optics with a delta-n of 0.4. These new materials transmit SWIR-LWIR (0.9 µm - >12 µm) and have dispersion gradients to enable multi-band color correction.

title: Unconventional Broadband Conversion of Infrared Supercontinuum at the Second Harmonic Wavelengths
authors: Farid El Bassri; Dominique Pagnoux; Fabio Baronio; Katarzyna Krupa; A. Tonello; Badr Mohamed Ibrahim Shalaby; Alexis Labruyère; Vincent Couderc
abstract: Broadband frequency doubling of an infrared supercontinuum is demonstrated. This unconventional Second Harmonic Generation process is obtained in a PPLN crystal excited along its Z axis, thanks to nonlinear Cerenkov and Raman-Nath interactions.

title: Control the optical magnification of a zooming tomography and profilometry with a spatial phase modulator installed interferometer
authors: Tuan Banh Quoc; Tatsutoshi Shioda
abstract: Optical magnification of the high-speed 2D imaging is proposed as a zooming tomography using optical grating and camera installed interferometer. The dynamic range can be optically changed by choosing the diffraction orders of the grating.

title: Carrier Phase Recovery for Optical Coherent M-QAM Communication Systems Using Harmonic Decompositionbased Maximum Loglikelihood Estimators
authors: Trung-Hien Nguyen; Michel Joindot; Pascal Scalart; Mathilde Gay; Laurent Bramerie; Olivier Sentieys; Jean–Claude Simon
abstract: A novel feedforward M–QAM carrier phase recovery is presented and validated with both square and cross M–QAM up to 128–QAM. The proposed method outperforms the VVMPE–ML method with reduced computational effort and improved linewidth tolerance.

title: Origin of sub-nanometer spatial resolution in tip-enhanced Raman mapping
authors: Chao Zhang; Baoqin Chen; Zhiyuan Li
corresponding_authors: Chao Zhang; Baoqin Chen; Zhiyuan Li
abstract: We present a microscopic theory to study Raman scattering of a molecule embedded within the palsmonic nanogap cavity in a tip-enhanced Raman spectroscopy instrument. We find that the strong near-field self-interaction of molecule with the plasmonic nano-gap strongly modulates the Raman excitation and radiation in both the signal intensity and spatial sensitivity, with a modification factor of g(r). The Raman enhancement factor is now given by G = g4 | E / E0 |4. As a result, a plasmon-molecule "super-hot spot" is created within the nanogap, leading to the sub-nanometer lateral resolution of Raman mapping.

title: Integrated Nonlinear Optical Resonators Based on AlN-on-insulator Platform
authors: Hojoong Jung; Hong X. Tang
abstract: Optical frequency combs can be generated by cascaded four-wave mixing with Kerr nonlinearity. Recently, by taking advantage of the field enhancement effect in high quality (Q) factor cavities, comb generations using continuous wave (CW) laser have been demonstrated in various materials, such as silica toroids, doped silica glass ring resonators, silicon nitride micro-ring resonators, diamond micro-ring resonators, crystalline CaF2 and MgF2 micro-toroids and etc. Aluminum nitride (AlN) possesses strong Kerr nonlinearity which can be used to generate optical frequency comb by cascaded four wave mixing [1. Also it has strong Pockels effect which allows electro-optic modulation [2. Here, we take advantage of both effects and demonstrate comb generation using on-chip aluminum nitride microring, high speed switching of the optical frequency comb,[3 and cascaded frequency conversions among the comb lines. [4. (a) IR frequency comb generated in 60 µm radius microring resonator (left inset) with 650 nm height and 3.5 μm width structure (right inset). Estimated power in the bus waveguide is 600 mW and 0.5 % of gathered output power is used for spectrum measurement. (b) The greenly glowing microring under daylight. (c) The microscope image without a filter and (d) with a 750 nm long pass filter. (e) The microscope image with the 750 nm long pass filter when on-resonance (top) and off-resonance (bottom). The white dashed lines represent the bus waveguides and the white dotted boxes on the left represent the input fibers. The white arrows indicate the ends of the bus waveguides of the chip.

title: In-plane Fabry-Pérot cavities: versatile, compact and highly sensitive sensors
authors: Yves-Alain Peter
corresponding_authors: Yves-Alain Peter
abstract: On chip in-plane Fabry-Pérot cavities are compact, robust and can be integrated with micro electro-mechanical components as well as microfuidics. They can efficiently sense acceleration, forces, gases, refractive index of liquids and living cells.

title: Displacement Sensing by Using Optical Fiber with a Polymer Microlens on the Fiber Endface
authors: Jie-Fang Hu; Chin-Ping Yu
corresponding_authors: Jie-Fang Hu; Chin-Ping Yu
abstract: Get PDF Email Share Share with Facebook Tweet This Post on reddit Share with LinkedIn Add to CiteULike Add to Mendeley Add to BibSonomy Get Citation Copy Citation Text J. Hu and C. title: Management and Control Complexity and Scalable Architectures of Optical Networks
authors: Vincent W. S. Chan
corresponding_authors: Vincent W. S. Chan
abstract: Future optical networks will integrate multi-layer functions in a fast adapting infrastructure. When data and control dynamics speed-up by 103-4, the entire architecture, from physical to application layers, must be redesigned to be scalable.

title: Applications of Arrayed Waveguide Gratings for 100GbE-and-Beyond Datacom Networks
authors: Yoshiyuki Doi
corresponding_authors: Yoshiyuki Doi
abstract: With the rapid growth of datacom traffic, arrayed waveguide gratings (AWGs) are promising for 100-Gigabit Ethernet and beyond. We review the applications of AWGs in regards to their scalability and functionality.

title: Near Infrared Fourier Transform Spectrophotometry based on a LiNbO3 Waveguide Mach-Zehnder Interferometer with Push-pull Electrodes
authors: Jinyang Li; Danfeng Lu; Zhi‐mei Qi
corresponding_authors: Jinyang Li; Danfeng Lu; Zhi‐mei Qi
abstract: A miniature stationary time-scanning Fourier Transform (FT) spectrometer was realized using a fiber-coupled LiNbO3 (LN) waveguide Mach-Zehnder interferometer (MZI) with push-pull electrodes. The spectrometer operates in the near infrared (NIR) region in which the MZI is a monomode device and allows to use a nonlinear voltage ramp to modulate the optical pathlength difference (OPD). The monotonous wavelength dependence of the half-wave voltage for the MZI used was measured using multiple DFB lasers of different wavelengths. The spectrometer utilizes the measured dispersion of half-wave voltage to convert the intermediate spectrum retrieved from the intensity-vs-voltage interferogram into the power spectrum of the input light source. In the previous work the spectrometer has been demonstrated to be able to accurately determine the laser wavelength. In this work, the spectrometer with a halogen-tungsten lamp source was used to implement the NIR absorption measurements of liquid and solid samples. Figure 1 shows the experimental results obtained with the miniature stationary FT spectrometer. Despite the lower spectral resolution of the present FT spectrometer, the peak position at 1451.5nm in the absorption spectrum exactly corresponds to the maximum absorption of water indicated in the literature.1

title: Spectroscopic Sensing with Laser Frequency Combs
authors: N. Picqué
corresponding_authors: N. Picqué
abstract: Laser frequency combs open up new opportunities for broad-spectral-bandwidth linear and nonlinear spectroscopy. The rapid progress in frequency comb generation technology and comb-based photonics tools may significantly expand the range of applications of molecular sensing.

title: Termination of special optical fibers for their integration in high performance laser system
authors: P. Dupriez
corresponding_authors: P. Dupriez
abstract: A large variety of special optical fibers are employed in an increasing number of applications. Integrating these high performing fibers requires specific expertise. Technologies exploited to prepare such fibers for specific applications will be reviewed.

title: A proposal of expanding phase dynamic range in CE-CO-OFDM systems using phase unwrapping
authors: Ryutaro Arita; Hajime Matsubara; Yasuhiro Tsutsumi; Joji Maeda
abstract: We propose a combination of phase unwrapping and oversampling to expand phase dynamic range of CE-CO-OFDM systems, and numerically confirm the effectiveness of the proposed detection scheme showing the tolerance for fiber transmission degradation.

title: Wavelength Modulated Bimodal Interferometer for Highly Sensitive Biosensing Applications
authors: S. Dante; Daphné Duval; Ana Belén González‐Guerrero; David Fariña; Carlos Domı́nguez; Laura M. Lechuga
corresponding_authors: S. Dante; Daphné Duval; Ana Belén González‐Guerrero; David Fariña; Carlos Domı́nguez; Laura M. Lechuga
abstract: With the final goal of implementing a Lab-on-Chip platform for highly sensitive biosensing applications, we demonstrate a phase modulation approach based on all-optical principles for integrated hetero-modal interferometers.

title: Lithium niobate compact photonic devices on silicon substrates
authors: Payam Rabiei; Ashutosh Rao; Aniket Patil; Jeff Chiles; Sasan Fahpour
abstract: Lithium niobate submicron waveguides and compact photonic devices are demonstrated on silicon substrates. Optical waveguides with loss of 1.2 dB/cm and Mach-Zehnder modulators with a Vπ.L of 3.6 V.cm and bandwidth larger than 8 GHz are demonstrated.

title: High Performance SDN Enabled Flat Datacenter Network Architecture Based on Scalable And Flow-Controlled Optical Switching System
authors: Nicola Calabretta
corresponding_authors: Nicola Calabretta
abstract: We present a novel flat datacenter network (DCN) architecture based on optical switching technologies enabled by SDN. Virtual DCN slicing can be flexibly generated and reconfigured for multi-tenant DC, efficiently sharing the data plane resources.

title: Analysis of SOA Optimization in Spectrum-Sliced WDM Systems for EIN Reduction and Dispersion Effect
authors: Qikai Hu; Changyuan Yu
abstract: we analyze through simulation the optimal gain-saturated semiconductor optical amplifier to reduce the excess intensity noise of the spectrum-sliced incoherent light with linewidth over a wide range. The dispersion effect on the SOA optimization is also investigated.

title: Closed-Form Theory of Kerr Frequency Combs
authors: William H. Renninger; Peter T. Rakich
abstract: A closed-form particular solution is identified for Kerr frequency combs and simple scaling laws are developed. The behavior of both soliton and wavetrain waveforms are reproduced and new regimes of performance are predicted.

title: Multi-photon Quantitative Sensing of Electrostatic Molecular Interactions
authors: Aleksander Rebane
corresponding_authors: Aleksander Rebane
abstract: Femtosecond 2-photon absorption spectroscopy is used to determine the strength of local electrostatic field in the molecular vicinity of dissolved dipolar chromophores. Experimental techniques facilitating high accuracy 2-photon cross section measurements will be discussed.

title: High Sensitivity Refractive Index Measurements Using Tilted Fiber Bragg Gratings
authors: Lei Shi; Yunqi Liu; Yunhe Zhao; Fang Zou; Tingyun Wang
corresponding_authors: Lei Shi; Yunqi Liu; Yunhe Zhao; Fang Zou; Tingyun Wang
abstract: Tilted fiber Bragg gratings with different tilt angle were fabricated for the measurement of surrounding refractive index (SRI). The resonance wavelength of cladding modes found to disappear gradually is linearly increased with the increasing SRI.

authors: Haijun Liu; Douglas A. Olson; Kevin O. Douglass; Miao Yu

title: Digitally Enabled Optical Links: Goals and Challenges
authors: Stephen E. Ralph
corresponding_authors: Stephen E. Ralph
abstract: Digital techniques including equalization and linearization enable transmitters and receivers to achieve precise waveform generation and detection of wideband signals. We review recent progress and identify the goals and challenges of future systems.

title: Solid-core and hollow-core photonic crystal fibre as nonlinear element for synchronously pumped ring cavities
authors: Nicolas Y. Joly; Michael J. Schmidberger; David Novoa; Pooria Hosseini; P. St. J. Russell
corresponding_authors: Nicolas Y. Joly; Michael J. Schmidberger; David Novoa; Pooria Hosseini; P. St. J. Russell
abstract: We present recent studies of photonic crystal fibre ring cavity synchronously pumped by femtosecond pulses. In the case of a Xe-filled kagomé fibre, we predict the appearance of spontaneous symmetry breaking as well as multistability.

title: Type I and Type II Čerenkov Second-Harmonic Generation Microscopy in χ(2)-Disordered Media
authors: Jörg Imbrock; Mousa Ayoub; Markus Paßlick; Jens Hänisch; Cornelia Denz
corresponding_authors: Jörg Imbrock; Mousa Ayoub; Markus Paßlick; Jens Hänisch; Cornelia Denz
abstract: We analyze the polarization properties of three Čerenkov-type second-harmonic (ČSH) signals in a crystal with a random distribution of the χ(2) nonlinearity. Applications in ČSH microscopy for three-dimensional domain visualization are discussed.

title: Monitoring of the Insulator-to-Metal Transition of Ultrathin Gold Coatings on Optical Fibers
authors: Wenjun Zhou; David J. Mandia; Seán T. Barry; Jacques Albert
abstract: The anisotropy of the optical properties of ultrathin gold evaporated films (with mass-equivalent thicknesses from 3 to 8 nm) during the insulator-to-metal transition process is measured from the polarization-dependent response of coated tilted FBGs.

title: Optical Properties of a Film of Composite Medium with Random Distribution of Metal Nano-inclusions
authors: Saswatee Banerjee
corresponding_authors: Saswatee Banerjee
abstract: We computed the transmission spectra due to a dielectric film impregnated with metal nano-inclusions. Effect of formation of aggregates is studied. A home-grown recursive-convolution finite-difference time-domain method is used for computation.

title: Passive mode-locking of transform-limited hundred-ps long pulses using an integrated nonlinear microring resonator
authors: Christian Reimer; Michael Kues; Benjamin Wetzel; Piotr Roztocki; Brent E. Little; Sai T. Chu; David Moss; Roberto Morandotti
corresponding_authors: Christian Reimer; Michael Kues; Benjamin Wetzel; Piotr Roztocki; Brent E. Little; Sai T. Chu; David Moss; Roberto Morandotti
abstract: We observe passive mode-locking at ultra-low power levels generating near transform-limited 570ps pulses at a 14.8MHz repetition rate. This is achieved by using high nonlinear enhancement in a CMOS-compatible microring resonator incorporated in a SOA based nonlinear loop-mirror laser architecture.

title: Metal Nanowire for Plasmonic Sensing
authors: Xin Guo
corresponding_authors: Xin Guo
abstract: Owing to remarkable properties for guiding light with tight confinement and strong evanescent fields, we investigate the waveguiding properties of single metal nanowires for plasmonic sensing, and report high-sensitive single nanowire gas sensors.

title: Scaling of Optical Forces with Material Response and Nanoscale Geometry
authors: Eric A. Kittlaus; Ryan O. Behunin; William H. Renninger; Peter T. Rakich
abstract: We develop scaling laws which explore the parameters that strongly impact optical forces in nanoscale guided-wave systems and demonstrate their application to device design. These analytical results also provide a benchmark for numerical simulations.

title: A Compact Wavelength Separator Based on Coupled Whispering Gallery Mode Resonators in the Mie Regime
authors: James B. Cole; Naoki Okada
abstract: We designed a compact wavelength separator based on coupled whispering gallery mode resonators in the Mie regime using a new high-accuracy version of FDTD derived from a nonstandard finite difference model.

title: New developments in optical coating characterization and utilization under high power laser irradiation
authors: Wolfgang Rudolph; Cristina Rodríguez; Yejia Xu; Zhanliang Sun; Luke A. Emmert
abstract: We present a novel technique to characterize coating imperfections that limit the performance under pulsed laser irradiation. We discuss the use of 1D photonic crystals based on dielectric metal oxides as nonlinear optical frequency converters.

title: Principal Component Analysis applied to the identification of spectral variations in depressed mouse brain
authors: Eusebio Real; Fuencisla Pilar-Cuéllar; Rebeca Vidal; Elsa M. Valdizán Ruiz; Ángel Carro; D. Hernández; José Miguel López Higuera; Olga M. Conde
abstract: Brain tissue from rats exhibits different composition and absorption FTIR spectra when compared health with a depression-like animal. When principal component analysis is combined with derivative spectroscopy, differences appear enhanced between healthy and depressed animals.

title: Powder-sintering Technique for High-power Fiber Lasers
authors: Kay Schuster; Stephan Grimm; B. Müller; Martin Leich; Jan Dellith
corresponding_authors: Kay Schuster; Stephan Grimm; B. Müller; Martin Leich; Jan Dellith
abstract: A new approach for silica laser materials is presented. The technology is based on reactive powder doping, sintering and vitrification and yields in homogeneous active doped bulk material with an excellent RI homogeneity of about 10-4.

title: Three dimensional beam splitters and lasing based on Nd:YAG waveguides by femtosecond laser writing
authors: Yuechen Jia; Chen Cheng; Javier R. Vázquez de Aldana; Feng Chen
corresponding_authors: Yuechen Jia; Chen Cheng; Javier R. Vázquez de Aldana; Feng Chen
abstract: We report on a 3D beam splitter monolithically integrated in a Nd:YAG crystal wafer by applying the femtosecond laser writing technique, capable of 1 to 3 and 1 to 4 beam splitting and waveguide lasing.

title: Spatial Oversampling to overcome High-speed ADC Noise Limited Performance
authors: Dan M. Marom; Ori Golani
abstract: We introduce the photonic spatial oversampling concept to overcome ADC noise limited performance, which is in many ways similar to temporal oversampling occurring nowadays in electronic ADC. Spatial oversampling is especially fitting for high-speed systems.

title: Microfluidic chip based microfiber sensors
authors: Lei Zhang; Limin Tong
abstract: We report microfluidic chip based microfiber sensors by using silica microfibers embedded in microchannels with a detection length of 2.5 cm. Ultra-sensitive absorption and fluorescence measurements are demonstrated.

title: The Fermi – Ulam Problem for Solitons
authors: N. N. Rosanov; N. V. Vysotina
corresponding_authors: N. N. Rosanov; N. V. Vysotina
abstract: We consider the periodic and chaotic longitudinal and transverse dynamics of the Bose-Einstein condensate solitons in a dynamical billiard with oscillating barriers and compare that with the dynamics of classical particles in the Fermi – Ulam problem.

title: Diamond Nanoparticle with Cross Aperture for Improving Absorbance Characteristics of Multispectral Sensors
authors: Erdem Aslan; Ekin Aslan; Sabri Kaya; Ömer Galip Saraçoğlu; Mustafa Türkmen
abstract: Optical characterization of a plasmonic absorber sensor is presented. FDTD method is utilized to obtain the absorption spectra and near field distribution. The results show that the structure can be utilized for infrared sensing applications.

title: Saturation of the Kerr effect in carbon disulfide
authors: Georges Boudebs; Valentin Besse; Hervé Leblond
abstract: Accurate measurements of the nonlinear index in carbon disulfide shows an unusual saturation law of the Kerr effect which can be used to built a model of light propagation describing the filamentation in this liquid.

title: Recent Advances in Hollow-Core Photonic Bandgap Fibres
authors: David J. Richardson; Yong Chen; Eric Numkam Fokoua; N.V. Wheeler; N. K. Baddela; J. R. Hayes; S. R. Sandoghchi; Gregory T. Jasion; J. P. Wooler; D. R. Gray; M. N. Petrovich; Francesco Poletti
corresponding_authors: David J. Richardson; Yong Chen; Eric Numkam Fokoua; N.V. Wheeler; N. K. Baddela; J. R. Hayes; S. R. Sandoghchi; Gregory T. Jasion; J. P. Wooler; D. R. Gray; M. N. Petrovich; Francesco Poletti
abstract: We review recent progress towards improving the transmission properties of hollow-core photonic band gap fibres including advances made in understanding the key issues limiting minimum loss and bandwidth in current fabricated structures.

title: Spatially Offset Raman Line Scan for Content Detection in Turbid Containers
authors: Bernhard Zachhuber; Henric Östmark
corresponding_authors: Bernhard Zachhuber; Henric Östmark
abstract: Spatially Offset Raman Spectroscopy (SORS) in a line scan arrangement allowed simultaneous collection of full Raman spectra at a multitude of different offsets in 5 s. From a distance of 67 cm, NaClO3 powder in a white plastic (HDPE) container was identified. To allow detection from various distances the system was equipped with a fast autofocus.

title: Ultrafast Spectrally-Efficient TDM Multiplexing/Demultiplexing Schemes Using Orthogonality in Coherent Optical Nyquist Pulses
authors: Masataka Nakazawa
corresponding_authors: Masataka Nakazawa
abstract: We present a novel ultrahigh-speed transmission scheme with high spectral-efficiency (SE) using time-domain orthogonality in coherent optical Nyquist pulses. We demonstrate a 1.92-Tbit/s/ch (160-Gbaud), PDM-64-QAM transmission over 150 km with 10.6-bit/s/Hz SE with this scheme.

title: Biosensing Lasers using External Cavities with Photonic and Plasmonic Crystals
authors: Meng Zhang; Qinglan Huang; Brian T. Cunningham
abstract: Using the optically resonant surfaces of photonic crystals and plasmonic crystals, we demonstrate the design and application of a new class of label-free optical biosensors that utilize the stimulated emission process associated with an external cavity laser to achieve high resolution, while retaining the high wavelength shift sensitivity. The External Cavity Laser (ECL) biosensor approach has been applied to direct detection of small molecule interactions with immobilized proteins in the context of high throughput drug screening, using a novel self-referencing approach that accurately compensates for the effects of thermal drift and bulk refractive index variation.

title: Radiating Dissipative-Dispersive Shock Waves via Bistability in Passive Microcavities
authors: Stefania Malaguti; Matteo Conforti; Gaetano Bellanca; S. Trillo
corresponding_authors: Stefania Malaguti; Matteo Conforti; Gaetano Bellanca; S. Trillo
abstract: Bistability and dissipative modulational instability allow for the formation of mixed dissipative-dispersive shock waves in passive nonlinear cavities operating with weak normal dispersion. These shocks are found to resonantly radiate linear waves.

title: Light-Path Tracking and Circuit Reconfiguration of Silicon Photonic Circuits Assisted by Non-Invasive Optical Probes
authors: Andrea Melloni; Marco Carminati; Andrea Annoni; Francesco Morichetti; Pietro Ciccarella; Stefano Grillanda; Giorgio Ferrari; Marc Sorel; M. Sampietro
abstract: We demonstrate feedback-controlled reconfiguration of complex silicon photonic architectures assisted by non-invasive contactless integrated photonic probes (CLIPPs). On-chip light-path tracking and thermal tuning is managed by an integrated ASIC bridged to the photonic chip.

title: Specetral Bandwidth of Principal Modes in a Multimode Fiber
authors: Hui Cao
corresponding_authors: Hui Cao
abstract: We study the bandwidths of principal modes in a multimode fiber in the presence of mode mixing and mode-dependent loss. Furthermore we introduce a procedure to generate Super PMs which feature an even broader bandwidth.

title: In-Fiber Acousto-Optic Tunable Gratings for Sensing Applications
authors: Kwang Jo Lee
corresponding_authors: Kwang Jo Lee
abstract: The operating principles and implementation of in-fiber acousto-optic tunable gratings exploiting flexural and torsional acoustic waves are presented. Spectral shaping of each scheme and its potential applications to optical sensors will be described.

title: Reducing Raman noise in parametric frequency conversion by varying the input pump power
authors: Søren Friis; L. Mejling; Karsten Rottwitt
corresponding_authors: Søren Friis; L. Mejling; Karsten Rottwitt
abstract: The phase-matching condition of parametric frequency conversion and the impact of Raman scattering depend on the power of two separate pumps. We show that Raman noise is reduced by asymmetrically varying the pump powers.

authors: Semih Korkmaz; Ekin Aslan; Sabri Kaya; Mustafa Türkmen
abstract: The optical characterization of a novel plasmonic perfect absorber is analyzed. The effect of the dielectric spacer material on the resonance frequency is determined. The proposed sensing platform can be used in infrared applications.

title: Control and Orchestration for Future IP/Optical Transport Networks
authors: Domenico Siracusa
corresponding_authors: Domenico Siracusa
abstract: Transport network applications demand high capacity for tailored services. This talk presents (i) resource allocation strategies to exploit capacity of novel SDM-based optical networks and (ii) a multi-layer orchestration approach able to meet applications' requirements.

abstract: Self-rolled-up SiNx tube based vertical photonic couplers are monolithically integrated on top of planar ridge waveguides in various configurations. The coupling efficiency between the elements is >10 times higher than similar non-integrated device.

authors: F. Di Mei; Davide Pierangeli; Jacopo Parravicini; G. B. Parravicini; Aharon J. Agranat; Claudio Conti; E. DelRe
corresponding_authors: F. Di Mei; Davide Pierangeli; Jacopo Parravicini; G. B. Parravicini; Aharon J. Agranat; Claudio Conti; E. DelRe
abstract: We report an electro-optic response that is linear but independent of the sign of the electric field. Temperature dependence allows us to attribute the phenomenon to a reduced thermal agitation in the response of polar-nanoregions.

title: DSP-based Symbol-wise SOP Scrambling for Polarization-Multiplexed QAM Signals
authors: Keisuke Matsuda; Tsuyoshi Yoshida; Kenichi Uto
abstract: We propose a novel DSP-based symbol-wise 3-state cyclic SOP scrambling technique for polarization-multiplexed QAM signals. Simulation shows more than 0.4 dB improvement in the presence of 5 dB of PDL, reducing the SOP-dependent penalty.

title: Deployment Scenarios of MDM : MIMO Radio-over-fiber System and Metro Area Network
authors: Ken‐ichi Kitayama
corresponding_authors: Ken‐ichi Kitayama
abstract: Deployment scenarios of mode division multiplexing (MDM) using two-mode fiber (TMF) are presented, including W-band MDM multi-input multi-output (MIMO) radio-over-fiber (RoF) system for disaster recovery and MDM metro area networks for an immediate capacity increase.

title: Strong Light-Matter-Interactions in Nanocavities and 2D Material-Nanocavity Systems
authors: Mohammad H. Tahersima; Ke Liu; Volker J. Sorger
abstract: We report on showing strong light-matter-interaction enhancements of waveguide-integrated and 2D material-based spiral nanocavities. Both exploit high Q/Vmode values outperforming diffraction-limited cavities due to high optical densities.

title: Design for Sustainable, Multi-service Optical Network Architectures
authors: Marco Ruffini
corresponding_authors: Marco Ruffini
abstract: This talk will put in perspective rising traffic demands with design of scalable next-generation optical network architectures. We will discuss end-to-end design, network service convergence, access technologies and report on a number of case studies.

title: 3.5 kW-Peak Power Single-Frequency Double-Clad Erbium-Doped Fiber Amplifier
authors: Leonid Kotov; Mikhail E. Likhachev; Mikhail M. Bubnov; Vladimir M Paramonov; M I Belovolov; Denis S. Lipatov; A. N. Guryanov; Sébastien Février
corresponding_authors: Leonid Kotov; Mikhail E. Likhachev; Mikhail M. Bubnov; Vladimir M Paramonov; M I Belovolov; Denis S. Lipatov; A. N. Guryanov; Sébastien Février
abstract: We present a single-frequency nanosecond all-fiber amplifier based on a specially developed single-mode large mode area double-clad Erbium-doped fiber. We have demonstrated a record peak power of 3.5 kW before the onset of SBS.

title: Photo-isomerization induces pattern instability, labyrinth and foam textures
authors: V. Odent; Ignacio Andrade-Silva; Marcel G. Clerc; Daniel Escaff
corresponding_authors: V. Odent; Ignacio Andrade-Silva; Marcel G. Clerc; Daniel Escaff
abstract: We study experimentally, theoretically and numerically photo-isomerization transition between a nematic and isotropic phases, induced by a Gaussian laser beam. The photo-isomerization transition causes transitory phenomenon as pattern instability, labyrinth and foam textures.

title: Controlling Rogue Waves by Group-Velocity Horizons
authors: Ayhan Demircan; Carsten Brée; Shalva Amiranashvili; Ayhan Tajalli; Alexander Pape; Uwe Morgner; Günter Steinmeyer
corresponding_authors: Ayhan Demircan; Carsten Brée; Shalva Amiranashvili; Ayhan Tajalli; Alexander Pape; Uwe Morgner; Günter Steinmeyer
abstract: We present a way to actively control the appearance or destruction of rogue waves in supercontinuum generation. The scheme also allows manipulating the statistics of extreme events, independently of their generation mechanism.

title: What is an epsilon-near-zero mode?
authors: Salvatore Campione; Igal Brener; François Marquier
abstract: Metallic films much thinner than the skin depth can support surface plasmon modes whose dispersion approaches the plasma frequency, giving rise to the so-called epsilon-near-zero mode. We analyse its features and observation conditions.

authors: F. Ghiringhelli; Michael J. Welch; A. Malinowski; N. Daga; Christophe A. Codemard; M. Durkin; Michalis N. Zervas
corresponding_authors: F. Ghiringhelli; Michael J. Welch; A. Malinowski; N. Daga; Christophe A. Codemard; M. Durkin; Michalis N. Zervas

title: 2D plasmonic nanostructures for sensing
authors: Jean‐François Masson; Maxime Couture; Hugo-Pierre Poirier-Richard; Hu Zhu; Hélène Yockell-Lelièvre; Thibault Brulé
abstract: Plasmonic substrates on a solid support are ideally suited for several biosensing applications. The properties of nanohole arrays and nanoparticle arrays will be demonstrated for SPR sensing and surface enhanced spectroscopies (fluorescence and Raman).

title: Amplitude and Phase Modulation of Light Using Fano-Resonant Meta-Surfaces Integrated with Graphene
authors: Nima Dabidian; Iskandar Kholmanov; Alexander B. Khanikaev; Kaya Tatar; Simeon Trendafilov; S. Hossein Mousavi; Carl W. Magnuson; Rodney S. Ruoff; Gennady Shvets
abstract: We experimentally demonstrate amplitude and phase modulation in graphene-integrated Fano-resonant plasmonic metasurfaces. Order of magnitude modulation depth is achieved in mid-IR. Strong coupling between trapped graphene and metallic plasmons is predicted in high-mobility graphene.

title: Nonlinear symmetry breaking and rogue waves formation in a dissipative optical system
authors: M. Taki; Zheng Liu; S. Coulibaly; Arnaud Mussot; François Léo
corresponding_authors: M. Taki; Zheng Liu; S. Coulibaly; Arnaud Mussot; François Léo
abstract: The frequency spectrum asymmetry observed in fiber systems is shown to originate from a nonlinear symmetry breaking. Analytical and experimental results are in excellent agreement. Rogue waves formation in strongly nonlinear regimes is presented.

title: Fabricating fiber Bragg gratings with wide range and precise wavelength control
authors: Дмитрий Степанов; Leonardo Corena
corresponding_authors: Дмитрий Степанов; Leonardo Corena
abstract: We demonstrate a Bragg grating fabrication technique based on a phase-controlled interferometric approach with coarse and fine wavelength tuning by fabricating multiple Bragg reflectors in the range of 1200-2200 nm, all within a single device.

title: Volterra-based Digital Backpropagation: Performance and Complexity Assessment
authors: Fernando P. Guiomar; Sofia B. Amado; Celestino S. Martins; Jacklyn D. Reis; A. Teixeira; Armando N. Pinto
abstract: We review the latest developments on Volterra-based digital backpropagation (DBP) algorithms. Performance and implementation complexity are assessed through experimental results obtained for a 100G PM-64QAM transmission system.

title: Engineering Absorption Cross Section for Extraordinary Light Concentration
authors: Zongfu Yu
corresponding_authors: Zongfu Yu
abstract: We show that engineering the radiation channels in a phase index near-zero materials can significantly overcome the isotropic limit of the optical cross section of a single nanoresonator to achieve extraordinary large cross section.

title: Dual-Wavelength Raman Sensor Probes using Conjugated Polymer Nanovesicles
authors: Na Yeon Hong; Chunzhi Cui; Dong June Ahn
corresponding_authors: Na Yeon Hong; Chunzhi Cui; Dong June Ahn
abstract: We demonstrate the multi-module Raman detection system using polydiacetylene supramolecules in which fluorescence-resonance Raman scattering effect is observed by utilizing dual-wavelength laser excitation.

title: Intelligent Network Virtualization in Flexible Grid Optical Networks
authors: Xi Wang; Mukul R. Prasad; Indradeep Ghosh; Paparao Palacharla; Qiong Zhang; Inwoong Kim; Motoyoshi Sekiya
abstract: Software-defined flexible grid optical networks enable new revenue opportunities through delivery of virtual optical network (VON) services. This paper showcases an intelligent VON mapper capable of simultaneously and efficiently mapping large number of VON demands.

title: Gate-tunable Transparent Conducting Oxide Plasmonics
authors: Ho Wai Howard Lee
corresponding_authors: Ho Wai Howard Lee
abstract: I will present the use of low-loss active materials, transparent conducting oxides, to demonstrate an efficient plasmonic modulation that operates via MOS field-effect dynamics, and an plasmonic resonant structure that can tune the optical dispersion.

title: Polymer Laser Bio-sensors
authors: Anders Kristensen; Christoph Vannahme; Pétur Gordon Hermannsson; Cameron L. C. Smth
corresponding_authors: Anders Kristensen; Christoph Vannahme; Pétur Gordon Hermannsson; Cameron L. C. Smth
abstract: Organic dye based distributed feed-back lasers, featuring narrow linewidth and thus high quality spectral resolution, are used as highly sensitive refractive index sensors. The design, fabrication and application of the laser intra-cavity sensors are discussed.

title: Tunable fiber Bragg gratings at 1.3 μm to improve the characterization of InAs Quantum Dot emission
authors: Guillermo Muñoz‐Matutano; David Rivas Góngora; Amelia Lavinia Ricchiuti; David Barrera; Carlos R. Fernández‐Pousa; Juan P. Martínez‐Pastor; L. Seravalli; Giovanna Trevisi; P. Frigeri; Salvador Sales
abstract: Tunable FBG at 1.3 μm has been employed to improve the characterization of QD compared to conventional grating monochromators. Using this technique, single metamorphic InAs/GaAs QDs has been characterized by time-resolved photoluminescence.

title: Dynamic Photoacoustic Spectroscopy for Trace Gas Detection
authors: Charles M. Wynn; Michelle L. Clark; Roderick R. Kunz
corresponding_authors: Charles M. Wynn; Michelle L. Clark; Roderick R. Kunz
abstract: Dynamic photoacoustic spectroscopy (DPAS) is a trace-gas sensing technique recently developed at MIT Lincoln Laboratory. It is a novel laser-based means of remotely sensing extremely low concentrations of gases.

title: Room Temperature Terahertz photodetectors based on two-dimensional nanomaterials
authors: Miriam S. Vitiello
corresponding_authors: Miriam S. Vitiello
abstract: The raising interest in Teraherz radiation (loosely defined as the 0.1–10 THz frequency range, 3000 – 30 μm wavelength range) and in the related application-oriented issues, requires the development of sensitive and performing systems exploiting powerful, stable and coherent sources as well as fast, sensitive and portable photodetectors. These key priorities prompted in the last decade a major surge of interdisciplinary research encompassing the investigation of different technologies in-between optics and microwave electronics, different physical mechanisms and a large variety of material systems offering ad-hoc properties to target the expected performance and functionalities.

title: Single-mode Polariton Laser in a Designable Microcavity
authors: Hui Deng
corresponding_authors: Hui Deng
abstract: We demonstrate strong coupling and a coherent polariton laser in a microcavity consisting of a sub-wavelength grating in the top mirror. The designable grating mirror allows 3D confinement, polarization selectivity, and dispersion engineering by design.

title: Brillouin and Raman Scattering in Silicon and Siliconnitride Photonic Integrated Circuits
authors: Roel Baets
corresponding_authors: Roel Baets
abstract: The large refractive index contrast in silicon and siliconnitride nanophotonic waveguides allows for strong interaction between photons and phonons, between light and vibration or sound. This strong interaction has many different flavours and can be exploited in many different ways. Some of the recent advances in this field will be reviewed.

title: Control of Tm-doped Nanocrystal Precipitation and Upconversion in Glass-ceramics using CO2 laser
authors: Dong-Seon Kim; Jinho Lee; Ki-Soo Lim
abstract: Formation of CaF2 nanocrystals codoped with Tm and Yb ions in glass-ceramics has been controlled by power and exposure time of CO2 laser beam. Micro x-ray diffraction analysis showed two phases of CaF2 and Ca2SiO4. The glass-ceramics containing nanocrystals showed much enhanced upconversion emission from Tm3+ ions under 980 nm excitation due to energy transfer from Yb3+ to Tm3+ ions.

title: Mid-infrared spectroscopic imaging enabled by an array of Ge-filled waveguides in a microstructured optical fiber probe
authors: Xiaoyu Ji; Baigang Zhang; M. Krishnamurthi; John V. Badding; Venkatraman Gopalan
corresponding_authors: Xiaoyu Ji; Baigang Zhang; M. Krishnamurthi; John V. Badding; Venkatraman Gopalan
abstract: The proof-of-concept of mid-infrared spectroscopic imaging on biological tissues using a unique semiconductor-filled optical fiber probe is demonstrated [1]. This fiber design could potentially promote the advent of next-generation high resolution infrared medical endoscope technology.

title: Interaction of soliton with exceptional point defect in P T-symmetric coupler
authors: Yu. V. Bludov; Chao Hang; Guoxiang Huang; V. V. Konotop
abstract: We study interaction of a soliton in a parity-time symmetric coupler which has local perturbation of the coupling constant, achieving the exceptional point. We found different scenarios of bright soliton interaction with this defect.

title: Reversible photodegradation of organic-dye-based random lasers
authors: Benjamin R. Anderson; Ray Gunawidjaja; Hergen Eilers
corresponding_authors: Benjamin R. Anderson; Ray Gunawidjaja; Hergen Eilers
abstract: We report on the observation of self-healing after photodegradation in several different organic-dye-doped polymer random lasers. For each material the lasing intensity is found to fully recover after the damaging beam is blocked.

title: Coded Modulation Design for Robustness against Linear and Nonlinear Distortion
authors: David S. Millar
corresponding_authors: David S. Millar
abstract: In recent years, design of coding and modulation formats for the optical fiber channel has become increasingly important. We review different design methodologies for optimizing coded performance against linear and nonlinear distortion. The impact of soft-decision FEC is discussed, along with the different optical channels that are commonly encountered.

title: New Radio-Frequency Photonic Filter based on photonic-phononic emitter-receivers
authors: Heedeuk Shin; Jonathan A. Cox; Robert Jarecki; Andrew Starbuck; Zheng Wang; Peter T. Rakich
abstract: A new on-chip RF photonic filter based on the photon-phonon interaction is demonstrated. The measured RF filtering responses show the unprecedented combination of high power handling, wavelength insensitivity, and second-order filtering performances.

title: A broadband mid-infrared supercontinuum generation using Ge11.5As24Se64.5 channel waveguide
authors: Mohammad Rezaul Karim; B. M. A. Rahman; Govind P. Agrawal
corresponding_authors: Mohammad Rezaul Karim; B. M. A. Rahman; Govind P. Agrawal
abstract: We investigate mid-infrared supercontinuum generation in dispersion-engineered Ge11.5As24Se64.5 ChG-glass channel waveguides through numerical simulation. A broadband SC spanning from 1.8 to 9 µm could be generated with a moderate peak power of 3 kW.

title: Noise-induced traveling Nozaki-Bekki holes and vortices in experimental drifting patterns
authors: Marcel G. Clerc; S. Coulibaly; Francisco del Campo; Mónica A. García-Ñustes; E. Louvergneaux; Mario Wilson
corresponding_authors: Marcel G. Clerc; S. Coulibaly; Francisco del Campo; Mónica A. García-Ñustes; E. Louvergneaux; Mario Wilson
abstract: We show that, in drifting systems, noise is responsible for inducing permanent traveling phase singularities by generating specific initial conditions. Experimentally, these defects are evidenced in a Kerr medium submitted to a tilted optical feedback.

title: Biochemical Limits of Detection with Near Infrared Surface Waves on Optical Fibers
authors: Jacques Albert
corresponding_authors: Jacques Albert
abstract: Precise control of the phase, amplitude and polarization of surface waves on single-mode optical fibers with tilted fiber Bragg gratings allows for selective detection limits at picomolar levels and for monitoring living cell activity.

title: Grating Fabrication and Metal Filling in Six-Hole Microstructured Optical Fiber
authors: Jie Wang; Ravi Bhushan; Zhengyong Liu; A. Ping Zhang; Yonghang Shen; Hwa‐Yaw Tam
corresponding_authors: Jie Wang; Ravi Bhushan; Zhengyong Liu; A. Ping Zhang; Yonghang Shen; Hwa‐Yaw Tam
abstract: We present the fabrication of six-hole microstructured optical fiber (SH-MOF) for grating fabrication and metal filling. Fiber Bragg grating is fabricated in the core and BiSnIn is filled into the micro-holes of the SH-MOF.

title: Double-layered gold gratings as refractive index sensors with ultrahigh figure of merits
authors: Yang Shen; Chongjun Jin
corresponding_authors: Yang Shen; Chongjun Jin
abstract: Refractive index (RI) sensors based on localized surface plasmon resonances (LSPR) have attracted lots of attentions due to its potential applications in "point-of-care" clinical devices. In this presentation, we will review the progress in the field of LSPR-based RI sensor. Then LSPR-based RI sensing properties of double-layered gold gratings separated by dielectric gratings were studied. Two-dimensional double-layered gold gratings, named as gold mushroom arrays, show a superior advantage as a LSPR-based RI sensor because their figure of merits can reach 108 as high as the theoretical predicted upper limit for the propagating surface plasmon resonance (PSPR)-based RI sensor. However, such a high FOM is obtained under a detection light with an oblique incident angle which is still not a favorable testing scheme, because it increases the complexity of the system. Therefore, we also proposed another RI sensor based on one-dimensional double layer gold gratings working under normal incidence, which gives a high FOM as well.

title: Integrated Photonics Institute for Manufacturing Innovation (IP-IMI): Providing state-of-the-art integrated photonics manufacturing technology for U.S. Industry, Academia, and Government
authors: Peter G. Goetz
corresponding_authors: Peter G. Goetz
abstract: The IP-IMI is a government/industry collaboration creating an integrated photonics manufacturing ecosystem in the US. Commercial foundries and optimized standard component libraries will enable high quality manufacturing, test, and packaging for fabless photonic circuit designers.

title: Anisotropy of phase-matched third harmonic generation in germanium-doped silica optical fiber
authors: Adrien Borne; Katsura Tomotaka; Benoı̂t Boulanger; C. Félix; Patricia Segonds; Kamel Bencheikh; J. A. Levenson
abstract: We performed intermodal third harmonic generation around 515 nm in a germanium-doped silica optical fiber. The complex polarization behavior that was observed is well-described by uniaxial symmetry of the third order electric susceptibility.

title: Tunable Thin Film Optics and Metamaterials Based on Vanadium Dioxide
authors: Mikhail A. Kats
corresponding_authors: Mikhail A. Kats
abstract: We exploited the insulator-to-metal phase transition of vanadium dioxide (VO2) to create tunable thin film optical components and metasurfaces in the mid-infrared spectral range. Thermally and electrically tunable modulators and thermal emitters are demonstrated.

title: Mid-IR Fiberoptic Sensing and Mode Control in Distributed Feedback Quantum Cascade Laser
authors: Guy-Maël De Naurois
corresponding_authors: Guy-Maël De Naurois

title: Gravitational Phenomena Using Thermal Nonlinear Interactions
authors: Rivka Bekenstein; Ran Schley; Maor Mutzafi; Carmel Rotschild; Ido Dolev; Ady Arie; Mordechai Segev
corresponding_authors: Rivka Bekenstein; Ran Schley; Maor Mutzafi; Carmel Rotschild; Ido Dolev; Ady Arie; Mordechai Segev
abstract: By utilizing long-range interactions between solitons and accelerating beams in thermal nonlocal nonlinear media we demonstrate optical analogues of gravitational effects, such as tidal forces, gravitational lensing and gravitational redshift.

title: Signal Processing Opportunities for Next Generation >100 Gb/s DWDM and Single-λ Data Communication Networks
authors: Johannes von Lindeiner
corresponding_authors: Johannes von Lindeiner
abstract: We review recent advances in IM/DD systems and demonstrate how by exploiting low complexity and novel DSP structures, severely band-limited PAM-4 and OOK signals at 100 Gb/s+ may be implemented in DWDM and single-λ networks.

title: Hybrid Optoplasmonic Structures and Materials: from New Physics to New Functionalities
authors: Svetlana V. Boriskina; Jonathan Tong; Yi Huang; Lee A. Weinstein; Wei‐Chun Hsu; Gang Chen; Wonmi Ahn; Yan Hong; Björn M. Reinhard
corresponding_authors: Svetlana V. Boriskina; Jonathan Tong; Yi Huang; Lee A. Weinstein; Wei‐Chun Hsu; Gang Chen; Wonmi Ahn; Yan Hong; Björn M. Reinhard
abstract: We develop hybrid optoplasmonic architectures to tailor resonant energy transfer between trapped photons, plasmons, quantum emitters and elementary heat carriers for applications in near- and far-field emission manipulation, radiative cooling, imaging, and ultrasensitive detection.

title: Spatial Coded Modulation Method with Multi-core Fiber for Efficient Transmission
authors: Yoshinari Awaji
corresponding_authors: Yoshinari Awaji
abstract: We describe families of modulation formats for spatial super-channels which exploit the increased dimensionality and uniformity of parallel cores in multi-core fibers. Measurements reveal advantages in power and spectral efficiency over equivalent single-core formats.

title: Plasmon-Induced Nonlinearities in Polarized Materials
authors: Roderick B. Davidson; Benjamin J. Lawrie; Ying‐Zhong Ma; Richard F. Haglund
abstract: Optically excited plasmons are used to generate steep electric field gradients to alter the polarization of bulk materials. Ultrafast optical control of the polarization response is monitored by an orthogonally polarized supercontinuum probe.

title: Digital Coherent W-band MIMO Radio-over-Fiber Systems
authors: Ken-ichi Kitayama; Yuki Yoshida; Atsushi Kanno; Tetsuya Kawanishi
abstract: We present digital coherent W-band MIMO RoF system and its collected digital signal processing for optical and wireless signal. Its high resilience of dual optical wireless link will find immediate application to disaster recovery.

title: Sensing the Dielectric Properties of Metals at THz Frequencies Using Inverse Symmetry Broken Metamaterials
authors: Hannes Merbold; Yannik Weber; Axel Murk; Thomas Feurer
abstract: Positive and inverse, asymmetric, double split-ring resonator structures are analyzed experimentally and numerically. The structures exhibit very sharp dark resonances which allow probing the dielectric properties of metals at THz frequencies.

title: Broadband Frequency Combs and Terahertz Spectroscopy of Complex Materials
authors: Dmitry Yarotski; Rohit P. Prasankumar; Mark J. Hagmann; Rolando Valdés Aguilar; Pamela Bowlan; Sang‐Wook Cheong; Seung Jae Oh; A. J. Taylor
abstract: We discuss a broadband frequency comb generation by intermode mixing of ultrashort laser pulses in a tunneling junction, and applications of THz spectroscopy to reveal non-equilibrium dynamics in topological insulators and multiferroic materials.

title: Design, fabrication and characterization of suspended silicon nitride photonic crystal nanocavities
authors: Λουκάς Αθανασέκος; Aristi Christofi; N. Papanikolaou
abstract: We report on the design, fabrication and characterization of PhC cavities in Si3N4 suspended nanowires. Electromagnetic simulations indicate that the structures are promising to achieve strong light localization in visible and near infrared region.

title: Towards On-Chip Quantum Networks based on Spin Qubits in Diamond
authors: Tim Schröder; Luozhou Li; Edward H. Chen; Sara Mouradian; Michael Walsh; Igal Bayn; Matthew E. Trusheim; Jiabao Zheng; Ming Lu; Mircea Cotlet; H. Bakhru; Matthew Markham; Daniel J. Twitchen; Carl B. Poitras; Michal Lipson; Dirk Englund
abstract: A central aim of quantum information processing is the efficient entanglement of multiple stationary quantum memories via photons. Recently, quantum entanglement and teleportation have been shown between two nitrogen-vacancy memories (NV)1, but scaling to larger networks requires more efficient spin-photon interfaces, using optical resonators and efficient nanophotonic collection strategies. Here, we discuss progress towards the development of on-chip photonic integrated circuits (PICs) with multiple NV quantum memories entangled via photons.

title: Quantum Nonlinear Optical Interactions between Graphene Plasmons
authors: Darrick E. Chang
corresponding_authors: Darrick E. Chang
abstract: Graphene has attracted strong interest recently as a unique optical material. We discuss how its unique properties should enable a variety of nonlinear optical processes to be engineered, and to be strong even at the level of single photons.

title: Highly Nonlinear Soft Glass Microstructured Optical Fiber
authors: Yasutake Ohishi
corresponding_authors: Yasutake Ohishi
abstract: New microstructured optical fiber are developed using highly nonlinear soft glasses. Chromatic dispersions can be controlled better than conventional MOFs. Performances of supercontinuum and optical parametric gain are presented.

title: Metasurfaces based on artificially induced phase coexistence in phase-change materials
authors: Jura Rensberg; Shuyan Zhang; Alexander McLeod; Christian Schwarz; Michael Goldflam; Ronny Nawrodt; Mengkun Liu; Jochen Kerbusch; You Zhou; Shriram Ramanathan; D. N. Basov; Federico Capasso; Carsten Ronning; Mikhail A. Kats
abstract: We demonstrate a new type of tunable metasurface based on ultra-thin films of phase change materials. Effective optical properties arise from coexistence of a metallic and an insulating phase induced by patterned ion irradiation.

title: Ultra Compact Optical Switches and Polarization Splitter based on Non-Symmetric Slotted Si Wire Waveguides
authors: Raktim Haldar; Vishwatosh Mishra; Shailendra K. Varshney
corresponding_authors: Raktim Haldar; Vishwatosh Mishra; Shailendra K. Varshney
abstract: In this work we propose a novel and compact design of optical switches, directional couplers and polarization splitters by optimizing the slot position and coupling coefficients between two symmetric and non-symmetric slotted Si wire waveguides.

title: Optical Sensing and Light Modulation with Atomically Thin Materials
authors: F. Javier Garcı́a de Abajo
corresponding_authors: F. Javier Garcı́a de Abajo
abstract: We discuss recent advances in the study of graphene and other atomically thin materials for light modulation and sensing, including visible light switching, strong nonlinearities in nanographenes, and plasmons in atomic scale systems.

title: Femtosecond Maker Fringe measurement of discrete non-linearities in poled multi-layer silica structures
authors: Pouyan Nasr; Ksenia Yadav; Christopher W. Smelser
corresponding_authors: Pouyan Nasr; Ksenia Yadav; Christopher W. Smelser
abstract: In this presentation the use of femtosecond pulses to produce Maker Fringes in poled silica structures is studied. The impact of the discrete nature of the non-linearity in multi-layer structures is modeled.

title: Generation of Broadband Supercontinuum through Nonlinear Interaction in DNA Materials
authors: Young‐Ho Cho; Byoungho Park; Juyeong Oh; Hyo‐Suk Kim; Kwanil Lee; Minah Seo; Chulki Kim; Taikjin Lee; Young Min Jhon; Seok Lee; Hyung Min Kim; Sung Ha Park; Dong‐Il Yeom; Jae Hun Kim
corresponding_authors: Young‐Ho Cho; Byoungho Park; Juyeong Oh; Hyo‐Suk Kim; Kwanil Lee; Minah Seo; Chulki Kim; Taikjin Lee; Young Min Jhon; Seok Lee; Hyung Min Kim; Sung Ha Park; Dong‐Il Yeom; Jae Hun Kim
abstract: We demonstrated supercontinuum generation through DNA materials. The DNA material, which is modified copper ion, provided optical nonlinearity within a hollow optical fiber. The supercontinuum spectrum is optimized by fiber length and copper ion concentration for the bandwidth of more than 800nm.

title: Wave instabilities in nonlinear Schrödinger systems with non vanishing background
authors: S. Trillo; J. S. Totero; Andrea Fratalocchi
corresponding_authors: S. Trillo; J. S. Totero; Andrea Fratalocchi
abstract: We investigate wave collapse in the generalized nonlinear Schrödinger (NLS) equation and in the presence of a non vanishing background. Through the use of virial identities, we establish a new criterion for blow-up.

title: The Emergence of 100G Metro – How to Crack into the New Market Segment
authors: Maxim Kuschnerov
corresponding_authors: Maxim Kuschnerov
abstract: New technologies emerge for metro optical networks, such as flex-rate modulation, pluggable coherent optics or new direct detect solutions. They differ in performance, price and footprint and require various network architectures discussed in this presentation. Article not available.

title: Complex energy landscape dynamics at the origin of rogue wave soliton formation
authors: Andrea Armaroli; Claudio Conti; Fabio Biancalana
corresponding_authors: Andrea Armaroli; Claudio Conti; Fabio Biancalana
