title: Observation of Poynting’s Vector Reversal in a Cavity with Net Gain
authors: Ali K. Jahromi; Ayman F. Abouraddy
abstract: We report the first observation of Poynting's vector reversal in an active optical cavity, which results in a counter-intuitive drop in the transmission and reflection when the total gain exceeds the lasing threshold.

title: High-density Space Division Multiplexed Transmission over Multi-mode and Multi-core Fibers
authors: Chigo Okonkwo
corresponding_authors: Chigo Okonkwo
abstract: By employing compact multiplexers and advanced coding and multiple input multiple output equalization schemes, we demonstrate the viability of a high spatial channel multiplicity over multi-mode and/or multi-core fibers for high capacity transmission.

title: Metal-Insulator-Silicon-Insulator-Metal Waveguide with Its Insulator Replaced by Fluid
authors: Bonwoo Ku; Jin-Soo Shin; Min-Suk Kwon
abstract: Metal-insulator-silicon-insulator-metal waveguides, realized by using standard CMOS technology, are modified into plasmofluidic waveguides. The insulator of the former is replaced by fluid to implement the latter. The plasmofluidic waveguides are experimentally and theoretically investigated.

title: Precision Frequency Metrology with Parametric Micro-resonator Combs
authors: Scott A. Diddams
corresponding_authors: Scott A. Diddams
abstract: We describe 10+ GHz parametric frequency combs at 1550nm using high-Q silica micro-resonators. We realize a microcomb optical clock that divides terahertz frequencies to the microwave domain and demonstrate coherent octave-spanning spectra for self-referencing.

title: Optical characteristics of Mn2+ doped ZnS nanoparticles for laser based bio-sensing
authors: Jinseob Kim; Kyoungyoon Park; Luis Alonso Vazquez-Zuniga; Hyuntai Kim; Mingon Han; Yoonchan Jeong
corresponding_authors: Jinseob Kim; Kyoungyoon Park; Luis Alonso Vazquez-Zuniga; Hyuntai Kim; Mingon Han; Yoonchan Jeong
abstract: We synthesize ZnS:Mn2+ nanoparticles using a simplified co-precipitation method. The XRD, HR-TEM and PL analyses were performed to prove the validity of the method. Their characteristics are very comparable with those by conventional methods.

title: Statistical description of soliton clustering in fiber lasers with slow-gain dynamics
authors: J. Nathan Kutz; Philippe Grelu
corresponding_authors: J. Nathan Kutz; Philippe Grelu
abstract: We demonstrate theoretically that the dynamic clustering of solitons observed in a variety of experiments are due to the initial phase and position of interacting solitons with the slow gain dynamics of the fiber laser.

title: Enhanced Brillouin scattering in silica via saturable phonon losses
authors: Ryan O. Behunin; Prashanta Kharel; William H. Renninger; Heedeuk Shin; F. Carter; Eric A. Kittlaus; Peter T. Rakich
abstract: Acoustic dissipation in silica is dominated by defects that act as saturable absorbers at cryogenic temperatures. Using stimulated Brillouin spectroscopy we demonstrate that this loss channel can be mitigated in fiber, enhancing Brillouin gain.

title: Spectroscopic properties of LaF3:Tm3+ nanoparticle-doped silica optical fibers
authors: Manuel Vermillac; Jean-François Lupi; Michèle Ude; Stanislaw Trzesien; Bernard Dussardier; Wilfried Blanc; O. Totterau; Philippe Vennéguès; Courtney Kucera; John Ballato
corresponding_authors: Manuel Vermillac; Jean-François Lupi; Michèle Ude; Stanislaw Trzesien; Bernard Dussardier; Wilfried Blanc; O. Totterau; Philippe Vennéguès; Courtney Kucera; John Ballato
abstract: Silica-based fibers doped with LaF3 :Tm3+ nanoparticles, prepared by MCVD and solution doping exhibited a fluorescence lifetime of 70 µs at 810 and 1470 nm, with background losses below 0.1 dB/m at 1300 nm.

title: Statistical analysis of spatial frequency supercontinuum in pattern forming feedback systems
authors: V. Odent; Mikhail I. Kolobov; M. Taki; E. Louvergneaux
corresponding_authors: V. Odent; Mikhail I. Kolobov; M. Taki; E. Louvergneaux
abstract: We study numerically and experimentally highly nonlinear regime of a spatially feedback system. We perform statistical analysis of peak intensity in terms of the probability density function that we model with the Generalized Gamma Distribution.

title: Resource Orchestration for Optically Interconnected Distributed Clouds
authors: Qiong Zhang; Xi Wang; Paparao Palacharla; Motoyoshi Sekiya; Yi Zhu
abstract: We discuss technical challenges of resource orchestration and summarize our recent research on reliability-constrained resource orchestration on virtualized optical networks. We also propose a framework for distributed resource orchestration in multi-domain, multi-layer, and multi-tenant networks.

title: Concentric Multi-pixel Photodiode Array Probes For Optical Tissue Characterization
authors: Özlem Şenlik; N.M. Jokerst
abstract: This paper reports on new custom concentric Si PD array probes for spatially resolved diffuse reflectance (SRDR) measurements. The probes provide photon path information, which enables depth-resolved tissue analysis. Monte Carlo simulations of the probes were conducted to analyze malignancies of varying depths and thicknesses buried in benign tissue. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first reported compact, densely packed semiconductor SRDR probe.

title: Characterization of Fiber Nonuniformities with ppm Resolution Using Time-Resolved In-Fiber Acousto-Optics
authors: E. P. Alcusa-Sáez; A. Dı́ez; Miguel González‐Herráez; J.L. Cruz; Miguel V. Andrés
corresponding_authors: E. P. Alcusa-Sáez; A. Dı́ez; Miguel González‐Herráez; J.L. Cruz; Miguel V. Andrés
abstract: Time-resolved acousto-optic interaction using flexural waves enables the characterization of fiber nonuniformities along sections of about 1-2 m. A resolution better than 10 ppm of fiber diameter and core refractive index is demonstrated.

title: Using Multiplex Coherent Anti Stokes Raman Spectroscopy for Rapid Material Detection
authors: Stephen D. Roberson; Sherrie Bowman; Paul M. Pellegrino
abstract: Full spectroscopic identification of molecules has been hampered by the inability to use an information-rich spectroscopic method such as Raman scattering in a flowing aerosol environment due to the time needed to generate a Raman spectrum. Multiplex coherent anti-Stokes Raman spectroscopy (MCARS) has been shown to generate a complete Raman spectrum from the material of interest using a single ultrabroadband pulse to coherently drive multiple molecular vibrations simultaneously. When used in conjunction with a narrow probe pulse, a complete Raman spectrum is created that can be detected in milliseconds. We will report on the MCARS spectra obtained from materials of interest at a distance of 1 m from the sample location. We will also be reporting on an analytical method to remove the nonresonant background that utilizes a combination of the maximum entropy method to reproduce the spectrum as well as complex spectral filtering to remove the nonresonant background and accurately determine the CARS spectrum interest without prior knowledge of the material of interest.

title: Bistable optical propagation in nematic liquid crystals
authors: Armando Piccardi; Alessandro Alberucci; Nina Kravets; Oleksander Buchnev; Malgosia Kaczmarek; Gaetano Assanto
corresponding_authors: Armando Piccardi; Alessandro Alberucci; Nina Kravets; Oleksander Buchnev; Malgosia Kaczmarek; Gaetano Assanto
abstract: We demonstrate bistability when beams propagate and self-focus in nematic liquid crystals. Sample configurations subject to the Fréedericksz threshold support diffracting as well as self-confined beams for the same input power, leading to hysteresis.

title: SDM-Compatible and Mode-Selective Networking
authors: Guifang Li
corresponding_authors: Guifang Li
abstract: Spatial degrees of freedom have recently been exploited in space-division multiplexing for high-capacity transmission. This talk presents utilization of the spatial degrees of freedom as resources for optical networking in both SDM-compatible and mode-selective networks.

title: Broadband light generation in PPLN crystal and its interplay with spatial nonlinear effects
authors: Katarzyna Krupa; Alexis Labruyère; Badr Mohamed Ibrahim Shalaby; Alessandro Tonello; F. Baronio; Vincent Couderc
corresponding_authors: Katarzyna Krupa; Alexis Labruyère; Badr Mohamed Ibrahim Shalaby; Alessandro Tonello; F. Baronio; Vincent Couderc
abstract: We study spatio-temporal nonlinear dynamics in periodically-poled lithium niobate crystal. We discuss broadband conversion via cascading second harmonic generation in self-defocusing and self-focusing regime. Measurements well agree with simulations.

title: Substrate-blind photonic integration
authors: Hongtao Lin; Lan Li; Yi Zou; Qingyang Du; Okechukwu Ogbuu; Juejun Hu; Charmayne Smith; Erick Koontz; Kathleen Richardson
abstract: Using high-index glasses as the backbone optical material, both passive and active photonic devices with record performance were successfully integrated on a wide variety of substrates including semiconductors, glasses, infrared crystals, polymers, and graphene.

title: Brillouin light scattering from surface acoustic waves in photonic microwires
authors: Jean‐Charles Beugnot; Sylvie Lebrun; Gilles Pauliat; Vincent Laude; Thibaut Sylvestre
abstract: We investigate both numerically and experimentally Brillouin light scattering in sub-wavelength diameter optical fibers and report the observation of a new type of backward radiation driven by surface acoustic waves.

title: Integrated silicon optomechanical cavity-waveguide devices for coherent photonic-microwave signal processing
authors: Kejie Fang; Matt Matheny; Xingsheng Luan; Oskar Painter
abstract: In an integrated silicon optomechanical cavity-waveguide system, we demonstrated on-chip coherent photonic-microwave signal processing which shows clear advantages over purely photonic methods. Specifically, we obtain an optical delay of 13.3 µs for a phonon waveguide length of 43 µm. In addition, we demonstrated microwave filter with reconfigurable pass/rejection bands in the gigahertz frequency range due to a novel radiation-pressure force induced boundary condition change.

title: Broadband ultrathin optical absorber based on metal-dielectric nanocomposites
authors: Feng Peng; Weihua Zhang
corresponding_authors: Feng Peng; Weihua Zhang
abstract: We show broadband absorption by ultrathin metal-dielectric composite films which have abnormal dispersion behaviors at percolation threshold. The absorption property is robust, insensitive to either the morphology or the material of the components.

title: Experimentations for a plastic optical pH sensor
authors: Rui S. Carvalho; Licínio Ferreira; Tito Trindade; Paulo Lopes; Mário F. S. Ferreira
corresponding_authors: Rui S. Carvalho; Licínio Ferreira; Tito Trindade; Paulo Lopes; Mário F. S. Ferreira
abstract: In this paper we present the design of a transmissive pH sensor using plastic optical fiber (POF) and materials to entrap universal indicator. This sensor presents advantages over commercial ones namely lightweight, portability and low cost.

title: Visible range hollow waveguides by guided buckling of Ta2O5/SiO2 multilayers
authors: A. Melnyk; T. W. Allen; R. G. DeCorby
abstract: Hollow waveguides operating near 550 nm wavelength were fabricated by guided formation of delamination buckles within Ta2O5/SiO2 multilayers. Fabrication of straight and curved waveguides is described, along with preliminary light guiding results.

title: Ultra-broadband and Ultra-fast Optical Signal Processing
authors: Leif Katsuo Oxenløwe
corresponding_authors: Leif Katsuo Oxenløwe
abstract: We have recently seen that nanowires can provide unparalleled optical signal processing (OSP) bandwidth and provide ultra-fast operation as well. Utilising the ultra-broad OSP bandwidth for e.g. optical time lenses allows for energy-efficient optical switching. © 2015 OSA.

title: Dissipative Vectorial Solitons in Semiconductor Lasers
authors: M. Marconi; J. Javaloyes; S. Barland; S. Balle; M. Giudici
corresponding_authors: M. Marconi; J. Javaloyes; S. Barland; S. Balle; M. Giudici
abstract: Nonlinear polarization dynamics of VCSELs with a long-delay external cavity lead to vectorial dissipative solitons. The large temporal aspect-ratio enables the observation of multiple -- independent and/or bound -- solitons within the same roundtrip.

title: A Unified Control Architecture for Software Defined Packet over Optical Networks Using Resource Buffering
authors: Xiaohui Chen; Nan Hua; Xiaoping Zheng
abstract: We propose a software-defined unified control architecture for packet over optical networks based on "super virtual router". Analytical and simulation results show that fast and seamless connection establishment can be achieved by using resource buffering.

title: The development of bend-insensitive, highly-birefringent and spun, circularly birefringent fibers for ‘real world’, commercial sensors
authors: Chris Emslie
corresponding_authors: Chris Emslie
abstract: After 30 years for fiber sensors are a commercial reality. Specialty Fibers lie at the heart of FOG, hydrophones, geophones and current sensors. This paper tracks their development and emphasises their differences from conventional fibers.

title: Design of compact polarization splitter using silicon nanowires
authors: Sasan Soudi; B. M. A. Rahman
abstract: Design of an ultra-compact polarization splitter based on silicon-on-insulator platform is presented. Important waveguide design parameters have been analyzed by using full-vectorial H-field finite-element and least squares boundary residual methods.

title: Few-mode Fibers and Equalization Technique for MDM Transmission with MIMO DSP
authors: Takayoshi Mori
corresponding_authors: Takayoshi Mori
abstract: We review recent work on few-mode fibers for mode-division-multiplexed transmission with MIMO DSP and introduce our low DMD 10-spatial-mode fiber and equipartition multiplexing technique for equalizing channel dependent impairment induced by MDL and modal cross-talk.

title: Direct-band-gap, Pseudo Single Crystal GeSn on Amorphous Layers towards 3D Integrated Photonics and Flexible Photonics
authors: Haofeng Li; Xiaoxin Wang; Jifeng Liu
corresponding_authors: Haofeng Li; Xiaoxin Wang; Jifeng Liu
abstract: High-crystallinity, direct-band-gap Ge0.89Sn0.11 is achieved at <450°C on amorphous dielectric layers and flexible substrates. The geometrically confined growth of pseudo-single-crystal Ge0.89Sn0.11 enables monolithic, large-scale 3D Si photonics.

title: High Gain Nonlinear Optical Materials for the Mid-Infrared
authors: Peter G. Schunemann
corresponding_authors: Peter G. Schunemann
abstract: Advances in growth of bulk birefringent crystals ZnGeP2 and CdSiP2, as well as all-epitaxial growth of orientation-patterned GaAs (OP-GaAs) and GaP (OP-GaP), are enabling development of highly-efficient frequency-shifted mid-infrared laser sources.

title: Quantum Nonlinear Plasmonics in the Strong Coupling Regime
authors: Roderick B. Davidson; Pavel Lougovski; Benjamin J. Lawrie
abstract: The experimental development of a plasmonic analogue to cavity-quantum-electrodynamics is guided by a full quantum model for a plasmonic resonator coupled to a two-level emitter incorporating realizable plasmonic dispersion and field confinement.

title: Silicon Microphotonics: High Volume Manufacturing
authors: Lionel C. Kimerling
corresponding_authors: Lionel C. Kimerling
abstract: Cost, Energy and Bandwidth Density system requirements are driving photonic interconnection to shorter distances and to higher levels of integration. The number of optical interconnects scales inversely with distance to the chip. Silicon Microphotonics is capable of both high volume production and high levels of integration to meet this challenge.

title: Phase matched second harmonic generation from a metal coated rippled core optical fiber
authors: J. Parashar
corresponding_authors: J. Parashar
abstract: A metal coated, rippled core optical fiber supports a surface plasma wave. The surface plasma wave produces a resonant second harmonic as the ripple provides the additional momentum required to compensate for the phase mismatch between second harmonic and fundamental wave.

title: Self-powered Flexible Photodetector on Bio-cellulose Structure
authors: Jingda Wu; Lih Y. Lin
abstract: A self-powered Schottky junction flexible UV photodetector with a simple structure is fabricated on a reed membrane having ZnO nanocrystals embedded. Consistent and fast photoresponses are observed under zero bias with UV light illumination.

title: THz Parallel-Plate Waveguides with Resonant Cavities
authors: Kimberly S. Reichel; Victoria Astley; Krzysztof Iwaszczuk; Peter Uhd Jepsen; Rajind Mendis; Daniel M. Mittleman
abstract: We characterize the terahertz resonance due to a cavity inside aparallel-plate waveguide, and discuss its use for refractive index sensing. Insidethe waveguide, we observe a broadband field enhancement associated with thisnarrowband resonance. © 2015 OSA.

title: Nonlinear Crosstalk Mitigation in Superchannels Using Unequal Subcarrier Spacing
authors: Olga Vassilieva; Shoichiro Oda; Tomohiro Yamauchi; Inwoong Kim; Takeshi Hoshida; Yasuhiko Aoki; Jens C. Rasmussen; Motoyoshi Sekiya
abstract: We propose a novel technique to mitigate nonlinear crosstalk in superchannels by allocating wider spacing between center subcarriers compared to the edge. We demonstrate that it can equalize subcarriers performance and extend reach by 15%.

title: Distributed measurement of vibrations in a ramified fiber structure using phase sensitive optical time domain reflectometry and wavelength routing concepts
authors: Juan Pastor Graells; Hugo F. Martins; Sonia Martín‐López; Miguel González‐Herráez
abstract: We show the possibility of fully distributed measurement of vibrations in a complex fiber topology using phase-sensitive optical time-domain reflectometry (ΦOTDR) and wavelength routing. This could enable the monitoring of complex structures showing ramifications.

title: New pump and signal combiners
authors: Hakan Sayınc; Thomas Theeg; Gabriel Pelegrina-Bonilla; Katharina Hausmann; Henrik Tünnermann; P. Weßels; Jörg Neumann; Dietmar Kracht
corresponding_authors: Hakan Sayınc; Thomas Theeg; Gabriel Pelegrina-Bonilla; Katharina Hausmann; Henrik Tünnermann; P. Weßels; Jörg Neumann; Dietmar Kracht
abstract: We used numerical methods to study light coupling between non identical fibers. Our investigations enabled us to develop combiners which represent a significant improvement beyond the state of the art.

title: Quantum dot based quantum optics
authors: Valérian Giesz; Niccolò Somaschi; Lorenzo De Santis; Simone Luca Portalupi; Christophe Arnold; Olivier Gazzano; A. K. Nowak; A. Lemaı̂tre; I. Sagnes; L. Lanco; P. Senellart
abstract: We explore the possibility to implement a solid state quantum network based on semiconductor quantum dots in microcavities. The cavity enhanced light matter coupling allows creating a very efficient interface between the quantum dot and the optical far field. We deterministically position a single quantum dot in a connected pillar microcavity combined with a p-i-n junction and fabricate tunable ultrabright single photon sources. The collection efficiency is shown to exceed 60% and the indistinguishability of photons successively emitted by one device is in the 80-97% range depending on the excitation conditions. The quantum interference of photons emitted by two remote devices is shown to be greatly enhanced by the acceleration of spontaneous emission. Finally, we explore the possibility to store the quantum information on a longer time scale using the spin states of a hole in a quantum dot. We demonstrate the non-destructive measurement of a single spin by monitoring the spin dependent rotation of polarization of a probe beam: a polarization rotation of ±6° is observed depending on the spin state.

title: Engineering of Specialty IR Fiber Cables
authors: L. E. Busse; Frederic H. Kung; Catalin Florea; L. Brandon Shaw; Ishwar D. Aggarwal; J. S. Sanghera
corresponding_authors: L. E. Busse; Frederic H. Kung; Catalin Florea; L. Brandon Shaw; Ishwar D. Aggarwal; J. S. Sanghera
abstract: Ruggedized cables designed for specialty IR fibers were successfully tested for laser transmission and under harsh environmental conditions. Antireflective surfaces on the fiber endfaces reduced reflections and increased IR laser damage thresholds.

title: A Robust Wide-Angle Beam Propagation Solution Method for Large Problems
authors: G. Ronald Hadley
corresponding_authors: G. Ronald Hadley
abstract: This paper describes a robust iterative method for the solution of the wide-angle beam propagation equation for a two-dimensional optical field. The method is fast and allows the use of very large grids.

title: Modal Analysis in Fused-Type Mode-Selective Fiber Couplers
authors: Gabriel Pelegrina-Bonilla; Katharina Hausmann; Hakan Sayınc; Uwe Morgner; Jörg Neumann; Dietmar Kracht
corresponding_authors: Gabriel Pelegrina-Bonilla; Katharina Hausmann; Hakan Sayınc; Uwe Morgner; Jörg Neumann; Dietmar Kracht
abstract: LP11-type mode-selective couplers are fabricated by well-defined etching and pretapering. Coupler characteristics are reproduced by simulations and the impact of coupler geometry on the modal weight of the excited modes is analyzed by modal decomposition.

title: Terahertz near-field spectroscopy through a sub-wavelength size aperture
authors: Oleg Mitrofanov; Irina Khromova; F. Dominec; P. Kužel; J. L. Reno; Igal Brener; U‐Chan Chung; Catherine Elissalde; Mario Maglione; Patrick Mounaix
abstract: We demonstrate terahertz near-field spectroscopy of resonances in sub-wavelength size dielectric and conductive structures using the effect of enhanced transmission through a sub-wavelength aperture in the presence on a resonator.

title: Nonlinear Optomechanical Patterns and Dissipative Solitons
authors: G. Labeyrie; Enrico Tesio; P. M. Gomes; Gian‐Luca Oppo; W. J. Firth; G. R. M. Robb; Aidan S. Arnold; R. I. Kaiser; T. Ackemann
corresponding_authors: G. Labeyrie; Enrico Tesio; P. M. Gomes; Gian‐Luca Oppo; W. J. Firth; G. R. M. Robb; Aidan S. Arnold; R. I. Kaiser; T. Ackemann
abstract: Experimental, theoretical and numerical evidence of optomechanical self-structuring of a laser beam in a cloud of cold atoms in a single-mirror feedback configuration is presented. Optomechanical dissipative solitons can be encoded in the atomic density.

title: Multicore Fibers For Sensing Applications
authors: R. Amezcua
corresponding_authors: R. Amezcua
abstract: Fiber optics are currently being used for sensing in a broad range of industrial applications; including temperature, strain, pressure and acoustic waves. In this talk we present a versatile sensing platform based on multicore fibers.

title: Ultratrace Quantum Plasmonic Sensing
authors: Benjamin J. Lawrie; Wenjiang Fan; Phil Evans; Raphael C. Pooser
abstract: Surface plasmon resonance (SPR) based biochemical sensors are increasingly limited by the quantum statistics of light: the shot noise limit. We demonstrate an accessible method to surpass the shot noise limit in ultratrace SPR sensors.

title: Photonic Integration at Sandia National Laboratories
authors: Anna Tauke‐Pedretti; Allen Vawter; Erik Skogen; Charles Alford; Gregory M. Peake; M. E. Overberg; Florante Cajas
abstract: This talk will discuss recent work on photonic integration for applications in optical signal processing, digital logic, and fundamental device research with an emphasis on InP-based photonic integrated circuits.

title: Dynamics of Akhmediev breathers in a dispersion-varying optical fiber
authors: A. Bendahmane; Arnaud Mussot; Pascal Szriftgiser; Antoine Le Rouge; Yves Quiquempois; Laurent Bigot; Goëry Genty; John M. Dudley; Alexandre Kudlinski
corresponding_authors: A. Bendahmane; Arnaud Mussot; Pascal Szriftgiser; Antoine Le Rouge; Yves Quiquempois; Laurent Bigot; Goëry Genty; John M. Dudley; Alexandre Kudlinski
abstract: We investigate numerically and experimentally the dynamics of Akhmediev Breathers in an optical fiber with a longitudinally step dispersion profile. We experimentally show that they can be sustained near their point of maximal compression.

title: Silicon Photonic Circuits utilizing WDM for 100Gbps Applications
authors: Andrew P. Knights
corresponding_authors: Andrew P. Knights
abstract: The application of silicon photonics (SiP) for cost-effective transceivers for use in 100Gbps data links will be discussed. Results obtained from enabling SiP components and their deployment in a scaleable WDM geometry will be described.

title: Probing bio-molecular interactions in attoliter volumes
authors: Horst Vogel; Tor Sandén; Romain Wyss; Stefan Wennmalm
corresponding_authors: Horst Vogel; Tor Sandén; Romain Wyss; Stefan Wennmalm
abstract: We report on label-free volume, concentration, and mobility analysis of single protein molecules and nanoparticles during their diffusion through a subattoliter detection volume, confined by a 100 nm aperture in a thin gold film. A high concentration of small fluorescent molecules renders the aqueous solution in the aperture brightly fluorescent. Nonfluorescent analytes diffusing into the aperture displace the fluorescent molecules in the solution, leading to a decrease of the detected fluorescence signal, while analytes diffusing out of the aperture return the fluorescence level. The resulting fluorescence fluctuations provide direct information on the volume, concentration, and mobility of the nonfluorescent analytes through fluctuation analysis in both time and amplitude.

title: Fine Resolution Optical Processors for Sub-Channel Add-Drop Multiplexing
authors: Dan M. Marom; Roy Rudnick; Noam Goldstein; Ori Golani; David Sinefeld
abstract: Photonic spectral processors based on waveguide grating routers (WGR) having ~1GHz resolution are developed for flexible sub-band add/drop with an LCoS SLM. We describe the applications and methods for correcting the WGR's phase errors.

title: Software Defined Coherent Transceivers
authors: C. Rasmussen; M. Aydinlik
abstract: The flexibility of software defined transceivers enables a new level of network optimization but also presents design challenges for the coherent ASIC and other components in the transceiver as we will discuss in this paper.

title: Hybrid III-V Silicon Photonic Integrated Circuits
authors: Guang–Hua Duan; Guillaume Levaufre; Alexandre Shen; Nils Girard; S. Olivier; Stéphane Malhouitre; A. Accard; Christophe Jany; A. Le Liepvre; D. Maké; F. Lelarge; J. Décobert; G. de Valicourt; Karen Ribaud; Christophe Kopp
abstract: Recent advances on hybrid III-V silicon photonic integrated circuits using a wafer bonding technique are reported, with particular attention on the wavelength division multiplexing transmitters integrating distributed feedback lasers and semiconductor optical amplifiers.

title: Quantum Interfaces Based on Nanophotonic Systems
authors: Mikhail D. Lukin
corresponding_authors: Mikhail D. Lukin
abstract: We will discuss recent developments at a new scientific interface between quantum optics and nano science involving realization of hybrid systems combining quantum emitters and nanophotonic devices. We will discuss how these techniques are used for realization of quantum nonlinear optics and quantum networks.

title: Creation and Annihilation Dynamics of Temporal Cavity Solitons
authors: Miro Erkintalo; Jae K. Jang; Kathy Qian Luo; Stuart G. Murdoch; Stéphane Coen
abstract: We review recent results on the creation and annihilation of temporal cavity soli-tons. We focus on experiments in macroscopic fibre resonators, but also discuss connections to optical frequency combs generated in monolithic microresonators.

title: Selfhealing of asymmetric Bessel-like modes
authors: Stine Møller Israelsen; Lars Søgaard Rishøj; Karsten Rottwitt
corresponding_authors: Stine Møller Israelsen; Lars Søgaard Rishøj; Karsten Rottwitt
abstract: We numerically investigate asymmetric Bessel-like modes in an aircladding fiber. The selfhealing ability of asymmetric Bessel-like modes is demonstrated and quantified including the angular dependency of this ability.

title: Principle of Optical Cooling by Exciton-Polariton anti-Stokes Scattering
authors: Maxime Richard; Sebastian Klembt; Emilien Durupt; Thorsten Klein; A. Baas; Yoan Léger; Sanjoy Datta; Anna Minguzzi
abstract: In this experimental work, we demonstrate that a cold exciton-polariton fluid un-dergoes anti-Stokes scattering with thermal phonons, and thus behaves like a nonequilibrium coolant for its host solid-state semiconductor microcavity.

title: Enhancing Silver Photocathode Performance by Exciting Surface Plasmon Resonance on Ag corrugated thin films
authors: Zhaozhu Li; Kaida Yang; Mike Klopf; Jose Riso; R. A. Lukaszew
abstract: The silver photocathodes have been limited into application due to its low quantum efficiency. We explore the enhancement of silver photocathode performance by exciting surface plasmon resonance on grating Ag thin film to overcome high reflectivity.

title: Simultaneous determination of moisture and thickness of leather using terahertz time domain spectroscopy
authors: A. I. Hernandez-Serrano; S. C. Corzo-Garcia; Ernesto García; Mariana Alfaro-Gómez; Enrique Castro-Camus
abstract: Moisture content and thickness of leather are measured using terahertz time domain spectroscopy combined with effective-medium theory. This method is a new noninvasive technique. The results are in good agreement with conventional techniques.

title: Nonlinear combining of laser beams in optical waveguide
authors: Pavel M. Lushnikov; Natalia Vladimirova
corresponding_authors: Pavel M. Lushnikov; Natalia Vladimirova
abstract: We consider a combining of multiple laser beams into a single diffraction-limited beam by the beam self-focusing (collapse) in the Kerr medium. The beams with the total power above critical are first combined in the near field and then propagated in the optical fiber/waveguide with the Kerr nonlinearity. Random fluctuations during propagation eventually trigger strong self-focusing event and produce diffraction-limited beam carrying the critical power.

title: Experimental demonstration of electro-refractive phase modulators based on graphene
authors: Muhammad Mohsin; Anna Lena Giesecke; Daniel Neumaier; Daniel Schall; Martin Otto; C. Matheisen; Abhay A. Sagade; H. Kurz
corresponding_authors: Muhammad Mohsin; Anna Lena Giesecke; Daniel Neumaier; Daniel Schall; Martin Otto; C. Matheisen; Abhay A. Sagade; H. Kurz
abstract: We present the experimental demonstration of a compact waveguide-integrated graphene phase modulator marking an essential milestone in outperforming existing silicon based phase modulators. The results are reproduced by simulations.

title: Modulation format converter for mapping OOK to 4-level PAM data using balanced detection and intensity modulation
authors: Koichi Takiguchi
corresponding_authors: Koichi Takiguchi
abstract: I report a simple modulation format converter of OOK to 4-level PAM data, which comprises a balanced photo-detector and an intensity modulator. Two 20 Gbit/s OOK signals were converted into a 40 Gbit/s PAM signal.

title: Bound states of temporal cavity solitons
authors: Jae K. Jang; Miro Erkintalo; Stuart G. Murdoch; Stéphane Coen
corresponding_authors: Jae K. Jang; Miro Erkintalo; Stuart G. Murdoch; Stéphane Coen
abstract: We report experimental observation of bound states of temporal cavity solitons persisting in passive optical fiber ring resonators. Bound states have been identified in two different cavities, with soliton-to-soliton separations of 20 and 11 ps.

title: Proposal of Multistage-Feedforward Carrier Phase Estimation for Optical 16-QAM Signals
authors: Hiroki Matsuto; Ryutaro Arita; Yasuhiro Tsutsumi; Joji Maeda
abstract: Multistage-feedforward carrier phase estimation method is proposed and numerically studied, predicting good robustness against laser phase noise and a wide estimation range of the frequency offset 12% more than that of symbol rate.

title: SiGe Nanomembrane Active Materials for Far-Infrared Intersubband Devices
authors: Habibe Durmaz; Pornsatit Sookchoo; F. F. Sudradjat; Arnold Kiefer; M. G. Lagally; Roberto Paiella
corresponding_authors: Habibe Durmaz; Pornsatit Sookchoo; F. F. Sudradjat; Arnold Kiefer; M. G. Lagally; Roberto Paiella
abstract: SiGe quantum-well nanomembranes are developed where the internal stress due to lattice mismatch is relaxed via elastic strain sharing without plastic deformation. Record narrow far-infrared intersubband absorption spectra are measured.

title: Evaluation of Forces Generated by Cantilevers During Verticalization of Molar Using Fiber Sensors
authors: Neblyssa Ágatha Schneider; Maura S. Milczewski; Valmir de Oliveira; Odilon Guariza Filho; Stephani C. P. S. Lopes; Hypólito J. Kalinowski
abstract: Fibers Bragg Gratings were used to evaluate de transmission of the tensions generates by orthodontic mechanic based on cantilevers used to move molars of axis. The results showed levels forces of approximately 0,14 N.

title: Real-time Polychromatic Parametric Processing
authors: Andreas O. J. Wiberg
corresponding_authors: Andreas O. J. Wiberg
abstract: Recent advances in real-time polychromatic parametric processing are reviewed spanning applications from high speed OTDM data to photonic sampled ADC of broadband signals employing self-seeded parametric multicasting and polychromatic sampling.

authors: Sergey Mironov; E. I. Gacheva; Alexey V. Andrianov; V. V. Zelenogorsky; A. K. Poteomkin; Е. А. Хазанов; M. Krasilnikov; Frank Stefan; Mikhail Martyanov

title: Stability analysis of regenerated Fiber Bragg Gratings at high temperatures
authors: Luis Rodŕıguez-Cobo; José Miguel López Higuera
corresponding_authors: Luis Rodŕıguez-Cobo; José Miguel López Higuera
abstract: In this work, the spectral response of different regenerated Fiber Bragg Gratings has been analyzed for long time (more than 100 hours) under high temperatures (500°C and 700°C) to evaluate their degradation. These results have been compared to standard non-regenerated FBGs to analyze the future response of both devices types. The achieved results exhibit the temperature stability of regenerated FBGs even under extreme temperatures.

title: 2 Micron Fiber Lasers Using Silicate Glass Fibers
authors: Shibin Jiang
corresponding_authors: Shibin Jiang
abstract: This paper summarizes our recent progress in 2 micron fiber lasers using Tm and Tm-Ho-co-doped silicate glass fibers. Single frequency fiber lasers with linewidth less than 3kHz, Q-switched fiber lasers with greater than ten kilowatt peak power, and mode-locked fiber lasers near 2 micron wavelength will be described.

title: GaAs optomechanical circuits
authors: Kartik Srinivasan
corresponding_authors: Kartik Srinivasan
abstract: We present optomechanical circuits in GaAs, where localized photons and phonons interact via the photoelastic effect, and are coupled to propagating photons and phonons that are read out optically or electrically (via the piezoelectric effect). Experiments demonstrating the coupling of radio frequency waves, GHz phonons, and optical photons will be discussed.

title: Tailoring active far-infrared application with graphene metasurface
authors: Lin Wang; Xiaohong Chen; Wei Lü
corresponding_authors: Lin Wang; Xiaohong Chen; Wei Lü
abstract: In this work, we demonstrate strong electric resonance response in perforated graphene sheet at far-infrared part of electromagnetic spectrum. Unlike the metallic meta-materials relying on the geometrical inductance for magnetic response, the electric resonance in graphene is mainly caused by localized plasmons and thus enabling sub-wavelength confinement of electromagnetic field. The active tunable electric resonance by electrostatic doping on the graphene sheet provides efficient route for compact biosening, far-infrared imaging and detection.

title: Non-collinear electro-optic sampling techniques for efficient detection of THz radiation
authors: Masahiko Tani; Shinpei Ozawa; Syougo Azuma; Seiji Tsuzuki; Takashi Furuya; Hideaki Kitahara; Stefan Funkner; Gudrun Niehues; Elmer Estacio; Kazuyoshi Kurihara; Kohji Yamamoto; М. И. Бакунов
abstract: Non-collinear THz electro-optic (EO) sampling techniques based on Cherenkov phase-matching are presented. The non-collinear phase-matching enables us to use EO crystal with a large EO coefficient but poor phase-matching property when used in collinear scheme.

title: Aptamer and DNA hybridization assays on gold fiber optic sensors with nanoparticle signal enhancement
authors: Filip Delport; Karel Knez; Kris P. F. Janssen; Iulia Arghir; Neeve Marien; Thi Dinh Tran; Dragana Spasić; Steven Vermeir; Jeroen Lammertyn
abstract: Detection of allergens and micro bacteria on a fiber optic SPR sensor is performed by means of an oligonucleotide bio-recognition surface. In this work, the DNA surface is optimized by mixing with PEG monolayers to suppress unspecific and enhance specific detection. Furthermore, due to the surface characteristic of DNA functionalized gold nanoparticles the bioassay sensitivity is increased and a mean of real-time multiplexing is introduced.

title: Development and Experiment of A Novel Optical Fiber Pressure Sensor
authors: Yifei Qian; Deguang Liu; Hao Mu; Haidong Lu
abstract: The optical fiber pressure sensors using temperature insensitive technology designed by Andol technology have special advantages in application of low pressure measurement. The measurement accuracy can be reached at 10 pa level in our tests.

title: Management of Photo-excited Carriers in Light Trapping Nanostructured Si Solar Cells
authors: Dongwook Kim; Yunae Cho; Eunah Kim; Hyeong‐Ho Park; Joondong Kim
abstract: Nanostructures significantly improve light trapping capability of Si absorbers and also enhance light intensity near the surface. Such surface concentrated light can boost the carrier collection efficiency of the nanostructure-based solar cells.

title: Photorefractive Solitons in an Out-of-Equilibrium Disordered Ferroelectric
authors: Davide Pierangeli; Jacopo Parravicini; F. Di Mei; G. B. Parravicini; Aharon J. Agranat; E. DelRe
corresponding_authors: Davide Pierangeli; Jacopo Parravicini; F. Di Mei; G. B. Parravicini; Aharon J. Agranat; E. DelRe
abstract: We study two-dimensional soliton beams in disordered ferroelectrics. Super-cooling accelerates photorefractive response and changes steady-state anisotropy. Effects are attributed to the anomalous polarization response of polar-nano-regions.

title: Integrated bi-chromatically pumped optical parametric oscillator for orthogonally polarized photon pair generation
authors: Christian Reimer; Michael Kues; Lucia Caspani; Benjamin Wetzel; Piotr Roztocki; Matteo Clerici; Y. Jestin; Marcello Ferrera; Marco Peccianti; Alessia Pasquazi; Brent E. Little; Sai T. Chu; David Moss; Roberto Morandotti
abstract: We demonstrate a novel bi-chromatically pumped OPO operating on orthogonal polarizations in a CMOS compatible micro-ring resonator. Below threshold the device operates in the quantum regime and cross-polarized heralded photons are directly generated.

title: Imaging Ultrafast Light-Matter Interaction with Inverse Raman Scattering
authors: Stefano Minardi; D. Majus; Amrutha Gopal; G. Tamošauskas; Carles Milián; A. Couairon; Thomas Pertsch; A. Dubietis
corresponding_authors: Stefano Minardi; D. Majus; Amrutha Gopal; G. Tamošauskas; Carles Milián; A. Couairon; Thomas Pertsch; A. Dubietis
abstract: We exploit Inverse Raman Scattering to image the propagation and nonlinear losses of a tightly focused femtosecond pump laser pulse in water. The technique can be applied in general to all Raman active materials.

title: Origin of Extremely Small Bending Loss in Polaritonic Nano Fibers of Thiacyanine Molecules
authors: Hiroyuki Takeda; Kazuaki Sakoda
corresponding_authors: Hiroyuki Takeda; Kazuaki Sakoda
abstract: We calculated the dispersion relation and complex propagation constant of curved thiacyanine nano fibers by a finite-difference frequency-domain method with absorbing boundary conditions and reproduced their extremely small bending loss.

title: High Energy Pulsed Sources from Infrared to UV with Yb Rod Type fibers: current limits and prospects
authors: Philippe Roy; Aurélien Benoît; Dia Darwich; Raphaël Jamier; Romain Dauliat; Kay Schuster; Stephan Grimm; Julien Saby; Damien Sangla; François Salin
corresponding_authors: Philippe Roy; Aurélien Benoît; Dia Darwich; Raphaël Jamier; Romain Dauliat; Kay Schuster; Stephan Grimm; Julien Saby; Damien Sangla; François Salin
abstract: We present current performances and limits of industrial high power rod-type large-pitch fiber lasers in nanosecond and picosecond regime delivering high average power. To overcome current limitations, we propose improved inner microstructuration design.

title: Using high-power THz radiation imaging systems for implementation of classical optical techniques in the terahertz range
authors: B. A. Knyazev
corresponding_authors: B. A. Knyazev
abstract: A complex of imaging techniques to measure high-power THz radiation is developed and successfully used for implementation of classical optical schemes, such as speckle metrology, classical holography, Talbot self-imaging, generation of non-diffracting vortex beams, etc.

title: Impairment Mitigation in Optical Communication Systems using Digital Signal Processing
authors: S. Chandrasekhar; Peter J. Winzer; S. Randel
abstract: We examine impairments in optical communications systems (components, subsystems, fiber transmission and optical networking) and show how digital signal processing techniques can alleviate these impairments and provide system margins. Article not available.

title: Single-shot Optical Frequency Comb Imaging Using VIPA
authors: Takumi Miyaoka; Tatsutoshi Shioda
abstract: Virtually imaged phased array (VIPA) makes a traditional tomography upgraded to single-shot and wide range 2-dimensional imaging tomography. We propose a novel Fourier-domain comb interferometry with a combination of the VIPA and CCD.

title: Integrated Optical Systems Approach to Ion Trap Quantum Repeaters
authors: Jungsang Kim; Kai Hudek; Lou Isabella; Emily Mount; Stephen Crain; Dan Gaultney; Geert Vrijsen; Andre Van Rynbach
abstract: A quantum communication node with high quality quantum memories and photonic interfaces capable of quantum logic operations provide a technology platform for realizing quantum repeaters. We will discuss a viable implementation in trapped ion systems.

title: Tailoring of Optical Glasses for Multi-spectral Applications using Instantaneous Dispersion
authors: Nathan Carlie
corresponding_authors: Nathan Carlie
abstract: As infrared and multi-spectral imaging technology matures, more complex designs and special materials are needed. We examine a generalized method for selecting optical materials and the inverse problem of tailoring optical glasses for these applications.

title: Counter-propagating Airy beams in nonlinear media
authors: Noémie Wiersma; Nicolas Marsal; Marc Sciamanna; Delphine Wolfersberger
corresponding_authors: Noémie Wiersma; Nicolas Marsal; Marc Sciamanna; Delphine Wolfersberger
abstract: We numerically study the interactions of two counter-propagating Airy beams in a photorefractive crystal. By varying the Airy beams’ properties and the photorefractive coupling strength, soliton-like interactions create new waveguide structures.

title: Dynamics of cascaded multiple dispersive waves generation in a dispersion oscillating photonic crystal fiber
authors: A. Bendahmane; Flavie Braud; B. Barviau; Arnaud Mussot; Alexandre Kudlinski
corresponding_authors: A. Bendahmane; Flavie Braud; B. Barviau; Arnaud Mussot; Alexandre Kudlinski
abstract: We report experimental results demonstrating the generation and the subsequent cascade of multiple dispersive waves from a single Raman-shifting soliton hitting several times the second zero dispersion wavelength of a dispersion oscillating fiber.

title: Disaggregated and Programmable Optical Data Center Networks
authors: Georgios Zervas
corresponding_authors: Georgios Zervas
abstract: The talk will present concepts, requirements, challenges, as well as proposed architectures and experiments conducted to deliver open, programmable and disaggregated Data Centers and High Performance Computers using high performance optical interconnects.

title: A review of viscoelastic tuning of FBGs during regeneration
authors: John Canning; Shaorui Gao; Kevin Cook; Arnaud Loubert; Matthieu Lancry
corresponding_authors: John Canning; Shaorui Gao; Kevin Cook; Arnaud Loubert; Matthieu Lancry
abstract: Regenerating at constant temperature under load allows inelastic changes in glass that can be exploited to tune the Bragg wavelength of a filter to any arbitrary spectral position. We have reported > 20nm of tuning and broadband chirping by more than Δλ > 9 nm.

title: Advances in Single Molecule Biosensing
authors: Frank Vollmer
corresponding_authors: Frank Vollmer
abstract: In this presentation, we will report on advancing chip-scale biosensing capabilities with optical microresonators. His laboratory has developed a microcavity biosensing platform that is capable of monitoring single DNA molecules and their interaction kinetics, hence achieving an unprecedented sensitivity for label-free detection with light. By thermal stabilization of the sensor it is furthermore possible to characterize the structural change of biopolymers in response to temperature. Stand-off biodetection capabilities are demonstrated with asymmetric microspheres.

title: Industrial Ultrafast Lasers
authors: Eric Mottay
corresponding_authors: Eric Mottay
abstract: From advanced scientific tools to industrial equipment used in numerous factories worldwide, ultrafast lasers have come a long way during the last decade. We will review the current status of ultrafast technologies, present selected industrial case studies and outline future key developments.

title: Understanding the fission of higher-order solitons. Applications to the supercontinuum generation, pulse compression and frequency conversion
authors: Rodislav Driben; A. V. Yulin; Boris A. Malomed
abstract: A detailed study of the N-soliton fission mechanism in optical fibers with strong higher order dispersion reveals a mechanism of step-like ejections of fundamental quasi-solitons out of the parential N-soliton temporal slot. This mechanism, valid also in presence of high order nonlinear effect such as Raman and self-steepening governs the dynamics of N-soliton decomposition into individual frequency shifted solitons and dispersive waves and the resulting supercontinuum generation. Possibility to control the temporal compression/power enhancement of fission generated fundamental solitons will be discussed. Solitonic cavities created by several individual fundamental quasi-solitons and trapped dispersive waves in between will be demonstrated as a phenomenon occurring just after the N-soliton fission with corresponding projection of these light structure to an overall supercontinuum spectrum.

title: Heterogeneous Integration Methods and Devices
authors: John M. Dallesasse; P. L. Lam; B. Kesler; Guan-Lin Su; G. Walter
abstract: The integration of III-V or III-N materials onto selected regions of a silicon or silicon-on-insulator (SOI) with the goal of creating electronic-photonic circuits is examined. Epitaxial transfer and bonding methods are discussed, as well as issues of CMOS compatibility and the thermal environment of the III-V devices. Possible devices for future electronic-photonic integration are also discussed.

title: Investigation on moldable Ge-Sb-Se ternary chalcogenide glasses for night vision system
authors: Bong Je Park; Ki‐Uk Kyung; Yong Gyu Choi; Jong Heo; Ju Hyeon Choi; Hye-Jeong Kim
abstract: Moldable Ge-Sb-Se chalcogenide glasses have been investigated by IR transmittance (IR transmittance : >50% between 8 ~ 12um), thermal stability (glass transition temperature : 260 ~ 300 °C), and mechanical strength (Vickers hardness : >160 kgf/mm2).

title: Design Impact on Optical Absorption of the Graphene Coated Silicon Wire Waveguides
authors: Goran Kovačević; Shinji Yamashita
abstract: We observe reversals of the dominantly absorbed mode with thickness and width variation of graphene coated silicon wire waveguides using a self-developed numerical method. Quantitative and qualitative explanations of our findings are also presented.

title: Novel in-situ optical measurement techniques for combustion applications
authors: Gordon S. Humphries; John D. Black; Iain S. Burns; Michael Lengden
abstract: Two optical techniques for the quantification of acetylene and soot concentration in flames are presented using cavity ring-down and photoacoustics respectively. Results are described for each technique, including a discussion on detection sensitivity.

title: Interactions of Acoustic and Optical Waves in Ge-doped Silica Planar Optical Waveguide
authors: M. M. Rahman; B. M. A. Rahman
abstract: A full-vectorial finite element based approach, exploiting structural symmetry, is used to find interactions between guided fundamental quasi-TE optical mode and acoustic transverse and longitudinal modes in Ge-doped planar silica optical waveguide.

title: Metal-less Plasmonics: A Study of Plasmonic Effects in Amorphous Silicon at The Edge of UV/VIS Spectrum
authors: Shaimaa I. Azzam; S. S. A. Obayya
corresponding_authors: Shaimaa I. Azzam; S. S. A. Obayya
abstract: A theoretical study of plasmonic effects in silicon nanostructures is introduced. It is found that silicon exhibit metal-like properties at the edge of UV/VIS spectrum allowing silicon nanostructures to support surface plasmon modes.

title: Temperature Insensitive Ring-resonator by Polymer Coated Si Waveguide
authors: M. Rakib Uddin; Md. Abdus Salam; Yong Hyub Won
abstract: Temperature sensitivity of a polymer coated waveguide ring resonator is analyzed. Our analysis shows that the temperature insensitive resonator can be achieved by proper waveguide physical dimensions with TM polarized light.

title: Discrete Green’s Function Methodology to Solve Nanophotonics Design Problems
authors: James B. Cole
corresponding_authors: James B. Cole
abstract: We introduce a discrete Green's function (DGF) methodology to solve a nonstandard finite difference model of Maxwell's equations. The DGF is found using FDTD (finite time domain), can solve design problems faster than FDTD alone.

title: The Past, Present, and Future of Coherent Optical Communications
authors: K. Kikuchi
corresponding_authors: K. Kikuchi
abstract: The digital coherent optical receiver has enabled practical 100-Gbit/s optical transmission systems. After summarizing the history of coherent optical communications, this talk discusses the impact of the combination of analog optics and digital electronics.

title: Finite System Theory of Two Interacting Quantum Dots in an Optical Microcavity
authors: Juan S. Rojas-Arias; Luis Alfonso Briceño Villalba; Herbert Vinck Posada
abstract: We study the interaction of two Quantum Dots with a single light mode and a magnetic field. The effects of magnetic field in the ground state energy are determined, as well as the dependence of the number of photons on the number of polaritons.

title: Stimulated Forward Brillouin Scattering in Photonic Bandgap Fiber
authors: William H. Renninger; Heedeuk Shin; Ryan O. Behunin; Prashanta Kharel; Eric A. Kittlaus; Peter T. Rakich
abstract: Stimulated forward Brillouin scattering is observed in photonic bandgap fiber with a hollow core. Several acoustic resonances are identified from 0–100 MHz. The resonance quality-factor is enhanced when the air is evacuated from the fiber.

title: Mitigation of Linear and Nonlinear Impairments in Spectrally Efficient Superchannels
authors: Edson Porto da Silva; Knud J. Larsen; Darko Zibar
abstract: We assess numerically the performance of single-carrier digital backpropagation and maximum-likelihood sequence detection (MLSD) for DP-QPSK superchannel transmission. It is shown that MLSD is advantageous only against inter-carrier linear crosstalk.

title: Simultaneous detection of multiple trace chemical species using quantum cascade laser sensing in the mid-infrared region
authors: Richard Garner; Michael R. Davis; Ibukun Folarin; M. Amir Khan
corresponding_authors: Richard Garner; Michael R. Davis; Ibukun Folarin; M. Amir Khan
abstract: We show sensitive detection of methane, nitrous oxide and water-vapor using quantum cascade laser based spectroscopy systems. The technique is based on direct absorption and wavelength modulation spectroscopy to resolve and enhance sensitivity.

title: Observation of Dynamic Extinction Ratio and Bit Error Rate degradation due to thermal effects in Integrated Modulators
authors: Giovanni Gilardi; Weiming Yao; M.K. Smit; Michael J. Wale
abstract: We experimentally demonstrate how the thermal crosstalk between active and passive components limits the performance of integrated Mach-Zehnder modulators operating in radiofrequency regime.To evaluate the role of the distance between active and passive components, the MZs are placed at different distances with respect to a Semiconductor Optical Amplifier that represents the heat source.The thermal crosstalk is quantified by measuring the effects on the electro-optical response of MZ modulators considered as test structure. Both extinction ratio and bit error rate degradation are measured.The proposed investigation allows the introduction of design rules, based on the minimum distance between components to ultimately avoid unwanted thermal effects.According to the result provided by our analysis, we also show how the ER degradation can be recovered.

title: Silicon Photonic Enabled 400G/1T Short Reach Optical Interconnects for Data Center Applications
authors: David V. Plant; Mathieu Chagnon; Mohamed Morsy-Osman; David Patel; Alireza Samani; Venkat Veerasubramanian
abstract: We describe traveling wave silicon photonic modulator designs and their use in 112, 224, 280, and 350 Gb/s digital signal processing enabled short reach transmission systems. Scaling to 400G/1T is reviewed.

title: Low Cross-talk Fibers Using OAM
authors: Siddharth Ramachandran
corresponding_authors: Siddharth Ramachandran
abstract: We review the state of the art of fibers with annular index profiles that yield stable vector (equivalently OAM) modes with low cross-talk, which have been used to demonstrate MIMO-free data transmission over km lengths. Article not available.

title: Optical simulation of neutrino oscillation in binary waveguide arrays
authors: Andrea Marini; Stefano Longhi; Fabio Biancalana
corresponding_authors: Andrea Marini; Stefano Longhi; Fabio Biancalana
abstract: We theoretically investigate the optical analogue of neutrino oscillation in a pair of vertically displaced binary waveguide arrays with longitudinally modulated effective index. We demonstrate that neutrino oscillations can be quenched by nonlinear effects.

title: Waveguide Coupled Nanobeam Photonic Crystal Cavity via Transfer Printing Method
authors: Jaehyeon Son; Indra Karnadi; Ju‐Young Kim; Hoon Jang; Seungwoo Lee; Ki Soo Kim; Yong-Hee Lee; Bumki Min
abstract: We demonstrated waveguide coupling of InGaAsP nanobeam photonic crystal cavity integrated on SiO2/Si substrate via transfer printing. The coupled light from the cavity was imaged through grating vertical coupler at the end of the waveguide

authors: Yi Qiu; Yiqing Xu; Kenneth K. Y. Wong; Kevin K. Tsia
corresponding_authors: Yi Qiu; Yiqing Xu; Kenneth K. Y. Wong; Kevin K. Tsia
abstract: We present a new normal-dispersion-pumped supercontinuum seeding mechanism based on a combined effect of stimulated Raman scattering and seeded dispersive wave emission. The seeded SC bandwidth is drastically enhanced to more than one octave.

title: Diamond Photonics
authors: Marko Lončar
corresponding_authors: Marko Lončar
abstract: Diamond possesses remarkable physical and chemical properties, and in many ways is the ultimate engineering material. For example, it is transparent from the ultra-violet to infrared, has a high refractive index (n = 2.4), strong optical nonlinearity (Kerr and Raman) and a wide variety of light-emitting defects. These properties make diamond a highly desirable material for many applications, including those in quantum and nonlinear photonics.

authors: Guoqing Chang

abstract: Advanced Photonics, co-published by SPIE and Chinese Laser Press, is a highly selective, Gold Open Access, international journal publishing innovative research in all areas of optics and photonics, including fundamental and applied research.

title: Polymer-Clad Silicon on Insulator Slot Modulator
authors: Xi Chen; David Espinoza; Eric Dudley; Zheng Li; Moustafa Mohamed; Yonghao Cui; Wounjhang Park; Li Shang; Alan R. Mickelson
abstract: A commercially fabricated slot waveguide is post processed with FIB deposited electrodes and polymer coating to function as a phase modulator. A model for modulation performance based on transmission measurements is used to optimize the structure within commercial rules.

title: Graded-Index Optical Fiber Sound Sensor
authors: Aristides Marcano Olaizola
corresponding_authors: Aristides Marcano Olaizola
abstract: We describe an optical fiber sound detector based on the effect of diffraction of light that occurs at the exit end of a graded-index fiber. We provide experimental evidence of the sensor high sensitivity.

title: Green Hybrid Optical/Wireless Access/In-House Networks
authors: L.G. Kazovsky; Kadir M. Albeyoglu; Tolga Ayhan
abstract: This paper focuses on energy efficient hybrid access networks. Solutions to underutilization of network are investigated. Power optimization of distributed antenna systems and cell-breathing technology for hybrid access networks are explored.

title: Benchmarking Comparison of Physical Layer Performance for Various Implementations of OFDM Access Networks
authors: Ioannis Tomkos; Elias Giacoumidis; A. Kavatzikidis; Iván N. Cano; Josep Prat
abstract: A survey of optical transmission techniques based on Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (OFDM) is presented. The characteristics and power budget/transmission performance of these methods are evaluated on optical access networks.

title: Tunable Operation of Tm-Doped Fiber Ring Laser Controlled by Microbend-Induced Fiber Grating
authors: Hajime Sakata; M. Ichikawa; S Araki; H. Nakagami
abstract: We demonstrate a 1.9-μm band Tm-doped fiber ring laser by using bi-directional pumping with 1.6 μm laser diodes. The lasing wavelength is controlled by shifting the inter-resonance-mode passband due to a microbend-induced long-period fiber grating.

title: Experimental Demonstration of Ultra-Low Loss Coupling into Slow Light Slotted Photonic Crystal Waveguide on Silicon Nanomembrane
authors: Che-Yun Lin; Xiaolong Wang; Swapnajit Chakravarty; Wei-Cheng Lai; Beom Suk Lee; Yi Zou; Ray T. Chen
corresponding_authors: Che-Yun Lin; Xiaolong Wang; Swapnajit Chakravarty; Wei-Cheng Lai; Beom Suk Lee; Yi Zou; Ray T. Chen
abstract: We experimentally demonstrate highly efficient coupling to a slotted photonic crystal waveguide using a mode converter and a photonic crystal impedance taper. Measurements show a −2.6dB insertion loss for coupling in/out of the slow light waveguide.

title: High-purity tungstate-tellurite glasses and single-mode fibers: fabrication and studies
authors: V. V. Dorofeev; А. Н. Моисеев; М. Ф. Чурбанов; Billy Richards; Animesh Jha; A. F. Kosolapov; E. M. Dianov
abstract: The single-mode optical fibers were fabricated from TeO2-WO3-La2O3-(Bi2O3) glasses with low content of impurities and absorption losses less then 100 dB/km (1.56 μm). Rode-in-tube as well as monolith preform stretching techniques were used.

title: Photonic Integrated Dual-Mode Filters Realized with Ring Resonators Loaded by Bragg Gratings
authors: Carlos Alonso‐Ramos; Francesco Morichetti; Stefano Grillanda; Alejandro Ortega‐Moñux; Ignigo Molina-Fernández; Andrea Melloni
abstract: Dual-mode filters based on ring-resonators loaded with a Bragg grating are proposed. Second and fourth-order filters are demonstrated with one and two rings, respectively, exploiting contradirectional mode coupling inside the resonators.

title: WDM PON based on Silicon Photonic Micro-ring Modulators
authors: Lin Xu; Kishore Padmaraju; Long Chen; Michal Lipson; Keren Bergman
abstract: We demonstrate an optical access networks architecture uniquely enabled by CMOS compatible silicon micro-rings. The wavelength selective behavior of micro-ring modulators enables single-sideband modulation, which simultaneously generates downstream signals and centrally distributed carriers for upstream re-modulation.

title: Adiabatic wavelength conversion in travelling-wave and resonant photonic structures
authors: Yuzhe Xiao; Govind P. Agrawal; Drew N. Maywar
abstract: We present a simple and intuitive linear system model to study adiabatic wavelength conversion in integrated photonic structures and to reveal how this process affects the shape and spectrum of optical pulses.

title: Flat-Gain C+L Split-Band Hybrid Waveguide Amplifier for Dense Wavelength Division Multiplexed System at Reduced Channel Spacing
authors: R.S. Kaler; Rajneesh Randhawa; Simranjit Singh
abstract: In this paper, split-band Hybrid Waveguide Amplifier (HWA) is proposed using parallel configuration of Er-doped waveguide amplifier (EDWA) and Er-Yb co-doped waveguide amplifier (EYDWA) for C+L-band dense wavelength division multiplexed system at 0.2 nm interval. This HWA plays a role to boost the DWDM signals and giving a larger gain while keeping the little power/gain variations over effective gain bandwidth product. With the proposed amplifier, the gain and power variation is reduced from 7.2 to 3.1 dB without using any costly gain clamping techniques.

title: Waveguide Evanescent Field Spectroscopy of Trace Gases
authors: Todd H. Stievater; Marcel W. Pruessner; Scott A. Holmstrom; Doewon Park; William S. Rabinovich; R. Andrew McGill; Jacob B. Khurgin
abstract: We detect trace gases at ppb levels using evanescent-field absorption spectroscopy in microring resonators coated with sorbent polymers. The overtone spectra derive from mid-infrared resonances that provide a signature of analyte toxicity.

title: Overlapped Subcarrier Multiplexed WDM PONs Enabled by Burst-Mode Receivers
authors: David V. Plant; Ziad A. El-Sahn; Jonathan M. Buset; Bhavin J. Shastri
abstract: A symmetric WDM PON architecture using an innovative overlapped-SCM scheme that maximizes the spectrum usage of a bandwidth-limited RSOA is demonstrated. In addition, burst mode receivers for this application are discussed.

title: Evolution of 100-Gbit/s digital coherent signal processing moving to metro applications
authors: Etsushi Yamazaki
corresponding_authors: Etsushi Yamazaki
abstract: 100-Gbit/s transport technology based on digital coherent signal processing is becoming matured, and its adaptation to metro-access area would enhance survivability, interoperability, and low energy consumption features.

title: Contention Resolution using Control Packet Buffering in Optical Burst Switched Networks
authors: Ahmed I. Abdelrahman; Hossam M. H. Shalaby; Sherif I. Rabia
abstract: In this paper a novel contention resolution technique based on control packet buffering in OBS networks is proposed. This buffering is implemented in the electronic domain, thus avoiding complex optical domain solutions. I.

authors: Alfredo De Rossi; Sylvain Combrié; Pierre Colman; Chad Husko; Chee Wei Wong; I. Sagnes; I. Cestier; Vardit Eckhouse; G. Eisenstein
abstract: Efforts made by the community to improve the Photonic Crystal Waveguides against linear and nonlinear losses have made the promises of this technology possible. We discuss some of the major achievements, particularly the demonstration of optical solitons on-chip.

title: Nanoscale Mechanical Tuning of Optical Coupling in Planar Lightwave Circuits
authors: M. Mustafa Kaykisiz; Erdal Bulgan
abstract: Two nanoscale mechanical tuning mechanisms of evanescent wave mode coupling in planar lightwave circuits providing tunability and device footprint advantages are presented. Tunability of 1.13nm and 1.19nm per percent light intensity change in order.

title: A Promise for Software-defined Optical Networks: Optical Router Engine Design enabled by Cloud-based Spatio-Temporal Label Computing and Switching Protocol (Invited)1
authors: Anpeng Huang; Linzhen Xie; Anshi Xu; Zhangyuan Chen
abstract: With the trend of dominant IP traffic, an optical switch router is at the core "IP over Optical." To operate optical switch routers, a feasible spatio-temporal label engine is designed based on cloud computing.

title: Stimulated Brillouin scattering in silicon photonics
authors: Peter T. Rakich; Heedeuk Shin; Wenjun Qi; Robert Jarecki; Jonathan A. Cox; Roy H. Olsson; Andrew Starbuck; Zheng Wang
corresponding_authors: Peter T. Rakich; Heedeuk Shin; Wenjun Qi; Robert Jarecki; Jonathan A. Cox; Roy H. Olsson; Andrew Starbuck; Zheng Wang
abstract: Strong light-boundary interactions fundamentally alter the nature of traveling-wave photon-phonon coupling at nanoscales. Harnessing these interactions, stimulated Brillouin scattering is demonstrated silicon nano-photonics for the first time through a new class of hybrid photonic-phononic waveguides.

title: Magnetically Induced Simultaneous Slow and Fast Light by Phase Control
authors: Bin Luo; Hong Guo
abstract: Λ-type atom coupled by additional driving light and radio frequency (RF) field can generate controllable simultaneous slow and fast light at two frequencies. Distortions by radiative dampings are discussed and compensation method is suggested.

title: Ge/SiGe Quantum Well Optical Modulators
authors: Delphine Marris‐Morini; Papichaya Chaisakul; Mohamed-Saïd Rouifed; Jacopo Frigerio; Giovanni Isella; Daniel Chrastina; Xavier Le Roux; P. Crozat; Samson Edmond; Jean‐René Coudevylle; Laurent Vivien
abstract: Ge/SiGe quantum wells structures appear as a promising solution for compact low power consumption optical modulators. The presentation will give an overview of recent results including high speed absorption and phase modulation.

title: Ultrafast imaging of terahertz pulse generation by Cherenkov radiation in LiNbO3
authors: Zhenyou Wang; Fu Hai Su; Frank A. Hegmann
corresponding_authors: Zhenyou Wang; Fu Hai Su; Frank A. Hegmann
abstract: We demonstrate full-field imaging of terahertz (THz) phonon-polariton waves induced by a point focused optical pulse in MgO-doped lithium niobate (LN). The group velocities of the optical and THz pulses as well as the Cherenkov radiation angle are directly measured. Transition radiation from the LN surface is also imaged for the first time.

authors: R. Gente; Norman Born; Neil Voss; Wiebke Sannemann; Jens Léon; Martín Koch; Enrique Castro-Camus

title: Performance Comparison between Offset-QAM CoWDM and Nyquist WDM
authors: Hui Wang; Jian Zhao
corresponding_authors: Hui Wang; Jian Zhao
abstract: We show that offset-16QAM CoWDM, when compared to 16QAM Nyquist WDM, exhibits advantages of reduced crosstalk levels, shorter memory lengths for electrical pulse-shaping filters, enhanced tolerance to filter bandwidth, and longer transmission reach.

title: Science and Technology in the Submillimeter with High Resolution Techniques
authors: Frank C. De Lucia
corresponding_authors: Frank C. De Lucia
abstract: With emphasis on high-resolution systems, the interaction of the physics of the spectral region with the physics of applications will be discussed. It will be shown how this leads to optimal choices for system strategies.

title: A Simple Bend Sensor based on multimode interference and a Twin Core Fiber Mach-Zehnder Interferometer
authors: A. Harhira; Jérôme Lapointe; Raman Kashyap
abstract: An optimized Bend Sensor based on a multimode interference combined with a twin-core fiber is proposed. The section of twin-core fiber is spliced between a section of multimode fiber and a single mode fiber. The bend induced wavelength shifts on the interference fringes is experimentally monitored. A shift toward shorter wavelengths is observed. This device is simple to fabricate, and is used as a bend sensor with high sensitivity. Optimization and losses in multimode fiber are also studied.

title: Performance Evaluation of Coherent PS-QPSK (HEXA) Modulation
authors: Gabriella Bosco; Andrea Carena
abstract: We investigate the performance of the 8-point four-dimensional PS-QPSK (HEXA) modulation format in uncompensated WDM long-haul optical transmission systems, comparing it to standard 16-point PM-QPSK and 4-point PM-BPSK constellations.

title: Integrated-optic OFDM demultiplexers using silica PLC-based DFT and FFT circuits
authors: Koichi Takiguchi
corresponding_authors: Koichi Takiguchi
abstract: I report recent advances on our integrated-optic demultiplexers for optical OFDM signals. I describe the configuration, operating principle, and characteristics of the demultiplexers, which consist of optical FFT and DFT circuits fabricated with PLC technology.

title: Dielectric Properties of Heavy Oils Using Terahertz Time-Domain Spectroscopy
authors: A. Kabir; A. Ayesheshim; Lyubov V. Titova; Z. Wang; Patrice Abivin; Yuesheng Cheng; Kentaro Indo; Frank A. Hegmann
abstract: We investigate the terahertz dielectric properties of heavy oils as a function of temperature using terahertz time-domain spectroscopy. These results facilitate the study of temperature-dependent intermolecular interactions within heavy oils.

title: On Chip Generation and Sorting of Orbital Angular Momentum Beams
authors: Sebastian A. Schulz; Taras Machula; Jeremy Upham; Ebrahim Karimi; Robert W. Boyd
corresponding_authors: Sebastian A. Schulz; Taras Machula; Jeremy Upham; Ebrahim Karimi; Robert W. Boyd
abstract: We propose a structure consisting of concentric ring resonators, emitting beams carrying orbital angular momentum. Simulations show that this structure can generate and decompose OAM superposition states for classical and quantum communication.

title: Tapered fiber devices with azopolymer coating
authors: Amado M. Velázquez-Benítez; Juan Hernández-Cordero
abstract: Azopolymer coated fiber devices are demonstrated for in-fiber polarization control using an external laser beam. When placed in a fiber cavity, photo-induced birefringence on these devices modifies the spectral and polarization of fiber lasers.

title: Whisper Gallery mode based biosensor with a micro-well array
authors: Yefeng Yu; Jing Bo Zhang; Yuan Hsing Fu
abstract: A Whisper Gallery mode based biosensor with a micro-well array is designed, fabricated and characterized. The micro-well array is used not only for microsphere trapping and identification, but also for enhancement of output light coupled from the sphere to the wall. In experiment, 10 µm fluorescent polystyrene spheres are used for prostate-specific antigen (PSA) detection.

title: High-Sensitivity In-Band OSNR Monitoring on a Silicon Photonics Platform
authors: Francesco Morichetti; Andrea Annoni; Rajat Sharma; Michael J. Strain; Marc Sorel; Andrea Melloni
abstract: We demonstrate high-sensitivity in-band OSNR monitoring on a SOI platform. The integrated system, including a ring resonator and an unbalanced Mach-Zehnder interferometer, enables OSNR measurements from 8 dB to 28 dB with 0.3 dB accuracy.

title: Fiber-based Synchronized Programmable Laser system for Biomedical, industrial and defense applications
authors: A. Villeneuve; Bryan Burgoyne; Youngjae Kim; Alexandre Dupuis; Guido Pena; Joseph Salhany; Daniel Côté; Steve Bégin; Guy Lamouche; Francis Thérge
abstract: We present a fiber-based fully programmable Synchronized picosecond programmable Laser, composed of a fixed wavelength master-oscillator power amplifier and a fully programmable tunable in wavelength and adjustable in pulse width, and repetition rate Programmable Laser. Article not available.

title: Subduing or Harnessing Surface Recombination for CW Nanolaser or Fast Optical Switch Heterogenously Integrated on SOI
authors: R. Raj; Fabrice Raineri; Alexandre Bazin; P. Monnier
abstract: CW laser with 4µW threshold and 12ps recovery time ultrafast switching activated with 40fJ is demonstrated with hybrid Photonic crystals on SOI structures bringing III-V semiconductor/silicon photonics to the to nanophotonic world.

title: Challenges in Optical Microsystems for Sensing
authors: Hans Peter Herzig
corresponding_authors: Hans Peter Herzig
abstract: We present a platform concept for miniaturized sensing systems that is based on a dielectric multilayer supporting Bloch surface waves and compare it with other concepts, such as photonic crystals and plasmonic structures.

title: Nonlinear optics at the single-photon level inside a hollow core fiber
authors: Sebastian Hofferberth; Thibault Peyronel; Qiyu Liang; A. S. Zibrov; Vladan Vuletić; Mikhail D. Lukin
abstract: Cold atoms inside a hollow core fiber provide an unique system for studying optical nonlinearities at the few-photon level. Confinement of both atoms and photons inside the fiber core to a diameter of just a few wavelengths results in high electric field intensity per photon and large optical depths with a relatively small number of atoms. We present our experimental apparatus and discuss results regarding all-optical switching at ultra-low light levels.

title: Sensing applications of THz near-field microscopy
authors: Oleg Mitrofanov
corresponding_authors: Oleg Mitrofanov
abstract: Terahertz near-field microscopy enables THz spectroscopy analysis for a range of scientific and industrial applications. Recently developed THz near-field probe instrumentation and sensing applications will be discussed.

authors: Sourabh Roy; Marco Santagiustina; Pierre Colman; S. Combrié; Alfredo De Rossi
