title: Photonic Analog-to-Digital conversion with emphasis on parallel-configuration-free characteristics
authors: Tsuyoshi Konishi; Keiichi Takahashi; H. Matsui; Tetsuya Satoh
abstract: We briefly reviewed and introduced our proposed approach for photonic ADC and some experimental results in subsequent processing of optical sampling. Our parallel-configuration-free approach for optical quantization is also expected to effectively reduce power consumption.

title: BT NGA deployment & evolution strategy as drivers for NG-PON2 requirements
authors: Albert Rafel
corresponding_authors: Albert Rafel
abstract: This paper outlines the current regulatory situation in the UK and BTʼs open access operating model. It presents BTʼs current FTTP architecture and design giving details of the interconnection points for unbundling purposes at Ethernet level as well as the components making the design future proof. All these aspects, along with the expected increase in bandwidth demand and application areas, are drivers for BTʼs key requirements of future NG-PON2 systems.

title: Refractive Index Sensor Based on Optical Fiber Void Cavities Produced by the Catastrophic Fuse Effect
authors: Fátima Domingues; Paulo Antunes; Nélia Alberto; Paulo André
abstract: We propose an optical fiber sensor based on the micro-cavities generated by t fiber fuse effect. This sensor was tested for different refractive indices mediums, ranging from 1.003 to 1.361, with an estimated resolution of 1.8×10−4.

title: Low-Loss Tunable All-in-Fiber Filter for Raman Spectroscopy
authors: Anna Chiara Brunetti; Lara Scolari; Toke Lund-Hansen; Karsten Rottwitt
abstract: We show a novel in-line Rayleigh-rejection filter for Raman spectroscopy, based on a solid-core Photonic Crystal Fiber (PCF) filled with a high-index material. The device is low-loss and thermally tunable, and allows for a strong attenuation of the Rayleigh line at 532nm and the transmission of the Raman lines in a broad wavenumber range.

title: Ultra-small Highly Birefringent Slot-Microfiber
authors: Jun-long Kou; Fei Xu; Yanqing Lu
abstract: We present the wave guiding properties of the proposed ultra-small highly birefringent slot-microfiber. Due to the asymmetrical geometry in the two orthogonal directions and high-index-contrast slot interfaces, birefringence as large as 4×10−2 at 1550 nm can be obtained with microfibers 1 μm in diameter.

title: Temperature Level Fiber Sensor Network
authors: José Miguel López Higuera; Luis Rodŕıguez-Cobo; J. Uribe; Antonio Quintela Incera; Mauro Matías Lomer Barboza
abstract: A temperature level fiber sensor network is proposed and demonstrated. Each inline transducer is based on a FBG–SMA wire structure working as an on/off optical device being interrogated using a time domain technique.

title: Temperature-enhanced light emission from Er-TeO2 Photonic Crystals
authors: Pao Tai Lin; Michiel Vanhoutte; Rodolfo Camacho; Yan Cai; Lionel C. Kimerling; Anu Agarwal; Juejun Hu
abstract: Photonic crystals are fabricated in Er-doped TeO2 films. Strong photoluminescence around 1530 nm is observed by 488-532 nm laser pumping. 98x enhanced emission is demonstrated after annealing the thin films at 600°C.

title: Multi-Component Glass Fibers for 2 Micron Fiber Lasers
authors: Shibin Jiang
corresponding_authors: Shibin Jiang
abstract: Highly Tm-doped silicate glasses and fibers were developed, which exhibit a high slope efficiency of 68.3% and a gain per unit length of greater than 2dB/cm. Single frequency fiber lasers with laser linewidth less than 3kHz, Q-switched single frequency fiber lasers, and mode-locked fiber lasers near 2 micron wavelength were demonstrated using this newly developed fiber.

title: Multiplexed Gas Sensing with arrayed SOI microring resonators
authors: Zhixuan Xia; Ali A. Eftekhar; David Gottfried; Ali Adibi
abstract: We demonstrate a compact resonator-based integrated optical sensor for the detection of volatile organic compounds (VOC) with high resolution. On-chip reference is employed to compensate for environmental effects and laser instabilities to achieve high accuracy.

title: Optical Precursors in Slow and Fast Light Media
authors: Shengwang Du; J. F. Chen; M. M. T. Loy; George K. Wong
abstract: We observe optical precursors generated from slow and fast light cold atomic media. Using constructive interference between sequenced precursors, we produce optical transient pulses with peak powers of about 9 times the input power.

title: Ultrasound modulating optical imaging and sensing
authors: Stephen P. Morgan; Huiting Ruan; Melissa L. Mather; Barrie Hayes‐Gill
abstract: Ultrasound modulation of light offers potential for overcoming the effects of light scattering in heavily scattering media such as body tissue. With coherent light, a speckle pattern is produced at the detector plane which is modulated when ultrasound is applied. This can be used to extract light which has passed through the ultrasound column. Pulsed ultrasound can be used to allow time gated detection of the ultrasound modulated signal along the ultrasound column. The process of demodulating the speckle pattern using parallel speckle and digital holography is described. This demodulation is also applicable to detection of non-linear ultrasound modulated signal through a pulse inversion technique. Although more challenging in terms of signal detection, extending the ultrasound modulation approach to fluorescence and bioluminescence sensing is also discussed.

title: Towards 1-mW THz Photoconductive Sources with Low-Cost Laser Drivers
authors: E. R. Brown
corresponding_authors: E. R. Brown
abstract: A growing number of applications in the THz field require more power, efficiency, affordability, and reliability from time- and frequency-domains sources alike. We have developed efficient phoconductive switches and photomixers that can be driven by fiber mode-locked and cw-diode lasers, respectively. The average power of the PC switches is approaching 1 mW.

title: Plasmonic Photoconductors for High-Efficiency Terahertz Generation
authors: Christopher Berry; M. Reza Hashemi; Mona Jarrahi
abstract: We present an efficient plasmonic photoconductive terahertz emitter based on a logarithmic spiral antenna that generates 100 µW of terahertz radiation in the 0.1 – 2 THz range, under a 20 mW optical pump.

title: Subwavelength Hot Spot Generation for Sensor Applications
authors: Byoungho Lee; Sookyoung Rho; Dongho Oh; Jun-Bum Park; Eui‐Young Song; Seong-Woo Cho; Il-Min Lee
abstract: We present various methods for the generation of subwavelength plasmonic hot spots for sensor applications. It is shown that the structured nano-apertures on the metal film exhibit extremely small hot spots with enhanced field intensity.

title: Background Light Induced Noise and Its Effects on Indoor Gigabit Optical Wireless Communication Systems
authors: Ke Wang; Ampalavanapillai Nirmalathas; Christina Lim; Efstratios Skafidas
corresponding_authors: Ke Wang; Ampalavanapillai Nirmalathas; Christina Lim; Efstratios Skafidas
abstract: We experimentally study the receiver sensitivity and power-penalty due to shot noise induced by the background light in indoor gigabit optical wireless communication systems. This noise typically causes several dB power-penalties in the system.

title: Microcavity Filter Design Using Convex Optimization Methodology
authors: Mohamed A. Swillam; Osman Ahmed; Mohamed H. Bakr; Xun Li
abstract: We propose a novel and efficient approach for filter design using multiple microcavities. This approach is suitable of large number of coupled cavities and can be exploited to get wide range of responses.

title: Frequency unlimited optical delay lines based on slow and fast light in SOAs
authors: Perrine Berger; Jérôme Bourderionnet; Minhao Pu; Kresten Yvind; Fabien Bretenaker; Daniel Dolfi; Mehdi Alouini
corresponding_authors: Perrine Berger; Jérôme Bourderionnet; Minhao Pu; Kresten Yvind; Fabien Bretenaker; Daniel Dolfi; Mehdi Alouini
abstract: We experimentally demonstrate that up-converted coherent population oscillations (CPO) in SOA open the possibility to conceive integrated optical tunable delay lines beyond the carrier lifetime limit, up to THz frequencies.

title: US Manufacture of IR Fibers
authors: François Chenard
corresponding_authors: François Chenard
abstract: IRflex is the only US company specializing in the production of fiber-optic devices for mid-infrared applications from 2-12 micron. Our innovative mid-infrared fiber enables the development and production of leading-edge critical devices for mid-infrared applications.

title: A Bragg Microcavity Filter for Optical Sensing
authors: A. S. Jugessur; Mariya Yagnyukova; James Dou; J. Stewart Aitchison
abstract: A Bragg microcavity optical sensor is fabricated using Electron-Beam Lithography and Reactive Ion Etching techniques. An index change of 0.03 corresponds to a peak resonance wavelength shift of approximately 1 nm.

title: Nanophotonic Devices for the Generation and Manipulation of Quantum States of Light
authors: Kartik Srinivasan
corresponding_authors: Kartik Srinivasan
abstract: We review recent experiments on quantum frequency conversion of single photons produced by a semiconductor quantum dot, and describe efforts to develop frequency converters using four-wave-mixing and cavity optomechanics in the silicon nitride platform.

title: Interrogation of gold-coated TFBG-SPR refractometers based on differential orthogonal light states
authors: Valérie Voisin; Christophe Caucheteur; Patrice Mégret; Jacques Albert
abstract: A demodulation technique based on orthogonally polarized spectra of gold-coated tilted fiber Bragg gratings is proposed to measure the surrounding refractive index by comparing the differential amplitude of resonance peaks near a Plasmon resonance.

title: Resonant Cavity Enhancement of Polycrystalline PbTe Films for Two-Color IR detectors on Si-ROICs
authors: Timothy Zens; Jianfei Wang; Juejun Hu; Lionel C. Kimerling; Anu Agarwal
abstract: Dual color (1.5 and 3.5 µm) resonant-cavity-enhanced IR photodetectors on a silicon platform have been demonstrated. We describe the fabrication process and report detector performance demonstrating the feasibility of monolithic IR detectors-on-ROIC.

title: Ultra-broadband Optical Wireless For Indoor Applications
authors: Ampalavanapillai Nirmalathas; Ke Wang; Christina Lim; Estratios Skafidas
abstract: In this paper, we demonstrate an experimental 4×12.5 Gb/s ultra-broadband optical wireless system incorporating wavelength division multiplexing and an optical fiber feeder network for supporting future indoor applications that may demand scalable bandwidth, wireless connectivity and limited mobility.

title: Enhanced Optical Parametric Gain by Cascading Periodically Poled Fiber Segments
authors: Lijun Zhang; Li Qian
abstract: Numerical modeling shows that cascading multiple segments of periodically poled fiber without phase control can nonetheless improve non-degenerate optical parametric gain with high yield if sufficient idler filtering is applied in between segments.

title: SERS Active Substrates by Liquid Flame Spray and Inkjet Printed Silver Nanoparticles
authors: Jarkko J. Saarinen; Dimitar Valtakari; Janne Haapanen; Turkka Salminen; Jyrki M. Mäkelä; Jun Uozumi
abstract: Large-area SERS active substrates were made on glass via liquid flame spray deposition and inkjet printing of silver nanoparticles. Crystal violet target molecules were measured with approximately 10 μM detection limit for both deposition methods.

title: THz Signatures of Nucleic Acids in Nanochannels and Estimates of Detectable Molar Amount
authors: E. R. Brown; E. Adriana Mendoza; Yulia V. Kuznetsova; Alexander Neumann; S. R. J. Brueck
abstract: High-resolution, frequency-domain THz spectroscopy is combined with nanofluidic-chip technology to detect absorption signatures in nucleic-acid solutions between 800 and 1100 GHz. Two species are investigated, si- RNA and Lambda DNA, and clearly detected with ~4.2×10−15 and ~1.0×10−16 mol, respectively, in the nanochannels.

title: Spatio-temporal Characteristics of THz Emission at the Subwavelength Scale via Optical Rectification
authors: Sze Phing Ho; Matteo Clerici; Marco Peccianti; Fabrizio Buccheri; Alessandro Busacca; T. Ozaki; Jalil Ali; Roberto Morandotti
corresponding_authors: Sze Phing Ho; Matteo Clerici; Marco Peccianti; Fabrizio Buccheri; Alessandro Busacca; T. Ozaki; Jalil Ali; Roberto Morandotti
abstract: Highly localized THz emission via optical rectification in thin nonlinear crystals is a promising method for subwavelength microscopy. We present here the peculiar THz spatio-temporal characteristics induced by the non-paraxial generation regime.

title: Multi-material optical fiber fabrication and applications
authors: Ayman F. Abouraddy
corresponding_authors: Ayman F. Abouraddy
abstract: I review our progress in the emerging area of multi-material fibers. Applications range from mid-infrared linear and nonlinear chalcogenide glass fibers and fiber tapers, to the scalable and scale-invariant fabrication of micro- and nano-scale structures.

title: Towards High-Performance Monolithic Ge-on-Si Lasers for Integrated Photonics
authors: Jifeng Liu
corresponding_authors: Jifeng Liu
abstract: We present the latest progress in Ge-on-Si lasers and propose improved device design and fabrication, including enhanced n-type doping, strain engineering, and novel quantum well design, to achieve lasing performance comparable to III–V lasers.

title: Control of slow and fast light by incoherent interactions in atomic schemes
authors: Emilio Ignesti; Marco V. Tognetti; Roberto Buffa; Lorenzo Fini; E. Sali; Federico Tommasi; Stefano Cavalieri
corresponding_authors: Emilio Ignesti; Marco V. Tognetti; Roberto Buffa; Lorenzo Fini; E. Sali; Federico Tommasi; Stefano Cavalieri
abstract: We present recent theoretical and experimental results concerning both retardation and acceleration of light pulses in schemes involving a second 'control' laser field but that do not involve any coherent preparation of the atomic medium.

title: Theoretical Investigation of CMOS-Compatible Metal-Oxide-Silicon-Oxide-Metal Waveguides
authors: Min-Suk Kwon
corresponding_authors: Min-Suk Kwon
abstract: We propose a metal-oxide-silicon-oxide-metal (MOSOM) waveguide that is a hybrid plasmonic waveguide, and we discuss its fabrication process based on standard CMOS fabrication tools. The characteristics of the MOSOM waveguide mode are theoretically investigated.

title: Impact of Draw Inhomogeneitites on the Loss and Mode Content of Large-Mode-Area Fibers
authors: John R. Marciante; Andrew Sarangan
abstract: Inhomogeneities in the draw process cause variations in fiber diameter, leading to optical scattering. Beam-propagation simulations reveal that loss is acceptable for 1% RMS variations, but that good beam quality requires RMS variations below 0.1%.

title: Filamentation THz generation in air
authors: S.L. Chin
corresponding_authors: S.L. Chin
abstract: Experiments on THz pulse generation from single and multiple filaments in air using single or two-color technique will be discussed. Its application to sensing molecular rotational wave packet revival will be given. Stand-off detection of THz from a distance through monitoring nitrogen fluorescence in a filament was observed. The physics seems to be due to population trapping in the wake of strong field interaction with nitrogen molecules inside the filament. Article not available.

title: Optical Data Transmission with Fluctuating Frequency Offset and Strong Phase Noise
authors: James Mountjoy; Anthony J. Walsh; Barry Cardiff; J. O'Dowd; Liam P. Barry; A.D. Ellis; Anthony Fagan
corresponding_authors: James Mountjoy; Anthony J. Walsh; Barry Cardiff; J. O'Dowd; Liam P. Barry; A.D. Ellis; Anthony Fagan
abstract: We examine data transmission during the interval immediately after wavelength switching of a tunable laser and, through simulation, we demonstrate how choice of modulation format can improve the efficacy of an optical burst/packet switched network.

title: Characterization of fiber supercontinuum by chromatic scattering
authors: Е. Ф. Мартынович; Vladimir P. Dresvianski; A. A. Starchenko; Sergey Kobtsev; S. V. Kukarin; S.N. Bagayev
abstract: Chromatic scattering has been proved to characterize the polarization state of the fiber supercontinuum spectral components during propagation in media. Applications are considered for novel technology of multi-layer data recording.

title: Optical Fiber Sensors and their Specialty Fiber Needs
authors: Alexis Méndez
corresponding_authors: Alexis Méndez
abstract: This tutorial will review the basic principles, applications, and specialty fiber needs for optical fiber sensors. Key technical trends will be identified along with relevant commercial opportunities and challenges.

title: New Photonic components for Quantum Information Science
authors: Alberto Politi; Jonathan C. F. Matthews; Anthony Laing; Alberto Peruzzo; Konstantinos Poulios; Jasmin D. A. Meinecke; Damien Bonneau; Pete Shadbolt; Pruet Kalasuwan; Xiaoqi Zhou; Maria Rodas Verde; Mirko Lobino; Terry Rudolph; John Rarity; Mark G. Thompson; Jeremy L. O’Brien
abstract: New photonic components are required to exploit the integrated architecture for Quantum Information science. We demonstrate quantum interference in MMI couplers and two-particle quantum walks in coupled waveguides, showing unique quantum behaviour.

title: Transient Reflective Ultra-broadband THz Spectroscopy
authors: David G. Cooke; Lyubov V. Titova; Tyler L. Cocker; Frank A. Hegmann; A. Meldrum; Frederik C. Krebs; Peter Uhd Jepsen
abstract: We discuss recent experiments with a novel time-domain THz spectrometer using air plasmas to generate and detect ultra-broadband THz pulses. Using this novel setup, we map the ultrafast carrier response of nanocrystalline and organic semiconductors.

title: Metaflex - Metamaterials in flexible substrates at visible wavelengths
authors: Andrea Di Falco; Thomas F. Krauss
abstract: We discuss our recent results in the realization and characterization of Metaflex. We outline the fabrication procedure and show the electromagnetic response for different plasmonic structures, including nano-antennas and fishnet-type structures. Finally, we unveil a novel mechanism based on Fano resonances, which yields to ultra-narrow spectral features in flexible plasmonics.

title: Step Index POF Link Power Budget Calculation Today and Tomorrow
authors: Olaf Ziemann; Sven Loquai; Roman Kruglov
abstract: The correct calculation of the optical power budget is very important for the present standardization. This paper will present a present example and will show options for future improvements with optimized components.

title: Low-loss Dielectric-coated Hollow Rectangular Plasmonic Waveguide supporting THz guidance
authors: B. M. A. Rahman; A. Quadir; H. Tanvir; K. T. V. Grattan
abstract: Modal characteristics of a THz waveguide using an H-field based finite element method is presented. It is shown that by introducing Teflon coating, propagation loss of a hollow-core rectangular plasmonic waveguide can be significantly reduced.

title: High refractive-index-contrast polymer waveguide platform for excitation and sensing in aqueous environments
authors: Björn Agnarsson; Hamid Keshmiri; Jennifer Halldorson; Kristján Leósson
abstract: A high-refractive-index-contrast polymer waveguide platform is presented. The platform is applicable to a wide range of biophotonic applications which rely on evanescent-wave sensing or excitation in aqueous solutions and offers a high level of integration and functionality.

title: Pushing the limits of plasmonic biosensing in molecular biology
authors: Laura M. Lechuga
corresponding_authors: Laura M. Lechuga
abstract: We have recently proposed the use of plasmonic biosensing as an unconventional strategy for deciphering main cell pathways influencing diseases progression in order to improve diagnosis and follow-up of therapies for several diseases as cancer.

title: Perfect light absorbers with multiplexed plasmon resonance metal structures
authors: Joshua R. Hendrickson; Boyang Zhang; Nima Nader; Walter R. Buchwald; Richard Soref; Junpeng Guo
abstract: Surface plasmon gap-mode resonance structure surfaces are investigated for engineering absorption of metamaterial surfaces. By multiplexing different size structures within the unit cell, perfect light absorption has been achieved with broader near-perfect absorption of light.

title: Embedded microfiber in microchip for high sensitivity evanescent field absorbance detection
authors: Lei Zhang; Limin Tong
abstract: A 1.5-μm-diameter microfiber was embedded in a microchip for high sensitivity evanescent field absorbance detection. The sensitivity of the device was investigated by measuring the absorbance of Methylene Blue, achieving a detection limit of 2.8 μM.

title: Detecting absorption spectra of turbid media using a white light photothermal lens spectrophotometer
authors: Aristides Marcano Olaizola; Salvador Alvarado; E. Marı́n
abstract: We detect the absorption spectra of scattering dye solutions using a white light photothermal lens spectrophotometer. We estimate the quantum yield of scattering by comparing the obtained photothermal spectra with the usual absorbance spectra.

title: Low-power optical analyzer platform
authors: Axel Krämer; Yannick Maret; Th. A. Paul
abstract: We developed and analyzed a low-power optical sensor based on vertical cavity surface emitting lasers operated in pulse mode. A new signal processing concept with adaptive control is suggested to optimize the sensor performance.

title: Compact FIR Filter Architecture for Tunable Optical Dispersion Compensation in Silicon Photonics
authors: Abdul Rahim; Štefan Schwarz; J. Bruns; Christian G. Schäffer; K. Petermann
abstract: This paper presents the dispersion behavior of a 4-port asymmetric Mach-Zehnder-Interferometer, which can be used as a building block for a novel, compact and easy to control dispersion compensating filter.

title: Theory and modelling of gain in nano-plasmonics and metamaterials
authors: Ortwin Hess; Joachim M. Hamm
abstract: We give an overview of the theory and modeling of amplification and gain in nano-plasmonic metamaterials and discuss novel results of full time-domain simulations shedding light on the coupled spatio-temporal plasmon-light dynamics in fishnet metamaterials. Article not available.

title: Ultrafast Pulse Compression in Integrated Two-Photon Amplifiers
authors: Amir Nevet; Alex Hayat; Meir Orenstein
abstract: We demonstrate experimentally compression of femtosecond-scale pulses by two-photon gain in an electrically-driven AlGaAs waveguide. Dynamic control of pulse width from 240 to 140 fs is achieved by varying the current injection levels.

title: Crossed-polarization Analysis of Guided Modes in Photonic Crystal Slab Biosensors
authors: Ryan Schilling; Deniz Aydın; Hooman Akhavan; Mohamed El Beheiry; Ofer Levi
abstract: We present the crossed-polarization analysis of guided resonance modes in photonic crystal slab biosensors. A good agreement between experimental resonance peaks and theoretical modeling is presented, revealing high-Q values in these biosensors.

title: Molding Light in Plasmonic and Metamaterial Structures
authors: Dragomir N. Neshev
corresponding_authors: Dragomir N. Neshev
abstract: We present our advances on manipulation of light in metallic nanostructures, including arrays of nanoslits and left-handed fishnet metamaterials. In particular we show experimentally the nonlinear tuning of liquid crystal infiltrated metamaterials.

title: Organic and Hybrid Plasmonic Nanostructures for Energy Conversion
authors: Gary P. Wiederrecht
corresponding_authors: Gary P. Wiederrecht
abstract: Recent advances for photoinduced charge separation in nanostructures are discussed. Both organic and organic plasmonic hybrid nanostructures are described. Ultrafast electronic coupling in the hybrid nanostructures is also observed.

title: Enhanced Echo Retrieval Efficiency Using Ultraslow Light
authors: J. Hahn; Byoung S. Ham
abstract: Using ultraslow light phenomenon, we report two-orders of magnitude enhanced photon echo efficiency in a rare-earth doped solid medium, where the enhancement is due to lengthened photon-atom interaction time in a dilute optical medium.

title: Single-Chip Coherent Transceivers for Optical Transport Networks
authors: Norman Swenson
corresponding_authors: Norman Swenson
abstract: This talk reports on state-of-the-art CMOS transceivers for high-rate (40 Gbps, 100 Gbps, and above) coherent optical transmission. The focus is on recent progress and near-term future trends for commercially available components.

title: Frequency Comb-Based Laser Sensors for Precision Ranging, Spectroscopy and Frequency Transfer
authors: Nathan R. Newbury; Ian Coddington; Esther Baumann; Fabrizio R. Giorgetta; Greg Rieker; Laura C. Sinclair; William C. Swann; A. M. Zolot
corresponding_authors: Nathan R. Newbury; Ian Coddington; Esther Baumann; Fabrizio R. Giorgetta; Greg Rieker; Laura C. Sinclair; William C. Swann; A. M. Zolot
abstract: Frequency combs are a coherent broadband light source well-suited to precision sensing. We discuss a sensing approach that makes use of two coherent frequency combs for precision ranging, spectroscopy and frequency transfer over the air.

title: New Tools for Measurement: Opportunities for Sensing Chemicals or Biomolecules with Optical Fibers
authors: Erik P. Schartner
corresponding_authors: Erik P. Schartner
abstract: This talk will give an overview of some of the current work at IPAS, focussing on applications in which the use of optical fibres allows additional information to be acquired compared to what would otherwise be possible with conventional techniques. Article not available.

title: Quantum-Tuned Two-Junction Solar Cells
authors: Xihua Wang; Ghada I. Koleilat; Edward H. Sargent
abstract: We report quantum-size-effect tuned tandem solar cells. Our two-junction photovoltaic devices employ light-absorbing material of a single composition and use two rationally-selected nanoparticle sizes to harvest the sun's broad spectrum.

title: Terahertz Multiparameter Sensors Based on Frequency Selective Surfaces Interrogated with Subwavelength Fibers
authors: Martin Girard; Maksim Skorobogatiy
abstract: We propose using metasurfaces as sensors for simultaneous measurement of several optical properties of thick films. For paper sheets, simulations show detection resolution of 10 µm to changes in thickness and 0.13% to changes in the water content.

title: Polarizability of Single Split-Ring Nanoresonators at Optical Frequencies
authors: Yury E. Terekhov; А. В. Журавлев; G. V. Belokopytov
abstract: Full polarizability matrix including magnetoelectric cross-components of single SRR was calculated by finite elements method. Three plasmon modes which defines resonance behavior of polarizability were identified.

title: Frozen Light in Optical Waveguides with Absorption and Nonlinearity
authors: C. Martijn de Sterke; Nadav Gutman; Andrey A. Sukhorukov; Y. D. Chong
abstract: High-order stationary points in a dispersion relation, giving rise to frozen light, lead to efficient coupling into slow modes. Here we show that frozen light also enables low-threshold nonlinear effects and strongly enhanced optical absorption.

title: SDN/OpenFlow Based Flexible Optical Transport Networks
authors: Takehiro Tsuritani
corresponding_authors: Takehiro Tsuritani
abstract: Flexible optical networks with flexible transceivers/WSS have the potential to improve network spectral efficiency in existing optical infrastructures. In this paper, we investigate the applicability of SDN/OpenFlow in such networks to improve network flexibility.

title: Resonant Cavity Enhanced LWIR Sensing in Polycrystalline Pb1−xSnxTe
authors: Timothy Zens; P. Becla; Lionel C. Kimerling; Anu Agarwal
abstract: Polycrystalline Pb1-xSnxTe LWIR photodetectors have been fabricated in resonant cavity structures on Si platforms. We describe the fabrication process and report detector performance demonstrating the feasibility of monolithic LWIR detectors-on-ROIC.

title: Optimally coupled hybrid III-V Photonic Crystal Wire Cavity CW Lasers on passive SOI waveguides
authors: Y. Halioua; Alexandre Bazin; T. J. Karle; P. Monnier; I. Sagnes; R. Raj; Fabrice Raineri
corresponding_authors: Y. Halioua; Alexandre Bazin; T. J. Karle; P. Monnier; I. Sagnes; R. Raj; Fabrice Raineri
abstract: Preferential and efficient extraction and delivery of power of a compact low threshold hybrid III-V semiconductor photonic crystals lasers on SOI from/into a CMOS subjacent Silicon-On-Insulator waveguide is demonstrated. Probing the wire-cavity lasers through transmission, reveals a high (>80%) coupling efficiency.

title: Devices to guide and manipulate THz waves
authors: M. Koch
corresponding_authors: M. Koch
abstract: We present a multitude of low cost quasi-optical devices for terahertz waves. This includes lenses, reflectors, gratings, a waveplate, frequency selective surfaces, an electrically tunable notch filter and a device to steer THz beams.

title: Spatially-resolved spectroscopy for simultaneous distinguishment of both structures and materials
authors: Tatsutoshi Shioda; Banh Quoc Tuan
abstract: A spatially-resolved spectroscopy is developed based on a time-domain tomography to measure the reflectance and transmittance of materials. Power transmittance of a known filter sample is measured as a demonstration of the system.

title: Ultra Broadband Mid-IR Detectors Using Multilayer Anti-reflection Coupling
authors: Pao Tai Lin; Timothy Zens; Vivek Singh; Neil Patel; Lionel C. Kimerling; Anu Agarwal
abstract: Ultra broadband mid-IR detector is demonstrated in the spectral region at 2-4 um. The light coupler is composed of multilayer dielectric layers. A 60 % enhancement of transmittance is achieved at light incident angles θ=0°-75°.

title: Time-Frequency Domain Signaling/Multiplexing for Optical Filter-less Networking
authors: Takahide Sakamoto
corresponding_authors: Takahide Sakamoto
abstract: We describe optical filter-less time-frequency domain signal processing for large capacity and high-spectral-efficiency flexible networking. Optical multilevel signaling based on coherent synthesis approaches and time-frequency domain multiplexing/demultiplexing techniques are introduced.

title: III-V on Silicon Hybrid Tunable Lasers
authors: A. Leliepvre
corresponding_authors: A. Leliepvre
abstract: Recent advances on hybrid III-V/Si lasers using a wafer bonding technique are reported. In particular, widely tunable III-V/Si lasers exhibiting 45nm tuning range and selectable AWG-Laser are demonstrated with their applications.

title: All-Solid Photonic Bandgap Fibers for Pressure Sensing
authors: Aline dos S. Almeida; Christiano J. S. de Matos; Marcos A. R. Franco
abstract: A standard and a modified all-solid photonic bandgap fiber are numerically modeled and their pressure sensitivity evaluated aiming at distributed sensing. The modified fiber shows improved sensitivity both in its birefringence and confinement loss.

title: Multispectral Imaging in Combustion Analysis
authors: Marshall B. Long
corresponding_authors: Marshall B. Long
abstract: Optical techniques employing a variety of light scattering mechanisms and detection strategies are important tools for studying combustion. Continued developments in laser sources and detector technologies have enabled increasingly detailed measurements in these complex systems.

title: OCTANE: An Integrated Spectrometer for Optical Coherence Tomography
authors: Nicholas Sherwood; Arthur Nitkowski; Kyle Preston; Andrew Berkeley; Bradley S. Schmidt; A. Hajian
abstract: We introduce the Optical Coherence Tomography Advanced Nanophotonic Engine. OCTANE is the first product line of silicon-chip-based spectrometers for spectral-domain OCT, tailored for low-cost, high-volume medical and industrial applications.

title: Sensing Technique for the Development of Real-time and Low-cost Biosensors Using Photonic Bandgap Structures
authors: Jaime García‐Rupérez; Javier García-Castelló; V. Toccafondo; A. Brimont
abstract: We present experimental sensing results achieved using a novel technique based on the use of photonic bandgap structures where only the output power from a broadband source is monitored, providing a real-time and low-cost system.

title: Broadband enhanced 26 MV/cm THz radiation in uniform nano-slit arrays
authors: Mostafa Shalaby; Marco Peccianti; Luca Razzari; Gargi Sharma; T. Ozaki; Roberto Morandotti; Hannes Merbold; Thomas Feurer; Anja Webeer; L. J. Heyderman; H. Sigg; B. D. Patterson

title: A Practical Coherent WDM PON
authors: K. Y. Cho; S. P. Jung; Y. C. Chung
abstract: We review the recent progresses in the coherent WDM PON technologies achieved at KAIST. Using these technologies, we demonstrate the feasibility of implementing practical long-reach and high-split WDM PONs.

title: Scanless Hyperspectral Raman Imaging (HSRI) by Active-Illumination for SERS-based Multiplexed Molecular Imaging
authors: Wei‐Chuan Shih; Ji Qi; Jingting Li
abstract: We present hyperspectral Raman imaging for collecting Raman spectra from ~500 diffraction limited pixel within 1 second without mechanical scanning, from 100×100 µm2 field of view, which is applicable to multiplexed molecular imaging using SERS-tags.

title: Experimental Demonstration of Training-Aided Frequency Domain Equalization in Hybrid WDM Systems with 40-Gb/s PDM-QPSK and 10-Gb/s OOK Channels
authors: Fabio Pittalá; Martin Finkenbusch; Chen Zhu; Fabian N. Hauske; Peter M. Krummrich; Josef A. Nossek
corresponding_authors: Fabio Pittalá; Martin Finkenbusch; Chen Zhu; Fabian N. Hauske; Peter M. Krummrich; Josef A. Nossek
abstract: Training-aided 2×2 MIMO FDE supported by 16-symbol CAZAC sequences has been demonstrated in hybrid WDM channels transmitted over a 480-km dispersion compensated link. Performance is evaluated with respect to a commonly employed blind TDE.

title: Terabit/s Super-Channels Based on OFDM
authors: Juerg Leuthold; W. Freude; C. Koos; D. Hillerkuss; R. Schmogrow; S. Ben Ezra
abstract: OFDM emerges as a viable technology for the generation of Terabit/s super-channels. We review the concepts behind electrical and all-optical OFDM and report on recent electrical 100 Gbit/s and 26 Tbit/s all-optical super-channel generation experiments.

title: Modeling Active Silicon Photonics Components
authors: Dylan McGuire; Amy Liu
abstract: Characterizations of electro-optic modulators in a variety of configurations were determined from physics-based simulation of the electrical and optical behaviour. Ultimately, the complete transmission response was determined as a function of applied bias.

title: Experimental Demonstration of Grooming Functionality on Tbit/s Optical Superchannel
authors: Yuanxiang Chen; Juhao Li; Paikun Zhu; Yingying Xu; Yucheng Zhong; Bingli Guo; Yongqi He; Zhangyuan Chen
abstract: We propose a node architecture that supports grooming functionality for optical superchannel. And we experimentally demonstrate the add/drop, spectral defragmentation and power equalization functionality on Tbit/s OFDM superchannel.

authors: I. Alex Vitkin
corresponding_authors: I. Alex Vitkin

title: Nanophotonics Devices and Integration for Future Applications
authors: Solomon Assefa
corresponding_authors: Solomon Assefa
abstract: IBM has established a sub-100nm technology platform for monolithic integration of deeply-scaled nanophotonics devices with analog mixed signal circuits. The CMOS-integrated nanophotonics technology is promising for cost-effective 25Gbps transceivers operating within extended temperature ranges.

title: Orthogonal TDM Using Optical Nyquist Pulses
authors: Toshihiko Hirooka; Masataka Nakazawa
abstract: A new high-speed transmission technique using orthogonal time-division multiplexing with an optical Nyquist pulse train is presented. A substantial improvement in dispersion and PMD tolerance is demonstrated due to reduced signal bandwidth without sacrificing ISI.

title: Chip-scale platform for quantum interference-based slow light in atoms
authors: Bin Wu; John F. Hulbert; Katie Hurd; Aaron R. Hawkins; Holger Schmidt
abstract: Hollow-core waveguides form the foundation of a new class of atomic spectroscopy chips that allows for large light-matter interactions at ultralow power levels [1-3]. We will review the development of a chip-scale platform for large quantum interference effects in hot rubidium vapor [4]. These include 44% optical transparency and a group index of 1,200. The concomitant reduction in the group velocity of light results in the largest slow light effects observed in waveguide-based environments to date.

title: Femtosecond Three-Photon Counting in a Photomultiplier Tube
authors: Amir Nevet; Alex Hayat; Meir Orenstein
abstract: We demonstrate experimentally ultrafast three-photon counting by three-photon absorption in a photomultiplier tube, which may serve as a unique tool for ultrafast quantum state characterization as well as for ultrasensitive temporal measurements.

title: Demonstration of a Slow-Light Laser Radar with Two-Dimensional Scanning
authors: Aaron Schweinsberg; Zhimin Shi; Joseph E. Vornehm; Robert W. Boyd
corresponding_authors: Aaron Schweinsberg; Zhimin Shi; Joseph E. Vornehm; Robert W. Boyd
abstract: We demonstrate a proof-of-concept system for steering a coherently-combined multi-aperture slow-light laser radar. Each aperture incorporates slow-light elements, using dispersive delay and SBS, to ensure power overlap at the target.

title: Adaptive Single-Carrier Frequency-Domain Equalization for 100G Coherent Optical Communications
authors: Omid Zia-Chahabi; Raphaël Le Bidan; Michel Morvan; Christophe Laot
abstract: We investigate the principle and performance of fractionally-spaced adaptive single-carrier frequency-domain equalization for 16-QAM 100G coherent optical communications. The proposed solution is shown to be robust against linear impairments.

title: Practical Detection Schemes for Power Efficient Modulation Formats
authors: Pontus Johannisson; Magnus Karlsson
abstract: We discuss the detection process for a selection of power efficient formats. The receiver subsystems of dynamic equalization, phase estimation, and data detection are described with emphasis on the case with differential encoding.

title: Capacity Limits of Optical Fibre Based Communications
authors: Jian Zhao; A.D. Ellis; Danish Rafique
abstract: We discuss the nonlinear capacity limits imposed by inter-channel nonlinearities and signal-noise interaction, and investigate their impacts on the performance of coherent-detection based optical systems using high-level formats and electronic dispersion or intra-channel nonlinearity compensation.

title: Optical Components for Remote Chemical Sensors based on IR Absorption Spectroscopy.
authors: Ishwar D. Aggarwal; Ken Ewing; Lynda E. Busse; Brandon S. Shaw; Lynda E. Busse
abstract: Infrared absorption spectroscopy provides very high sensitivity and specificity. Report on infrared fibers including chalcogenide photonic crystal fibers and progress on a novel Anti-Reflection Surface Structure (ARSS) technique for reducing surface reflection will be presented.

title: Leaky Surface Modes at an Interface Between Isotropic and Uniaxially Anisotropic Materials: Analytical Solution and Finite-Element Analysis
authors: Hsuan-Hao Liu; Hung-Chun Chang
corresponding_authors: Hsuan-Hao Liu; Hung-Chun Chang
abstract: Leaky surface waves are found to exist at an interface between isotropic material with negative permittivity and uniaxially anisotropic material. Analytical solution is derived for such waves, which is confirmed by the finite-element eigenmode analysis.

title: Novel Optical Sensors Based on Integration of Fiber Micro-machining with Sensitive Thin Films
authors: Minghong Yang; Min Wang; D. N. Wang
abstract: The combination of fiber optics with micro-structure and sensitive thin films offers great potential for novel sensor concepts. This paper reviews some works on the integration of thin films with fiber micro-structures for sensing application.

title: An Efficient Polarization Converter for Mid-IR Wavelength
authors: Ajanta Barh; B. M. A. Rahman; Ravi K. Varshney; Bishnu P. Pal
abstract: Design of a silicon-based polarization converter through phase matched power coupling between TE and TM modes is presented. Conversion efficiency up to 90% is feasible at 3 μm wavelength with device length of 536 μm.

title: Fano Resonance with Tunablity in a Single Ring Resonator Based Add/Drop Interferometer
authors: Yundong Zhang; Kaiyang Wang; Changqiu Yu; Xiaoqi Liu; Ping Yuan
abstract: Theoretical investigation in a single resonator based add/drop interferometer was made to achieve Fano resonance tenability. The results show Fano resonance is tunable by controlling the coupling coefficients between the waveguide and ring resonator.

title: Nano-optomechanical System
authors: Mo Li; Wolfram H. P. Pernice; Hong X. Tang
abstract: We describe the convergence of NEMS and nanophotonics in novel optomechanical circuits. Through active coupling of NEMS with high Q cavities, we demonstrate further scaling of NEMS in size, mass, sensitivity, frequency, and damping rate.

title: Performance of a DSP Phase Control Method for Phase Regenerators Based on Phase Sensitive Amplification
authors: Shu Zhang; John C. Cartledge
abstract: A digital signal processor based phase control method is investigated for all-optical phase regeneration using phase sensitive amplification. The phase Q factor is improved by 5.3–7.3 dB for a sampling rate of 312.5 MSa/s.

title: Modeling Polarization in a Bidirectional Fiber System
authors: William La; Li Qian
abstract: We present, for the first time, methods to model the polarization of the output lightwave of a bidirectional fiber-optic system, in which the lightwave propagates through polarization control elements in both directions.

title: Design of One-Dimensional Photonic Crystal Coupled Resonator Optical Waveguides Embedded in Air-Slot Waveguide
authors: Yuki Kawaguchi; Kunimasa Saitoh; Masanori Koshiba
abstract: We propose a design method of slow-light slot waveguide based on one-dimensional photonic crystal coupled resonator optical waveguides (1-D PC-CROWs). We show that slot waveguides proposed here realize small group velocity and low-loss simultaneously.

title: Photonic Crystal Sensor for monitoring the vibration of a laser beam
authors: Andy Ying‐Guey Fuh; Ming Shian Li; Shing Trong Wu
corresponding_authors: Andy Ying‐Guey Fuh; Ming Shian Li; Shing Trong Wu
abstract: Photonic crystals based on polymer dispersed loquid crystals are fabricated using continuous multi-exposures of two-beam interference. It can be applied for use as a beam-vibration sensor for laser beams. Details are reported.

title: Time and frequency-resolved terahertz microscopy with a photoconductive near-field probe
authors: Jan Wallauer; A. Ortner; Andreas Bitzer; Stefan Waselikowski; M. Walther
abstract: By terahertz microscopy based on a photoconductive antenna as scanning near-field probe we demonstrate mapping of electromagnetic fields close to microstructures. Our approach visualizes electric and magnetic near-fields with sub-ps temporal and sub-wavelength spatial resolution.

title: New Prospect of Tellurite Microstructured Fibers
authors: Yasutake Ohishi
corresponding_authors: Yasutake Ohishi
abstract: Dispersion tailored microstructured fibers and nanowires are developed using tellurite glasses. We demonstrate low threshold single-mode supercontinuum generation by using a tellurite nanowire with long suspended struts under the pump of a picosecond fiber laser.

title: CMOS Photonics Technology Platform for High-Speed Optical Transceivers
authors: Peter De Dobbelaere; Sherif Abdalla; Steffen Gloeckner; Drew Guckenberger; Michael Mack; G. Masini; Attila Mekis; Adithyaram Narasimha; Thierry Pinguet; Subal Sahni; B. Welch; Shuhuan Yu
corresponding_authors: Peter De Dobbelaere; Sherif Abdalla; Steffen Gloeckner; Drew Guckenberger; Michael Mack; G. Masini; Attila Mekis; Adithyaram Narasimha; Thierry Pinguet; Subal Sahni; B. Welch; Shuhuan Yu
abstract: We present a mature CMOS photonics technology platform suitable for design, simulation and manufacturing of a variety of high performance optical transceivers. We will highlight some key technology differentiators such as light coupling to optical fibers and very close integration of electronic and photonic devices. The capabilities of the technology platform are illustrated with some examples. Finally we present a roadmap towards higher speed, denser data transmission and closer integration with electronics circuits.

title: Hybrid Transmitter Cells for DWDM Systems
authors: Hua Zhang; Matt Pearson; Serge Bidnyk; A. Balakrishnan
abstract: A compact 10 Gb/s transmitter cell for 100 Gb/s DWDM transmission has been successfully developed using hybrid planar lightwave circuit technology. It is confirmed that the hybrid transmitter cell provides high performance on output power and wavelength stabilization.

title: Compact and widely wavelength tunable lasers based on flexible polymer Bragg reflection waveguide
authors: Kyung-Jo Kim; Jun-Whee Kim; Min‐Cheol Oh
abstract: Widely tuning and reproducible operation of tunable laser is demonstrated based on the extraordinary elastic property of flexible polymeric Bragg reflector. Compact tunable laser package is also demonstrated by incorporating a small PZT actuator.

title: Ultra-precision LIDAR System using Femtosecond Light Pulses
authors: Young‐Jin Kim; Joohyung Lee; Keun‐Woo Lee; Seongheum Han; Yoon‐Soo Jang; Heesuk Jang; Seung‐Woo Kim
abstract: Femtosecond pulse lasers offer breakthroughs in precision metrology particularly in the fields of time, distance and spectroscopy. This advance attracts much attention to extend today's space missions by improving the precision of remote sensing and control capabilities. In this presentation, we introduce how femtosecond lasers are being investigated for space explorations in the near future.

title: Analytical modeling of intrachannel nonlinear impairments in QAM fiber optic system
authors: Sina Naderi Shahi; Shiva Kumar
abstract: Analytical expressions for the PSDs and variances of intrachannel nonlinear impairments are obtained for a fiber optic system based on QAM. The total analytical variance is found to be in good agreement with simulations.

title: Tailoring the Far Field of Bragg Reflection Waveguides
authors: Nima Zareian; Payam Abolghasem; Amr S. Helmy
abstract: A comprehensive study of the far field of Bragg reflection waveguides is presented. Insight obtained by a newly developed Gaussian approximation of the near field provides a valuable tool for optimizing the far-field pattern.

title: Germanium on Silicon Lasers and Detectors
authors: Jürgen Michel
corresponding_authors: Jürgen Michel

title: All-optical control of the group velocity, central frequency and spectral bandwidth of a laser pulse
authors: Emilio Ignesti; Roberto Buffa; Lorenzo Fini; E. Sali; Marco V. Tognetti; Stefano Cavalieri
corresponding_authors: Emilio Ignesti; Roberto Buffa; Lorenzo Fini; E. Sali; Marco V. Tognetti; Stefano Cavalieri
abstract: We present recent results on different schemes (involving both coherent and incoherent interactions) that allow all-optical control of several properties of a large-spectral-bandwidth (up to 3.3 GHz) laser pulse propagating in an atomic medium.

title: Antimonide Optoelectronics for Infrared Chemical Sensing
authors: J. P. Prineas
corresponding_authors: J. P. Prineas
abstract: GaInAsSb quaternary alloy, compound III-V semiconductors are investigated for broadband, high-brightness light emitters and sensitive detector photodiodes spanning 2.0-2.5 ums, a wavelength region of interest for optical chemical sensing of a variety of biomolecules such as glucose, lactate, and urea. Growth of GaInAsSb quaternary alloys across the compositional range are investigated by molecular beam epitaxy. It is found that even the most thermodynamically unstable alloys can be grown epitaxially under nonequilibrium conditions, and through the use of strain. Results of superluminescent and cascaded light emitting diodes, and detector photodiodes fabricated from these materials are presented.

title: Saturation and Delay in Broadband Brillouin Slow-Light
authors: Andrzej Wiatrek; Kambiz Jamshidi; Stefan Preußler; Thomas Schneider
abstract: In this contribution we investigate the influence of gain saturation on the pulse width and the pulse delay. It is shown that saturation can lead to a pulse width compression while increasing the delay time.

title: Infrared laser spectroscopy of explosives particles and residues
authors: Mark C. Phillips; Bruce E. Bernacki; Jonathan D. Suter; Ian M. Craig; Carolyn S. Brauer; Timothy J. Johnson
abstract: We present detection and characterization of explosives residues and particles using infrared quantum cascade lasers, including standoff detection, hyperspectral imaging, micro-spectroscopy, nano-spectroscopy, reference spectra collection, and modeling.

title: Surface profile measurement for a large depth object using optical frequency comb and compressive sensing
authors: Quang Duc Pham; Yoshio Hayasaki
abstract: We demonstrate a profilometer using an ultra-stabilized mode-locked frequency comb laser and the compressive sensing. The ultra-stabilized laser is used to measure an object with a large depth, wide dynamic range without any 2π phase ambiguity. The compressive sensing can obtain the object profile using two photo-receivers and the number of measurements which is fewer than the number of sampling points.

title: Clock Recovery by Fractionally Spaced Equalizers for Parallelized Receivers in Optical Networks
authors: Daniel Schmidt; Zifeng Wu; Berthold Lankl
abstract: A fractionally spaced equalizer (FSE) can perform timing phase adjustment. This paper explains how FSEs can also achieve clock frequency offset compensation. The proposed architecture is suitable for parallelized high speed receivers.

title: Micro-Displacement Sensors Based on Plastic Photonic Bandgap Bragg Fibers
authors: Hang Qu; T. Brastaviceanu; F. Bergeron; J. Olesik; Maksim Skorobogatiy
abstract: We demonstrate a micro-displacement sensor that detects changes in the fiber reflection intensity caused by deflection of a few cm-long, photonic bandgap Bragg fiber. Displacements below 10 µm can be detected with this sensor.

title: Ultra high capacity transmission based on high-order QAM for future optical transport networks
authors: Takayuki Kobayashi; A. Sano; Akihiko Matsuura; Tadao Nakagawa; Eiji Yoshida; Y. Miyamoto
corresponding_authors: Takayuki Kobayashi; A. Sano; Akihiko Matsuura; Tadao Nakagawa; Eiji Yoshida; Y. Miyamoto
abstract: High-capacity transmission using high-order QAM enhanced by powerful DSP is being intensely investigated. In this paper, we review recent high capacity transmission approaches and propose a 400-Gb/s superchannel configuration for future OTNs.

title: An optical microfiber acoustic sensor
authors: George Y. Chen; Gilberto Brambilla; Trevor P. Newson
abstract: An acoustic sensor is demonstrated from a microfiber coiled around an air-backed-mandrel. As acoustic waves induce pressure variations, the mandrel diameter varies and the resulting changes in optical path are detected as phase modulations in an interferometer.

title: Gbps Long-Reach Access Network with Multi-Video Services Broadcasting
authors: C. H. Yeh; Chi‐Wai Chow; Ling Yang; Y. L. Liu; Ci‐Ling Pan
abstract: We propose and demonstrate the 40 and 10 Gb/s downlink and uplink traffic in long-reach PON architecture with multi-services broadcasting, such as CATV, DVB-T, IP-TV and HD-TV etc., in 100 km fiber access transmission.

title: Securing Free Space Optics Communications through Optical Chaos
authors: Fabrizio Chiarello; Leonora Ursini; Marco Santagiustina
abstract: A free space optical chaotic communication system for the secure transmission of a digital message at hundreds Mb/s is presented. The performance of the system is investigated including the indoor infrared channel impairments.

title: Photosensitivity at 1550 nm and Bragg grating inscription in As2Se3 microwires for sensing applications
authors: Raja Ahmad; Martin Rochette
abstract: We demonstrate the writing of Bragg gratings in As2Se3 microwires. Bragg gratings are written from a 1550 nm laser source; we demonstrate strain sensing with an improved sensitivity of 1.3 pm/με compared to silica-based sensors.

title: Nanoridge Surface Plasmon Waveguides
authors: Zeyu Pan; Junpeng Guo; Richard Soref; Walter R. Buchwald
abstract: Metal nanoridges can support well-confined propagating surface plasmon modes. Various geometries of silver nanoridges are investigated in this work. It is found that semicircular top nanoridges are optimal for supporting high figure-of-merit surface plasmon modes.

title: A surface plasmon resonance spectrometer sensor using a super-period metal nanohole grating
authors: Junpeng Guo; Haisheng Leong
abstract: We demonstrated a surface plasmon resonance spectrometer sensor with a patterned super-period metal nanohole grating. With the super-nanohole grating and a CCD, surface plasmon resonance can be measured without using an external optical spectrometer.

title: Optrodes for Electric Field Detection in Muscles and Bacterial Counting
authors: John D. Harvey; Frédérique Vanholsbeeck
abstract: Fibre optic probes can be used to monitor induced fluorescence in very small sample volumes. This talk discusses the design of such probes for the detection of electric fields in muscles and for bacterial counting.

title: Integrated Quarter-Wave Shifted Bragg Grating Array with Equalized Channel Spacing
authors: Jie Sun; Purnawirman; Ehsan Shah Hosseini; Jonathan D. B. Bradley; Thomas Adam; Gerald Leake; Douglas Coolbaugh; Michael R. Watts
abstract: A 4-channel integrated quarter-wave shifted Bragg grating array with precisely equalized channel spacing was demonstrated in a CMOS-compatible process using sidewall Bragg gratings and the equivalent phase shift method.

title: Spectrally-Sliced Coherent Receivers for THz Bandwidth Waveform Measurement
authors: Nicolas K. Fontaine
corresponding_authors: Nicolas K. Fontaine
abstract: Spectrally-sliced coherent receivers use efficient optical spectral demultiplexing, an optical frequency comb (OFC), and an array of coherent receivers to measure wideband signals in many narrowband slices. 214-GBd QPSK waveform measurement is demonstrated.

title: Proposal of a Reconfigurable Ultrafast Optical Pulse Shaping Technique Using Multi-Arm Optical Differentiators
authors: Mohammad H. Asghari; José Azaña
corresponding_authors: Mohammad H. Asghari; José Azaña
abstract: We propose and numerically evaluate a simple, reconfigurable ultrafast optical pulse shaping technique using multi-arm time differentiators with programmable weights that can be implemented using available integrated-waveguide/in-fiber technologies.

title: Slow light optical modulators
authors: Toshihiko Baba; Hong C. Nguyen
abstract: Slow light in photonic crystal waveguides allows the size reduction in MZ modulators. Even with 50 – 200 μm phase shifters, modulators operate at 10 Gbps and beyond in the wide spectral and temperature ranges.

title: Physical Layer Constraints in Dynamic Optical Mesh Networks at Higher Bit-rates
authors: Danish Rafique; A.D. Ellis
abstract: We demonstrate that addition of higher-order modulation formats and increased network flexibility significantly degrades the through traffic due to severe XPM effects, in a WDM optical transport network employing dynamic 28Gbaud PM-mQAM transponders.

title: Erbium-Doped Chalcogenide Glass Micro-Disks as Monolithic Mid-IR Laser Sources
authors: Faleh Al Tal; Clara Dimas; Juejun Hu; Anu Agarwal; Lionel C. Kimerling
corresponding_authors: Faleh Al Tal; Clara Dimas; Juejun Hu; Anu Agarwal; Lionel C. Kimerling
abstract: The feasibility of Mid-Infrared (MIR) lasing in Erbium-doped Gallium Lanthanum Sulfide (GLS) micro-disks was investigated. Based on state-of-the-art Chalcogenides micro-disk resonators parameters, lasing was simulated and shown to be possible.

title: Silicon Photonics Devices for Optical Interconnection
authors: Takahiro Nakamura; Junichi Fujikata; Masashige Ishizaka; Keishi Ohashi
corresponding_authors: Takahiro Nakamura; Junichi Fujikata; Masashige Ishizaka; Keishi Ohashi
abstract: For optical interconnection, we demonstrated high-speed and high-efficiency optical modulator and photodetector by introducing nanostructure. Also, compact WDM optical source was developed using hybrid integrated semiconductor optical amplifier and silicon waveguide resonators.

title: Amplitude and Timing Jitter Performance of Spectrally Periodic Phase Filters for Optical Pulse Rate Multiplication
authors: Antonio Malacarne; José Azaña
abstract: We analyze simultaneous amplitude and timing jitter performance in commonly believed equivalent phase filters for implementing the Talbot-based optical pulse rate multiplication technique, demonstrating different behaviors than classical Talbot filtering, varying their spectral periodicity.

title: Enhanced speckle microstrain measurements in PDMS doped with SiO2 nanoparticles
authors: Carlos Briones; A. Hernández-Suárez; Natanael Cuando-Espitia; Juan Hernández-Cordero; Francisco M. Sánchez-Arévalo
abstract: Measurements of microstrain levels in PDMS membranes doped with SiO2 nanoparticles were obtained using digital image correlation (DIC). The mechanical behavior of PDMS can be analyzed using the enhanced speckle pattern obtained from the samples.

title: Transmission line modeling of nano-plasmonic devices
authors: Osman Ahmed; Mohamed A. Swillam; Mohamed H. Bakr; Xun Li
abstract: We demonstrate the application of the time domain transmission line method (TLM) to accurate modeling of surface plasmon polariton (SPP) structures. The constructed TLM node allows for modeling of dispersive materials and perfect absorbing boundaries.

title: FM-to-AM effect induced by Mode interference in Low NA Large-Mode-Area Fiber
authors: Dangpeng Xu; Wang Jian-Jun; Jing Li; Honghuan Lin; Deng Ying; Rui Zhang; Na Zhu; Mingzhong Li
abstract: The mode interference effect in large mode area fiber was investigated in the paper, the results shown that interference effect can induce output mode and spectral distortion, especially for phase modulated pulse, the temporal waveform can generate modulations on the top of the pulse.

title: Optical Current Transducers Incorporating Polymeric Integrated Optical Chip
authors: Min‐Cheol Oh; Woo-Sung Chu; Kyung-Jo Kim; Jun-Whee Kim
abstract: Various functional optical devices are integrated on a single chip in order to construct optical current transducers based on polarization rotated reflection interferometry, which consists of polarization maintaining 3-dB couplers, TE-pass polarizers, TE/TM polarization converters, and thermo-optic phase modulators. The integrated-optic chip is incorporated in a current sensor module to measure the optical phase retardation. The sensor exhibited good linearity with a signal deviation less than 0.2%. The integrated-optic device provides inherent polarization maintenance and precise control of the optical propagation length, which are important in interferometric sensors.

title: Engineering Circular Multiple Light Scattering For Polarization-Insensitive Planar Diffraction
authors: Jacob Trevino; Luca Dal Negro
abstract: Plasmonic aperiodic spirals, which are shown to support structural resonances carrying orbital angular momentum, are investigated by dark-field imaging with analytical multi-particle calculations in the framework of the Generalized Mie Theory.

title: Circular Bragg Grating Reflector Suitable for Integration with Narrow Silicon Nanowires
authors: Thomas Chae
corresponding_authors: Thomas Chae
abstract: We propose a deeply etched curved Bragg grating on a 460nm-wide silicon nanowire and demonstrate its potential to help achieve reflectivity of above 0.99 over a 362nm bandwidth through 2D FDTD simulation.

title: Delayed Single-tap Subband Processing for Chromatic Dispersion Compensation
authors: Israa Slim; Amine Mezghani; Leonardo Gomes Baltar; Juan Qi; Fabian N. Hauske; Josef A. Nossek
abstract: Our method for subband processing frequency domain (FD) chromatic dispersion (CD) compensation is based on a single tap with delay equalizer in each subband. With this technique uncompensated trans-Pacific transmission becomes feasible.

title: High power terahertz pulse generation, imaging, and detection
authors: Frank A. Hegmann
corresponding_authors: Frank A. Hegmann
abstract: The generation of intense single-cycle THz pulses by tilted-pulse-front techniques for probing ultrafast nonlinear THz dynamics in semiconductors is described. Full-field imaging of THz Cherenkov waves and novel THz pulse detection methods are also discussed. Article not available.

title: High-throughput Fabrication of Nanoplasmonic Devices for SPR and SERS Biosensing
authors: Sang‐Hyun Oh
corresponding_authors: Sang‐Hyun Oh
abstract: We will present high-throughput fabrication techniques for nanoplasmonic devices, including template stripping, nanoimprinting, and interference lithography. Then we will discuss how to combine nanoplasmonic sensors with free-space optics and microfluidics to construct high-performance biosensing instruments.

title: Optical Resonance Sensing in Surface Bloch Modes on Woodpile Photonic Crystals
authors: Shu-Yu Su; Lingling Tang; Tomoyuki Yoshie
abstract: Low loss and high sensitivity are confirmed in surface Bloch modes on (100) and (001) dielectric woodpile photonic crystals. A flat-top (100) woodpile surface is also designed for optical resonance sensing.

title: High power titanium Q-switched nano-antennas
authors: Evgeny G. Mironov; Ziyuan Li; Haroldo T. Hattori
abstract: In this paper, we show that titanium based nano-antennas can withstand considerably higher power (18 dB) than their gold counterparts without a significant drop in their electric field enhancement capability.

title: Magnetooptical Materials for Integrated Nonreciprocal Devices
authors: Caroline A. Ross
corresponding_authors: Caroline A. Ross
abstract: Magnetooptical materials enable nonreciprocal light propagation which is essential for the operation of isolators and circulators in optical systems. The growth of magnetooptical garnets with Ce and Bi substitution as well as magnetooptically active perovskites by pulsed laser deposition, and application to a monolithically integrated racetrack isolator, are described.

title: Optical Performance Monitoring Based on Filtering in High-speed Optical Fiber Communication Systems
authors: Changyuan Yu; Yi Yu
abstract: Optical performance monitoring (OPM) is important for management of high-speed optical networks. In this paper, our techniques for chromatic dispersion (CD) and optical signal to noise ratio (OSNR) monitoring based on filtering methods are reviewed.

title: On the Implementation of Soft-Decision Decoders for High-Speed Optical Transmission
authors: Ivan B. Djordjević
corresponding_authors: Ivan B. Djordjević
abstract: In this invited paper, we discuss large-girth LDPC codes suitable for high-speed optical transmission, and describe several reduced-complexity LDPC-decoding algorithms. We evaluate the quantization effect BER performance degradation and discuss FPGA implementation of reduced-complexity LDPC-decoders.

title: Low Loss Antiresonant Hollow Core Fibres
authors: Francesco Poletti; J. R. Hayes; David J. Richardson
abstract: We study the loss mechanisms in novel antiresonant hollow core fibres and demonstrate the importance of optimising the air cladding thickness and reducing the node size. Based on these rules we fabricate fibres with wide bandwidth and low loss.

title: High-Accuracy Calculations of Light Scattering by Plasmonic Cylinders Using the Legendre Pseudospectral Frequency-Domain (PSFD) Method
authors: Chih-Yu Wang; Shih-Yung Chung; Chun-Hao Teng; Chung-Ping Chen; Hung-Chun Chang
corresponding_authors: Chih-Yu Wang; Shih-Yung Chung; Chun-Hao Teng; Chung-Ping Chen; Hung-Chun Chang
abstract: A high-order accurate pseudospectral frequency-domain (PSFD) method is used to analyze light scattering by plasmonic cylinders. Field coupling and enhancement within the gap of close spaced cylinders are examined. Dielectric-coated metallic cylinders are also studied.

title: The transition from a TEM-like mode to a plasmon-like mode in a parallel plate waveguide
authors: Jingbo Liu; Rajind Mendis; Daniel M. Mittleman
abstract: We experimentally characterize the spatial mode inside a finite-width parallel-plate waveguide using a subwavelength probe. We observe a transition from a TEM-like spatial mode at low frequencies to a plasmon-like mode at high frequencies.

title: In-line evanescent-wave microfluidic absorption sensor based on an embedded optical microfiber coil
authors: Roberto Lorenzi; Yongmin Jung; Gilberto Brambilla
corresponding_authors: Roberto Lorenzi; Yongmin Jung; Gilberto Brambilla
abstract: We present the absorption spectra collected with an evanescent-field absorption sensor. The device comprises a fluidic channel with an embedded fiber coil resonator. Deviations from Beer-Lambert law will be discussed in terms of adsorption mechanism.

title: Pre FEC Error Burstiness for 100G Systems Operating in Heavily XPM-Limited Regime
authors: Paolo Leoni; V.A.J.M. Sleiffer; Stefano Calabrò; V. Veljanovski; Maxim Kuschnerov; Berthold Lankl
abstract: We experimentally investigate the impact of high-power 10G-OOK neighbors on the pre FEC bit error distribution of a 100G-PDM-DQPSK system, evidencing a remarkable deviation from the ideal case of independent and identically distributed errors.

title: Architecture, System, and Enabling Technologies for Elastic Optical Networks: Future Opportunities and Challenges
authors: S. J. Ben Yoo
corresponding_authors: S. J. Ben Yoo
abstract: This tutorial will review underlying concepts, architecture, system, and enabling technologies of elastic optical networking. Coherent systems integration using optical arbitrary waveform generation/measurement towards realization of software-defined-networks will also be covered.

title: Chalcogenide Microstructured Optical Fibers for IR Photonics
authors: Jean‐Luc Adam; Johann Trolès; Laurent Brilland
abstract: Chalcogenide glasses show broad mid-infrared transparency and high non-linear refractive index. Single-mode chalcogenide microstructured optical fibers were obtained with losses around 0.3dB/m in the mid-IR. Fibers with small and large effective mode areas were demonstrated.

title: Monolithically Integrated Digitally Tunable Laser Using a Reflective Arrayed Waveguide Grating with Multimode Interference Reflectors
authors: Emil Kleijn; M.K. Smit; X.J.M. Leijtens
abstract: We present a novel monolithically integrated semiconductor laser based on a Reflective Arrayed Waveguide Grating and Multimode Interference Reflectors. The laser emits at seven distinct wavelengths using only four optical amplifiers.

authors: Brandon S. Shaw; Rafael R. Gattass; Jas Sanghera; Ishwar D. Aggarwal

title: Tungstate-Tellurite Optical Fibers for Special Applications
authors: A. F. Kosolapov; Yuri Yatsenko; V O Nazaryants; M. S. Astapovich; V. G. Plotnichenko; А. Н. Моисеев; V. V. Dorofeev; Г. Е. Снопатин; М. Ф. Чурбанов; E. M. Dianov
abstract: Different types of optical fibers with losses less than 100 dB/km were produced from high-purity tungstate-tellurite glasses. The microstructured fiber for supercontinuum generation in the range 1-5 μm with optical loss of 4 dB/m has been fabricated.

title: LPG in perfluorinated GI-POF for concentration measurement in liquids
authors: J. Castrellón-Uribe; Mauro Matías Lomer Barboza; Hany Shokry Girgis Roufael; Luis Rodŕıguez-Cobo; José Miguel López Higuera
corresponding_authors: J. Castrellón-Uribe; Mauro Matías Lomer Barboza; Hany Shokry Girgis Roufael; Luis Rodŕıguez-Cobo; José Miguel López Higuera
abstract: This paper describes the manufacture of long period gratings (LPG) for liquid concentration sensing. The LPGs are made in perfluorinated polymer optical fiber point to point using a pulsed laser at 355 nm. A LPG of period 75 µm and a wavelength of resonance of 910 nm is used for measurement of water with different concentrations of sugar.

title: Integrated Carrier Phase and Frequency Estimation for Coherent Detection based on Multi-Symbol Differential Detection (MSDD)
authors: Moshe Nazarathy; Netta Sigron; Igor Zelniker
abstract: We review and present new results on MSDD carrier recovery for optical coherent detection. The frequency and phase estimation functions are jointly accomplished with lowest complexity, high performance and automatic adaptation to the channel statistics.

title: Enhanced Efficiency of Light Emission from ZnO/Ni Core/shell Nanowires: Effects of Surface Plasmons
authors: Qianqian Ren; Sheng Chen; M. Devika; N. Koteeswara Reddy; C. W. Tu; Weimin Chen; I. A. Buyanova
corresponding_authors: Qianqian Ren; Sheng Chen; M. Devika; N. Koteeswara Reddy; C. W. Tu; Weimin Chen; I. A. Buyanova
abstract: Enhancement of light emission mediated via surface plasmons is demonstrated in ZnO/Ni core/shell nanowires, based on time-resolved photoluminescence measurements. The obtained results are promising for future light emitters with spin-enabling functionality.

title: Optical Identification of Dielectric and Metallic Nanoparticle Colloids
authors: Jarkko J. Saarinen; Jun Uozumi; Erik M. Vartiainen∥; Kai‐Erik Peiponen
abstract: Optical identification of dielectric and metal nanoparticles in a colloid is presented using the maximum entropy method for phase retrieval of surface plasmon resonance reflectance and direct reflectance with TE/TM linearly polarized light.

title: Spectral-Domain Low-Coherence Dynamic Light Scattering to Analyze Spatio-Nonstationary Brownian Dynamics
authors: Toshiaki Iwai; Toshiharu Watarai
abstract: Spectral-domain low-coherence dynamic light scattering is developed to analyze spatio-nonstationary dynamics of Brownian particles close to the interfaces between different phases, the liquid-solid and the liquid-gas interfaces. This work confirms experimentally the potential of the developed system from the metrological viewpoints.

title: Optical control of the Faraday Effect in a Slow-light Medium
authors: Paul Siddons; Lee Weller; Charles S. Adams; Ifan G. Hughes
abstract: We demonstrate modified Faraday polarization rotation of an optical field controlled by a pump beam in hot rubidium vapour. Induced rotations of greater than π/2 rad are seen with a transmission of 95%.

title: Designer Media and Pulses for Optimally Long-Lived and Reversible Energy Storage
authors: Scott Glasgow
corresponding_authors: Scott Glasgow
abstract: Given a dielectric resonance structure and geometry, we outline design of pulses stored most reversibly. Given a pulse and medium geometry, we outline design of a resonance structure for most reversible pulse storage.

title: Multi-Megahertz OCT: Technology, recent developments and advantages
authors: Thomas Klein; Wolfgang Wieser; Benjamin R. Biedermann; Christoph M. Eigenwillig; Robert Huber
abstract: Fourier domain mode locked (FDML) lasers enable unprecedented line rates in optical coherence tomography for completely new imaging protocols and data analysis approaches. The optical design and potential benefits for clinical diagnosis will be discussed.

title: Efficient Raman Sensor for Nanoparticles using Hollow Core Photonic Crystal Fiber
authors: Jacky S. W. Mak; Abdiaziz A. Farah; F. Chen; Amr S. Helmy
abstract: Strong Raman modes of the semiconductor core, thiol agents, and their interfacial compound in colloidal CdTe quantum dots were observed and compared for the first time in aqueous solution through efficient Raman scattering in HC-PCF.

title: Monolithic Nanoporous Gold Disks as Surface-Enhanced Raman Scattering Substrates
authors: Ji Qi; Pratik Motwani; J. C. Wolfe; Wei‐Chuan Shih
abstract: Monolithic nanoporous gold disks, 500 nm in diameter, 75 nm in thickness and 3.5 nm in pore radius, exhibit a surface-enhanced Raman scattering enhancement factor of at least 108 using benzenethiol with 785 nm excitation.

title: Cavity-Resonator-Integrated Guided-Mode Resonance Filter for Highly Efficient Coupling with Gaussian Beam
authors: Kenji Kintaka; Koji Hatanaka; Junichi Inoue; Shogo Ura
abstract: A cavity-resonator-integrated guided-mode resonance filter can provide a narrowband reflection with small aperture. An efficiency improvement for an incident Gaussian beam was achieved experimentally by using a nonuniform grating coupler for the first time.

title: Notch Nonlinear Frequency Shift in AlGaAs Bragg Grating Waveguides
authors: Pamela Tannouri; Michael J. Strain; Matteo Clerici; Marco Peccianti; Alessia Pasquazi; Sze Phing Ho; I. Rowe; Katarzyna A. Rutkowska; Marc Sorel; Roberto Morandotti
corresponding_authors: Pamela Tannouri; Michael J. Strain; Matteo Clerici; Marco Peccianti; Alessia Pasquazi; Sze Phing Ho; I. Rowe; Katarzyna A. Rutkowska; Marc Sorel; Roberto Morandotti
abstract: We present an investigation on the nonlinear dynamics of intense pulses in an AlGaAs Bragg waveguide and we report the experimental observation of an intensity dependent blue-shift of the Bragg notch spectral line.

title: Sensing and Imaging in Tissue Using Fiber Optics: 3D Micro-imaging Optics and Medical Applications
authors: David D. Sampson
corresponding_authors: David D. Sampson
abstract: We have designed high-performance imaging optics on the tip of single-mode optical fibers. Embedding such probes within a rigid needle provides access to deep tissues impossible with surface-based imaging and, as well, a natural actuator for optical elastography.

title: Photonic Band Structure of Circular Photonic Crystals in Silicon-on-Insulator Slab by Surface Coupling Reflectivity Technique
authors: Jian Lin; Danh Bich; Georg W. Rieger; Jeff F. Young; Hung‐Chih Kan; Chia‐Chen Hsu
corresponding_authors: Jian Lin; Danh Bich; Georg W. Rieger; Jeff F. Young; Hung‐Chih Kan; Chia‐Chen Hsu
abstract: We investigated the photonic band structure of a two dimensional (2D) circular photonic crystal (CPC) silicon membrane slab waveguide with surface coupling reflectivity (SCR) technique. Fano-like sharp resonance modes were found in the angle-resolved SCR spectra for both P- and S-polarized light. By extracting energies of the resonance modes as a function of incident angle, we determine the dispersion of the sample. For the rotational symmetry of the photonic band structure of the sample, we measure its SCR spectra as a function of azimuthal angles, from which we identified two P-polarized isotropic photonic bands, consistent with the circularly symmetrical structure of the waveguide structure reflected by the circular ring diffraction pattern from the structure.

title: Building Scalable Data Centers with Silicon-Photonic Enabled Data Movement
authors: Keren Bergman
corresponding_authors: Keren Bergman
abstract: In this paper we explore the impact of silicon photonic interconnects on the system level performance using an integrated software environment that uniquely couples models of the physical link, network, and application layers

title: Comparison of Cascade, Baseline, and Lattice Architectures for Ultra-Compact RF Photonic Filters on SOI
authors: Payam Alipour; Ali A. Eftekhar; Amir H. Atabaki; Qing Li; Siva Yegnanarayanan; Christi K. Madsen; Ali Adibi
abstract: We compare the cascade, baseline, and lattice architectures for a four-pole, four-zero photonic filter implemented using high-Q resonator-based components on SOI. These filters are fully reconfigurable and very compact (total area 0.15 mm2).

title: Photonics-Electronics Convergent System Technology
authors: Yasuhiko Arakawa; Takahiro Nakamura; Yutaka Urino; Tsuyoshi Horikawa
corresponding_authors: Yasuhiko Arakawa; Takahiro Nakamura; Yutaka Urino; Tsuyoshi Horikawa
abstract: We demonstrate silicon optical interposers for inter-chip interconnects, integrating lasers, optical splitters, modulators, waveguides and photodetectors on a single silicon substrate. Innovative challenge of quantum dot lasers for silicon photonics application is also discussed.

title: Guided Mode Resonance Sensors for the Monitoring of Film Growth in Atomic Layer Deposition
authors: Adriana Szeghalmi; E.‐B. Kley; Mato Knez
corresponding_authors: Adriana Szeghalmi; E.‐B. Kley; Mato Knez
abstract: Guided mode resonance optics consisting of linear gratings are highly sensitive optical sensors. Their use for monitoring the film growth during atomic layer deposition will be discussed based on rigorous coupled wave approach calculations.

authors: Anil K. Patnaik; Paul S. Hsu; Sukesh Roy; James R. Gord
corresponding_authors: Anil K. Patnaik; Paul S. Hsu; Sukesh Roy; James R. Gord

title: Large Blueshift of Resonance Wavelength Simulated With a Small Refractive-index Change of a Nanoporous Waveguide
authors: Zhi‐mei Qi; Zhe Zhang; Qian Liu; Danfeng Lu
corresponding_authors: Zhi‐mei Qi; Zhe Zhang; Qian Liu; Danfeng Lu
abstract: Simulation of the refractive-index sensitivity of nanoporous leaky waveguide resonance sensors based on waveguide theorey combined with Fresnel equations reveals an extraordinary feature, that is, a large blueshift of the resonance wavelength induced by a small change in refractive index of the surrounding liquid.

title: OCDMA and OFDMA Technologies for NG-PON
authors: Ken-ichi Kitayama
corresponding_authors: Ken-ichi Kitayama
abstract: R&Ds and standardization activities of Next-Generation (NG) passive optical network (PON) have been underway, which will upgrade beyond 10G-PON existing commercial Fiber-To-The-Home (FTTH) systems. NG-PON1 aims at an evolutional growth of gigabit-PON, while, on the other hand, NG-PON2 coming after NG-PON1 will bring a revolution change and is planned to be standardized by 2015. NG-PON2 includes several technology candidates such as 40/100G TDMA, DWDMA, OCDMA, and OFDMA.

title: Dynamics of noise in THz photomixers as a receiver sensor
authors: Barmak Heshmat; Hamid Pahlevaninezhad; J. Zhang; T.E. Darcie
abstract: We present an analytical estimation and experimental measurement of noise spectral density and noise average power in THz photomixers as receivers in heterodyne THz sensing. The estimations take into account generation-recombination, thermal, and flicker noise. This provides insight into effect of different photomixer parameters on the noise level of a detected signal, and to noise behavior prior to detection of THz signals in the alignment stage of the receiver photoconductive sensor.

title: Active Device Modeling and Simulation: Multi-Stable Micro-Lasers for All-Optical Switching
authors: Dmitry N. Chigrin; Sergei V. Zhukovsky
abstract: Multistability in microstructures can pave the way towards designing an all-optical memory cells suitable for applications in integrated optics. We review general theoretical principles behind the multistable microlaser operation and applications.
