title: Fully Optimized Long Period Fiber Grating Designs for Ultrafast Optical Differentiation
authors: Reza Ashrafi; Mohammad H. Asghari; José Azaña
abstract: We propose a novel design for arbitrary-order optical differentiation based on a especially-apodized long period fiber grating operated in transmission to fully optimize the energetic efficiency and processing speed of the device.

authors: Sang Hoon Chin; Luc Thévenaz

authors: Seán Ó Dúill; G. Eisenstein

authors: Zun Huang; Evgenii E. Narimanov
abstract: We describe a novel zero-th order resonance in a Perot-Fabry resonator with planar hyperbolic metamaterials. This resonance combines sub-wavelength light confinement with strong radiative coupling, enabling a practical planar design of nanolasers and subwavelength waveguides.

title: Characterization of extremely short LiNbO3 Bragg gratings
authors: Clément Guyot; Gwenn Ulliac; Arnaud Gerthoffer; Jean Dahdah; Benattou Sadani; Blandine Guichardaz; Roland Salut; M.-P. Bernal; Fadi Baida; Nadège Courjal

authors: Hagen Renner
corresponding_authors: Hagen Renner
abstract: We show analytically for long low-loss p-i-n silicon waveguides that upshifting the electric-field-screening threshold intensity simultaneously requires an adequate reduction of the low-intensity free-carrier lifetime to improve the high-intensity transmissivity.

title: Bragg gratings in sub-wavelength chalcogenide wires
authors: Raja Ahmad; Martin Rochette
abstract: We report the photo-inscription of Bragg gratings in chalcogenide (As2Se3) fibers tapered down to 1 µm. A transmission dip of <-30 dB at a wavelength of 1573 nm is achieved after 9 minutes of exposure time with 633 nm light.

title: Nanoparticle identification from a liquid matrix using the maximum entropy method for SPR reflectance
authors: Jarkko J. Saarinen; Erik M. Vartiainen∥; Kai‐Erik Peiponen
abstract: We show that surface plasmon resonance (SPR) reflectance measurement can be used to identify nanoparticles from a liquid matrix using the maximum entropy method once the optical properties of the host liquid are known.

authors: Cladia Goy; Maik Scheller; Benedikt Scherger; Vincent P. Wallace; Martín Koch
corresponding_authors: Cladia Goy; Maik Scheller; Benedikt Scherger; Vincent P. Wallace; Martín Koch
abstract: We present a prism for the terahertz range. The prism is made of polypropylene and uses waveguide dispersion to spatially separate terahertz frequencies. Experimental data obtained with a fiber-coupled terahertz spectrometer agree with theoretical expectations.

title: Fast light in erbium doped fibers based on coherent population oscillations with nonlinear negative absorption.
authors: Francisco Arrieta-Yáñez; Sonia Melle; Óscar G. Calderón
corresponding_authors: Francisco Arrieta-Yáñez; Sonia Melle; Óscar G. Calderón

authors: Fetah Benabid
corresponding_authors: Fetah Benabid
abstract: We review the recent progress on hollow-core photonic crystal fibers and its integrated form of photonic microcells in both their design and fabrication and in their applications in Raman fibre lasers.

authors: A. Willinger; G. Eisenstein
corresponding_authors: A. Willinger; G. Eisenstein
abstract: We describe a numerical study of narrowband parametric processes in a dispersion engineered photonic crystal waveguide with one or two pumps placed in the normal dispersion regime. Gain and distortion of 40Gbit/s data are analysed.

authors: A. A. Veselov; Alexander Efimov; Alexander Chamorovskiy; Oleg G. Okhotnikov; A. F. Kosolapov; A.E. Levchenko; Helge Lemmetyinen; Nikolay V. Tkachenko

corresponding_authors: D. M. Beggs; Isabella H. Rey; Tobias Kampfrath; Thomas F. Krauss; L. Kuipers

authors: Sangjun Lee; Sangin Kim; Jaejin Lee; Hanjo Lim

authors: Sookyoung Roh; Taerin Chung; Byoungho Lee
corresponding_authors: Sookyoung Roh; Taerin Chung; Byoungho Lee

Nanostructures such as deep metallic 1D or 2D gratings in metallic layer are analyzed and utilized for inducing the plasmonic absorption in infrared region. Fiber-optic probe based sensor shows a resonance curve with the sensitivity of 1000 nm/RIU in the reflection spectrum.

title: SHAPING THE FUTURE OF NANOBIOPHOTONICS
authors: Kishan Dholakia; Tomáš Čižmár; Michaël Mazilu; Joerg Baumgartl; P. Ashok; X. Tsampoula; Frank J. Gunn‐Moore
corresponding_authors: Kishan Dholakia; Tomáš Čižmár; Michaël Mazilu; Joerg Baumgartl; P. Ashok; X. Tsampoula; Frank J. Gunn‐Moore

authors: Zhongchao Duan; Meisong Liao; Xin Yan; Weiqing Gao; Takenobu Suzuki; Yasutake Ohishi

title: Numerical Simulations of Temperature Dependence of High-Efficiency Multi-Junction Solar Cells Under Concentrated Sunlight
authors: Jeffrey F. Wheeldon; Alexandre W. Walker; Olivier Thériault; Mark D. Yandt; Karin Hinzer
corresponding_authors: Jeffrey F. Wheeldon; Alexandre W. Walker; Olivier Thériault; Mark D. Yandt; Karin Hinzer
abstract: The temperature dependence of GaInP/GaAs/Ge multi-junction solar cells are numerically modeled. The temperature dependence of the solar cell dark current and the spectral sensitivity of the solar cell are demonstrated. Both aspects of the temperature dependence are connected to the temperature dependence of the semiconductor band gaps. Reduction in the efficiency is simulated by shifting the semiconductor band gaps using the Varshni relation, which in the model creates the corresponding increase in solar cell dark current with increasing temperature. The Varshni relations is further utilized to develop a temperature dependent absorption coefficient model. This model simulates the shift in the external quantum efficiency to longer wavelengths as the temperature increases, which shows good agreement with experimental results. Since standard test conditions of solar cells is at 298 K, this complex numerical model represents an important step forward to studying temperature dependences of multi-junction solar cells under real-world conditions, in which solar cell can operate at temperatures of 50 K above ambient temperatures.

title: Mode Propagation Analysis of 1-to-N Multimode Interference Power Splitter with Small Cuts
authors: Sheng-Hsien Wong; Tso-Yun Wei; Wan‐Shao Tsai; Way Seen Wang
abstract: Field distributions of 1-to-N multimode interference optical power splitters with two cascaded multimode interference regions are calculated. An improved objective function is presented for the optimization of the proposed devices.

authors: C. H. Yeh; Chi‐Wai Chow; Ling Yang; Ci‐Ling Pan
corresponding_authors: C. H. Yeh; Chi‐Wai Chow; Ling Yang; Ci‐Ling Pan
abstract: We first propose and investigate the dynamic uplink traffic rate adjustment employing RSOA-based optical network unit (ONU) in current PON and long reach PON systems, according to the injected power level of downlink signal.

title: Automatic Extraction of Chirp Parameter of DFB Laser
authors: Lin Han; Yefeng Wen; Wei-Ping Huang
corresponding_authors: Lin Han; Yefeng Wen; Wei-Ping Huang
abstract: A new method is proposed for extracting chirp parameter of DFB laser by fitting the side-band strengths ratio curve obtained from frequency spectrum measurement. It is validated by comparing with the result obtained from fiber dispersion measurement.

title: Optical Method for Microfluidic Detection of Bacteria in Water
authors: Narendra Kumar Sharma; Donna Meyer; Assem Abolmaaty
corresponding_authors: Narendra Kumar Sharma; Donna Meyer; Assem Abolmaaty
abstract: Fluorescence scanner was used to detect and quantify K12 bacteria in water to a detection limit of 3800 CFU/mL by correlating quantum dot fluorescence signal intensity to number of bacteria obtained by plate count.

title: Refractive Index Profiling of an Optical Waveguide with Optical Path Perturbation
authors: Kai-Hsun Tsai; San-Yu Ding; Wan‐Shao Tsai
corresponding_authors: Kai-Hsun Tsai; San-Yu Ding; Wan‐Shao Tsai
abstract: Two-dimensional index profile of an optical fiber was reconstructed with the measured differential optical fields by perturbing the optical path in the end-fire coupling measurement. Good results were obtained compared with the known index profile.

title: Few-cycle Self-Induced-Transparency Solitons
authors: YuanYao Lin; I-Hong Chen; Ray‐Kuang Lee
corresponding_authors: YuanYao Lin; I-Hong Chen; Ray‐Kuang Lee
abstract: We reveal the existence of optical self-induced-transparency soliton family in a two-level absorbing system down to few cycle limit based on the few-cycle envelope approximation. The effects of number of cycles on area theory and pulse group velocity are given to demonstrate possible coherent photon-matter interactions in the extreme regime.

title: Destructive Interference of Dark Resonances in a Room Temperature Tripod System
authors: Santosh Kumar; T. Lauprêtre; Fabien Bretenaker; R. Ghosh; Fabienne Goldfarb
corresponding_authors: Santosh Kumar; T. Lauprêtre; Fabien Bretenaker; R. Ghosh; Fabienne Goldfarb
abstract: We explore the response of a tripod system in 4He* under excitation by perpendicularly polarized pump and probe beams in the presence of a transverse magnetic field. Destructively interfering dark resonances are observed and interpreted.

title: Benzocyclobutene Multimode Interference Power Splitters Fabricated by Ultraviolet Laser Illumination
authors: Yu-Shuan Chang; Wan‐Shao Tsai; Way‐Seen Wang
abstract: Various multimode interference power splitters fabricated by laser illumination on benzocyclobutene are compared. With suitable beam expansion ratios, experimental results show the devices can be fabricated with high accuracy, short time, and good controllability.

title: Role of localized surface plasmon resonance in various nano-structures for sensing
authors: Taerin Chung; Sookyoung Roh; Byoungho Lee
corresponding_authors: Taerin Chung; Sookyoung Roh; Byoungho Lee
abstract: We numerically investigate the role of localized surface plasmon resonance produced at diverse nano-structures when illuminating visible light for enhanced sensing. The comparisons of optical properties in various nanostructures are illustrated.

title: Interactions of Acoustic and Optical Waves in Silicon Slot Waveguides
authors: B. M. A. Rahman
corresponding_authors: B. M. A. Rahman
abstract: A full-vectorial numerical approach is developed to obtain the transverse acoustic modes and for the first time its interaction with the optical modes in slot waveguides and generation of SBS frequency shift is shown here.

title: High n-type Doping for Ge Lasers
authors: Jonathan T. Bessette; Rodolfo Camacho‐Aguilera; Yan Cai; Lionel C. Kimerling; Jürgen Michel
corresponding_authors: Jonathan T. Bessette; Rodolfo Camacho‐Aguilera; Yan Cai; Lionel C. Kimerling; Jürgen Michel
abstract: We present evidence of enhanced n+-type doping of epitaxial Ge-on-Si for integrated light emitting devices. SIMS, Hall Effect, and photoluminescence measurements confirm dopant concentrations as high as 4 × 1019 cm-3 with efficient PL emission.

title: Forced Boundary Change Demonstration on Optical Packet and Circuit Integrated Networks for Recovery from Congestion in a Large-Scale Disaster
authors: Hideaki Furukawa; Takaya Miyazawa; Naoya Wada; Hiroaki Harai
abstract: Increasing packet-communication bandwidth is promising for recovery from congestion in large-scale disaster. A forced resource allocation change from packet to circuit in optical packet and circuit integrated networks is demonstrated experimentally.

title: Dielectric strip grating embedded trapezoidal plasmonic waveguide
authors: Michelle Xu; J. Stewart Aitchison
corresponding_authors: Michelle Xu; J. Stewart Aitchison
abstract: Novel dielectric strip grating embedded trapezoidal SPP waveguides are designed, fabricated, and characterized in air and under index matching oil. The resonance has a 1100 nm/RIU sensitivity and is validated by calculation.

title: Characterization of a Low-Cost Long-Period Fiber Grating Induced by a Polymeric Microstructure
authors: Jorge A. Soto-Olmos; Juan Hernández-Cordero; Laura Oropeza-Ramos
corresponding_authors: Jorge A. Soto-Olmos; Juan Hernández-Cordero; Laura Oropeza-Ramos
abstract: In this paper a low-cost long-period fiber grating induced by a polymeric microstructure is reported. Fabrication and characterization of the device and experimental results of the spectrum variations due to external pressures are presented.

authors: Alvydas Lisauskas; Sebastian Boppel; Maris Bauer; Martin Mundt; Viktor Krozer; Hartmut G. Roskos; Rimvydas Venckevičius; Linas Minkevičius; Irmantas Kašalynas; D. Seliuta; Gintaras Valušis
corresponding_authors: Alvydas Lisauskas; Sebastian Boppel; Maris Bauer; Martin Mundt; Viktor Krozer; Hartmut G. Roskos; Rimvydas Venckevičius; Linas Minkevičius; Irmantas Kašalynas; D. Seliuta; Gintaras Valušis

Detectors are implemented in several imaging systems which include raster-scan imaging with the ability of spectroscopic discrimination and real-time operational plane-to-plane imaging with direct detection and heterodyne mixing modalities.

authors: Ioannis Tomkos; Konstantinos Kanonakis; E. Palkopoulou; Ch. Kachris; P. Zakynthinos; Dimitrios Klonidis; Juerg Leuthold
abstract: In this presentation, we survey the recent developments in the field of flexible/elastic optical networking, we discuss the main technologies that are required to enable its introduction in the market place and we highlight the associated research challenges

title: Parametric excitation of silicon-on-insulator microcantilever beams by fringing fields probed with laser Doppler vibrometery
authors: Yoav Linzon; Said Mahajna; Bojan Ilic; Slava Krylov
abstract: Large amplitude flexural vibrations were excited in single layer silicon-on-insulator micromechanical cantilever beams in ambient air, driven by symmetrical actuating electrodes around grounded cantilevers and characterized optically with a laser Doppler vibrometer under ambient conditions.

title: Athermal silicon waveguides using the subwavelength grating effect
authors: Jens H. Schmid; M. Ibrahim; Pavel Cheben; Jérôme Lapointe; S. Janz; P. Böck; A. Densmore; R. Ma; W. N. Ye; Dan‐Xia Xu
corresponding_authors: Jens H. Schmid; M. Ibrahim; Pavel Cheben; Jérôme Lapointe; S. Janz; P. Böck; A. Densmore; R. Ma; W. N. Ye; Dan‐Xia Xu
abstract: We present a method for designing temperature independent silicon waveguide devices using the subwavelength grating effect. Photonic wire waveguides are patterned with periodic gaps and filled with SU-8 polymer to cancel the silicon thermo-optic effect.

title: A Novel Upstream Link Scheme for OOFDM-PON
authors: Qing-Yi Guo; Kan He; Xun Li; Wei‐Ping Huang
corresponding_authors: Qing-Yi Guo; Kan He; Xun Li; Wei‐Ping Huang
abstract: We propose an efficient OOFDM-PON scheme: orthogonal subcarrier multiplexing at the ONU with colorless laser diode, and all-optical FFT at the OLT for high speed demultiplexing. The deterioration caused by laser perturbation is also investigated.

title: Nano-Photonics with Ordered Systems of Semiconductor Quantum Dots
authors: E. Kapon
corresponding_authors: E. Kapon
abstract: Site-controlled semiconductor quantum dots (QDs) with tailored heterostructure potential, grown on patterned substrates, are described. Examples of device applications include single photon emitters, integration with photonic micro-cavities for cavity-QED experiments, and few-QD nanolasers.

title: Optical Equalization of PMD-Induced Penalties in 112 Gbit/s Metro Networks
authors: Matthias Westhäuser; Christian Remmersmann; Stephan Pachnicke; Peter M. Krummrich
corresponding_authors: Matthias Westhäuser; Christian Remmersmann; Stephan Pachnicke; Peter M. Krummrich
abstract: We investigate the performance of optical equalization of distortions induced by polarization mode dispersion (PMD) in 112 Gbit/s metro networks using FIR filters. The PMD-induced mean OSNR penalties are reduced to < 0.1 dB.

title: Analyzing Photonic Crystals with Arbitrary Unit Cells using Boundary Integral Equations
authors: Wangtao Lu; Ya Yan Lu
abstract: An accurate boundary integral equation method is developed to calculate the Neumann-to-Dirichlet (NtD) map for unit cells of two-dimensional photonic crystals, where the cylinders in the unit cells have arbitrary shapes and corners. The NtD map can be used to solve various mathematical problems associated with the photonic crystal.

authors: Kambiz Jamshidi; Stefan Meister; Bülent A. Franke; Aws Al-Saadi; Sebastian Kupijai; Hui Tian; Lars Zimmermann; Thomas Schneider
corresponding_authors: Kambiz Jamshidi; Stefan Meister; Bülent A. Franke; Aws Al-Saadi; Sebastian Kupijai; Hui Tian; Lars Zimmermann; Thomas Schneider

title: High Power Thulium Fiber Lasers
authors: Martin Richardson; Lawrence Shah; R. Andrew Sims; Christina C. C. Willis; Pankaj Kadwani; Joshua Bradford
abstract: In a similar manner to high power Yb fiber lasers, thulium-doped fiber lasers have followed a path of development towards high powers and efficiencies driven by advances in fiber production and high power diode pump technology. This presentation will summarize the current state-of the art in Tm fiber laser development, identify many of their future application areas, and outlining the challenges in development still needing to be resolved.

title: Movable High-Q Nanocavity using III-V Nanowire on Silicon Photonic Crystals
authors: Muhammad Danang Birowosuto; Atsushi Yokoo; Guo-Qiang Zhang; Kuota Tateno; Eiichi Kuramochi; Hideaki Taniyama; Masato Takiguchi; Masaya Notomi
corresponding_authors: Muhammad Danang Birowosuto; Atsushi Yokoo; Guo-Qiang Zhang; Kuota Tateno; Eiichi Kuramochi; Hideaki Taniyama; Masato Takiguchi; Masaya Notomi
abstract: High-Q nanocavity is created by putting III-V nanowires into the slot in silicon photonic crystals. We use quantum disk emission in nanowires to probe the cavity. The nanocavity is also moved by manipulating nanowire position.

title: Metamaterials, Plasmonics, and Nanofluidics for Ultrasensitive Spectroscopy and Bio-detection
authors: Hatice Altug; Ahmet Ali Yanik; Arif E. Çetin; Alp Artar; Min Huang
abstract: We will present on-chip integrated plasmonic and metamaterial systems for ultrasensitive spectroscopy and biodetection. We will also introduce opto-fluidic systems for targeted analyte delivery as well as for optical trapping and manipulation.

title: Stand-off detection of liquid chemical warfare agents
authors: Chris R. Howle; Rhea J. Clewes; Keith Ruxton; Gordon Robertson; W. David Miller; Graeme P. A. Malcolm; Gareth T. Maker; Rick Cox; Brad Williams; Matt Russell
abstract: Involatile liquid chemical warfare agents were detected using two complementary stand-off detection prototypes. Midwave IR hyperspectral imaging was used to locate the contamination and shortwave IR Raman spectroscopy was used for chemical identification.

title: Towards Large-scale Silicon Photonics Integration
authors: Michael R. Watts
corresponding_authors: Michael R. Watts
abstract: We present on the development of a 300mm silicon photonics platform incorporating multilevel copper interconnects, vertical junction modulators, germanium detectors, and silicon nitride layers. Within this platform, we demonstrate large-scale silicon photonic circuits.

title: Enhancing WGM Biosensing with Plasmonics & DNA Nanotechnology
authors: Frank Vollmer
corresponding_authors: Frank Vollmer
abstract: Plasmonic nanostructures on Whispering Gallery mode resonator can produce intensity hotspots within the sensing domain hence affording the means to improve detection limit. Combined with DNA Nanotechnology one can achieve unprecedented biosensitivity and -specificity.

title: Characteristics of Terahertz Antenna Pulsed Sources Made on Fe-Implanted InGaAsP/InP Photoconductive Materials
authors: André Fekecs; Maxime Bernier; M. Chicoine; F. Schiettekatte; Paul G. Charette; Richard Arès; Denis Morris
corresponding_authors: André Fekecs; Maxime Bernier; M. Chicoine; F. Schiettekatte; Paul G. Charette; Richard Arès; Denis Morris
abstract: Pulsed terahertz emitters were fabricated on Fe-implanted InGaAsP/InP photoconductive materials. The terahertz signals are detected by electro-optic sampling using fs-pulse excitation at 790 nm or at 1.55 µm. Characteristics of this new terahertz pulsed source are discussed.

title: Noise Reduction Effect of Semiconductor Optical Amplifier Using Fiber Bragg Grating
authors: Yoshinobu Maeda; Tatsuya Matsuo; Hirokazu Tanimoto; Hideki Nakayama
corresponding_authors: Yoshinobu Maeda; Tatsuya Matsuo; Hirokazu Tanimoto; Hideki Nakayama
abstract: A negative feedback semiconductor optical amplifier was realized in an InGaAsP-InP amplifier using a fiber Bragg grating. The negative feedback optical amplification effect can be utilized to recover signal loss with a lower error probability.

title: Integrated Optical isolators: An Introduction
authors: Roel Baets
corresponding_authors: Roel Baets
abstract: The basic options for building an integrated optical isolator are reviewed. For the most relevant case of linear time-independent isolators some fundamental aspects with respect to (non)-reciprocity are discussed. Some specific implementations are presented, especially the options for isolation in a silicon photonics context.

title: Smartphone based Molecular Diagnostics
authors: David Erickson; Matt Mancuso
abstract: In this talk I will discuss our recent efforts towards integrating lab-on-chip technology with smartphone based systems. Scientific challenges as well as potential business opportunities will be discussed.

title: Real-Time Group Delay Monitoring of Ultrawide-Band Dispersive Devices by Low-Noise Incoherent Interferometry
authors: Antonio Malacarne; Yongwoo Park; José Azaña
corresponding_authors: Antonio Malacarne; Yongwoo Park; José Azaña
abstract: A simple incoherent interferometry technique is demonstrated and applied for accurate real-time group-delay monitoring of a dispersion-compensating fiber and group-delay ripples of a 10m-long chirped fiber grating over up to 70nm-bandwidth at 15frames/s update rate.

title: Homogenization of dielectric rod-type metamaterials
authors: Didier Felbacq; Guy Bouchitté
abstract: The scattering by a medium with dielectric inclusions is considered, when the wavelength is larger than the period. Various regimes are demonstrated: the usual quasi-static homogenization, artificial magnetism near resonances, spatial dispersion.

title: Biosensing with a Twist: Detection and Characterization of Biomaterials with Sculpted EM Fields
authors: Malcolm Kadodwala
corresponding_authors: Malcolm Kadodwala
abstract: We have developed a new paradigm for plasmonic enhanced sensing, which utilises evanescent field created by chiral plasmonic nanostructures. These "sculpted" EMfields are able to detect biological structure over a unprecedented range of lengthscales.

title: Prospects and Challenges in High Power Fiber Laser Technology
authors: Andreas Tünnermann; Jens Limpert
abstract: Solid-state lasers are attractive sources of coherent radiation for various applications. At present fiber lasers and amplifiers are capturing the different markets. Novel developments and challenges in high power fiber laser technology are reviewed.

title: Detection of Heterogeneous Characteristics Using Multiple Surface Plasmon Resonance Dips
authors: Hansik Yun; Hyeonsoo Park; Byoungho Lee
corresponding_authors: Hansik Yun; Hyeonsoo Park; Byoungho Lee
abstract: We proposed a metallic grating structure to generate multiple surface plasmon resonance dips in Kretschmann configuration. They can detect heterogeneous characteristics as well as change of refractive index of bulk sample on the structure.

title: Nonlinearity Compensation for Digital Coherent Receivers
authors: Fatih Yaman; Eduardo Mateo; Shaoliang Zhang; Dayou Qian; Ting Wang; Takanori Inoue; Yoshihisa Inada; Takaaki Ogata
abstract: Nonlinear penalties can be removed using digital signal processing. As signal processing became available at the transmitter side, back-propagation can be implemented both at transmitter and receiver to increase performance and reduce complexity.

title: Practical Hybrid PON Technologies
authors: Naoto Yoshimoto
corresponding_authors: Naoto Yoshimoto
abstract: This paper describes possible optical access network architectures using hybrid PON technologies designed to meet operators' requirements in the next decade. From the technical continuity viewpoint, TDM-PON based WDM access technology will be a promising candidate.

title: Full-Vectorial Finite-Difference Scheme for the Analysis of Layered Structures
authors: Cheng-Han Du; Yih‐Peng Chiou
abstract: We develop a full-vectorial finite-difference formulation for layered structures. Fields and their derivatives across the layers are related by matrices. Sampled points can step over multiple layers. The computation is greatly saved.

authors: Qixian Peng; Detian Wang; Guanghua Chen; Shouxian Liu; Liu Qiao; Xiangyang Deng; Liu Jun; Zeren Li
corresponding_authors: Qixian Peng; Detian Wang; Guanghua Chen; Shouxian Liu; Liu Qiao; Xiangyang Deng; Liu Jun; Zeren Li
abstract: The proposed interferometer are assembled using the components well developed in the telecommunication industry, which consists of a fiber-pigtail laser, fiber couplers, a three-port optical circulator, a fiber probe, EDFA , filter, a detector and so on.

title: Generation of sub-200-fs microjoule pulses from an all-fiber CPA system
authors: Dirk Mortag; Thomas Theeg; Katharina Hausmann; Lars Grüner-Nielsen; Kim G. Jespersen; Dieter Wandt; Uwe Morgner; Dietmar Kracht; Jörg Neumann
abstract: Chirped-pulse amplification (CPA) is an established scheme for the generation of high-energy femtosecond pulses. At the wavelength of 1 μm a standard fiber stretcher exhibiting normal second-order dispersion β2 can be used in combination with a grating compressor. But for ultrashort pulses with broad spectra, this scheme is disadvantageous due to the cumulative positive third-order dispersion (TOD) β3 of the stretcher and the compressor. As a consequence, the advantages of the fiber stretcher as a waveguide device are accompanied by longer minimum pulse durations compared to the use of a grating stretcher, unless the TOD is addressed by a more complicated compressor setup with gratings and prisms.

title: Unique Word Based Phase Noise Suppression for Nyquist SCFDE Systems
authors: Tingting Zhang; Fan Zhang; Zhangyuan Chen
corresponding_authors: Tingting Zhang; Fan Zhang; Zhangyuan Chen
abstract: Coherent optical nyquist SCFDE systems are discussed with emphasis of laser phase noise degradation and mitigation. A unique word method is proposed to suppress the phase noise, validated through numerical simulations in a 40Gb/s PDM 16-QAM system.

title: Label-free Detection of Single Nanoparticles and Lentiviruses Using an Optical Microcavity
authors: Yun‐Feng Xiao
corresponding_authors: Yun‐Feng Xiao
abstract: Optical microcavity biosensing has emerged as one of the most sensitive detection technologies. We report a new label-free detection method of single nanoparticles by employing nanoparticle-scattering-induced mode broadening in a free-space-coupled deformed microcavity. By monitoring the change of resonance linewidth, our method transcends the detecting ability limited by the intrinsic resonance linewidth and demonstrates the biosensing ability to detect single lentiviruses.

title: Active and Passive Surface Plasmon Photonics
authors: Pierre Berini
corresponding_authors: Pierre Berini
abstract: This paper reviews recent progress made on integrated surface plasmon components and devices operating at near-infrared and visible wavelengths. Thin narrow metal stripes used as waveguides are designed into passive elements such as S-bends, Y-junction splitters, couplers, and Mach-Zehnder interferometers. Such elements are then used to achieve active plasmonic functions, such as modulation, amplification and lasing, detection, and sensing.

title: Training-Aided 2×2 MIMO Channel Estimation with Frequency-Offset Tolerant Update
authors: Fabio Pittalá; Majdi Msallem; Josef A. Nossek
corresponding_authors: Fabio Pittalá; Majdi Msallem; Josef A. Nossek
abstract: A frequency-offset tolerant update method for training-aided 2×2 MIMO channel estimation based on 16-symbol CAZAC sequences is proposed. Performance is evaluated in a 112-Gbit/s PDM-QPSK coherent optical transmission system with frequency domain equalization.

title: Amplitude Modulation by Coherent Perfect Loss
authors: Richard R. Grote; Jeffrey B. Driscoll; Richard M. Osgood
corresponding_authors: Richard R. Grote; Jeffrey B. Driscoll; Richard M. Osgood
abstract: We propose a new type of phase-controllable modulator using coherent perfect loss (CPL) from a resonator. Device operation is described with temporal coupled-mode theory, and is verified by finite-difference time-domain simulations of two devices.

title: Highly Polarizing Single-Mode Optical Fiber for Sensing Applications
authors: Bill Jacobsen; A. Soufiane
corresponding_authors: Bill Jacobsen; A. Soufiane
abstract: We demonstrate a high performance, highly manufacturable Single-Polarization Fiber (PZF), which offers a wide polarization bandwidth, very high polarization extinction ratio, and consistent performance within lot and from-lot-to-lot. The principle of the design is discussed in this paper and the full spectral attenuation results shown. We demonstrate the exceptional performance of the fiber for various fiber lengths, layouts, and operating wavelengths. In addition, PZF is designed with a circular mode field, which makes it low-loss and highly compatible with standard single mode fiber systems and devices. We will also discuss on-going R&D projects involving PZF.

authors: Amr S. Helmy; Payam Abolghasem; Junbo Han; Bhavin J. Bijlani; Dongpeng Kang
corresponding_authors: Amr S. Helmy; Payam Abolghasem; Junbo Han; Bhavin J. Bijlani; Dongpeng Kang
abstract: Recent advances in phase-matching second-order nonlinearities using Bragg reflection waveguides are discussed. The limitations on the choice of the composition of the AlxGa1−xAs layers are highlighted. Multi-layer cores are proposed and demonstrated as a novel design with relaxed constraints over the choice of the Al composition.

title: Extended-Reach Passive Optical Networks
authors: An V. Tran; K. L. Lee; Chang-Joon Chae; Kerry Hinton
corresponding_authors: An V. Tran; K. L. Lee; Chang-Joon Chae; Kerry Hinton
abstract: We review several techniques to extend the reach of PON beyond 60 km utilizing a repeater at the remote node and distributed Raman amplification. We also discuss practical deployment issues and economics of extended-reach PON.

title: Photonic Signal Processing in Time, Frequency, and Space for Unified Elastic Optical Networking
authors: S. J. Ben Yoo
corresponding_authors: S. J. Ben Yoo
abstract: We propose signal processing in time, frequency, and space domains for elastic optical networking that benefits from flexible and adaptive resource management in the three domains. Proof-of-concept demonstrations using OAWG and orbital-angular-momentum will be discussed.

title: All-Solid Photonic Bandgap Fiber Lasers
authors: Christina B. Olausson; Akira Shirakawa; Jens K. Lyngsø; K.P. Hansen; Jes Broeng; Ken‐ichi Ueda
corresponding_authors: Christina B. Olausson; Akira Shirakawa; Jens K. Lyngsø; K.P. Hansen; Jes Broeng; Ken‐ichi Ueda
abstract: Solid core photonic bandgap fibers exhibit a unique spectral filtering effect with efficient out-of-band suppression. This is used for artificial gain shaping and ASE filtering in high power fiber lasers for operation at unconventional wavelengths.

title: Optical impedance spectroscopy based on electro-active single mode integrated optical waveguides for redox reaction studies in proteins
authors: Xue Han; Sergio B. Mendes
abstract: Electro-active single mode integrated optical waveguide was designed and fabricated for sub-monolayer cytochrome-c electron transfer rate constant investigations under AC potential modulation with purely optical impedance data.

title: Multiplexed Integrated Interferometers for Advanced Lab-on-a-Chip Biosensors
authors: Daphné Duval; Daniel Grajales García; S. Dante; Johann Osmond; Carlos Domı́nguez; Laura M. Lechuga
corresponding_authors: Daphné Duval; Daniel Grajales García; S. Dante; Johann Osmond; Carlos Domı́nguez; Laura M. Lechuga
abstract: We present our last achievements towards the assembly of lab-on-a-chip platforms based on ultrasensitive Mach-Zehnder interferometers. In particular, we will focus on the development of a label-free and real-time multiplexed detection scheme.

title: Truly Continuous-Wave Spatial-Domain Cavity Ring-Down Technique Based on Frequency-Shifted Interferometry
authors: Fei Ye; Bing Qi; Li Qian
corresponding_authors: Fei Ye; Bing Qi; Li Qian
abstract: We present a novel spatial-domain cavity ring-down technique using frequency-shifted interferometry, by monitoring the intensity decay of a continuous-wave beam circulating in a fiber-loop cavity. It was applied to fiber bend loss measurements.

title: Transfer Printed Nanomembrane Lasers on Silicon
authors: Weidong Zhou; Zhenqiang Ma
abstract: We proposed and demonstrated a membrane reflector surface-emitting laser on silicon, based on multi-layer semiconductor nanomembrane stacking via stamp transfer printing processes, and photonic crystal Fano resonance membrane reflectors. The potentials and prospects of nanomembrane materials and transfer printing processes will also be discussed, for applications in silicon photonics, flexible electronics and optoelectronics.

title: A Novel Fragment-aware Spectrum Allocation Algorithm in OFDM-based Flexible Optical Networks
authors: Xin Chen; Songwei Ma; Bingli Guo; Yan Wang; Juhao Li; Zhangyuan Chen; Yongqi He
abstract: We propose a spectrum fragmentation evaluation standard and a fragment-aware spectrum allocation algorithm in OFDM-based flexible optical networks. The simulation result indicate that the proposed algorithm perform better than previous schemes.

title: Enhanced Light Emission from Silicon using Photonic Crystal Nanocavities
authors: Liam O’Faoláin; Mattéo Galli; Abdul Shakoor; Roberto Lo Savio; Simone Luca Portalupi; Karl Welna; Dario Gerace; G. Guizzetti; Lucio Claudio Andreani; Thomas F. Krauss; Alessia Irrera; G. Franzò; F. Priolo
abstract: Using Photonic crystal nanocavities, we first dramatically enhance third harmonic generation from silicon (at <1mW pump power). Then, by virtue of a strong Purcell factor, we significantly increase defect state photoluminescence and greatly suppress thermal quenching.

title: Efficient Channel Estimation using Weighted Inter-frame Averaging for CO-OFDM Transmission
authors: Paikun Zhu; Juhao Li; Hui Zhao; Yuanxiang Chen; Yuping Zhao; Yongqi He; Zhangyuan Chen
abstract: We propose a weighted inter-frame averaging channel estimation method for CO-OFDM transmission system. Simulation results show that the proposed method has better performance than LS and ISFA methods at the same spectral efficiency.

title: InP-Based Transmitter PICs
authors: Hiroyuki Ishii; H. Oohashi
corresponding_authors: Hiroyuki Ishii; H. Oohashi
abstract: InP-based photonic integrated circuits (PICs) that contain semiconductor lasers are promising as compact high-performance transmitters for future photonic networks. Recent activity on InP-based transmitter PICs is described.

authors: Chad Husko; Trung D. Vo; Bill Corcoran; Jun Li; Thomas F. Krauss; Benjamin J. Eggleton
corresponding_authors: Chad Husko; Trung D. Vo; Bill Corcoran; Jun Li; Thomas F. Krauss; Benjamin J. Eggleton
abstract: We demonstrate ultracompact chip-based all-optical exclusive-OR (XOR) logic via slow-light enhanced four-wave mixing in a silicon photonic crystal waveguide. The device is error-free for 40 Gbit/s differential phase shift keying (DPSK) signals.

authors: Lars Zimmermann; Andrzej Gajda; Georg Winzer; H. Richter; Karsten Voigt; Stefan Meister; Hanjo Rhee; Christoph Theiss; Aws Al-Saadi; Bülent A. Franke; Sebastian Kupijai; U. Woggon; Bernd Tillack; K. Petermann

title: Relating DC-Field to Induced Nonlinear Susceptibility in Periodically Poled Silica Fiber
authors: Christopher A. Sapiano; J. Stewart Aitchison; Li Qian
corresponding_authors: Christopher A. Sapiano; J. Stewart Aitchison; Li Qian
abstract: The relationship between DC-fields and effective second order nonlinearity is investigated. DC-induced processes are modeled and fitted against equivalent natural second order processes. Insight is provided into the disparity between bulk glass and poled fiber.

title: Flexible Transceiver with Format-Transparent Digital Signal Processing for Ultra-large Data-rate Transmissions
authors: Qunbi Zhuge; Mohamed Morsy-Osman; Xian Xu; Mathieu Chagnon; Meng Qiu; David V. Plant
corresponding_authors: Qunbi Zhuge; Mohamed Morsy-Osman; Xian Xu; Mathieu Chagnon; Meng Qiu; David V. Plant
abstract: Flexible transceivers using high speed digital-to-analog converters, format-transparent digital signal processing and novel modulation formats are presented and discussed for future agile optical networks.

title: Glass for optical fibers
authors: Ji Wang
corresponding_authors: Ji Wang
abstract: The talk will review the requirement of key glass attributes for optical fiber fabrication for both soft (multi-component) glasses, and high-silica based glasses. Examples will be given in each case on how the glass properties are tailored via composition and/or processing for successful fiber optic applications.

title: All-Optical Signal Processing using Optical Nonlinearities
authors: Alan E. Willner
corresponding_authors: Alan E. Willner
abstract: Optical nonlinearities can be used to transparently manipulate a high-speed optical data signal in amplitude, phase and wavelength. This paper will discuss various signal processing applications such as: constellation manipulation, traffic grooming and channel equalization.

title: Mid-infrared Plasmonics for Ultra-sensitive Chemical Fingerprinting and Real-time, in-situ Spectroscopy
authors: Ronen Adato; Hatice Altug
abstract: We demonstrate a plasmonic platform performing real-time, in-situ infrared absorption spectroscopy on biomolecule binding interactions. Leveraging nano-antennas for near-field enhancement and to direct radiation, our approach enables an ultrasensitive compact chip based biosensor technology.

title: Concatenated QC-LDPC and SPC Codes for Turbo Decoding in Differentially Encoded System
authors: Yu Zhao; Nebojša Stojanović; Fan Yu; Dae Ig Chang; Zijian Xiao; Changsong Xie
abstract: A new class of codes is proposed for differentially encoded coherent systems. Regular Quasi Cyclic Low Density Parity Check codes concatenated with two-dimensional single parity check codes improved performance by 0.4 dB without complexity increase.

title: Extraction of CROW parameters using a scattering tree
authors: Roman Novitski; Jacob Scheuer; Ben Z. Steinberg
corresponding_authors: Roman Novitski; Jacob Scheuer; Ben Z. Steinberg
abstract: We present a method for extracting the coupling coefficients and the resonant frequency detunings of a coupled resonator optical waveguide (CROW) from its discrete impulse response calculated from the frequency response of the through port.

title: Optical Forces in Plasmonic Nanostructures: New Functionalities for Nanophotonic Circuits
authors: Olivier J. F. Martin
corresponding_authors: Olivier J. F. Martin
abstract: We study in detail the modeling requirements for realistic plasmonic nanostructures and show that strong field gradients created at their vicinity can be used to trap nanostructures; this plasmonic trapping is also demonstrated experimentally.

title: Liquid mass sensing with resonant micro-plates under harsh drop and spray conditions
authors: Said Mahajna; Yoav Linzon
abstract: We perform in-situ sensing of droplet and spray mass using plate-like micro-resonators, where robust and reusable operation was attained over harsh conditions and multiple cycles. An electro-optical sensing system in ambient conditions has been used.

title: Optical fiber capacity at its limits: From spectrally efficient modulation to spatial multiplexing
authors: Peter J. Winzer
corresponding_authors: Peter J. Winzer
abstract: We will discuss the state-of-the-art in high-spectral-efficiency optical transmission systems as well as their theoretical and practical scalability limits. We will then examine spatial multiplexing as an energy- and cost-efficient method to scale beyond WDM.

authors: Mahmood Bagheri; Menno Poot; Wolfram Pernice; Hong X. Tang
corresponding_authors: Mahmood Bagheri; Menno Poot; Wolfram Pernice; Hong X. Tang
abstract: we demonstrate coherent switching of nanomechanical resonators by optical cooling and amplification. The dynamic manipulation by optical backaction drives nanomechanical resonators at high amplitudes. A non-volatile memory is also demonstrated.

title: Integrated Nanoscale Porous Silicon Photonic Structures for Molecular Sensing
authors: Jeremy W. Mares; Xing Wei; Gilbert A. Rodriguez; Judson D. Ryckman; Sharon M. Weiss
abstract: The application of porous silicon photonic structures for integrated, label-free biosensing is presented. Specifically, on-chip porous silicon waveguides and Bloch surface-wave sensors will be discussed for the real-time detection of DNA and small biological molecules.

title: Tunable Light-Storage for almost 1 Microsecond
authors: Thomas Schneider; Stefan Preußler; Kambiz Jamshidi
corresponding_authors: Thomas Schneider; Stefan Preußler; Kambiz Jamshidi
abstract: We describe the latest results of the investigation of a new method to store optical packets called Quasi-Light-Storage (QLS). We discuss the method and show experimental results with a delay-bandwidth product of around 700 Bit.

title: Quantum Information Processing on Photonic Chips
authors: Dirk Englund
corresponding_authors: Dirk Englund
abstract: We describe a technique to deterministically couple a single, pre-selected nitrogen vacancy (NV) center to a high-quality factor photonic crystal nanocavity in a Gallium Phosphide membrane. Article not available.

title: Visible Light Emitting Optical Fibers using Up-Conversion
authors: Michael Bass; John Ballato; William Hageman; Jung Hyun Cho; D.G. Deppe; Thomas W. Hawkins; Paul Foy
corresponding_authors: Michael Bass; John Ballato; William Hageman; Jung Hyun Cho; D.G. Deppe; Thomas W. Hawkins; Paul Foy
abstract: Optical fibers are described that emit visible light along their length when particulate up-converters in the cladding are excited by light from semiconductor light sources propagating in the core and leaking into the cladding.

title: Silicon Integrated Quantum Photonics
authors: Mark G. Thompson
corresponding_authors: Mark G. Thompson
abstract: Silicon integrated waveguide circuits are a promising approach towards the development of quantum technologies. Here we presented the on-chip generation and manipulation of entangled states of light for applications in quantum photonics.

authors: Jie Zhang
corresponding_authors: Jie Zhang
abstract: Spectrum Engineering (SE) is proposed for flexible grid optical networks to achieve high spectrum resource utilization, which will also play an important role in software defined networking (SDN) enabled cognitive optical networks (CON).

title: Optical biomedical sensors: what can nanophotonics bring?
authors: Dan‐Xia Xu
corresponding_authors: Dan‐Xia Xu
abstract: We discuss how nanophotonics is influencing the field of optical biomedical sensors. View points are exemplified in the context of developing integrated silicon photonic wire molecular sensor systems. Article not available.

title: Slow Light for Cancer Detection: Ultrasound-Modulated Optical Tomography Using Slow Light in Spectral Hole Burning Materials
authors: Philip Hemmer; Stefan Kröll; Lihong V. Wang; Huiliang Zhang; Mahmood Sabooni; Lars Rippe; Chulhong Kim
abstract: Ultrasound modulated optical tomography allows optical imaging with ultrasound resolution inside highly scattering tissue, and this has application to early tumor detection. Slow light provides additional time domain filtering to selectively detect ultrasound tagged light.

title: Cavity Optomechanical Magnetometry
authors: Eoin Sheridan; Stefan Forstner; Halina Rubinszstein-Dunlop; Warwick P. Bowen
abstract: Ultra-low field magnetic field sensors are essential for many applications including geology, mineral exploration, archaeology and medicine [1]. However, such magnetometers typically either require cryogenic systems to operate, or suffer poor dynamic range, limiting their ability to operate in ambient conditions. Here, we introduce the concept of a cavity optomechanical magnetometry[2], and demonstrate microscale room temperature magnetometry operating in the picoTelsa sensitivity range (see Fig. 1a). The peak sensitivity of 200 pT Hz−1/2 exceeds all previous microscale room temperature magnetometers. Furthermore, we demonstrate that an inherent paramagnetic nonlinearity allows mix-up of low frequency to the RF frequency band, enabling magnetic field sensing in the Hz-kHz frequency window crucial for applications such as medical imaging, geosurvey, and magnetic anomaly detection (see Fig. 1b). This presents an enabling step towards real applications of cavity optomechanical magnetometers in high-performance microscale magnetometry.

title: All-optical and electro-optical active plasmonic telecom components
authors: Sukanya Randhawa; J. Renger R. Quidant; Alexey V. Krasavin; Anatoly V. Zayats; S. Lacheze; Alexandre Bouhélier; Alain Dereux
abstract: Active plasmonics is an attractive emerging field in which the ability to control the surface plasmon polariton (SPP) propagation finds many applications such as realization of fully functional integrated photonic circuitry. We demonstrate both numerically and experimentally switching of the SPP transmission based on two different approaches namely the all-optical and electro-optical at telecom wavelengths. The plasmonic component consists of a compact and efficient SPP switch utilizing highly sensitive ring resonator which has high sensitivity to the refractive index changes. Fabrication was done via e-beam lithography utilizing advanced proximity corrections. The compenents were characterized via scanning near field optical microscope (SNOM) and leakage radiation microscopy respectively. Large modulations of upto ~ 40 % in SPP mode transmission were observed.

abstract: Spatiotemporal optical vortex (STOV) pulses can carry transverse orbital angular momentum (OAM) that is perpendicular to the direction of pulse propagation.For a STOV pulse, the spatiotemporal profile can be significantly distorted due to unbalanced dispersive and diffractive phases.This may limit its use in many research applications where a long interaction length and a tight confinement of the pulse is needed.The stable and robust transmission of transverse photonic OAM through optical fiber may open new opportunities for transverse photonic OAM studies in telecommunications, novel OAM lasers, and nonlinear fiber-optical research.The image on the cover of Advanced Photonics Volume 5 Issue 3 illustrates the propagation of a spatiotemporal optical vortex wavepacket through an optical fiber, based on original research presented in the article by Qian Cao, Zhuo Chen, Chong Zhang, Andy Chong, and Qiwen Zhan in their article "Propagation of transverse photonic orbital angular momentum through few-mode fiber" (doi 10.1117/1.AP.5.3.036002).This article presents the first demonstration of STOV pulse propagation through a few-mode optical fiber.The authors note that the wavepacket maintains its spatiotemporal phase structure well, demonstrating the new possibility of transmitting transverse OAM inside fiber.
